sentence: b'I cant believe I wrote all that last year'

b'Because Ive been grading all damn day and am as tired as a Swearengen of hearing other about the finished semesters of pretty much every other academic blogger I thought that it might be best to avoid jealously lashing out and scribble a Best of Acephalous 2009 post'
b'However when I started looking through my archives it occurred to me that my output this year defines me much more sharply than in years past'
b'What do I mean'
b'The posts I consider foundational to my current professional identity all seem to have been composed in 2009'
b'Granted the likelihood that Im suffering from the identitarian equivalent of presentism is awfully high but I honestly thought Id written some of the posts from early 2009 in 2006 or so'
b'It may also be that I remember the scene of their writing which would have been in the old apartment ie the place I barely remember ever having lived in anymore'
b'If you have absolutely nothing better to do on a Friday night feel free to scan through my 2009 archives and tell me what you think should be included in the Best of post'
b'If you do have something better to do though by all means do it '
b'Why is someone so young not having fun with friends on a Friday night'
b'Granted grading papers is important but no fun makes for a boring life'
b'I should know'
b'since when I was your age I had fun playing with my adorable son and caring for another baby'
b'You need to try to have a life outside your computer'
b'Just sayingit seems I have more life now then you have and we know how little I get out'
b'The one that really stuck in my mind was explaining transitions in the panels of Watchmen '

b'Id read Watchmen a short while before and appreciated its narrative complexity but not being used to reading comics hadnt registered all the technical tricks that the artist was using to achieve this'
b'The post not only taught me something about the grammar of such images but more importantly led to me realising that there is a grammar to look for in the first place'
b'So thanks a lot for that one'

b'SEK I started going through your back posts and noticed a pattern in my selections so I think it would be easier for me because Im rubbish with html to just say all the scene analysis posts and the close reading comics posts like the one Magistra mentioned and many others after that'
b'Plus Justifying Comics as a Legitimate Object of Study Parts I  II'
b'I also liked Teaching the Overdetermined Image'
b'Your takedown of Cashill and the whole AyerswroteDreams was excellent and the Cruelcrueldeath post you know what Im talking about right'
b'Also The Day in Actual Communist and Real Nazi History seems as relevant today as ever'
b'Agree with the previous two comments'
b'I dont remember if youve made noises here before about turning these into a book but if you do youve got at least one reader'
b'What happened to your post that appeared in my RSS reader yesterday'
b'Would it be possible to arrange your posts into three parties and give your many readers the opportunity to vote for one of them by secret ballot'
b'I feel your British readers would appreciate that'
b'The Internet occasionally reminds me of how different life is because of it'

b'I noted on Facebook that from a statistical perspective what makes baseball such an amazing sport is that you can watch it your entire life and still see on a daily basis something you\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen before'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a truism I know but it has the benefit of actually being true'
b'In this case the something in question was watching the wonderfully named Angel Pagan hit an insidethepark home run and initiate a triple play in the same game'
b'John Emerson responded with some humbug about it not being an insidethepark grand slam which made me remember that I had seen an insidethepark grand slam at some time in the remote past'

b'I remember being six or seven years old and watching the Mets play the Cardinals in an afternoon game at Shea Stadium and thanks to the miracle of the Internet I can definitively say that at approximately 430 pm on 9 June 1985  I watched Terry Pendleton hit an insidethepark grand slam off Joe Sambito in a game the Cardinals would go on to win handily '
b'The fact that I can verify vague memories of events that occurred twentyfive years ago astounds me in a way I sometimes forget the Internet is capable of doing'

b'This realization is obviously not of worldhistorical importance merely a reminder that this thing whose existence we take for granted daily represents a fundamentally weird complement to human memory'
b'The fact that at some point in the future I can know who I rode in an elevator with on 28 December 2005 is less weird because I chose to write about riding in an elevator with Grimace '
b'That I can access detailed information about events I have no right remembering in detail is another matter entirely'
b'Joe Sambito'
b'Wow'
b'Id completely forgotten about him'
b'I sometimes wish I could forget that Pendelton is the Braves hitting coach'
b'Closest I came to that was watching Dale Murphy get tagged out at the plate on what would have been an insidethepark slam'
b'He pitched for the Astros before he came to the Mets stayed for 85 then he pitched for the Red Sox against the Mets in 86 World Series'
b'I remember him being ineffective and as it turns out he was '
b'Now that I remember him which I didnt before I remember him as being the pitcher whod pitched for 1 the team the Mets faced to get to the 86 Series and 2 the one they faced in it'
b'I didnt remember that I remember that but now that I do I do'
b'Memory as Gertrude Stein would say is funny'
b'Apparently the drug use sexual excess and weird UCI experiences havent softened your brain yet'
b'Whats really bothersome though is when you only remember things from your distant past'
b'My grandpa was alert till the end but when I last saw him at age 92 everything he wanted to talk about was 70 years in the past'
b'A guess but perhaps your grandfathers life at 22 was more interesting than the ensuing 70 yrs'
b'You know what makes this post great'
b'No stinking cricket'
b'Yeah I remember Sambito from the Astros when the Braves were in the old NL West because it made sense to have a team 3000 miles from most of their division rivals'
b'Solid pitcher for a while'
b'But burned out toward the end'
b'Apparently he is a players representative now'
b'Prosthetic memory'
b'I like to read about others watching baseball more than I like to watch baseball by a factor of nine'
b'Having given up on watching the actual sport mention of baseball now only sparks memories of The Old Man and the Sea and the old time baseball writers'

b'It is true that at the end of time the old time baseball writers will be hailed as the very best writers as they had access to an event that was susceptible to beautiful writing but horrendous to watch in person'
b'Plus they smoked a prodigious quantity of cigarettes'
b'nota bene An overdue library book is a crime against Humanities'
b'The AntiTerrorist  Undermining The Motivation For Terrorism'
b'By Rev Bill McGinnis  Director  LoveAllPeopleorg'
b'This website and everything on it is in the Public Domain so you may use it freely even without attribution'
b'BACKGROUND  September 11 2004'
b'Three years have now gone by since the September 11th attacks in 2001 and terrorism is a far greater threat to us now than it was then'
b'The number and severity of terrorist attacks worldwide has increased dramatically as has the number of active terrorists'
b'Before 911 terrorism was confined to a small number of extremist individuals loosely linked by radical Islam and hatred of Israel and its sole supporter the USA'
b'Now many more moderate Muslims have become radicalized worldwide willing to kill innocent civilians in order to achieve their purposes'
b'And the serious targets have expanded to include civilians in Russia India Maylasia the Philippines Spain and elsewhere as well as Israel and its sole supporter the United States'
b'True the USA has not suffered a successful major attack since 911 but this does not mean that we are safer'
b'The terrorists could strike any time they choose through any of the numerous loopholes so well reported in our media'
b'But they have chosen not to attack perhaps because they are waiting to produce an effect even greater than the 911 attacks so they do not appear to be losing strength'
b'What could be more spectacular than the 911 attacks'
b'Nuclear'
b'Or massive biochemical attack'
b'And I think this is what they are waiting for'

b'All of our frantic preparations may have had some effect in preventing smalltime casual attacks but they cannot stop a serious planned attack any more than a mere door lock can stop a serious robber who really wants to get into your house'
b'So the Bush administration can keep claiming that we are safer now under their policies'
b'But this claim is merely feelgood propaganda intended to keep the neocons in power'
b'It cannot withstand clearheaded scrutiny'
b'The fact is Bush policies have failed completely even to diminish terrorism much less defeat it'
b'By trying to stamp out terrorism by killing terrorists Bush and Israel have made things infinitely worse for us more dangerous not safer'
b'And proof that Bush has failed may come at any moment explosively with one big successful attack here in the USA'
b'May God help us all'
b'WHAT IS TERRORISM'
b'TERRORISM is the systematic use of violence to create a general climate of fear in a population and thereby to bring about a particular political objective'
b'We believe that any terrorist act is a crime against humanity and against the will of God because it deliberately intends to injure and kill innocent people '
b'NEUTRALIZING TERRORISM'
b'Our purpose here is to NEUTRALIZE TERRORISM by removing the motivation for it'
b'Without motivation terrorism will quickly die down like a plant without water'
b'We completely reject the idea that terrorism can be defeated by brute force because brute force radicalizes the moderates and they then join the terrorists'
b'So you end up fighting the entire population'
b'Brute force has failed in Palestine and it is failing in Iraq'

b'We try to be evenhanded in opposing all terrorism although we recognize that the greatest terrorist threat in the world today comes from radical Muslims who falsely believe that Allah approves of their criminal behavior against Israel The United States Russia India the Philippines Australia and others whom they falsely believe to be waging war against Allah'

b'And the secondgreatest terrorist threat comes from several countries mainly Israel who sometimes resort to terrorism themselves claiming selfdefense as they desperately try to prevent further attacks by radical Muslims'
b'In all of these cases above if the radical Muslims would cease their attacks all terrorism on both sides of every dispute would quickly end'

b'Beyond these two sources there is virtually no terrorist activity in the world with the possible exception of localized disputes such as in Northern Ireland and occasional domestic episodes in various places involving isolated disaffected groups'
b'The moral and religious theories which support terrorism are quite faulty and erroneous'
b'They need to be identified and attacked'
b'If the terrorist loses faith in the righteousness of his acts he is less likely to perform them'
b'EXAMPLE 1 Terrorists Offend Allah'
b'EXAMPLE 2 Terrorist Murderers Insult Allah Bring Shame To Islam'
b'EXAMPLE 3 LATEST AND BEST  Framed Below Quran Forbids Terrorism'
b'In every case of terrorism we will find some kind of legitimate underlying grievance'
b'If we eliminate the legitimate grievances we have eliminated much of the motivation'
b'Is this negotiating with terrorists or trying to appease the terrorists as some IsraeliNeoCons would try to say'
b'No'
b'It is simply recognizing the realities of human motivation right or wrong'
b'To deny reality as the IsraeliNeoCons do is to invite disaster as they have done'
b'BIG PICTURE'
b'A big picture of our entire AntiTerrorism strategy can be found at our website'
b'Blessings to you'
b'May God help us all'
b'Blessings to you'
b'May God help us all'
b' Rev Bill McGinnis Director  LoveAllPeopleorg'
b'Tibetan Buddhist Retreat'
b'Faded squares of fabric strung together in repeating bluewhiteredgreenyellow chains crisscross the branches of barelimbed trees'
b'The gentle wind makes them flutter'
b'Orangegold light filters into the grassy meadow touching a row of canvas tents and the temple house beyond'
b'Tsechen Kunchab Ling  Temple of AllEncompassing Great Compassion'
b'This is the seat of His Holiness the Sakya Trizin in the United States a Tibetan Buddhist monastery established nine years ago'
b'I spent the past weekend there'
b'The field work office at my college arranges this retreat every semester'
b'Everyone Ive talked to who has previously attended says wonderful things about it this semester one of my friends told me she was going I should join her'
b'I like learning new things so I signed up'

b'A good decision I didnt return all chill and zen as one friend told me his roommate had but I certainly gained a few new ideas and approaches to mull over and dipped my hand into a previously unfamiliar piece of the world'
b'Medicine for ones mind'

b'The first evening the twentysomething studentsmost from my college four from anothergathered in the shrine room sitting crosslegged on cushions as we listened to Khenpo Kalsang introduce Tibetan Buddhist philosophy'
b'He began by telling us Do not take any of what I say on faith'
b'Do not take any of what I say on faith Take it through analysis if there is some benefit in it for you'
b'Take it through analysis if there is some benefit in it for you'
b'Religion he said is like a drugstore full of medicine'
b'You do not go to the drugstore and buy everything in ityou just buy what would be beneficial to you now'
b'You believe the other medicine may have just as much value but in other situations not this one'
b'We discussed the foundations the Three Turnings of the Wheel of Dharma the four noble truths karma defilements the six perfections'

b'When we talked about the giving and how one should try to give what one could to other sentient beings in the form of material items kind words protection and so on Khenpo Kalsang shared a story of the Buddha and how the Buddha had given his flesh so that a family of hungry tigers could eat'
b'So a fellow student asked Giving ones life for another being is the ultimate gift'
b'So'
b'Giving ones life for another being is the ultimate gift'
b'Khenpo Kalsang he smiled and shook his head'
b'Only if you feel no regret he said'
b'Only if you feel no regret'
b'If you feel regret it destroys the merit'
b'Until then preserve your own life and do not give away anything that would cause you regret'
b'This struck a chord'
b'Selfpreservation above all else unless the right situation arises'
b'Knowing and understanding'
b'Later I talked to the resident nun Ani Kunga about psychology and cognitive science'

b'She had studied psychology for a while in grad school but now holds the view that psychologists are going about understanding the mind and understanding the knower and what knowing is the wrong way'
b'Psychologists she said study the brain and the self externally'
b'Psychologists'

b'study the brain and the self externally Ever since the 1920s their science has been about observation of behavior questionnaires recordings of electrical brain activity But the mind can only be known by you the person whose mind it is'
b'Ever since the 1920s their science has been about observation of behavior questionnaires recordings of electrical brain activity'
b'But the mind can only be known by you the person whose mind it is'
b'She said philosophy and epistemology were doing it right looking at experiences from the inside'
b'A big overlap exists between Tibetan Buddhism psychology and cognitive science'
b'All three examine the distinction between the self and others between the observer and the observed between knowing and the knower'
b'I agree with Ani Kunga to some extentonly so much can be known about the mind from external observation'
b'But this doesnt mean that there isnt merit to such studies nor that nothing of use can be learned in that way'
b'Tibetan Buddhist philosophy also approaches the mind and the self from the inside'
b'During a second philsophy session Khenpo Kalsang translated a sutra about a king who received advice from the Buddha'
b'This sutra delved into some questions about the nature of the self whether the self is a delusion and how the clinging of self is a defilement'
b'I intend to discuss it in more depth later so stay tuned'
b'Compassion training and prayer flags'
b'In the afternoon a group of us gathered outside for a meditation session with Ani Kunga'
b'Sunshine melted lazily through the tree branches above a breeze animating the branches shadows so they danced between our cushions'
b'Compassion and anger were the sessions topics'
b'The key message'
b'If theres something you can do why are you unhappy Just do it If theres nothing you can do why are you unhappy'
b'If theres something you can do why are you unhappy'
b'Just do it'
b'If theres nothing you can do why are you unhappy'
b'Ani Kunga explained several offsession and one onsession technique for dealing with negative emotions anger hate irritation stress jealousy and so on'
b'All the methods built off the idea that you are in control anger is an emotion and you can change your emotions'
b'Stay tuned for a more indepth post on the topic'
b'Another of the days activities was making prayer flags'
b'As Ani Kunga explained Prayers wishes hopes aspirationssomeone many people may share those with you'

b'Prayers wishes hopes aspirationssomeone many people may share those with you Hanging the prayer flag shares your prayer with everyone else in the world This may do no good at all but it mayif everyone hopes and wishes and dreams and aspires perhaps it will do good It may not But if no one shares their prayers it will certainly do no good So on the offchance that it will help why not'
b'Hanging the prayer flag shares your prayer with everyone else in the world'
b'This may do no good at all but it mayif everyone hopes and wishes and dreams and aspires perhaps it will do good'
b'It may not'
b'But if no one shares their prayers it will certainly do no good'
b'So on the offchance that it will help why not'
b'Never done'
b'This weekend reminded me that Im not done learning'

b'If I stay still long enough if Ive achieved a relatively constant level of happiness and satisfaction I forget that I can and should continue to seek out new ideas and approaches and incorporate beneficial ones into my life'
b'A person is never done and so Ill continue to observe and discuss and study trying to pick the directions in which Ill change and trying to make tomorrow better than today'
b'done'
b'Ever onward and ever upward'
b'Selfcontrol Selfefficacy and New Years Resolutions Unresolved'
b'Im not one to make New Years resolutions'

b'I mean sure I could take my pick of popular New Years resolutions  I could decide on the first day of the new year that this year Ill start exercising more and eating better or that Ill spend more time with my family and friends or that Ill learn a new skill'
b'And if I chose to make resolutions Id be far from alonea 2008 survey on Dorthycom found that 66 of the 2000 adults polled had made resolutions at some point though only 17 managed to keep them'
b'Making resolutions Its about selfcontrol'

b'The question Anirban Mukhopadhyay of the Hong Kong University and Gita Venkatarmani Johar of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University asked is this What determines how many goals a person will set and how successful a person will be at achieving those goals'
b'They performed a few studies in 2005 to look at the relationship between selfcontrol goal setting and goal achievement'
b'They suggested that what you believe about selfcontrol affects the goals you set and achieve PDF'
b'In the paper selfcontrol is used to mean a sense of willpower'
b'selfcontrol'

b'Mukhopadhyay  Venkatarmani discuss various lay theories of selfcontrol noting that the amount of selfcontrol a person has can be seen as either an inherently limited or unlimited resource and that this resource can be seen either as malleable or as fixed the amount of selfcontrol a person has can change over time or not'
b'An important premise to note here is the idea that the probability of choosing a goal or making a resolution increases if a person thinks that goal can be attained'
b'So if you think youll be able to achieve a goal youre more likely to set it'
b'Combine this with theories of selfcontrol and in general if you believe you have unlimited stores of selfcontrol youll set a larger number of goals'
b'If you believe selfcontrol is malleable but limited youll set fewer goals'
b'Mukhopadhyay  Venkatarmani also discuss selfefficacy belief in ones capabilities the perceived ability to carry out a desired action'

b'They propose that people with high selfefficacypeople who believe that failure is the result of insufficient effort and thus exhibit increased commitment and persistencewill achieve more of their goals than people with low selfefficacy who tend to view failure as the result of deficient ability and thus may simply give up'
b'The studies'
b'In the first study 85 participants all college students each read one of four passages presenting lay theories of selfcontrol'
b'Each passage contained two paragraphs the first discussed selfcontrol either as limited or as unlimited and the second discussed selfcontrol as either malleable or fixed'
b'The participants then answered questions about their belief in each of two theories presented followed by a second questionnaire to assess motivation in which they listed all their current goals'
b'The study was testing whether a belief in unlimited malleable selfcontrol would result in most resolutions and indeed this is what was found'

b'The experimenters had some concerns about participants natural beliefs in relation to the passages they read however so in study two the order of the two measures lay theories and motivationgoal listing was varied'

b'Data from 130 new participants revealed that as hypothesized if the motivation  goals questionnaire were assessed first then among the people who believed selfcontrol is malleable those who also believed selfcontrol to be unlimited vs'
b'limited set more goals'
b'When lay theories were assessed first this result reversed'
b'The people who believed that selfcontrol is fixed were unaffected by order'
b'The third study moved on to examine goal achievement adding a measure to look at selfefficacy'
b'The study had two sessions in November then February'

b'In the first session  the 159 participants read passages about lay theories much like in study one but with longer passages to strengthen the manipulation listed the resolutions they were planning on making at New Years rated how disappointed they would be if they failed to keep their resolutions and filled out individual difference measures which included a selfefficacy scale'
b'Only 86 participants successfully returned for the second session during which they indicated how much success they had had at keeping their resolutions'
b'What does this mean for your resolutions'
b'The resolutions made by participants across all conditions were qualitatively similar take a look at any list of popular New Years resolutions and youll see the majority of the goals'

b'As shown in the first two studies more goals were set by people who believe selfcontrol is unlimited and malleable than by any other peoplethat is if you expect more success you may increase the difficulty and number of tasks that you set for yourself'
b'Selfefficacy did not have a significant effect on goalsetting'
b'As far as success goes only the interaction between lay theory and selfefficacy was significant'
b'If participants believed in limited selfcontrol and were low in selfefficacy they tended to give up more often failing to achieve their goals'

b'But if participants believed in unlimited selfcontrol selfefficacy had no effect participants achieved just as many goals regardless and people who set more resolutions were marginally more likely to succeed'

b'Mukhopadhyay  Venkatarmani realize that their research does not directly look at the relationship between lay theories of selfcontrol and beliefs about ones own amount of selfcontrol and selfefficacy and propose this as an area for future study'

b'But in general lay theories about selfcontrol can determine how much success youll expect and thus how many goals youll set and selfefficacy beliefs can determine how much success youll actually have'
b'References'
b'Mukhopadhyay A  Johar GV 2005'
b'Where There Is a Will Is There a Way'
b'Effects of Lay Theories of SelfControl on Setting and Keeping Resolutions'
b'Journal of Consumer Research  31 779786  PDF '
b'Detroit and the Myth of the 100 House  Uprooted an ecotravel blog'
b'Americas Rust Belt is a swath of cities and towns that boomed during the Industrial Era and now lie  well rusting  as empty remainders of glory days past'
b'Chief among these is Detroit Motor City'
b'The longtime center of American automotive manufacturing was gutted when the Big Three car companies simultaneously failed'
b'Detroit already plagued by corruption and crime saw its unemployment rate skyrocket in 2009'
b'Whats left behind when an economy collapses'
b'Cheap real estate thats what'
b'Id read a New York Times article about some forwardthinking artisttypes who bought a house in Detroit for 1900 '
b'Some of us and lots of New Yorkers pay that much in rent every month'
b'In fact the article went on soon a nearby house went on the market for 100'
b'The artist types notified their buddies who moved in post haste'
b'I was intrigued'
b'Really'
b'A 100 house'
b'Even if it was a real fixerupper even if you really were better off tearing it down than living in it thatd still be a hell of a deal'
b'Why out in New Mexico where you can still buy unincorporated land with no water or roads youd pay at least 1000 for a housesized plot of dust'
b'So how can you buy an actual home for 100'
b'Thats literally cheaper than dirt'
b'The possibilities of this were fascinating'
b'I had visions of hipsters from coast to coast converging in Detroit building a new city on rockroll'
b'I pictured young artists owning homes fixing up neighborhoods'
b'I saw community gardens art parks a grassroots transformation of a city'
b'We could take that oilstained soil and those rusted factories and create something new and beautiful'
b'With houses going for 100 I thought what would you have to lose by moving to Detroit'
b'And so Quiet Earp and I did some research and came up with a list of houses selling for under a grand'
b'We had plenty to choose from there were more cheap houses than we would have time to visit'
b'We picked two neighborhoods to cruise and dove in'
b'But once we entered Detroit the truth hit fast this is a modern American ghost town'
b'The place is practically deserted'
b'Its streets built wide to accommodate heavy traffic are mostly empty'
b'Houses and businesses are boarded up painted up bombed out and falling down'
b'Even in the center of the business district theres no traffic and hardly any people'
b'Dont believe me'
b'I videotaped it'
b'It got worse as we drove into residential areas looking for those cheap houses'
b'In fact Ive never felt so out of place in all my life '
b'Even in Chicagos South Side where we counted five white people in an hour I felt fine just driving around not so in Detroit'
b'Truthfully it wasnt about race it was about being naive'
b'It was about driving down streets where we truly did not belong and were not welcome'
b'Detroit is a ghost town and its inhabited by ghosts the only people left here are those who cant or wont leave'
b'They live in deserted neighborhoods in houses with collapsed front steps and missing windows'
b'They sit on the porch and watch the cars go by watch the deals go down watch their neighborhoods crumble'
b'And we driving through slowly and reading house numbers in a latemodel Honda stuck out like a couple of thumbs'
b'So we sped up and went straight to the houses'
b'Sometimes we stopped to take a photo but mostly we didnt'
b'Earp and I have each lived happily in the wilds of West Oakland but the danger I felt in Detroit was like nothing Id experienced before'
b'I was actually afraid for my life'
b'The New York Times correspondent wrote that his friend Mitchs 1900 home had already been stripped of its appliances and wiring '
b'But for Mitch that only added to its appeal because he now had the opportunity to renovate it with solar heating solar electricity and lowcost highefficiency appliances'
b'As for the 100 house'
b'It needed some work a hole patched some windows replaced'
b'needed some work a hole patched some windows replaced'
b'Well I dont know what part of Detroit these folks live in but the 100 houses I saw looked more like this'
b'You see abandoned houses in this town get set on fire'
b'No exceptions'
b'Wherever we went in those neighborhoods one in four houses had been torched'
b'On one corner we saw a giant banner hung across a charred front porch'
b'We didnt slow down to take a photo but Ill paraphrase DONT BURN HOUSES DOWN'
b'DETROIT POLICE ARE WATCHING YOU'
b'Except that they obviously arent'
b'People who live in this part of town are on their own'
b'And although I and many others would love to own even a firescarred condemned building the fact is that we wouldnt last a week here'
b'Buy a 100 house in Detroit and you get a lifetime supply of sleepless nights youll spend the next several years waiting for burglars and arsonists murderers and crackheads to break in the windows'
b'Its like the Wild West without the scenery the gold and the hope'
b'Its the Rust Belt'
b'Ultimately I do believe that change will come to Detroit'
b'There will be a green movement here  in fact its already being cultivated by forwardthinking groups and intrepid locals '
b'One day this place will be reborn'
b'But right now the NYTs story reeks of Shinola'
b'Truth is any artisttype who moves into this part of Detroit is probably pretty handy with a pistol or a shotgun '
b'Anyone who takes this plunge is risking their life every day betting on a future that may take a long time to arrive'
b'Long story short Yes you can buy a house in Detroit for 100'
b'And you will get what you pay for'
b'Cheers to Toby Barlow  who inspired my trek to Detroit and who believes in a happier greener future'
b'May your every dream come true sir and your book sell fabulously'
b'16 Responses to Detroit and the Myth of the 100 House'
b'bisnis 16 Sep 2009 at 946 pm'
b'Great post'
b'Thank you for this info'
b'I need that'
b'Myself 19 Sep 2009 at 1006 am'
b'Please track down and watch a movie called Detroit A City to Yourself by Nicole MacDonald'
b'Detroit A City to Yourself'
b'Its full of this imagery and talks about the 1805 fire and rebuilding and the postindustrial devastation thats ravaged the city since'

b'Most poignantly it talks about Hurricane Katrina which focused attention on rebuilding another city with this level of devastation and how without a single catastrophic event to blame for it Detroits decay has gone unsympathetically ignored'
b'The movie wraps up by observing this how abandoned buildings and spaces are being reclaimed by nature'
b'About the pop fiction which explores the concept of a posthuman world and how it already exists now'
b'And about how if youre a pheasant thats not such a bad thing'
b'HOWEVER '
b'Theres a lot more to Detroit than that'
b'There are industrial spaces being turned into lowrent artist lofts and business incubators'
b'Look at the Russell Industrial Complex for one example'
b'There are neighborhoods that refuse to cave'
b'west of Livernois around McNichols'
b'Theres a whole bunch of nice stuff happening along the riverfront from downtown up towards Stroh Place'
b'And theres always Belle Isle'
b'When friends come to Detroit I take them there'
b'Its our intheriver park 982 acres of green space with a zoo a botanical garden and conservatory rentable paddle boats and tons of other neat stuff'
b'Next time youre in Detroit please head over'
b'Oh and entry is free so its available to anyone regardless of economic status'
b'Youre liable to see families picnicking bums gathering bottles and cans geese foraging and deer cautiously wandering the edge of the woods'
b'Within a hundred yards of each other'
b'Some of that cheap real estate isnt too horrible either'
b'Theres a whole street being taken over by artists Farnsworth between Moran and McDougall'
b'Some of the things theyve done down there are amazing and the community garden is a great bridge to the surrounding neighborhood'
b'A few weeks ago someone broke into their shed to steal their garden tools'
b'Think about that for a moment hoes and shovels dont have enough pawn value to be worth carrying out'
b'Whoever took that stuff is probably using it in their own garden'
b'Yes Detroits got more than its share of bad spots youre right'
b'Ive lived in the metro area my whole life and there are areas I cant call them neighborhoods down there where I dont feel safe in daytime much less at night'
b'But there are bright spots and behind every one of them is a person or a bunch of people who refuse to give up'

b'Fermentation The Daily Wine Blog'
b'Eminent Domain Used To Usurp Wine Label Real Estate'

b'I was disappointed though not surprised to see that today a conjunctive labeling law dictating that Sonoma County be placed on every label on wines produced from grapes grown in Sonoma County was unanimously passed by the California Legislature '
b'Pushed as an effort to promote Sonoma County wines and a consumer education effort the new law instead forces vintners to needlessly sully their package and undermines their own marketing efforts'
b'Yet the law does nothing to educate consumers'
b'Passed unanimously out of the California Assembly and Senate AB 1798 now awaits the Governors signature which it will surely obtain'

b'According to Noreen Evans an Assembly sponsor of the bill this new conjunctive labeling law requires that any wine labeled with an American Viticultural Area AVA located entirely within Sonoma County  \xe2\x80\x93 like Russian River Valley or Dry Creek Valley  must also include the word Sonoma County on the label starting in 2014'
b'There are 13 AVAs in Sonoma County'

b'The problem of course is that by placing the words Sonoma County on a bottle of wine that is made with grapes grown in Russian River Valley Dry Creek Valley Sonoma Valley or any other AVA in Sonoma'
b'County consumers learn absolutely nothing about the wine in the bottle'

b'There no evidence that grapes grown in Sonoma County have any single distinguishing feature derived from the fact that they were grown inside the borders of Sonoma County Assemblywoman Evans concludes By improving consumer education on each bottle conjunctive labeling will unleash the full potential of our delicious wines to represent Sonoma around the world'
b'Shes correct'

b'Beginning in 2014 Sonoma County will receive a tremendous boost in recognition due to the conjunctive labeling law that forces vintners to add more wording to their labels\xe2\x80\x94whether they think the words Sonoma County help or hurt their marketing efforts'

b'Frankly if I was making high end wine from the Sonoma Valley Sonoma Mountain or Sonoma Coast AVAs that depended in part on the quality recognition that comes wtih these AVAs Id be pissed that Im forced now to put a placename on my label that told my buyers nothing of real value about the wine behind my label and in some cases demonstrably lowered its perceived quality'
b'Honore Comfort Executive Director of the Sonoma County Vintners Association and an outstanding representative for Sonoma County wines noted this '
b'This moment marks the beginning of a stronger Sonoma County brand for generations to come'

b'Proponents of the new Sonoma County Conjunctive labeling law like to point to a similar law that demands Napa Valley be placed on all wines that are made from grapes grown in that appellation rather than simply using a sub appellation'
b'They point to the prestige that the Napa Valley designation carries'
b'But this prestige has nothing to due with the law that demands Napa Valley in addition to simply Rutherford be placed on these wines'
b'It has to do entirely with the promotional effort that has gone into making Napa Valley a place associated with great wines'
b'The vintners in Sonoma County simply cant make a case for Sonoma County having any meaning or for a region as vast as Sonoma County delivering any degree of quality to the grapes'

b'Why is it important for someone making Sonoma Coast Pinot Noir or Sonoma Valley Zinfandel to help promote Sonoma County a designation that has no ability to define the quality or character of the wines in my Sonoma Coast Pinot Noir or my Sonoma Valley Zinfandel'
b'This is an example of a County usurping the private label real estate and its very valuable real estate for the sake of promoting something that is of little use to private commercial interests'

b'Ask yourselfIf putting the words Sonoma County on ones wines was such a great thing why dont more vintners who make Dry Creek Valley Russian River Valley Alexander Valley or Sonoma Valley wines already put these words on their label '
b'They legally couldif they wanted to'
b'The new Sonoma County conjunctive labeling law is the equivalent of the State of California and the County of Sonoma claiming imminent domain over the labels of hundreds of vintners'

b'Facebook Fans You Get What You Pay For 24 Mar 2010 by Rick'
b'Take a look at the Facebook Fan Pages of some brands and what you see is not a pretty picture'
b'Oh the numbers look good but when you dig a little deeper a different picture emerges'
b'Walls filled with off topic conversations at best vile language and real antipathy for the brand at worst'
b'What happened'
b'Wasnt having thousands of fans supposed to be a good thing'
b'Well yes and no'
b'Sure its great having several hundred thousands fans'
b'But how did you come to get those fans'

b'Did you earn them through fantastic customer service fulfilling the brand promise providing value to the community in an authentic and passionate voice or did you run a Facebook ad campaign and hit the broadcast airwaves with a promotion'
b'Lets look at \xc2\xa0 my old favorite  TGI Fridays If you can see this then you might need a Flash Player upgrade or you need to install Flash Player if its missing'
b'Get Flash Player from Adobe'
b'Remember that ad'
b'Pretty cool right'
b'In fact as I recall they got over 1 million Facebook fans'
b'Google TGI Fridays Fan Woody and it looks pretty good'
b'But then something not so awesome happened'
b'All those fans wanted their free burgers and they wanted them now'
b'TGI Fridays completely lost control of the page and eventually doled out a lot of free burgers'
b'Now from a short term perspective Im sure they did ok on the deal'
b'People came in and ate their food'
b'But they could have accomplished that with coupons in the mail the newspaper or by an email list'
b'But they decided to go the Social Media route'
b'Now lets take a look at what the Fridays FanWoody Facebook\xc2\xa0page looks like today Whoops'
b'Its gone'
b'Apparently Woody and his 900000 fans went poof '
b'How come'
b'Im guessing it had something to do with the venom and general anarchy the page had created by buying fans rather than growing them'
b'A TGI Fridays Facebook page does exist with roughly a third of the fans they used to have'
b'TGI Fridays pretty much had to spray Agent Orange on their relationship with 600000 people'
b'I think plenty of brands have heard the siren call of Facebook ads'
b'The ability to target your demo is really terrific but youre in danger of creating a relationship with fans that ultimately is built on a what have you done for me lately foundation'
b'First you essentially bought these fans'
b'You paid Facebook for the right to target them'
b'Then in the case of TGI Fridays or other brands that offer free product or discount coupons you are essentially buying them again'
b'This sets up a pattern where the consumer now expects to be rewarded for being your fan with a tangible item that is free stuff'
b'Thats not a bonus item its now a standard part of the agreement'
b'Want me as a fan'
b'Give me free stuff'
b'The point of Social Media isnt to distribute coupons and a real fan wants to engage with a brand for a whole host of reasons often free  discounted product is the least of these reasons'
b'Im not saying that special bonuses or surprise and delight offers arent ever a good thing'
b'I think when used properly they can be terrific'
b'What do I mean by used properly'
b'As a reward for people who have engaged with the brand in a meaningful way'
b'Send us a picture of you wearing a brand tshirt and sure youve earned a free sandwich'
b'Recruit some friends and Im happy to give you all some coupons'
b'But when fans enter the relationship feeling they are entitled to free samples and youre in trouble'
b'Kathy Sharpe says April 18 2010 at 102 pm'
b'About time there was some acknowledgement of the true value of fans'
b'Even if you have 3 million fans and they are all well behaved citizens what is the real marketing value'
b'How soon is now Lebron James Makes His Decision The ARod Route 8 Jul 2010 by Rick'
b'Lebron James is an extremely talented basketball player'
b'Hes also a very astute individual who understands how to use the media  and various communication channels  to his advantage'
b'Hes also managed to surround himself with people who understand business but Im starting to wonder if hes lost a bit of understanding of American culture'
b'Lebron didnt play college basketball he went straight from high school to the pros and since joining the Cleveland Cavaliers hes won exactly zero NBA champions'
b'Hes a free agent now and tonight he made his decision about which team hes going to play for in a very public manner with a live announcement on ESPN'
b'Earlier this week Lebron jumped on Twitter and quickly gained a massive following'
b'This morning he announced'
b'Lebron James was of course a trending topic and that hashtag was burning as well'
b'But Im starting to wonder if Lebron isnt painting himself into a corner and has maybe misread how quickly sentiment can change'
b'Sure Shaquille ONeal once said\xc2\xa0 Ive won at every level but college and pro but Shaq was always a larger than life literally character who was outgoing and had a great relationship with fans'
b'Ive won at every level but college and pro'
b'Thats one of the reasons\xc2\xa0 Shaqs been a huge hit on Twitter '
b'Lebron doesnt have that sort of relationship with fans'
b'I think an appropriate comparison might be Alex Rodriguez'
b'By making his announcement in this public way Lebron has only heaped more pressure on himself'
b'Ask ARod how the media can turn on you when you put yourself above your teammates above the game'
b'James now finds himself in the following position'
b'1 Winning a title is expected immediately wherever he goes'
b'2 Not winning a title will be seen as a massive disappointment'
b'3 Winning a title will result in some saying that he couldnt do it alone'
b'4 Hes put himself in a position where if he leaves Cleveland every other city and Cleveland will be rooting against him'
b'Sounds just like Alex Rodriguez doesnt it'
b'Im no longer the target demographic for most of the products Lebron endorses but you know what matters to me'
b'Winning championships'
b'Not live prime time press conferences not selfaggrandizing twitter hashtags and not quitting on his teammates during the playoffs'
b'Lets see what the future holds for Lebron'
b'We know hell be rich but how will he be viewed by fans across the country'
b'Perhaps Lebron should have hired a\xc2\xa0 Chief Culture Officer along with his coterie of other advisors'
b'If I were to fulfill that role for him I would have told him to go low key with this decision and let it be led by his new team'
b'Make sure its clear that the team comes first and that hes looking forward to being\xc2\xa0part of the team'
b'That the only thing that matters is winning a championship'
b'That that\xc2\xa0was the main factor'
b'Update\xc2\xa0 Lebron chooses the Miami Heat and the similarities to ARod continue with Dwyane Wade playing the role of Derek Jeter'
b'Update 2 And so it begins'

b'This is the first in a series of articles by guest blogger The Apocalyptic Housewife '
b'Somewhere in California a blighted mosquitovector abandoned property is about to get an echinacea dose via seedbomb'
b'Seedbombing combines elements of childhood disgruntled mudbombhurling the balance of meticulousness and zen that good gardeners possess and my own forte the invisibility and vigilance of a sniper'
b'It also requires a certain attitude'
b'The first step to seedbombing is'
b'1 Understand that a job worth doing is worth doing crappily'
b'You will fuck it up '
b'Live with this'
b'Embrace it'
b'Nothing worth doing was learned perfectly the first time'
b'If Mother Nature herself were perfect she wouldnt need us urban urchins to help cover her scars with flowering seeds'
b'Heres where we started '
b'Gift seeds of California Poppy via Jessica Reeders mom'
b'Thanks MamaHun'
b'2 Mix in seeds'
b'Use seeds of any kind even dumpstersalvaged ones or the ones that might be too old for the garden'
b'You can mix them with a 303040 mix of potting soil worm casings and clay'
b'Or you could go out to the shed and grab a few handfuls of that sod mix you got at that estate sale last year and get to mixing'
b'NOTE Cover your work area'
b'Dust can fly into your mouth and eyes very easily'
b'If the fertilizer in the mix is what I think it is that wouldnt be pretty'
b'Use gloves to break up the soil with your fingers'
b'3 Make bombs'
b'Form the mix into balls of any size from slingshotpellet up to softball'
b'Youre going to be throwing them'
b'Customize it yourself'
b'Mine were more or less matzohball size and shape out of habit'
b'This worked out pretty well'
b'Allow to dry overnight or until theyre solid enough for the next step'
b'4 Throw'
b'Today I kept it simple'
b'I chose one abandoned property a few minutes from downtown and two vacant lots'
b'The leftovers went onto the jungles alongside the freeway offramps'
b'First lesson learned  you need at least two people to seedbomb from a vehicle '
b'The first responsibility should be driving safely'
b'I found this hard to do while also avoiding cops dealing with the camera and the car window scoping out angles of approach for throwing etc'
b'I ended up with a broken fingernail and dirt all over my lap'
b'Also a perfect strike'
b'But youll have to take my word because a camera at that moment would have been crazy'
b'Second Lesson  keep the seedbombs in a shallow covered container '
b'You want both tidiness and easy access'
b'Plus those things are crumbly'
b'I made eight the last two were totally pulverized after being jostled in a paper bag for half an hour'
b'And the last lesson  have fun '
b'Its play'
b'Seedbombing is a hitormiss way for change to take root pun intended'
b'Its chlorophyll graffiti'
b'No one I know is getting diggd or favrd yet for throwing color and scent around the ghetto'
b'Do it to see how it feels'
b'You may want to keep checking on your flowers I promise I will or you might get an idea to do something else completely unexpected I did'
b'Enzo Angolini spike heels found by serendipity at St Pauls Thrift for 398'
b'Sexy non'
b'For example make smaller wildflower seedbombs and carefully plant them in a meridian by making holes in the ground with your heel and then gently tamping the dirt over them with your sole'
b'plant'
b'This is also good practice for looking lost and cluelessly invisible'
b'More on that in future posts'
b'5 Enjoy'
b'Earth is my friend like that old classmate who you keep forgetting to drop a note to on Facebook'

b'When I took a victory lap and handwash break in the mall I was happy not in a smug superior way but in the knowledge that I had avenged myself against the whole Sundayatthemall culture that I felt smothered by'
b'I did it by throwing flowers all along those places no one goes but where our planets future lives'
b'There is one overriding message to this  Quit being such a goddamned perfectionist'
b'Yes yes I know you know of much better places to never throw those seedbombs you havent made'
b'You could get better soil if you put it on the shopping list'
b'You undoubtedly write much better and could have a real serious article with awesome nonblurry pictures taken by a person who actually can get the timer to work for a goddamn change'
b'The actions that you never do are absolutely perfectly effective in your imagination'
b'But my actions accomplished something today'
b'Which brings us back to 1'
b'A job worth doing is worth doing crappily'
b'This blog is the digital proof'
b'6 Responses to The Apocalyptic Housewife Goes Seedbombing'

b'memoir'
b'In the vividly told book Ms Seltzer wrote about her AfricanAmerican foster brothers Terrell and Taye who joined the Bloods gang when they were 11 and 13'
b'She chronicled her experiences making drug deliveries for gang leaders at age 13 and how she was given her first gun as a birthday present when she was 14'

b'This is my favorite line in the whole NYT article Sarah McGrath the editor at Riverhead who worked with Ms Seltzer for three years on the book said she was stunned to discover that the author had lied'
b'Sarah McGrath the editor at Riverhead who worked with Ms Seltzer for three years on the book said she was stunned to discover that the author had lied'

b'Noshin at the Tupelo Honey Cafe  Plus how to get great service in busy restaurants 23 Mar 2010'
b'By the time I got to Asheville I was nearing the end of my journey and the bottom of my wallet'
b'But'
b'When Id posted on Facebook that I was coming to town no fewer than three people told me I just had to visit the Tupelo Honey Cafe '
b'So I checked their website and instantly fell in love'

b'Tupelo Honey Caf\xc3\xa9 opened in downtown Asheville in 2000 an early pioneer in the farm to fork movement and an active advocate for the independent restaurant landscape that pervades the city Our food is fresh made from scratch sassy and scrumptious Our cuisine salutes our love of Southern traditions at the table but like the good people of Asheville marches to its own drum The result is a unique riff on Southern favorites'
b'Tupelo Honey Caf\xc3\xa9 opened in downtown Asheville in 2000 an early pioneer in the farm to fork movement and an active advocate for the independent restaurant landscape that pervades the city'
b'Our food is fresh made from scratch sassy and scrumptious'
b'Our cuisine salutes our love of Southern traditions at the table but like the good people of Asheville marches to its own drum'
b'The result is a unique riff on Southern favorites'
b'tupelohoneycafecom'
b'I was convinced but I wasnt alone'
b'On a sunny Sunday afternoon the waiting list was an hour long'
b'After hemming and hawing and assessing my food stash contents 10 saltines I decided to go for it anyway'
b'By the time I finally got a seat at the counter I was starved'
b'It took me about thirty seconds to pick out the Charleston Chicken Sandwich grilled marinated freerange chicken breast on sourdough with melted havarti romaine lettuce and cranberry mayonnaise'
b'grilled marinated freerange chicken breast on sourdough with melted havarti romaine lettuce and cranberry mayonnaise'
b'Free range'
b'Cranberry'
b'Havarti'
b'Yes I could dig it'

b'While I waited for the food I checked out the back of the store where Tupelo Honey Cafe hawks their homestyle wares preserves pickles salsa honey tshirts aprons and all sorts of miniadvertisements for the restaurant'
b'Ive visited plenty of farmtofork restaurants and this one may be the best Ive seen at selfmarketing'
b'Theres nothing wrong with it the food in those jars is probably delicious though I question whether the 10 tupelo honey had to come from Florida or if its produced locally'
b'Either way its nice to see a restaurant built on ethics that also happens to be incredibly busy'
b'Some of that is surely due to good marketing but the real reason for its popularity is this'
b'That sandwich was so good I found myself eating slower and slower with each bite to savor it more completely'

b'The potatoes were light and ungreasy the flavors were perfectly balanced the chicken was juicy and rich and lets be honest here Im always happier eating dead animals when I know theyve lived a good life'
b'I found myself silently thanking the chicken for its delicious contribution'
b'Thank you chicken'
b'I will never forget you'
b'I stopped eating halfway through not because I was full'
b'I stopped so I could take the rest home and taste it again later'
b'On another topic I made a discovery there in the Tupelo Honey Cafe one which Id like to share with you now'
b'If youre going to a busy restaurant and want great service bring a camera'
b'Take a few photos of the menu the kitchen the food'
b'No sooner had I taken the above photo when a server not even my server appeared at my elbow'
b'Now Im not saying the service before my cameraflash was bad because it was awesome'
b'But wow it sure improved once I appeared to be some sort of food critic or travel writer'
b'Which it just so happens I am'
b'But even if youre not try this out sometime'
b'I cant guarantee itll work but I personally will do it againand probably back it up with a stellar review just like the one Ive given the Tupelo Honey Cafe'
b'Everybody wins'
b'Okay thats it'
b'I could talk about Asheville for weeks but its time to move on'
b'Next stop sunny Tennessee where I get down on The Farm'
b'Save the World Ride a Bike a visit to Troy Bike Rescue'
b'This post is the first of a threepart series on bike culture'
b'Come back Friday to read about anarchy bike jousting and twowheeled social protest '
b'Remember when you got your first bike'
b'Was it a Christmas present or maybe a birthday gift'
b'Well these days most kids want an Xbox for their birthday their parents ride around in cars with seatbelts talking on their phones '
b'Cycling is a thing of the past a sport a hobby but rarely a mode of transportation'
b'But Im here to tell you riding your bike is still fun and still fast and its the cheapest and most socially responsible workout youll ever get '
b'And there are no two ways about it if you give a kid a bike that kid will ride'
b'In Troy New York I met one Andrew Lynn'
b'Hes somewhat of a man brain trust  and one of his best creations is the Troy Bike Rescue '
b'It started in 2001 when Andrew would ride around town pulling bikes out of dumpsters'
b'He started hosting work parties with friends in his backyard teaching them to fix their bikes and helping them get started riding'
b'Slowly but surely the circle grew and Andrews backyard parties became weekly workshops'
b'When Andrew decided to leave town for a few years schooling in NYC friends and cohorts took over operations'
b'By the time Andrew returned Troy Bike Rescue lets call it TBR had a life of its own'
b'These days its an established club run by volunteers and donations turning trashed bikes into treasures'

b'Its influence now includes a legitimate downtown storefront a sister shop in Albany  Albany Bicycle Coalition  movie screenings and procycling political events and a dedicated core crew that keeps everything rolling'
b'TBRs customers run the gamut from businessmen to street kids to college students to families'
b'The one thing they have in common'
b'This group understands the value of a bicycle more than just transportation a bike is a statement against fossil fuels'
b'More than a toy its an equalizer that allows poor kids to ride with rich'
b'More than a hobby its a way of traveling through the world that lets you interact use your muscles breathe fresh air  all for the cost of a free dumpster bike'
b'When I visited the TBR shop it was packed with frames wheels gears chains handlebars kids and anarchist art the space is being donated by some supporters who are also anticapitalist activists'
b'TBR hosts workshops twice a week'
b'For a few hours the doors are open to anyone who walks in'
b'Tools are available and volunteers will help with advice and knowledge'
b'Parts can be had for a pittance and you can pick out your own bike from the stacks and racks of machines filling the space'
b'The main focus of TBR however is not selling bikes'
b'The idea is to give people a workspace and teach them how to maintain their own bicycle'
b'Selfsufficiency is a major tenet of the bike movement and Troy Bike Rescue is training selfreliant individuals of all stripes'
b'All around me college students and bike punks tinkered with their machines'
b'An older man asked for tips on tuning his racer'
b'A young kid came in to say his last bike was stolen and he needed a new one and despite Andrews stern reprimand that he couldnt just walk in every week and leave with a free bike he did just that'
b'A dad came in with his three kids all of whom left with snazzy rides  but first they all sat down and worked on their new wheels together'
b'And as we left at the end of the workshop a woman walked up to Andrew'
b'I love what you do she said'
b'I love what you do'
b'I have a whole bunch of bikes to give you'
b'See ultimately TBR is about more than just bicycles'
b'Its about building community and triggering a quiet but inexorable social movement'
b'This is not the worlds first bike collective in fact its only one of many that have stealthily sprung up around America'
b'These collectives are not waiting for change to happen theyre creating it through small positive peaceful actions'
b'You too can change the world all you have to do is ride a bike'
b'Try This at Home Ride Around'
b'Fall is here which in most places means great riding weather'
b'What are you waiting for'
b'Bikes are cheap you can get one at your local thrift store for 550'
b'It doesnt have to be perfect just good enough to get you places'
b'So pick one up and ride it to the end of your block'
b'Then keep going'
b'Even if your life requires four wheels you can use a bike for local errands'
b'Ride it to the corner store when you need milk instead of driving across town to the grocery store'
b'Dont like the milk they sell'
b'Tell the store owner what you like and see if hell carry it'
b'Now youre changing the world'
b'On weekends instead of driving to the park hop on your bike and go exploring'
b'It doesnt have to be a workout you can just toodle around town and look at stuff'
b'Or if youre a gym buff trade a workout for a bike ride'
b'Unless you live on a major highway odds are you can ride straight from your front porch to someplace interesting'
b'On vacation rent a bike instead of a scooter or God forbid a Segway'
b'Its cheaper and much better for the local florafauna'
b'Still not convinced'
b'Then think of it this way by riding your bike instead of driving your car youre reducing your consumption of fossil fuels'
b'You can even calculate the money you save on gas and keep it in a jar for a rainy day'
b'Want to get involved'
b'Bike clubs tend to be pretty anarchic but if you look around your community youll find both bike riders and shop owners who ride for change'
b'Cant find a bike community'
b'Start your own'

b'Farming on Sand The trouble with eating local on Cape Cod  Uprooted an ecotravel blog'
b'This is part 4 of a 4part series on tourisms impact on Cape Cod'
b'Read about death  carnage in the shell shop  find out about the ecofriendly food scene  look at the pretty pretty sunset  or continue on'
b'David DeWitt doesnt look like a farmer'
b'With his long hair scruffy beard and tshirt hed fit in more at a Phish show than behind a plow'
b'But appearances are deceiving and Davids comfy mien belies a passion that is influencing the culture of northern Cape Cod'
b'To wit in 2009 David helped launch the Truro Ag Fair  an event that exceeded all expectations and brought huge crowds to local farmers booths'
b'He runs the Rock Spray nursery a Certified Natural provider of evergreens and ornamentals'
b'And he manages the First Light Organic Farm a lush green spot in a hollow of North Truro'
b'Here David and his partner Arthur Teubner work yearround growing heirloom and hardy fruits and veggies to sell at market'
b'Davids a dedicated and inspired agrarian whose passion for farming keeps him optimistic'
b'But farming on the Outer Cape is the sort of Sisyphian challenge that can wear anybody out'
b'The hard truth The soil of North Truro is not strong enough to support agriculture'
b'Without fertilization it deteriorates shockingly fast'
b'David points out a patch of sand with a thin strip of fertile loam along the edge'
b'Last season it was a fertile veggie bed  but it was left unfertilized as an experiment'
b'This is what happens David says'
b'This is what happens'
b'You have to keep feeding it organic material or it turns back into sand'
b'This plot was a test run left untended for a single season'
b'Last years rich loam is now useless sand'
b'Its always been this way in North Truro'
b'The Outer Cape is really just a spit of sand  but still farmers lived here for generations'
b'How'
b'Salt marsh hay'
b'There used to be a local tradition in this area at each spring tide  the local community would head out to the bogs and marshes to harvest the grasses'
b'This was called salt marsh haying'
b'salt marsh haying'
b'Salt marsh hay has no weed seeds and it doesnt compact as heavily as other types of hay'
b'This makes it an excellent and bountiful source of compost and it was used for generations as a soil enricher'
b'But haying had to happen regularly says David Theres so much oxygen in this soil any added compost gets burned up in six weeks'
b'Theres so much oxygen in this soil any added compost gets burned up in six weeks All the nutrients get depleted'
b'All the nutrients get depleted'
b'That means soil left for two months without fresh compost will become  you guessed it  sand'
b'The only way to keep things going here is to keep a steady flow of compost coming in'
b'That means truckloads of hay and that means a lot of work'
b'Last year David and Arthur brought in a semi truck loaded with leaf mulch'
b'It worked  but it cost money and it disappeared fast into the hungry ground'
b'Not a longterm plan'
b'Without that community support its nearly impossible for him to harvest hay often enough to keep the farm green'
b'Meanwhile in Tourist Town USA'
b'The Provincetown farmers market has lovely produce but little of it was grown on the Cape'
b'Provincetowns official population of 3500 supports a tourism industry that serves millions of visitors each year'
b'City folk marvel at the quaint charms of the Cape its idyllic beauty and simple pleasures'
b'And then they go out to eat'
b'Even if tourists were interested in sustainable food they totally dont care  theyd be hard pressed to find a locallysourced meal'
b'Raina Stefani serves Davids produce at her restaurant Terra Luna  but it only makes up a portion of her fares the rest has to be shipped from the mainland'
b'You cant squeeze blood from a stone and you cant get big vegetable crops from sand dunes'
b'End of story'
b'Well not exactly'
b'David isnt giving up  in fact hes got plans and ideas to refashion North Truros farming community'
b'Hence the Ag Fair and the ongoing experimentation with varieties and soils at First Light'
b'David isnt alone hes got the support and companionship of a growing group of gamechangers'
b'If the young farmers and foodies of Truro can organize they might just be able to get local agriculture back on its feet'
b'Their main opponent'
b'The tourism and real estate industries which insist upon turning every arable inch of the Cape into somebodys backyard'
b'The same population that would consume the food produced here is actively inhibiting its production'
b'No surprise there'
b'After all whats the point of farming on the beach'
b'2 Responses to Farming on Sand'

b'Zombies and Vampires and Ninjas and Pirates 25 Jul 2010 by Rick'
b'Its tough to kill the vampiregenre'
b'I was noodling on Vampires the other day but also lumped Zombies Pirates and Ninjas in the mix'
b'These archetypes seem different to me than other trends'
b'trends'
b'Surely the Vampire was dead after the spoof Love at First Bite  in 1979'
b'Love at First Bite '
b'But then the Anne Rice led revival brought it back technically the 1st \xc2\xa0book Interview with the Vampire  \xc2\xa0was published in 1976 but didnt gain widespread popularity until later'
b'Then it jumped the shark with the Tom CruiseBrad Pitt movie based on the Anne Rice novel in 1994'
b'But bubbling below the surface was Blade and other genre flicks then Twilight hit and now vampires are hot'

b'Surely Ninjas were done with horrible movies like American Ninja 1985 or with comedies starring Chris Farley  Beverly Hills Ninja  1997 and yet Ninja has become a replacement word for expert to the point where its almost accepted parlance A twellow search for ninja turned up more than 7000 Twitter accounts using the term in their profiles'
b'expert'
b'ninja'
b'Ninja Warrior is one of the most popular shows on G4'
b'We can put Pirates away now after the 3rd Pirates of the Caribbean flick right'
b'No actually if weve learned anything its that genre memes just go back underground  Pirates for adults NSFWYou get the point0'
b'These characters are like Zombies pun intended they just keep coming back to life'
b'So its not just a matter of knowing when to jump off the Vampire merrygoround its knowing when and where to jump back on'
b'If you jumped off Vampires would you have known to jump back on in time to publish Twilight'
b'Fourteen literary agents rejected it before Stephenie Meyer got a deal'
b'If you were off Zombies would you have gotten back on it time to publish NY Times bestseller Pride  Prejudice and Zombies '

b'I dont think you can get off any of these you have to triangulate your decision across several nodes of popular culture a triangulation that has to revolve around the audience young adult  Twilght mature  True Blood and subgenre comedy horror scifi and then the actual quality of the content'
b'get off'
b'So what sort of matrix board do you have to create to know that a NC17 comedy horror Zombie video game will work but a PG13 young adult timetravelling Vampire TV show wont'
b'You cant'
b'All you can do is hope you bat 300 and that when you fail you fail fast '
b'Ahh the classics'

b'If you broaden your scope a bit I think it would be difficult to find a time over the last 40 years or so when any of these four archetypes didnt have a level of bubbling popularity via books comic books tv movies video games music'

b'If all youre looking at is 1 or 2 content categories maybe it looks like theyre dead but they may be flourishing elsewhere and like a virus theyre just waiting for a new host to carry them to the mainstream'
b'Publishers producers editors TV execs they all have to calibrate their decisions based on so many factors and yet even with access to sophisticated data it often comes down to human factors'
b'A gut instinct that something is going to work'

b'Somebody at AMC is greenlighting The Walking Dead based partly on historical evidence that says people like Zombies but also partly on the notion that this particular iteration will have a new twist that will bring new people into the zombie and AMC tent '
b'Personally Im waiting for someone to make Pirate Zombies v Ninja Vampires'
b'Hey if they can make Aliens and Cowboys  anything is possible'

b'A defense of Michael Moore and Bowling for Columbine'
b' probably the most comprehensive among many rebuttals of the Oscarwinning documentary'
b'Critics have now gone so far as to call for the revocation of the award'
b'Their chances are small however as their arguments rely on polemic exaggeration and misrepresentation  in other words on the same techniques which they accuse Moore of using'
b'Dear David Hardy'
b'It is fascinating to watch the organized character assassination of Michael Moore that has been going on in the United States since the release of his last documentary'

b'In a time of simpleminded patriotism loud clear and dissenting voices like Mr Moores are perceived as disturbing and have to be silenced partially through well funded public relations campaigns partially through conservative grassroots propaganda'
b'Not surprisingly much of the criticism of Moores film is misguided or outright wrong often vastly more inaccurate than Moores work itself'
b'His documentary is full of subtle humor jawdropping dialogue and dark contrasts'
b'All in all it is an accurate portrayal of Americas gun and violence culture'
b'It also raises questions about Americas foreign policy of recent decades questions which have been all but ignored by Moores critics'
b'On your webpage you state that Moores resolution is questionable'
b'Moores resolution is questionable'
b'After all early in the movie he discards the possibility that playing violent video games and watching violent flicks can cause violence  because Canadians like and Japanese positively love those'
b'If violent movies and violent videogames cannot cause violence  then how can newscasts about violence do so'
b'This is a faulty generalization'
b'If as Moore implies although never states as fact video games and violent movies are relatively harmless it does not logically follow that all types of media presentation are harmless'
b'There is a huge difference for example between playing a game like Quake and listening to a radio broadcast that tells you that your family will be killed unless you take action to kill others now'
b'Similarly the main motivation for the crusades beyond the promise of wealth was that Christians were supposedly being slaughtered and had to be saved'
b'Obviously media propaganda can incite people to kill'

b'Interactive fiction like video games on the other hand presents violence in a narrative context which may very well desensitize participants to said violence but no causative link has ever been proven'

b'Moores hypothesis which apparently comes at least in part from the book Culture of Fear by Barry Glassner also advertised on Moores website is that the constant bombardment with messages of fear can incite paranoia which itself can lead to violent acts'
b'This is consistent with the kind of mediaincited violence described above and in no relationship whatsoever to the theory of video game or music incited violence'
b'It is no surprise however that US and European media do not question their own propaganda of fear'

b'Moores second hypothesis is that Americas foreign policy may contribute to the belief that violence is an appropriate means to solve conflicts a hypothesis which is shared by many sociologists and psychologists'
b'Children who grow up in wartorn regions are known for having similar views  war is perceived as a normal part of existence violence as a natural way to solve disputes'

b'In a weaker sense the same message is projected to American children who grow up being told that it is not acceptable to be violent to one another but who simultaneously have to endure corporal punishment and media messages about how the enemies of freedom are punished'
b'Moores film was made before the dead bodies of Qusay and Uday Hussein were paraded on national TV'
b'Americans were gloating over this demented corpse show'
b'They squealed like little piggies too so youll have to make do with oink oink squeeeeeeeallll for their last words'
b'oink oink squeeeeeeeallll'
b'That goes for your grandson Mustafa too by the way'
b'Still think fucking with the US was a good idea Sammy'
b'Mustafa was 14 years when he was killed'
b'Americans cheer the killing of children yet wonder why their own children grow up to be more violent than those in other nations'
b'It is paradoxical notions like this one which Moores film seeks to address'
b'Inaccuracies'
b'Your webpage list a number of alleged inaccuracies in Moores movies'
b'It is true that Moores film is sometimes unintentionally deceptive but to call it fraudulent is hyperbole to the extreme'
b'It is no more so than any other successful documentary of the last decades'
b'Lets look at some specific criticisms'
b'1 The bank scene listed on your website on a separate page'
b'Critics have stated that this scene was staged but in the bank interview the official tells Moore that the bank has its own vault storing about 500 weapons at any given time'
b'It is also a licensed firearms dealer which can perform its own background checks'
b'In an interview with the Wall Street Journal linked from your site an employee claims that the gun would have been normally picked up at another dealer'
b'It is not explained what normally is supposed to mean but that claim flatly contradicts the statement of the bank official in the film'
b'This sounds more like a later correction for public relations purposes but of course nobody questions the bank claims when they can be used against Moore'
b'The only thing that Moore compressed is the timeframe'
b'According to the same WSJ interview Typically youre looking at a week to 10 days waiting period'
