b'This text is in the public domain'
b'Proposal for a Red Harvester Ant Robot Colony Infiltration and Task Switching'
b'Introduction'
b'Background'
b'Science fiction writers have been anticipating humanoid androids that could pass a Turing Test for years'
b'Unfortunately as of yet no robot has managed to fool a human for more than a few seconds and no robot has been created that can integrate itself into human society'
b'Infiltrating insect societies however is much simpler'

b'Extensive research has been done on the interactions of social insects such as honeybees ants and cockroaches and in fact robots have passed undetected in cockroach society performing single simple behaviors already Halloy et al 2007'

b'No robot has yet been constructed however that could pass undetected within a colony of the red harvester ants species Pogonomyrmex barbatus nor has a robot managed to pass undetected in a society of insects while combining in its design several different behaviors and the thresholds of stimulation required to switch between them'
b'Such a robot would allow for both longterm studies of antrobot interactions and studies of taskswitching in the robots'

b'I propose here the theoretical construction and programming of a robot hereafter referred to as Antie that will be able to infiltrate a red harvester ant nest switching between the foraging patrolling and midden work behaviors'
b'Environment'
b'The red harvester ant lives in hot dry deserts building its nests in light yellowy sand and foraging for seeds deposited by winds and rain'

b'The ants forage for more than 30 different varieties of seeds many of which do not grow in the desert Gordon 54 where only a few varieties of small shrubs small herbaceous flowering plants and short grasses do grow Gordon 51'
b'Other insects and creatures including other species of ants are present in the desert but red harvester ants seem to be relatively undisturbed by these animals Gordon 711'
b'Though fights sometimes do break out with other red harvester ants from different nests intraspecies interactions tend not to be aggressive Gordon 11'
b'Because of this I will ignore other ant species in the design of Antie and will not create a fighting behavior'
b'Antie will be equipped to navigate in this environment and will be designed to find seeds in sandy soil'
b'The Ant  the Robot'
b'Ants of this species are of two types breeding ants queens and drones and sterile female workers'

b'Queens and drones will not be considered in this proposal as their behaviors and design is much more specialized and would be applicable only during the breeding season which occurs but once per year'
b'The behaviors of the sterile workers may be divided into several subcategories brood care nest maintenance patrolling and foraging'
b'Little is known about brood care as this occurs only in the deepest regions of the nest and observation would generally require the destruction of the nest'

b'Nest maintenance and seed processing are likewise difficult to observe in the deeper regions of the nest but the sorting and deposition of waste dirt and nest garbage outside of the nest midden work occurs close enough to the surface to be observable'
b'Patrolling and foraging too occur for the most part outside of the nest and have therefore been studied extensively ex Schafer et al 2006 Gordon et al 2002 Gordon 2002 Gordon 1987'
b'These three behaviors each present different puzzles to the ant and to the modeler though there is some overlap particularly with navigational problems'

b'In the case of midden work Antie must be able to identify garbage grasp it carry it out of the nest and deposit it about halfway down the mound before returning to repeat the process ad infinitum or until stimulated to switch behaviors'
b'Patrolling may be divided into two distinct subbehaviors nest patrolling and trail patrolling'

b'An ant engaged in nest patrolling must exit the nest at the proper time in the morning and wander about for a bit on the nest mound presumably taking measurements of the temperature and humidity in some way and making sure that it is safe for the other ants to exit'

b'Perhaps the level of degradation of the nest patrollers\xe2\x80\x99 cuticular hydrocarbons after this short foray into the sun and heat acts as an indication of the outside conditions to the foragers who may then upon smelling the returning patroller be stimulated either to forage or to remain inactive inside the nest'
b'An ant engaged in trail patrolling must exit the nest wander around searching for food sources identify food upon discovery and return to the nest to show the foragers where the food is'

b'This is thought to be accomplished by the deposition of chemical markers from a gland on the abdomen that the patroller drags along the ground on her return route to the nest that the foragers may then follow Gordon 3334 Holldobler et al 1990 as cited in Webb 1998'
b'In addition to following these trails to the food foragers must also be able to identify food grasp it and carry it back to the nest'

b'Ants engaged in all three behaviors must be able to identify other nestmates and their current tasks as well as indicate to other ants their own nestmate status and current task walk navigate both within and outside of the nest and of course switch tasks at appropriate times'
b'The Agent'
b'Chassis'
b'Antie will be implemented on a tiny Road Warrior robotic system'
b'Behaviors will be coded in Interactive C for which some pseudocode is included'
b'Sensors will include a thermometer photoreceptors bump sensors a polarization compass and a series of chemical receptors'
b'Antie be a circular robot no more than 1cm in diameter the length of a red harvester ant with two driving wheels and one rear wheel for stabilization'
b'A gripper will be located on the front of the robot consisting of two elongated tongs'

b'Antie will also feature a skirt of bump sensors sonar detectors and chemical emitters including sacs of hydrocarbons extracted from ants of the nest being infiltrated and pheromones for successful patrolling and foraging'
b'These sacs will be refilled at a filling station each morning as Antie determines that they are getting depleted'
b'Antie will likewise recharge at a special station at night just inside the nest entrance'
b'For the purposes of this proposal I will assume that Antie has enough battery life to remain powered the whole day'
b'A rudimentary blueprint of Antie is attached'
b'Sensors'
b'In order to inform itself about its environment Antie will need a number of sensors'

b'In an attempt to mimic the red harvester ant as closely as possible these sensors include a thermometer photoreceptors bump sensors and sonar a polarization compass and a series of chemical receptors on a pair of stalks corresponding to the antennae'
b'On its front grippers Antie will have a tactile skin to sense pressure'
b'The locations of the rest of these sensors will depend on their function'
b'The thermometer will be located on the rear of the robot to keep it out of the way and will detect and input to the robot the outside temperature in degrees Celsius'
b'Harvester ants do not exit the nest when the outside temperature is above 52 degrees Celsius Gordon 9 and the ability to use a temperature gradient will enable innest navigation'
b'Antie will also be equipped with one photoreceptor located in the middle of the top of its chassis corresponding to the ant\xe2\x80\x99s eyes'

b'These will be useful for initiating patrolling behavior in the morning and shutting off behaviors at night the patrollers first poke their heads out of the nest shortly after sunrise and scuttle back in at night Gordon 5'
b'The bump sensors and sonar will form a skirt around Antie to keep it from colliding with other objects'

b'The sonar will constantly be detecting nearby objects and initiate an escape maneuver when their inputs pass a certain threshold of stimulation and the bump sensors will when depressed also initiate the escape function'
b'The sonar will correspond to the ant\xe2\x80\x99s limited optical object detection ability and the bump sensors will allow the robot to detect collisions'

b'The polarization compass will consist of two polarized light sensors placed at 45 and 45 degrees from the center front of Antie respectively that will orient Antie towards a desired polarization pattern'

b'These sensors would correspond to the cells in the ants\xe2\x80\x99 eyes sensitive to polarized light and research has shown that many insects including ants do navigate using a path integration system synthesizing input from a polarization compasses and from a sort of odometer Labhart et al 2002'

b'Antie would use a system for processing the input from its polarization compass based on the compass designed by Lambrinos Moller Labhart Pfeifer and Wehner in 2000 consisting of two photodiodes with blue filters and polarizers'

b'The difference of their logarithmized signals would be returned to Antie who will use a simultaneous model to navigate returns to the nest Upon each exit from the nest Antie will take a single 360o scan of the sky and will orient itself according to an analytical procedure to derive compass information from different polarization patterns perceived later'

b'This should be sufficient to return Antie to the nest given the accuracy achieved by Lambrinos et al and the relatively short periods of time that harvester ants spend outside the nest before returning'
b'Diagram of the polarizationopponent unit described by Lambrinos et al 2000'

b'The unit takes in polarization levels through the two polarizationsensitive photodiodes and feeds them into the logarithm ratio amplifier which returns the difference of the logarithmized signals from the photodiodes'
b'The evector heading returned from the two polarizationsensitive photodiodes 1 2 follows a cos2function'

b'Ants themselves rely primarily on chemical information taken in through their antennae and to mimic this Antie will have chemical sensing and emitting \xe2\x80\x9cstalks\xe2\x80\x9d with which to both interact with other ants who may be surprised to find an ant without antennae and take in chemical information'

b'These stalks will need to have receptors to measure the nalkene levels present in another ant\xe2\x80\x99s cuticular hydrocarbons which research indicates is the marker for harvester ants of a nestmate\xe2\x80\x99s current task perhaps because the hydrocarbons are altered in the dry sun causing a different ratio of nalkanes to nalkenes and the presence of branched nalkanes in the hydrocarbon profile Wagner et al 2001 as cited in Gordon  Greene 2003'

b'Antie\xe2\x80\x99s stalks would also have receptors for the hydrocarbons themselves which research shows indicate to the ants whether another ant is their nestmate Arnold et al 1996 as cited in Gordon  Mehdiabadi 1999 receptors to detect food and receptors for three types of pheromones those released by successful foragers returning with food those released by successful patrollers returning to the nest and those marking piles of trash as midden'
b'Research shows that successful foragers returning to the nest do have a different effect on the inactive workers than unsuccessful foragers returning Schafer et al 2006'

b'Returning successful patrollers have an even greater effect on foraging activity foragers will not leave the nest unless a patroller returns Gordon 2002 and the rate of foraging in a colony can be controlled by rolling glass beads coated with cuticular hydrocarbons extracted from patrollers into the nest Gordon  Greene 2003 Greene  Gordon 2007'
b'Midden seems to be marked in some olfactory way since removing midden from nests makes them more likely to be invaded by other species Gordon 35'
b'For the purposes of this proposal I will assume that the nest maintenance and food processing ants have marked the midden with a particular pheromone'
b'All of these chemical receptors will be arranged in an array on a pair of chemical stalks with four of each type of receptor per stalk'
b'This technique described by Ishida et al 2001 has been shown to improve the chemical plumetracking abilities of robots'
b'The wires will lead back down through the stalk to the onboard PC'
b'Finally Antie will have tactile sensors on its grippers to analyze the pressure being exerted on a gripped object'

b'These sensors will be of the type patented by Peterson et al Patent 4492949 and will feature several layers of electrically insulating and parallel flexible conductive rods arranged such that an exerted pressure may be measured in output voltage'
b'These will correspond to the muscles of the ant\xe2\x80\x99s mandibles which provide sensorimotor feedback to the ant when grasping objects'
b'A table of the sensors and their relation to the ant\xe2\x80\x99s sensory system is provided below'
b'Table of sensors and their relations to the ant'
b'Motors'
b'Antie\xe2\x80\x99s motors will allow it to move around and interact with its environment and fellow ants'
b'There will be two individually operated motors to drive the two side wheels in lieu of legs'
b'Two simultaneously operated motors will open and close the grippers emulating the grasping power of the ant\xe2\x80\x99s mandibles'
b'A third motor will lift and lower the grippers allowing Antie to raise and lower gripped items as an ant would by raising and lowering its head'
b'Three small sprayers will emit successful patroller and forager pheromones and cuticular hydrocarbons from the appropriate sacs'

b'These will be located in different places the sprayer for the successful patroller pheromone will be located on the rear at the base of Antie corresponding to the glands that researchers believe the ants drag along behind them to mark returning paths while the successful forager and cuticular hydrocarbon sprayers will be located on the skirt'
b'Antie will not spray different pheromones depending on its task on the assumption that its time in the sun will alter its hydrocarbons enough that its tasks will be recognizable to other ants'
b'Almost all motor output will be a direct function of sensory input as indicated in the following section'
b'The Behavior'
b'Antie will have a hybrid software architecture a subsumption hierarchy will be responsible for switching between behaviors but many subbehaviors will operate on a schema basis'
b'Pseudocode will approximate this architecture as closely as possible and where appropriate different subroutines running on a schema basis will be marked'
b'Common Behaviors'
b'A few subbehaviors will be necessary for more than one behavior'

b'To ease Antie\xe2\x80\x99s onboard memory requirements and processing capabilities and to make all the rest of the pseudocode easier for the reader to understand I propose a few global variables and subroutines'
b'The following global variables will be used throughout the pseudocode and are compiled here for ease of reference'

b'Common behaviors will include a forward cruise and turning mechanism procedures to determine the orientation towards nest and the distance from the nest when outside innest navigation an escape function for when objects are detected or bumped into object identification and gripping a generic algorithm for pheromone plume and chemical trail following and the identification of other ants'
b'For a simple start the forward cruise function will merely take in a double integer representing a speed and cause Antie to move forward at this speed'
b'These behaviors will often be used in other subroutines running on a schema basis and when combined with the forward cruise function should cause the robot to move at an angle'

b'In order to orient itself toward the nest while navigating outside Antie will need to determine which direction the nest is in and rotate toward that heading and also how far from the nest it is at its current location'
b'The orientation and distance should be calculable by the polarization pattern according to the system set up by Lambrinos et al'

b'Antie will therefore have a polarization function that will return a compass direction toward which it should orient in order to return home to the nest and a distance function that will return the shortest direct distance'
b'We may assume that this first function will return a direction in degrees positive or negative and that the second function will return a distance in centimeters'
b'The first function might look something like this'
b'Innest navigation will be a function of the temperature read by Antie\xe2\x80\x99s thermometer and a light source'
b'To exit Antie will seek a high temperature until the photoreceptor reaches a threshold of stimulation indicating sunlight and to get deeper Antie will seek a lower temperature'
b'The code may look something like this'
b'This void function will be called nestEnter and will take in no inputs'
b'To avoid bumping into things including other ants Antie be provided with an escape function'
b'Each of Antie\xe2\x80\x99s eight bump sensors will cause the robot to rotate a different amount and the sonar will cause it to rotate 90 degrees in the opposite direction'
b'Regardless this will be a very simple function'
b'I will include one example'

b'Because this function responds to the sensors on Antie\xe2\x80\x99s around the sides and only its sonar detectors will be able to detect objects in front of it this escape function will not prevent Antie from being able to locate and pick up objects such as seeds'
b'Before picking objects up however Antie will need to identify them'
b'This object detection process will be activated when the front bump sensor is stimulated or when both sonar detectors are stimulated'
b'Chemical inputs will be checked to see what this object is most likely to be given its smell'
b'The code may look something like this'
b'Once the object has been identified Antie may grip it and lift it'
b'A simple void function grip taking in no inputs will tighten the grippers until a certain threshold of pressure is reached at which point the grippers will be lifted for carrying'
b'A void function release will perform this same action in reverse'

b'Antie will also need to follow several different kinds of chemical gradient trails it will need to track the trails left by successful patrollers and localize the source of foododors and middenodors'

b'Implementations of chemical gradient following robots using two sensors on \xe2\x80\x9cantennae\xe2\x80\x9d stalks has been successful in with analog robots in the past Webb 1998 regardless of the potential problem of airflow causing a disturbed gradient over evaporating pheromones'
b'As a partial control for the problem of imprecise sensing a function will perform an analysis of the array information coming on from Antie\xe2\x80\x99s four sensors on each stalk'
b'The differences between these outputs is what is being compared everywhere there is a \xe2\x80\x9cleftIP\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9crightIP\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Antie will use the chemical gradient algorithm of Braitenberg\xe2\x80\x99s aggressive type 2 vehicle described in his book \xe2\x80\x9cVehicles Experiments in Synthetic Psychology\xe2\x80\x9d as this was found through a series of experiments by Russell et al 2003 to be very efficient when compared to several biomimetic models'
b'Because the same general algorithm will be followed for the localization of all three chemical traces I will provide pseudocode for only one generic subroutine'
b'Note that a portion of this subroutine does run on a schema basis'
b'For the purposes of calls later in the pseudocode I will refer to these subroutines as trailFollow findFood and findMidden'
b'All three are void and take no inputs'
b'The final common subroutine will be one for the identification of other ants'
b'When both sonar sensors are stimulated simultaneously Antie will check hydrocarbon inputs and determine whether the detected object is a nestmate'
b'As harvester ants tend not to engage aggressively with nonnestmates Antie will only identify other ants as ants if they belong to its nest'

b'Research has shown that red harvester ants may identify the tasks nestmates are engaged in based on the ratio of nalkenes to nalkanes in their hydrocarbons and the presence or absence of branched nalkanes'
b'Antie will attempt to determine the tasks of other ants by sensing only the nalkene levels'
b'The code will be similar to the object identification subroutine and may look something like this'
b'Using these basic common behaviors more complex behaviors may be coded'
b'Red harvester ants do not retain one task throughout their lifespan but instead change their behaviors as is appropriate for the colony Gordon 1996'

b'Research has shown that red harvester ants switch tasks partially as a function of age ex Ingram et al 2005 and partially as a function of interactions with other workers ex Schafer et al 2006 Gordon 2002 Greene  Gordon 2007'
b'Younger ants work more inside the nest and older ants work more outside the nest'
b'As a result I will model the three main behaviors in the order that they are to be engaged in'

b'Midden work which consists of moving dirt between the inside of the nest and the outside will occur first patrolling which involves a shorter overall amount of time spent outside will occur second and foraging will be the final behavior'
b'Finally I will discuss a main method encoding the task switching between these behaviors'
b'The midden work behavior will be Antie\xe2\x80\x99s default initial behavior'

b'It will be initiated in the morning by the sunrise and will continue until the outside temperature reaches 52\xc2\xad\xc2\xad\xc2\xadoC at which point all red harvester ants must return to the nest'
b'As previously stated a midden worker must identify midden grasp it and carry it to the surface depositing it halfway down the mound before returning to collect more midden'
b'A program encoding this behavior might look like this'
b'The second behavior patrolling involves two subbehaviors nest patrolling and trail patrolling'
b'Nest patrolling will involve leaving the nest roaming around on the nest mound for a few minutes and reentering the nest'
b'This behavior will be implemented in two parts with a taskswitching algorithm based on age'

b'Research shows that ants do change their behaviors based partly on their perceived life expectancy Moron et al 2007 and that taskswitching is partly genetically controlled by a switch in gene expression as the individual ages Ingram et al 2005'
b'It is therefore reasonable to assign a constant age at which Antie will switch from nest patrolling to trail patrolling'
b'In order to perform both of these functions Antie will need a subroutine to explore in a zigzag fashion as harvester ants do Gordon 34'
b'Harvester ants display a preference to wander in familiar territory though foragers and patrollers do sometimes wander into other nests\xe2\x80\x99 territories Gordon 5760'
b'To control for this behavior Antie\xe2\x80\x99s explore subroutine will display a preference for exploration in places where there is a low gradient of nestmate pheromones'
b'This model is reasonable because patrollers and foragers change their explored territory from day to day even though they do retain some more commonly chosen paths Gordon 45'
b'The code may look something like this'
b'Nest patrollers will only call this behavior for a short distance before returning to the nest to idle for a few minutes and exit again'
b'Trail patrollers will go much further until food sources are found and will then orient towards the nest and create trails for the foragers to follow'
b'A general site of food is all that the patroller need find the foragers will dig through the sand for the food'
b'Code for the patrolling behavior might look like this note that part is on a schema basis'

b'For the taskswitching in the patrolling behavior assume some variable \xe2\x80\x9cage\xe2\x80\x9d that Antie has been keeping track of using the CPU\xe2\x80\x99s clock pulses to track the time since its last bootup'
b'The integers nestpatrolage and trailpatrolage will represent the ages at which it is appropriate to switch to these tasks'
b'The final behavior foraging will involve one extra subroutine that will employ an algorithm designed by R'
b'Andrew Russell to localize an object through sand based on a chemical plume'
b'This will emulate the digging that foragers must often do in order to locate seeds and will enable Antie to accurately retrieve seeds for its host nest'
b'This algorithm will keep track of the last two intensities of the desired chemical input and compare them'
b'It would also keep track of whether the last rotation was clockwise or counterclockwise'
b'The code for this adapted from Russell\xe2\x80\x99s paper might look like this'
b'Foragers will follow trails marked by patrollers to their conclusion before collecting food to bring back to the nest even if more tantalizing food presents itself in their path Gordon 47'
b'To address this a strict subsumption hierarchy will make sure that the foragers do not stop to collect food too soon'
b'The code might look like this'
b'Of course what makes Antie an innovative robot is the taskswitching between these larger behaviors'
b'Because the midden work behavior is Antie\xe2\x80\x99s initial default behavior I will not address task switching to midden work'

b'Workers probably switch to patrolling based on their perceived life expectancy and as a function of a gene whose expression changes between young and old ants and this is easily emulated using a clock pulse counter in Antie\xe2\x80\x99s CPU that will count its \xe2\x80\x9cage\xe2\x80\x9d since last boot'
b'To remind the reader this technique was implemented earlier in this proposal to create the limited taskswitching between nest patrolling and trail patrolling'

b'The switch from patrolling to foraging has been modeled as a function of successful foragers\xe2\x80\x99 returns with great accuracy by Schafer et al 2006 and evidence from experiments in which successful foragers were removed before reentry to the nest does support the theory that returning successful foragers have an effect on the activation of new foragers Gordon 2002'
b'Activated foragers form a queue to exit the nest and exit at a steady rate'

b'According to Schafer\xe2\x80\x99s et al model of forager activation every time a successful forager returns and no foragers are currently in line to exit a fraction modeled at 00035 of inactive foragers joins the queue'

b'For the purposes of modeling Antie I will assume that the switches between these behaviors are permanent irreversible and partly a function of age with new foragers being activated by returning successful foragers'
b'The code to model this taskswitching might look something like this'
b'Conclusion'

b'Antie will be a fully autonomous situated and embodied agent infiltrating a red harvester ant colony and providing valuable information not only about the hypothesized rules of these ants\xe2\x80\x99 behaviors and their taskswitching thresholds but also about the combination of complex behaviors into a single autonomous system with the ability to switch between behaviors as necessary'

b'Biomimetic robots have long been a rich source of information for both biologists and robotics engineers and complex robots that can switch tasks as the situation demands and communicate information about current tasks could be useful for further studies of complex robot behaviors as well as for the obvious practical applications of robot swarms such as on the battlefield and standard building maintenance'
b'REFERENCES'
b'Indigenous Revitalization Movements of Latin America The Rediscovery of Language and Identity'
b'Humans in the process of defining themselves look to immediately recognizable factors in order to differentiate themselves from others'

b'This process leads to the development of what can be broadly termed culture a group of people joined by characteristics traits and beliefs comes to view themselves as sharing a distinct identity discernible from that of those \xe2\x80\x9coutside\xe2\x80\x9d them those who do not belong'
b'Naturally this can be signaled by any number of things  clothing food lifestyle choices'
b'One of the most dominant and easily noted factors is language'
b'The command of a language while not affording guaranteed access to the community which speaks it is often the key to gaining entry'
b'In turn communal identity can be formed around a language it is used as the focal point around which the group gathers'

b'Therefore when considering the indigenous revitalization movements which began in 20th century Latin America the impact of those indigenous languages on those movements and the nature of the identity of the peoples themselves is key'

b'Language plays a complex and integral role in the development and redefinition of an identity particularly when that identity has been oppressed and subsumed by a dominant other for as long as that of the indigenous peoples in Latin America has In particular I will examine two divergent yet remarkably parallel cases that of the Maya in Guatemala and the Nasa and Guambiano peoples of Colombia'

b'Their struggle to attain status in societies still bearing the marks of Spanish colonialism is deeply tied to their struggle to reaffirm the nature of their \xe2\x80\x9cindigenous identity\xe2\x80\x9d and is in turn linked to the interaction of Spanish and their native languages'
b'The effects of Spanish colonialism are both farreaching and deeply embedded in both countries'

b'One of the most prominent lasting influences is that of the land grant system Initially the Spanish government attempted to instate the encomienda system in which a conquistador maintained direct control over the indigenous peoples and their land'

b'This was in turn replaced by the repartimento the natives were allowed to maintain control over their land and their laws but remained in every way the inferior of the Spanish providing labor and taxes as demanded'

b'In reality land ownership rights were the exclusive right of the Spanish resulting in modernday malappropriation of land ownership in the hands of the descendants of the Spanish colonialists Warren 1978 78 Indigenous peoples are commonly sharecroppers or migrant workers'
b'The impoverished plight of the native populations was first recognized by the Marxist movements of the early 20th century'

b'Those were the first to articulate the necessity of affirming the independent identity of the indigenous populations previously both the left and right maintained a belief in indigenous assimilation into the dominant Spanish culture'

b'However they also claimed that they were part of a larger group the working class whose poverty was a direct result of American imperialism therefore they should join these new popular leftist movements in order to reorganize society into a workerfriendly one Jackson 1995 67'
b'In Colombia this resulted in a civil war between the Liberal and Communist parties and Conservative party'
b'A truce established between the Liberals and Conservatives failed to meet the demands of the Communists who in turn sustained guerrilla attacks in response'

b'Guerrilla warfare has since become a part of Colombian life multiple groups maintain an ongoing presence often stationing themselves in the remote mountainous villages often populated by various indigenous peoples'

b'This is similar to the situation of Guatemala the government felt it needed to battle communism an \xe2\x80\x9carmed and dangerous menace within\xe2\x80\x9d plunging the country into civil warfare in the 1960s and continuing through the 1980s Warren 1993 25'

b'This resulted in persecution against the Mayans who make up about 60 of the overall population In both counties guerrillas were often associated with the native peoples in many cases there were coalitions but in others the guerrillas merely used the remote inaccessible villages as hideouts'
b'In Guatemala over 450 villages were destroyed 200000 Mayans were killed and over 1 million more were displaced'
b'The main guerrilla force was demilitarized in 1996 with the establishment of a peace accord Warren 2002 157158'
b'The growth in popularity and militarism of these popular leftist movements is intertwined with the development of the indigenous revitalization movements'
b'By the 1970s the need to assert a cause separate from the general left was seen and indigenous rights movements formed Warren 2003 174 Jackson 2002 82'
b'Central to these was the question of indigenous identity'
b'largely lost amidst the overwhelming Spanish influence local leaders sought to rediscover their native roots and redefine what it meant to be a part of indigenous culture'
b'PanMayanism in particular has sought to organize itself around the Mayan language despite local dialectical differences it is seen as the unifying force behind the diverse Mayan people'
b'Most still speak it in various forms and efforts by Mayan linguists to standardize the language are producing a coherent modern version of Maya England 2003 733 739'

b'PanMayanism has succeeded in part due to its focus on issues of ethnicity it largely avoids specifically political overtones instead concentrating on the development of the reemerging Mayan culture England 2003 734'
b'The popular left however continues to see the rhetoric of ethnic rights as a politically viable tool'
b'It therefore often invokes the banner of indigenous rights in its own discourse '

b'The PanMayan movement thus benefits from the lasting influence of the popular left on Guatemalan governmental policies without risking drawing the often negative attention of the government England 2003 735 Warren 2003 181'

b'A main concern among panMayanists is the reversal of the longseated inferiority complex of the Mayan people despite their position as majority within the Guatemalan population they remain impoverished and marginalized on the fridge of society'
b'This results in part from the ingrained influences of Spanish colonialism Spanish continues to be associated with modernity and social mobility whereas Maya is seen as backward and inferior'
b'PanMayan leaders therefore seek to develop a return to Maya as it was in its classical renaissance a language of power and prestige England 2003 736'
b'By doing so they hope to inculcate among the Mayan peoples a renewed sense of pride which will in turn reverse the dogma of Spanish superiority'
b'Colombia in contrast has no unified panIndian sentiments the indigenous population is a small fraction of the overall population a fractured entity divided by region and language'

b'Several competing and oftentimes conflicting indigenous rights advocacy groups have developed the ONIC poses itself as the sole panIndian group yet lacks legitimacy in the eyes of many indigenous peoples Jackson 2002 83 85'
b'The CRIC which focuses on language development and renewal is primarily representative of the Nasa peoples Jackson 2003 82'
b'It often stands in conflict with the AICO its Guambiano counterpart Jackson 2003 8384'
b'Whereas the Mayanists benefit from a single main identity those of Colombia must operate under historical differences between the various ethnic groups Jackson 2002 109'
b'The Nasa and Guambiano have stood in opposition since precolonial times therefore any coalition between the two advocacy groups is tenuous at best Rappaport 2005 2'
b'This reflects a desire among the peoples themselves to maintain distinct ethnic identities both from the Spanish Colombian population and each other'

b'In the 1990s the rhetoric of cultural diversity was picked up the Colombian media and subsequently entered the consciousness of the greater metropolitan public thereby cementing its place in Colombian society as necessity and further complicating the role of indigenous movements in gaining rights for indigenous peoples as a whole'

b'A major success in the Colombian saga is the revamped constitution of 1991 which includes a section on indigenous rights as the Congress which drafted it included representatives from native groups Gow and Rappaport 2002 57'
b'Central is a return to the old land grant system stemming from the repartimentos of the colonial era along with judicial sovereignty'
b'While the repartimento was originally used to repress the indigenous groups it is now used to support them resguardos or communally owned plots of land are granted to communities'
b'They are ruled by the cabildo local governing boards formed of community leaders Gow and Rappaport 2002 5152'
b'The return to customary law reflects a substantial shift in indigenous identity'
b'no longer ruled by Western laws and discourse communities are forced to assess the efficacy of their old judicial systems in light of the modern era'

b'The oral nature of jurisprudence directly conflicts with the desire of the Colombian government to codify law and questions of human rights violations are common as punishments are often corporal in nature Gow and Rappaport 2002 5758'
b'The Colombian constitution stands in stark contrast to the failure of the Guatemalan indigenous rights referendum of 1999'

b'Mayans gained formal recognition in 1995 as the majority population in a precursor to the 1996 peace accord by 1999 its government floated a referendum on an indigenous bill of rights resembling that codified in the Colombian constitution Warren 2002 157158'
b'It failed despite the Mayan majority possible reasons include the overwhelming illiteracy rates among the indigenous population and inaccessibility of voting stations Warren 2002 149 151'

b'However it reflects on a greater level both the desire of many Mayans to assimilate as they still feel that is necessary for social mobility and a belief among the general population that Mayans do not require a separate bill of rights as they are covered under the general rights already in the constitution Warren 2002 159 172'
b'Illiteracy rates are in fact correlated with the Mayan language itself those who speak Spanish are more likely to be literate than those who speak Mayan alone England 2003 733'

b'Nonetheless in 2003 the legislature passed the law of national languages which while reaffirming Spanish as the official language recognizes the importance of indigenous languages as part of national identity and encourages their active promotion'
b'This question of identity as defined by language manifests differently in Guatemala and Colombia'

b'Within the panMayan movement there remains a desire to maintain linguistic diversity some view the reduction of their language to the status of dialect devalues their unique identity and place in the Mayan world however despite differences over standardization the panMayan movement itself is largely cohesive'
b'In contrast Colombian indigenous groups are divided to the extent that linguistic diversity is not only valued but serves to split the population both between groups and within groups themselves'

b'An example is the Tukanoans while considered a single \xe2\x80\x9cethnic group\xe2\x80\x9d they maintain 16 distinct language groups and practice linguistic exogamy in which members of one language group must marry into another Jackson 1995 4'
b'Language further works to establish identity by encapsulating a worldview markedly removed from that of the dominant Western culture'

b'Indigenous cosmology or \xe2\x80\x9ccosmovision\xe2\x80\x9d is difficult to translate into Romanticized languages it maintains a concept of culture defined as \xe2\x80\x9cthe form of behavior resulting from a permanent harmonic relationship with Nature\xe2\x80\x9d Gow and Rappaport 2002 58 and view of history as cyclic that is often at odds with Western modes of thought'

b'Conflict between cultures arise as cosmovision is rediscovered and developed often by native shamans in tandem with indigenous leaders aided by outside researchers and nongovernmental organizations'

b'The differences between Western and native perceptions then lead to conflict within the revitalization movements themselves the question of embracing Western law and discourse is continually grappled with'
b'It is necessary to work within the national legal system in order to gain policy reform beyond the local level however with widely differing concepts of justice a a balance is difficult to achieve'

b'Customary law in Colombia contrasts with Western law as it maintains a different perception of casual relationships tying back to the indigenous concept of harmony crimes are viewed as imbalances in the communitys harmony and can often be traced back to those who did not perpetuate the crime but may have influenced the accused to do so'
b'When a punishment  often public and corporal in nature  is carried out the group feels the effects as a whole'
b'Shamans often sit with the criminal as he fills his sentence sharing in their ordeal'

b'Rappaport 2005 Once punishments are completed the criminal is seen as rehabilitated having fulfilled his duty to restore harmonic order and is welcomed back into the community Gow and Rappaport 2002 61 Rappaport 2005 97'
b'Translation of law into native languages has proved to be a difficult task as Western ideas often have no parallel in indigenous cosmovision'

b'The translation of the Colombian constitution sparked the development of neologisms as the goal of the translators was not to provide a direct translation of the constitution but to recapture its spirit in a native rather than Western discourse Gow and Rappaport 2002 5859'

b'This provides a second interpretation of law distinct from that of the Spanish Colombian culture and in turn an interpretation aligned with native ideology for the cabildos to follow when governing Rappaport 2005 93 236'
b'Translation fulfills another vital role as it is employed in the rediscovery of the indigenous identity itself'

b'Workshops and advocacy groups regularly work to translate native histories back into native forms of knowledge distancing them from the Western influences that have invaded over the past six centuries'

b'The Guambiano history project charts native history as the outward spiraling events which are both cyclic and parallel in nature Mayan historians translate and document oral histories whose legacy is in danger of being forgotten Rappaport 2005 165'
b'This attempt to regain identity via translation is indicative of the intimate relationship between indigenous revitalization within a modern context and native language use'
b'Difficulties arise however as conflicts between the traditional and modern and native languages and Spanish develop'
b'Many native peoples in Colombia are monolingual Spanish speakers raising the question of the practicality of indigenous language use'
b'The differences between cosmovision in Spanish and indigenous languages are great leading to the difficulty of governing in Spanish yet embracing indigenous mode of thought'
b'In addition there exists a complex relationship between what are perceived as different levels of indigenous identity the Nasa for example divide themselves into the traditional modern and new'

b'The authenticity of the modern Nasa who are often metropolitan Spanish speakers attempting to reconnect with their roots is brought into question by the traditional who speak Nasa Yuwe and lead a rural existenceRappaport 2005'

b'In Guatemala the fact remains that Spanish is the gateway to social mobility years of conflict and refugee status have established the desire to leave a rural way of life for an updated urban one and those literate in Spanish have the tools to do so'

b'Illiteracy and poverty is associated with Maya thus there is the conflict between the desire to recapture the unique Mayan identity via the language and the need to improve living conditions which most often occurs under Spanish influence'
b'A further complication is the necessity of establishing authentic \xe2\x80\x9cIndianness\xe2\x80\x9d both in the eyes of fellow indigenous peoples and the outside Spanish culture'

b'The ONIC of Colombia lacks legitimacy precisely because it is perceived as not \xe2\x80\x9cIndian enough\xe2\x80\x9d it embraces the use of Spanish and Western discourse leading to distrust among indigenous peoples Jackson 2002 85'

b'Politicians make a point of appearing in their native dress and speaking in their native language in assembly even if they are more at home in a business suit and speaking Spanish indigenous identity has become a calling card to the extent that at times it appears to be a caricature of itself'

b'The Colombian constitution is problematic in that it provides little guide as to what exactly forms an indigenous group the concept of culture is so complex and divergent that establishing selfdetermination in the eyes of the Colombian government requires emphasizing differences'
b'Efforts towards development then cannot endanger traditional culture and values for fear of losing cultural legitimacy Jackson 1995 5'
b'There develops a duality in native culture for example many Nasa children receive instruction in Nasa Yuwe yet converse in Spanish outside the classroom'

b'An emphasis on preserving rather than practicing native culture arises indigenous authenticity is maintained by sustaining knowledge of traditional practices and beliefs without fully embracing them on a daytoday basis Gow and Rappaport 2002 6667'
b'This intersection of language and indigenous identity poses challenges which have yet to be fully addressed'

b'In Guatemala they are largely comprised of the conflict between poverty and progress the panMayan movement must meet the dual trials of establishing a positive identity within the Mayan population itself and legitimacy in the legal and political arenas in order to gain policy reforms and codified rights in law'

b'In Colombia legal successes have often come about due to the Colombian governments recognition of the political viability of the rhetoric of indigenous rights by granting indigenous peoples judicial sovereignty they hope to win the trust of a people who view the government as incapable of protecting them from the ongoing civil strife and by giving them blocks of land they hope that the indigenous community will be able to keep out drug traffickers and guerrillas where the government itself has not Jackson 1995 8'

b'Regardless of the ulterior motives behind their legal status indigenous peoples in Colombia now possess the rights to teach and govern in their own languages according to their own laws Jackson 1995 5'
b'Conflicts arise due to internal differences and the everpersist problem of defining indigenous identity and authenticity in a pluralistic linguistic environment'
b'Works Cited'
b'Tonal Structure and Form in Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s Concerto for Orchestra I'
b'Before beginning an analysis of any piece by B\xc3\xa9la Bart\xc3\xb3k one must first decide to what degree tonal analysis will be used'
b'Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s music although it is often difficult to call completely tonal never entirely sheds itself of tonal elements and structure'
b'This remains true even with one of his last compositions the Concerto for Orchestra written two years before his death in 1943'
b'The discussion that follows analyzes the first movement of the Concerto focusing on the tonal structures at play throughout the movement'

b'We will also examine to what degree a \xe2\x80\x9ctonal\xe2\x80\x9d reading of this movement is limited in its analytical potential in an attempt to pinpoint exactly where Bart\xc3\xb3k strays from commonpractice compositional techniques'
b'Harmonic Structure and Form'
b'Bart\xc3\xb3k describes the form of the first movement as \xe2\x80\x9cmore or less regular sonata form\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'While that does not seem to be a meaningful assertion it is perfectly accurate the movement is in sonata form but there is an introduction that does not relate thematically to any other parts of the movement not unheard of in Mozart sonatas and the recapitulation presents the two themes of the exposition in reverse order'
b'The \xe2\x80\x9cbackwards\xe2\x80\x9d recapitulation is a technique that Bart\xc3\xb3k employs frequently because of the formal symmetry it creates'
b'For example the fifth string quartet'
b'Also see Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s comments on that Bart\xc3\xb3k 414'
b'Example 1 shows a diagram of the form of the movement the symmetry is apparent within the seven sections following the introduction'

b'As the example shows the development section is divided into three subsections the first and third subsections draw their thematic material from the first theme group and the second subsection involves new material not drawn from the exposition'
b'Hence on either side of the middle section of the development we have the alternation FTGSTGFTG which makes the overall form with the exception of the Introduction symmetric'
b'Paul Wilson also discusses the inherent symmetry of the movement although his interpretation is somewhat different'
b'See Wilson 168170'
b'The abbreviations FTG and STG stand for First Theme Group and Second Theme Group respectively'
b'Sonata form\xe2\x80\x94or \xe2\x80\x9cmoreorless\xe2\x80\x9d sonata form\xe2\x80\x94carries harmonic as well as formal connotations'

b'While \xe2\x80\x9ctonality\xe2\x80\x9d in this piece and in Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s music in general is quite different from its classical interpretation we find that the harmonic structure is at least analogous to the standard sonataform structure'
b'To begin with the movement is in F'

b'When we say \xe2\x80\x9cin F\xe2\x80\x9d we do not imply F major or minor for that matter\xe2\x80\x94the majorminor tonal system in general does not apply to this piece\xe2\x80\x94but rather that the pitchclass F is the tonal center of the movement and acts analogously to the tonic in a Mozartian sonata movement'
b'Using this interpretation we can map out the local tonics tonal centers used throughout the movement as shown in Example 2'

b'In this example the barlines divide the formal sections of the piece Introduction\xe2\x80\x93Exposition\xe2\x80\x93Development\xc2\xad\xe2\x80\x93Recapitulation\xe2\x80\x94so we can immediately see that the tonic F is not established until the exposition begins'

b'Beginning with the exposition the largescale progression of tonal centers is a wholetone descent from F to F represented by the stemmed notes in Example 2 while the Introduction ascends from C\xe2\x99\xaf to F through D\xe2\x99\xaf shown as D\xe2\x99\xad and E\xe2\x99\xad in the graph in a quasibass Anstieg'

b'The middle pitch of the descent B acts as the \xe2\x80\x9cdominant\xe2\x80\x9d to F based on its symmetrical division of the wholetone scale and the fact that the second theme appears in B in the exposition'
b'Bart\xc3\xb3k has often applied a tonicdominant relationship to a pitchclass and its tritone partner and even admits to using that as a compositional framework in his fifth string quartet'
b'See Bart\xc3\xb3k 414415'

b'In this particular movement Bart\xc3\xb3k feigns moving to the tonal dominant C for the second theme before reinterpreting C as a chromatic passing tone between D\xe2\x99\xad and B\xe2\x80\x94this and other subtleties shown in Example 2 will be explained in detail in later sections'
b'Our analysis will focus instead on relating the foreground activity to the overarching background structure'

b'The graph in Example 2 will serve as a point of departure for the subsequent analysis while we will periodically refer back to some of its specific elements it should be understood that even when not explicitly referenced this graph serves as the explanatory goal of this paper'
b'The Introduction'
b'As Paul Wilson points out the title \xe2\x80\x9cIntroduzione\xe2\x80\x9d given to the movement as a whole seems to apply only to the first 75 measures'

b'The Introduction does not relate thematically to any of the main sections of the movement\xe2\x80\x94in fact it is the third movement that draws its thematic material from this section\xe2\x80\x94but the harmonic and motivic principles at play here foreshadow some important elements of the entire piece'
b'To begin with the opening motive in the celli and basses shown in Example 3 outlines a pentatonic set and strongly presents C\xe2\x99\xaf as the tonal center'
b'The pentatonic set here is exclusively a pitchclass set and its incarnations throughout the movement are devoid of any connotations associated with the pentatonic scale'
b'Indeed this set can be seen more as a byproduct of stacked perfect fourths than a generative element itself'
b'The perfect fourth in fact generates much of the motivic and harmonic material of the entire movement and its importance is immediately evident in the Introduction with the opening bass motive'

b'Furthermore the following two instances of this opening motive shown in Examples 4 and 5 remove any doubt as to the motivic importance of the perfect fourth and in turn diminish the importance of the pentatonic set'
b'Example 4 transitions from C\xe2\x99\xaf to F\xe2\x99\xaf and adds pitchclass E to the pentatonic set of Example 3 creating a sixnote set of stacked fourths'
b'Example 5 shows the true dominance of the perfect fourth the set created is a tennote set derived by stacking fourths'
b'If we begin from the final D\xe2\x99\xaf and ascend the circle of fourths until we reach C we obtain the entire set presented in this example'
b'Each note is either approached or left or both by a fourth and the structural motion is from F\xe2\x99\xaf to D\xe2\x99\xaf'

b'The overall motion in the first 29 measures is C\xe2\x99\xaf to D\xe2\x99\xaf through F\xe2\x99\xaf these are represented enharmonically in Example 2 as D\xe2\x99\xad E\xe2\x99\xad and G\xe2\x99\xad'
b'As previously mentioned this motion constitutes the initial ascent to what will eventually be a wholetone descent from F to F'
b'So the prevailing structural motion of the movement as a whole is a descending whole step and the prevailing melodic motion is a usually ascending perfect fourth'

b'We can connect the two by noting that the descending whole step consists of two ascending fourths indeed the structural wholetone descent is often \xe2\x80\x9cfilled in\xe2\x80\x9d with the intervening fourth'
b'This motion is exemplified in Example 2 in the second theme group mm'
b'155233 and as we will see it occurs in other places though not relevant enough to the background structure to be represented in Example 2'

b'Each time the motion in Examples 3 through 5 breaks from chains of fourths the same sequence of intervals occurs two descending perfect fourths separated by an ascending major second 5 2 5 each instance of this intervallic cell is bracketed in the examples'
b'This sequence of intervals is the inversion of those found in the second head motive of the first theme of the exposition shown in measures 23 of Example 8'

b'So although there is no thematic relation between the Introduction and the main sections of the movement within the first 29 measures we can already see structural harmonic and motivic elements that apply to the movement as a whole'
b'The section from measures 3550 is centered on E upon the return of D\xe2\x99\xaf enharmonically respelled as E\xe2\x99\xad in measure 58 we see that E acts as its upperneighbor'

b'This relationship is somewhat obscured by measures 5157 however while there is no clear tonal center for this section G appears in the outer voices in measure 51 although the harmonic material is reminiscent of C minor'
b'The concluding motive of this section in the violins the bracketed sections of Example 6 as well as the bass motive of measure 58ff'
b'Example 7 are related to the first head motive of the first theme which is shown in the first measure of Example 8'
b'All three of these motives span a tritone which as mentioned is the \xe2\x80\x9cdominant\xe2\x80\x9d relationship in this movement'
b'Paul Wilson describes the transition from the Introduction to the Exposition as \xe2\x80\x9cquite abrupt and seemingly unmotivated\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Wilson 173'
b'but it is in fact this motivic relationship that ties them together and creates a rather smooth transition'
b'The Exposition'
b'Although the motivic relationship between the Introduction and the first theme of the exposition smooth the transition nearly every other element changes when the first theme appears'
b'The drastic tempo and meter changes as well as the first appearances of staccato articulations make it clear to the listener that the introduction is over'

b'As mentioned the first theme the beginning of which is reproduced in Example 8 contains two head motives the first is the tritonespanning ascent that appears in the first measure and the second is an iteration of the interval cell 5 2 5 that appears in the second through third measures'
b'While the presence of the perfect fourths that was so prevalent in the Introduction is clear in the latter the former does not employ the perfect fourth in its formation'
b'Rather this motive is a smallscale representation of the tonicdominant relationship of tritone partners specifically F and B that is the basis for the harmonic structure of this movement'
b'Rhythmically we have a dissonance between the melody which follows the written meter and the accompanying chords in the bassoons horns and lower strings'
b'Example 9 reproduces the chords and Example 10 rewrites them in a meter that is more consistent with their rhythmic pattern'
b'As Example 10 shows the chords are moreorless in duple meter 48 and 28 with one \xe2\x80\x9chiccup\xe2\x80\x9d occurring in the 58 measure'
b'This is in strict metric dissonance with the triple meter of the melody with its own \xe2\x80\x9chiccups\xe2\x80\x9d occurring in the written 28 measures'
b'As we will later see this dissonance disappears when this theme returns in the recapitulation'

b'We have already mentioned that the first theme group is in F\xe2\x80\x94this is made clear from the onset both in the melodic line and by the F minor triad that occurs on the downbeat of measure 77'
b'While the material occasionally departs from this F in measures 7694 these departures are all subordinate to the prolonged F'
b'E\xe2\x99\xad is the tonal center for measures 95134 although it does not appear as a strong bass note until measure 131'
b'Measures 95130 contain a mostly chromatic descent from C to E\xe2\x99\xad where E\xe2\x99\xad is anticipated throughout as a goal tone for the bass'
b'Example 11 illustrates this structure'
b'Immediately following the arrival of E\xe2\x99\xad in the bass C\xe2\x99\xaf D\xe2\x99\xad is established as the tonal center for the final transition to the second theme'
b'The trombone motive in measures 134141 shown in Example 12 is the subject of the fugato section in part 3 of the development although its importance is downplayed here'
b'Note that the initial G\xe2\x99\xaf is a pickup to the section in C\xe2\x99\xaf which fills in the wholetone descent from E\xe2\x99\xad to C\xe2\x99\xaf with the intervening fourth'

b'This motive also contains the intervallic cell of the second head motive of the first theme in the form of G\xe2\x99\xafC\xe2\x99\xafBE with the addition of some passing tones in addition to consisting largely of motion by perfect fourths'
b'Wilson claims that C and E\xe2\x99\xad are \xe2\x80\x9clocal dominants\xe2\x80\x9d to F in this first section of the exposition'
b'While the strong VI motion from measures 9091 does carry a tonal implication of dominanttonic such cadential bass motion does not imply anything about structural function in this context'
b'E\xe2\x99\xad furthermore is not convincingly established as a dominantfunctioning tone at all'

b'The passage from measures 8589 is centered on E\xe2\x99\xad and the pentatonic set from the opening of the exposition is transposed down a whole step but its mere presence as local tonic does not signify any sort of dominant function'

b'Rather we can consider this occurrence of E\xe2\x99\xad as a middlegroundlevel wholetone descent that foreshadows the structural descent to E\xe2\x99\xad at measure 131 that is represented in Example 2'
b'In measures 9195 the bass descends FE\xe2\x99\xadD\xe2\x99\xadC which might seem to support C\xe2\x80\x99s functioning as structural dominant'
b'However as previously mentioned C acts as a \xe2\x80\x9cfake\xe2\x80\x9d dominant that in measures 149155 actually functions as an upper neighbor to B the \xe2\x80\x9ctrue\xe2\x80\x9d dominant'
b'The descent in measures 9195 in fact participates in the farce by projecting a descent ending on C which makes the eventual reinterpretation of C and descent to B stronger'
b'This creates both a smooth transition to the second theme and a strong sense that a new section is beginning a combination that is generally rather difficult to forge'
b'The second theme is tranquil and harmonically simple which is in stark contrast to the first theme'
b'B dominates as tonal center from measures 155191 with little or no harmonic motion away from it'
b'Measures 192197 are in E\xe2\x99\xad with the bass notes in the harp and measures 198209 are in D\xe2\x99\xad'
b'A\xe2\x99\xad intervenes between E\xe2\x99\xad and D\xe2\x99\xad in measure 195\xe2\x80\x94another instance of the wholetone being \xe2\x80\x9cfilled in\xe2\x80\x9d by a fourth'
b'The return to B in measure 210 is also filledin in this way by F\xe2\x99\xaf in measures 208209'

b'Hence measures 155210 constitute the bass progression BE\xe2\x99\xadD\xe2\x99\xadB the same stepwise descent E\xe2\x99\xadD\xe2\x99\xad occurred in the first theme group while F rather than B was being prolonged'
b'Paul Wilson points out that \xe2\x80\x9cin substituting for F within an analogous structure B receives confirmation at this point as the crucial interior center of the movement\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cin substituting for F within an analogous structure B receives confirmation at this point as the crucial interior center of the movement\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'In our terminology this is the point at which B is unequivocally established as the structural dominant'
b'The Development'
b'As mentioned the development is divided into three subsections'

b'In Example 2 the entire development section is represented by exactly three pitches and indeed each subsection is associated with one of these three pitches as its tonal center\xe2\x80\x94none of these pitches is involved in the structural wholetone descent'

b'As Paul Wilson states the development \xe2\x80\x9cis for Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s music developmental in a relatively conventional way\xe2\x80\x9d the themes from the exposition are expanded and modified and tonalities other than those expected arise'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cis for Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s music developmental in a relatively conventional way\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The only slight abnormality though it is certainly not unheard of even in classicalperiod sonata movements is the emergence of a new theme in the second section of the development'
b'Although Wilson claims that this theme is based on \xe2\x80\x9ca transformation in rhythm and contour of the second headmotive of the firsttheme\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9ca transformation in rhythm and contour of the second headmotive of the firsttheme\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Wilson 182'
b'there is no intervallic relationship between the two motives and it is not clear what elements of a motive remain when rhythm contour and interval content are changed'
b'Furthermore this section being the middle section of the movement upholds the formal symmetry if interpreted as its own theme'
b'The first section of the development measures 231271 begins with a big Dminor chord which immediately establishes D as the tonal center for the section'
b'Although it moves to E\xe2\x99\xad minor in measure 239 it returns to D minor in measure 248 which suggests that E\xe2\x99\xad is an upper neighbor prolonging D'
b'The passage beginning at measure 248 shown in Example 13 can be considered to be the \xe2\x80\x9ctheme\xe2\x80\x9d of this section and is a development of the second head motive of the first theme'
b'This motive undergoes inversion and extension throughout the section'

b'While Wilson rightly identifies the resultant set of measures 261264 as 6Z50 014679 identifying it as such does not offer much analytical insight until we point out that this is a simple extension of the intervallic sequence 5 2 5 from the original motive'
b'The second section of the development is in C\xe2\x99\xaf which is sometimes spelled D\xe2\x99\xad'
b'This section is reproduced as Example 14'
b'This section returns to the calm simplicity and tempo of the second section though apart from affect there are no references to that section'

b'Although the C\xe2\x99\xaf major chord in measure 293 preceded by A\xe2\x99\xad major V in measure 285 suggests C\xe2\x99\xaf as tonal center the tonality is not strongly established until measure 303'

b'The arrival at C\xe2\x99\xaf was foreshadowed by the first two measures of the development Example 15 which are almost a direct transposition of the two head motives of the first theme to C\xe2\x99\xaf'
b'Because of its emphasis here in the development section and its position as leading to B in the second theme group we could conceive of C as a subdominant in this movement'

b'As tempting as this interpretation may be this observation is relegated to the notes section because it constitutes a horrible abuse of terminology\xe2\x80\x94there is only so far that such tonal analogies can go before they begin to hide any true analytical insight behind misused terms'

b'The third section of the development takes the trombone motive from the transition between the first and second sections of the exposition shown in Example 12 transposed to begin on F and turns it into a fugato sequence reproduced in Example 17'
b'The tonal center B\xe2\x99\xad is established immediately in measures 316318 by the strong VI chord progression Example 16'
b'As previously mentioned the fugato motive incorporates the motion by perfect fourths found in the Introduction as well as the intervallic cell found in the second head motive of the first theme'
b'The resultant set is the pentatonic set FB\xe2\x99\xadE\xe2\x99\xadA\xe2\x99\xadD\xe2\x99\xad the entire passage shown in Example 17 remains within this set'

b'The second and fourth entrances of the fugato subject are transposed up a perfect fifth but the first note is B\xe2\x99\xad rather than C which allows Bart\xc3\xb3k to remain in this pentatonic set and also to reinforce B\xe2\x99\xad as tonal center'
b'The second instance of the fugato section not reproduced in its entirety but based on the subject in Example 18 is an exact pitch inversion transposed to begin on C'
b'The inversion blends seamlessly back into the original subject in measure 363'

b'The following section measures 363389 especially brings out the quartal harmonies within the pentatonic set so much so that B\xe2\x99\xad is obscured as tonal center which allows A\xe2\x99\xad to emerge as the goal tone of this section\xe2\x80\x94only to be immediately reinterpreted as a leading tone to the A that begins the recapitulation'

b'Both B\xe2\x99\xad and A\xe2\x99\xad are chromatic neighbors to A which intensifies the arrival on A and brings out the fact that the appearance of A continues the largescale wholetone descent that has been left stranded on B for the entire development section'
b'The Recapitulation'
b'The recapitulation as we have seen presents the themes in reverse order'
b'The second theme is initially presented in A as part of the wholetone descent and proceeds directly to G where it is restated slightly modified'
b'It is worth pointing out that the arrival on G at measure 425 is led into by D which constitutes another \xe2\x80\x9cfilling in\xe2\x80\x9d of the wholestep by the intervening fourth'
b'The A\xe2\x99\xaf in measure 438 might initially seem to be a new tonal area but it leads to D in measure 444 which constitutes a V chord still applied to G'
b'Rather than resolve this D back to G however Bart\xc3\xb3k shifts briefly to F\xe2\x99\xaf in measure 456 and leads to E in measure 467'

b'E and F\xe2\x99\xaf are both active throughout the entire transition from second theme back to first theme measures 456487 which brings out their functions as upper and lower chromatic neighbors to F which returns triumphantly in measure 488 with the muchanticipated recapitulation of the first theme'
b'The return of the first theme is certainly immediately recognized as such however there are some important differences'
b'Firstly its initial appearance in the exposition had a minor flare to it the first chord in Example 9 is an Fminor triad and the first four notes of Example 8 ascend the Fminor scale'
b'In the recapitulation of this theme shown in Example 19 the first chord is an Fmajor chord and the A\xe2\x99\xad is replaced by A\xe2\x99\xae in the melody'

b'In fact the chord progression of the first four measures of Example 19 can be thought of tonally as IviV in F major\xe2\x80\x94while we are reluctant to say that this passage is in major the conspicuous A\xe2\x99\xad in measure 490 easily brings doubt to this interpretation we can certainly say that the minor flare of the beginning has been replaced by a major flare here in the recapitulation'

b'In addition to the \xe2\x80\x9cmode\xe2\x80\x9dshift we notice that the metric dissonance shown in Examples 9 and 10 no longer appears notice how regular the rhythm of the accompanying figure is in Example 19 and also that the written meter no longer changes'

b'In other words the piece in becoming more regular is beginning to drive towards the finish\xe2\x80\x94because of the formal structure the recapitulation of the first theme also serves as the closing section of the movement'
b'Indeed this section has the feel of a Coda to it\xe2\x80\x94it is much shorter than any other major section or subsection and the tonic harmony is active throughout'

b'There are also no phrase divisions\xe2\x80\x94the music simply drives forward with no pause until measure 514 where the fugato motive appears in the brass over an obvious VI cadence signaling the end of the movement which occurs as the motive completes'
b'There is no fine line between music that is \xe2\x80\x9ctonal\xe2\x80\x9d and music that is \xe2\x80\x9catonal\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Bart\xc3\xb3k is one of the many earlytwentieth century composers whose music fits entirely in the gray area between tonality and atonality'

b'While we know from his writings that he often composed with a tonal centers and relationships in mind and that he regularly applied tonal structures and forms to his compositions by merely glancing at any one of his pieces we can see that tonality as it is understood in the common practice period is not at work'

b'Thanks largely to the work of tonal theorists such as Heinrich Schenker and others we have a detailed system for analyzing tonal music\xe2\x80\x94their system however is virtually useless in analyzing music that falls entirely on the atonal side of the spectrum'
b'But if we apply it to music such as Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s that is in the middle area we can come up with some enlightening and perhaps unexpected results'
b'To do so was the goal of this analysis of the first movement of the Concerto for Orchestra'

b'By applying our tonal system to music that slips outside of the tonal realm we not only find the elements of tonality that do remain but we also pinpoint exactly when and how this music breaks from previous conventions'
b'It is not disputed that Bart\xc3\xb3k\xe2\x80\x99s music has great expressive power\xe2\x80\x94perhaps now we can understand why'
