b' \xe2\x80\x9cWhite expresses a certain incorporeality'
b'The use of white is therefore decisive for the bodily appearance of a space'
b'Concrete bodies decrease the space more or less depending on their color value'
b'Against white one can actually establish the intensity of clashing colors white determines the tone in the first place'
b'Because of this it is possible to take up any given colors and make them harmonize'
b' For this reason white walls are favored over colored ones for both galleries and architectural spaces'
b'The white of the walls intensifies the color of what is set before them'
b'It stabilizes and controls forms because it brings to light the contours of the space'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn the white painted room the clarity of spatial sensation and disposition was surest and most convincing all the details of the form and color of the furnishings could be developed undisturbed in front of this background\xe2\x80\xa6In this a form was discovered which was completely convincing in its simplicity and which could be seen as one of the essential formulas for wall treatment in \xe2\x80\x9cclosed\xe2\x80\x9d spaces\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'In the 19th century it became fashionable for bourgeois women to dress in white while men dressed in black Wigley'
b'These distinctions proved a certain rational order only attained by those able to afford of it'
b'White walls white clothing they both require much more maintenance than something colored where a stain can merely hide away among the other colors'
b'Crisp whiteness on the other hand expresses a sort of luxury and leisure'

b'White clothing proved that someone was of a level of society in which they were not forced to work for the clothing would immediately become soiled if not and thus the reason why women who were the ones to stay at home dressed in all white while men who were the ones to go out and work wore black for black did in fact hide stains '

b'The same goes with white walls in their impeccability it proved to whoever that the owner could afford to not live actually live in this space or could afford more simply for the upkeep and constant fresh coats of paint'
b'Both as well were signs of the modern age man had reached'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cPure white was de rigueur partly because of its exciting novelty partly because it emphasized the smoothly mechanical texture and pointed the contrast between it and surrounding nature\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The use of white was proof that man had conquered nature'
b' The use of white and black in dress and architecture also became a way of distinguishing oneself from the vulgar normal lower classes'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cit is also worthy of remark that savage nations uneducated people and children have a great predilection for vivid colors that animals are excited to rage by certain colors that people of refinement avoid vivid colors in their dress and the objects that are about them and seem inclined to banish them altogether from their presence'
b'Furthermore with the advent of industrialization the invention of new synthetic dyes meant that color in dress became democratized for all classes'
b'Now anyone could afford to wear colorful clothing and the masses began to dress themselves in what once would have been inconceivable to them'
b'Thus said the use of black in white in wardrobe perhaps was a way for the new bourgeoisie to distinguish themselves from the decadence of the upper class and the vulgarity from the low'

b' \xe2\x80\x9cIn the prevailing styles of the European bourgeoisie there long survived a tendency to limit the use of color with strong emphasis on what are generally thought of as non colors such as white black and gray\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Another reason why it is believed that the bourgeoisie took preference in black and white is because of the Victorian sobriety of the age and their obsession with purity and cleanliness'
b'Wearing black and white also marked the distinction of labor between men and women and in a highly rigid and segmented society the wearing of different colors seemed the most obvious way to do so'
b'This simplicity of dress was seen as a mark of the modern man'
b'Other major technologies during the age of industrialization also had an effect on this preference for black and white'

b'Photography took over as a means of portraiture for the bourgeois and the upper class and despite the fact that it was possible to color the photographs for the most part they were left in black and white because it was seen as more \xe2\x80\x9cnatural\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Above all it is believed that the expanse of literacy and the printed word mainly the newspaper had a profound effect in influencing the choice of black and white'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis world was viewed as orderly and relatively uniform a world in \xe2\x80\x9cblack and white\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'This led to the idea of writing  rationality  production that confined images especially images in color to the emerging field of \xe2\x80\x9cart\xe2\x80\x9d which was understood as an essential activity but one that was essentially unproductive while it assigned to the twotoned and orderly world of printed paper the role of a daily guide to existence\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Black and white became a symbol for the superiority of man\xe2\x80\x99s intellect and technology'

b'This then translated down into the world of fashion as seen with the distinction between black and white clothing as well as art namely photography but also film and as discussed before architecture and gallery space '
b'Seeing as since the time of Aristotle form was valued over that of color the arts which did not require color to be enjoyed were perceived to be that of a higher form'
b'The explosion of mass production and printing allowed for a plethora of colorful advertising and consumer goods which came to be known as kitsch'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cKitsch is a product of the industrial revolution which urbanized the masses of Western Europe and America and established what is called universal literacy\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'In order to meet the demand of mass markets cheap and bright things of little use were made to attract the attention of consumers'
b'Kitsch made cheap what once was truly cultural by the way it reproduced it d infinitum'
b'Greenberg continues by saying \xe2\x80\x9cKitsch using for raw material the debased and academicized simulacra of genuine culture welcomes and cultivates this insensibility'
b'It is the source of its profits Kitsch is mechanical and operates by formulas'
b'Kitsch is vicarious experience and faked sensations'
b'Kitsch changes according to style but remains always the same'
b'Kitsch is the epitome of all that is spurious in the life of our times'
b'Kitsch pretends to demand nothing of its customers except their money  not even their time\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'With the advent of kitsch came a great need for the distinction between higher and lower artforms'
b'Avant guard at the time was considered to be true art while this kitsch was simply pure imitation'

b'Thus said this along with the influence of black and white print perhaps was the cause for the belief that which was black and white was deemed a serious high art while that which was colorful was mere rubbish and imitation for the lower classes'

b'Of course during the early stages of color film and photography the quality was so poor that it gave a cheap look whereas black and white film really allowed one to see the light and the shadows in the images'
b'For the play of light and form was key in demonstrating the true art form'
b'That was what made up the essence of an image not the artificial or superficial filling in of form with color'
b' Color was thought to distract the viewer from the soul of the image '
b'These beliefs have changed since color technology as tweeked to the point of being almost better than reality'
b'Still though black and white is seen as something of a more sober tradition'
b'Photographers still use black and white and white is still the most widely used color for walls within gallery spaces'
b'These non colors allow for the appreciation of color'
b'When something is black and white it allows the mind to fill in and imagine for itself the amazing colors that must exist beyond the screen'
b' Many actually complained with the invention of color in movies that this stunted the mind since one was forced to look at the garish colors placed before them'
b'It is for this reason that ultimately the use of black and white is seen as more of an intellectual process'
b'Whether it mean going beyond the mind or simply the purity of non color the use of black and white has been debated over for the last hundred years'

b'Now we have entered an era where we are seeing once again more color but perhaps it is human instinct to want to surpass and rebel against generations before so possibly we shall return to a state of non color veneration'
b'Thus is the ebb and flow of life '
b'The debate over homosexuality has been one of the most longlasting and controversial ones ever'
b'What exactly causes homosexuality'
b'Some would say it is a gene passed on from parents to child'
b'Others would argue that it is a result of a child\xe2\x80\x99s upbringing'
b'Still more would claim that it is a mental illness that can and should be cured'
b'Perhaps then it is a combination of some of these'
b'No one knows for sure and it is possible no one ever will but that surely does not stop everyone from coming up with their own theories and beliefs on the matter'
b'Documented homosexuality dates as far back as ancient Greece and other cultures of the time where it was considered to be a very normal and natural occurrence Emond'

b'In his book The Symposium Plato wrote \xe2\x80\x9cThose who are halves of a man whole pursue males and being slices so to speak of the male love men throughout their boyhood and take pleasure in physical contact with men\xe2\x80\x9d qtd in Isay 11'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cThose who are halves of a man whole pursue males and being slices so to speak of the male love men throughout their boyhood and take pleasure in physical contact with men\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'This shows that not only did Plato consider it normal for a male to be attracted to another male he also believed that it began at a very young age as the word \xe2\x80\x9cboyhood\xe2\x80\x9d signifies'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cboyhood\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'In fact Plato even considered love between two members of the same sex to be the only \xe2\x80\x9creal and lasting love\xe2\x80\x9d and necessary for democracy'
b'\xe2\x80\x9creal and lasting love\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Furthermore there were many occurrences of homosexual behavior in Greek mythology Hercules is rumored to have had 14 male lovers and Zeus himself partook in such behavior'
b'Even Homer wrote about Achilles and Patroclus who have been considered to be the perfect model of true love Emond'

b'But it was not until 1869 that the term \xe2\x80\x9chomosexual\xe2\x80\x9d was first used to describe \xe2\x80\x9ca man or woman whose feelings of sexual attraction are for someone of the same sex\xe2\x80\x9d Marcus 1'
b'\xe2\x80\x9chomosexual\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9ca man or woman whose feelings of sexual attraction are for someone of the same sex\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'However for the purposes of this paper homosexuality will be looked at solely in terms of men'
b'At this point in time Karl Maria Kertbeny used the word in a pamphlet which fought to repeal the current antihomosexual laws of Prussia'

b'Kertbeny derived this word from the Greek word for \xe2\x80\x9csame\xe2\x80\x9d and the Latin word for \xe2\x80\x9csex\xe2\x80\x9d whereas a heterosexual is a person\xe2\x80\x9d whose feelings of sexual attraction are for the opposite sex\xe2\x80\x9d Marcus 1'
b'\xe2\x80\x9csame\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9csex\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9d whose feelings of sexual attraction are for the opposite sex\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'It was also in the 1800s when the debate itself over the cause of homosexuality was started by Magnus Hirschfeld a physician sex researcher leading sexologist homosexual and founder of the first gay rights movement in Germany who believed that homosexuality was biological in nature Marcus 10'
b'Hirschfeld also founded the Scientific Humanitarian committee which was mostly homosexual in 1897'
b'The committee published many books and other forms of literature which gave Hirschfeld a great amount of prestige in his field'

b'He became known as one of the founding fathers of sexology and furthered this position when he opened the world\xe2\x80\x99s first sexological institute the institute for Sexual Science in Berlin in 1919 which was destroyed by the Nazis 15 years later'

b'Hirschfeld largely supported the Urning theory of Karl Ulrichs with minor additions he believed in some hormonal theories as a cause of homosexuality but this only led to unsuccessful attempts to \xe2\x80\x9ccure\xe2\x80\x9d homosexuals with the use of hormone injections'
b'This theory which defined Urnings as males who turned to other males as sexual partners was published in twelve pamphlets by Ulrichs starting in1864'
b'The first Vindex defended Urnings while the second Inclusa which followed shortly after described the first scientific theory of homoerotic desire'

b'Ulrichs believed that Urnings were attracted to other males because they were \xe2\x80\x9chermaphrodites of the mind\xe2\x80\x9d meaning while they may have been male in body they were female in soul and mind leading them to be naturally attracted to males in terms of sexual partners'
b'\xe2\x80\x9chermaphrodites of the mind\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'This he claimed made laws such as paragraph 175 a law adopted by King William I throughout the German Kingdoms at the time of their unification which forbade sex between males and forced criminal penalties upon individuals partaking in such behavior unfair and unreasonable '
b'Ulrichs claimed that the origin of such a disposition was natural and inborn Wikholm'
b'A couple thousand years after Plato and Homer Sigmund Freud still believed homosexuality to be a natural behavior'
b'In an interview in 1903 he professed his beliefs \xe2\x80\x9cI am\xe2\x80\xa6 of the firm conviction that homosexuals must not be treated as sick people\xe2\x80\xa6 Homosexual persons are not sick'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am\xe2\x80\xa6 of the firm conviction that homosexuals must not be treated as sick people\xe2\x80\xa6 Homosexual persons are not sick They also do not belong in a court of law\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'They also do not belong in a court of law\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'In 1935 he furthered his claims when he wrote a now famous \xe2\x80\x9cLetter to an American Mother\xe2\x80\x9d of a homosexual which stated that \xe2\x80\x9cHomosexuality is assuredly no advantage but is nothing to be ashamed of no vice no degradation it cannot be classified as an illness\xe2\x80\xa6 Many highly respectable individuals of ancient and modern times have been homosexuals\xe2\x80\x9d qtd in Isay 3'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLetter to an American Mother\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cHomosexuality is assuredly no advantage but is nothing to be ashamed of no vice no degradation it cannot be classified as an illness\xe2\x80\xa6 Many highly respectable individuals of ancient and modern times have been homosexuals\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'However the general public of the 1800s and early 1900s including the medical professionals regarded homosexuality as a curable mental illness'
b'Treatments such as castration hysterectomy lobotomy and electroshock therapy were used as attempted cures'
b'By the mid 1900s psychotherapy became the most common \xe2\x80\x9ccure\xe2\x80\x9d and many homosexuals spent countless hours being analyzed in hopes of changing their sexual preference Dudley 125'
b'Dr Evelyn Hooker a heterosexual psychologist conducted a groundbreaking study in the mid 1950s that went along similar reasoning as Freud'
b'In this courageous experiment Hooker compared the psychological profiles of sixty men half homosexual and half heterosexual'

b'She disagreed with the popular belief at the time that homosexuality was a mental illness and concluded that there was no significant psychological difference between homosexual and heterosexual men \xe2\x80\x9cgay\xe2\x80\x9d men were no more insane than their \xe2\x80\x9cstraight\xe2\x80\x9d counterparts Marcus 183'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cgay\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Fortunately many prominent psychiatrists also believed that homosexuality was not an illness and their lobbying along with the innovative study performed by Hooker who has been referred to as \xe2\x80\x9cthe Rosa Parks of the gay movement\xe2\x80\x9d convinced the American Psychiatric Association Board of Trustees to vote to remove homosexuality from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual as a mental illness in December of 1973'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cthe Rosa Parks of the gay movement\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Just over a year later the American Psychological Association also removed homosexuality from their list of mental illnesses Marcus 11'

b'The American Psychological Association further reiterated this belief when an overwhelming majority of the Council of Representatives adopted the Resolution on Appropriate Therapeutic Responses to Sexual Orientation in 1997 which publicly chastised those who attempted to \xe2\x80\x9ccure\xe2\x80\x9d homosexuality by means of various forms of treatment'
b'\xe2\x80\x9ccure\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'It stated rather that homosexuality was merely a difference in the opinion and values of the common person but must still be respected as an individual orientation and thus treated as one Resolution on Appropriate Therapeutic Responses to Sexual Orientation'

b'Perhaps one of the most famous studies on this topic was concluded in 1991 by Michael Bailey an assistant professor of psychology at Northwestern University and Richard Pillard an associate professor of psychiatry at Boston University School of Medicine and found that sexual orientation in males is largely due to genetics'

b'For two years these men studied the number of occurrences of homosexuality in both monozygotic or identical twins a set of twins coming from the same fertilized egg and thus having identical DNA and dizygotic or fraternal twins a set of twins from too separate zygotes causing them to have similar DNA but not any more so than that of two ordinary siblings in addition to adoptive brothers of gay males meaning that all of these males would have been raised in the same environment'

b'In total 110 pairs of twins identical and fraternal and 142 sets of male and their adopted brothers were studied where at least one of the two had been classified as homosexual either by selfidentification or other means'

b'Out of the 56 homosexual males who had identical twins 29 or approximately 52  of their identical twin brothers were also found to be homosexual as compared to only 12 or approximately 22  of the 54 nonidentical twins of homosexual males and 6 or approximately 11  of the 57 adopted brothers of homosexual males who were unrelated in terms of genetics'

b'Strangely enough the study also included pairs of biological brothers that were not twins and out of the 142 homosexual males studied only 14 or about 9  had homosexual brothers which is approximately the normal statistical incidence of homosexuality in the general population Bailey  Pillard'
b'More and more people are beginning to believe that homosexuality is not a \xe2\x80\x9cchoice\xe2\x80\x9d but rather a feeling that one is born with'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cchoice\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'As one grows older they become aware of sexual feelings towards other persons'
b'The only difference between homosexuals and heterosexuals is that while heterosexuals are attracted to members of the opposite sex homosexuals are attracted to those of the same sex'

b'Therefore neither homosexuals nor heterosexuals really have a \xe2\x80\x9cchoice\xe2\x80\x9d in the matter and asking a homosexual \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you attracted to other members of your sex\xe2\x80\x9d is likened to asking a heterosexual \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you attracted to members of the opposite sex\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you attracted to other members of your sex\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you attracted to members of the opposite sex\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'After all why would anyone choose such a difficult lifestyle'

b'As a homosexual one risks horrifying their parents other family members and friends to the point of losing all contact with them ruining their career being condemned by their religion being beat up for publicly displaying their sexuality and much much more'

b'Rather the only actual choice is whether or not to be open with one\xe2\x80\x99s sexuality and sexual preference whether to act on one\xe2\x80\x99s sexual desires whether to tell others about such feelings or whether to live a whole life as a lie and suppress these attractions Marcus 9'
b'To supplement my findings from research I have conducted personal interviews with two adolescent homosexual males James Dobbens and Daniel Woods'
b'Both were asked how what they thought determined homosexuality nature vs nurture and why when they realized they were homosexual and how they knew and similar questions'
b'Both believed that homosexual was a result of nature rather than nurture Dobbens  Woods'
b'Dobbens reasoned that most parents would not raise their children to be homosexual \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not like \xe2\x80\x98My child\xe2\x80\x99s going to be gay\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not like \xe2\x80\x98My child\xe2\x80\x99s going to be gay\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99'
b'\xe2\x80\x98My child\xe2\x80\x99s going to be gay\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99'
b'Dobbens'
b'Dobbens believes that he was born homosexual'

b'When why he was a homosexual he explained \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just the way you are you can\xe2\x80\x99t explain it I was just born that way it\xe2\x80\x99s like asking how the world was made \xe2\x80\x93 no one really knows\xe2\x80\x9d Dobbens'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just the way you are you can\xe2\x80\x99t explain it I was just born that way it\xe2\x80\x99s like asking how the world was made \xe2\x80\x93 no one really knows\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'He went on to explain that while his nurture did not impact his sexual orientation it did affect his view of it'

b'When discussing the role of parents and upbringing in a child\xe2\x80\x99s sexuality he commented \xe2\x80\x9cThey can bring you up to be open minded to homosexuality but they don\xe2\x80\x99t bring you up to be a homosexual\xe2\x80\xa6 I grew up in a place where homosexuality is accepted so that\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99m so open about being gay I accept myself\xe2\x80\xa6 Whether or not you accept homosexuality and can be honest with yourself if you are homosexual depends on how you\xe2\x80\x99re brought up\xe2\x80\x9d Dobbens'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey can bring you up to be open minded to homosexuality but they don\xe2\x80\x99t bring you up to be a homosexual\xe2\x80\xa6 I grew up in a place where homosexuality is accepted so that\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99m so open about being gay I accept myself\xe2\x80\xa6 Whether or not you accept homosexuality and can be honest with yourself if you are homosexual depends on how you\xe2\x80\x99re brought up\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Woods generally agreed with Dobbens and justified his belief that homosexuality was caused by one\xe2\x80\x99s nature rather than nurture when he commented that \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s nothing in my upbringing that exposed me to anything like homosexuality\xe2\x80\x9d Woods'
b'When asked why he was gay he explained that it is simply \xe2\x80\x9csomething that I can\xe2\x80\x99t help\xe2\x80\xa6 embedded in my head nothing made me do it\xe2\x80\x9d Woods'
b'He went on to explain that it the same thing as the primitive attraction between males and females only it was between males and other males'
b'He added that \xe2\x80\x9cnothing happened to make me homosexual it\xe2\x80\x99s always been there'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cnothing happened to make me homosexual it\xe2\x80\x99s always been there I\xe2\x80\x99ve always been attracted to guys\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve always been attracted to guys\xe2\x80\x9d Woods'

b'What I find to be extraordinary about Woods\xe2\x80\x99 case is that he remarked how while he has always been sexually attracted go guys he is romantically attracted to women in the sense that he has always wanted a girlfriend and to be close with other females etc\xe2\x80\xa6 but never in a sexual sense'

b'Though he has \xe2\x80\x9calways kind of fantasized about getting married to a female\xe2\x80\x9d these feelings come from his \xe2\x80\x9cromantic side which is different from the sexual side\xe2\x80\x9d Woods'
b'\xe2\x80\x9calways kind of fantasized about getting married to a female\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cromantic side which is different from the sexual side\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'He says that if he married a female with which he shared a strong trust maybe he could work it out'
b'He then went back to talk about homosexuality as in innate characteristic \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like race'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like race It\xe2\x80\x99s all something you can\xe2\x80\x99t help it all comes to you\xe2\x80\xa6 It\xe2\x80\x99s internal you can\xe2\x80\x99t help it\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s all something you can\xe2\x80\x99t help it all comes to you\xe2\x80\xa6 It\xe2\x80\x99s internal you can\xe2\x80\x99t help it\xe2\x80\x9d Woods'
b'When asked if he thought homosexuality was caused by a gene he commented that he thought that it was more of an instinct'
b'He gave the example of birds which are born with instincts such as knowing how to build a next or catch their prey'
b'Woods also thought that maybe it was caused by something in the development of the embryo'
b'All in all Woods views homosexuality as \xe2\x80\x9cfascinating\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cfascinating\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'His final thought \xe2\x80\x9cI also believe everyone has at least one homosexual attraction'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cI also believe everyone has at least one homosexual attraction It\xe2\x80\x99s not black and white homosexual vs heterosexual it\xe2\x80\x99s a spectrum\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not black and white homosexual vs heterosexual it\xe2\x80\x99s a spectrum\xe2\x80\x9d Woods'
b'Yet there are arguments against homosexuality as caused by genetics'
b'According to Darwin\xe2\x80\x99s theory of natural selection the advantageous traits are passed on while the disadvantageous ones eventually die out'

b'For instance heterosexual males have an average of five times as many children as homosexual ones as a female is required to reproduce children yet homosexuals are by definition not sexually attracted to females'
b'Therefore from the evolutionary standpoint homosexuality becomes one of the disadvantageous traits'

b'Because consequently heterosexual men contribute five times as much genetic information to the next the gene pool if homosexuality was indeed caused by a gene it would have died out entirely by now or at least been reduced immensely in the number of occurrences'
b'Since neither of these events have yet taken place it can be concluded that homosexuality is not caused by a gene Fulkerson'
b'My findings throughout my research have led me to conclude that there is no definitive answer on what causes homosexuality'
b'No one knows for sure now although many think they do and perhaps no one ever will know the whole truth'
b'Nonetheless I am apt to believe that homosexuality is the product of some kind of combination of genetic and environmental causes'
b'Perhaps one may have a genetic predisposition towards homosexuality that has been passed on from previous generations'
b'However this does not necessarily determine a homosexual rather this predisposition must be triggered by environmental factors'

b'This is why Bailey and Pillard found in their study that while they was a greatly elevated chance that two males sharing the same genetic makeup would also share the same sexuality this was not the case 100  of the time'
b'This seems to be the most likely explanation as of now but even as I write this new studies are being done'
b'Perhaps the truth is right around the corner'

b'Amanda Bates November 11 2008 Madame White Snake East Asian Femme Fatale of Old'
b'The Chinese legend of Madame White Snake the snake demon that takes human form and becomes the wife of a man has exerted a lasting influence over East Asian folktales and fiction for centuries'

b'Two quintessential novellas \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lust of the White Serpant\xe2\x80\x9d from Ugetsu Monogatari by the Japanese author Ueda Akinari and \xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner under Thunder Peak Pagoda\xe2\x80\x9d a traditional Chinese story are both relatively complex and demonstrate not only the evolution of the White Snake figure to become a more believable human but also what aspects may have given her enduring appeal'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lust of the White Serpant\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner under Thunder Peak Pagoda\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'While both these stories are ostensibly morality tales about the dangerous beauty of this femme fatale the true source of pleasure from these narratives is the femme fatale\xe2\x80\x99s transgressive behavior not her eventual punishment for it'

b'Early tales of Madame White Snake appeared in China as early as the Song Dynasty and initially her portrayal was fairly direct as a villainous demon who drains the life force out of her human husband'
b'Lai Whalen From Folklore to Literate Theater Unpacking Madame White Snake Asian Folklore Studies 51 no 1 1992 52'
b'Madame White Snake'

b'But over time characterizations of her became more complex and the persona of Madame White Snake became more sympathetic and perhaps even a model of the ideal Confucian wife particularly in \xe2\x80\x9cPagoda\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cPagoda\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Whalen Lai notes \xe2\x80\x9cShe was a loving wife a caring mother rescuer of her family from the first flood and at that point a general benefactor of man'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cShe was a loving wife a caring mother rescuer of her family from the first flood and at that point a general benefactor of man She took on the virtues of a traditional Chinese female particularly forbearance\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'She took on the virtues of a traditional Chinese female particularly forbearance\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Ibid 53'
b'But if she were really an ideal wife why could she not live happily with her human mate'
b'Her dangerous sexuality is the key'

b'Femme fatale might seem an unusual term to apply to a character from premodern Chinese and Japanese literature who may exemplify the virtues of an ideal Confucian wife since it is primarily associated with film characters particularly those of the film noir genre'

b'But this term which is relatively speaking a neologism The earliest uses were around the beginning of the 20th century Oxford English Dictionary \xe2\x80\x9cFemme \xe2\x80\x9d Oxford University Press httpdictionaryoedcomcgientry5008354150083541se3single1querytypewordquerywordfemmefatalefirst1maxtoshow10hilite50083541se3  is an apt description of the depiction of Madame White Snake and all her incarnations'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cFemme \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'It refers to a woman who is dangerously attractive and lures men to their downfall with her sexual attractiveness'
b'In both incarnations of Madame White snake the authors depict her as bewitchingly beautiful'

b'Toyoo her human lover in \xe2\x80\x9cLust of the White Serpant\xe2\x80\x9d cannot shake the image of her beauty from his mind and dreams of her and finds himself \xe2\x80\x9cdisturbed and agitated\xe2\x80\x9d by her \xe2\x80\x9cethereal beauty\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLust of the White Serpant\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cdisturbed and agitated\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cethereal beauty\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Ueda Akinari Ugetsu Monogatari  Tales of Moonlight and Rain  A Complete English Version of the EighteenthCentury Japanese Collection of Tales of the Supernatural Vancouver University of British Columbia Press 1974 162164'

b'In \xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner\xe2\x80\x9d Madame White Snake\xe2\x80\x99s bewitching beauty follows her lover Hs\xc3\xbc into his dreams and the next morning \xe2\x80\x9che was so distracted that he could not concentrate on doing business\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9che was so distracted that he could not concentrate on doing business\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner under the Thunder Peak Pagoda\xe2\x80\x9d Trans Diana Yu in Y W Ma and Joseph S M Lau Traditional Chinese Stories  Themes and Variations Boston Zheng  Zui Co 1986 358'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner under the Thunder Peak Pagoda\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Both of these stories align negative connotations with her beauty suggesting that her sexuality is the cause of their distraction'
b'In addition to distracting sexuality the irregular characterization of Madame White Snake might be another trait her character has in common with the archetypical noir femme fatale'

b'In her essay analyzing the noir film from a feminist perspective Christine Gledhill writes \xe2\x80\x9cNot only is the hero frequently not sure whether the woman is honest or a deceiver but the heroine\xe2\x80\x99s characterisation is itself fractured so that it is not evident to the audience whether she fills the femme fatale stereotype or not\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot only is the hero frequently not sure whether the woman is honest or a deceiver but the heroine\xe2\x80\x99s characterisation is itself fractured so that it is not evident to the audience whether she fills the femme fatale stereotype or not\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Christine Gledhill \xe2\x80\x9cKlute 1 A Contemporary Film Noir and Feminist Criticism\xe2\x80\x9d in Feminism and Film ed E Ann Kaplan New York Oxford University Press 2004 81'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cKlute 1 A Contemporary Film Noir and Feminist Criticism\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'While both stories each characterize Madame White Snake fairly consistently within their narratives the uneven characterization in film noir perhaps mirrors the evolution of her character over time readers may not be sure whether she is a pure villainess or whether she is a good wife who is badly treated by society because there is evidence of both throughout her legend'
b'She is a loyal wife to her husband as she has promised but she also causes him to find trouble with the law and deceives him about her supernatural nature'
b'The complications in her character serve to undercut the ostensible didactic intent of these stories'
b'This is quite similar to the expected end for the femme fatal character in films  she is punished in some way so that social order and proper gender roles are restored'
b'In both stories Madame White Snake\xe2\x80\x99s secret is uncovered and a monk comes to exorcise her and she is eventually rendered powerless and trapped under a pagoda'
b'Her husband becomes a monk and this further implicates Lady White Snake this time from a Buddhist perspective'
b'Female beauty is a dangerous thing that ties men to the transitory world and prohibits them from being free from desire and ascending to Nirvana'
b'Furthermore Lady White Snake\xe2\x80\x99s lover is far from the ideal man'
b'He is weakwilled and not particularly useful'
b'In \xe2\x80\x9cLust\xe2\x80\x9d the priest informs Toyoo \xe2\x80\x9cThose creatures took advantage of your fair looks and tempted you'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLust\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cThose creatures took advantage of your fair looks and tempted you But you yourself owing to a lack of courage and spirit fell victim to their temporary form\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'But you yourself owing to a lack of courage and spirit fell victim to their temporary form\xe2\x80\x9d Ugetsu Monogatari 177178 '
b'The implications of this are that a stronger more capable man would not fall for the Lady\xe2\x80\x99s trickery'
b'But are the morals of these stories entirely sincere'
b'If they were Madame White Snake would be unmistakably depicted as an evil character'
b'Instead both these stories feature many moments where readers have great sympathy for her despite her depraved sexuality'

b'Certainly readers admire her patience and loyalty \xe2\x80\x9cI searched everywhere and now that at last I\xe2\x80\x99ve found you I\xe2\x80\x99m very happy\xe2\x80\x9d Ibid173 she gushes to him in \xe2\x80\x9cLust\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cI searched everywhere and now that at last I\xe2\x80\x99ve found you I\xe2\x80\x99m very happy\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLust\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Readers must also acknowledge that her human lover is breaking his promise to her when he leaves her'
b'She pleads with him \xe2\x80\x9cWe have a love bond between us as constant as the T\xe2\x80\x99ai Mountains and the Eastern Sea and we must live and die together'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe have a love bond between us as constant as the T\xe2\x80\x99ai Mountains and the Eastern Sea and we must live and die together Please since we are already married take me back and let\xe2\x80\x99s stay together the rest of our lives Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t that be wonderful\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Please since we are already married take me back and let\xe2\x80\x99s stay together the rest of our lives'
b'Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t that be wonderful\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner\xe2\x80\x9d 369'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cEternal Prisoner\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'In another traditional vernacular story \xe2\x80\x9cTsu ShihNiang Sinks the Jewel Box in Anger \xe2\x80\x9cTu ShihNiang Sinks the Jew Box in Anger\xe2\x80\x9d trans Richard M W Ho in Y W Ma and Joseph S M Lau Traditional Chinese Stories  Themes and Variations Boston Zheng  Zui Co 1986 358 \xe2\x80\x9d the male protagonist breaks a promise he made to his concubine lover and suffers for it suggesting that traditionally loyalty and keeping ones word was valued on the man\xe2\x80\x99s part as well as a woman\xe2\x80\x99s'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cTsu ShihNiang Sinks the Jewel Box in Anger \xe2\x80\x9cTu ShihNiang Sinks the Jew Box in Anger\xe2\x80\x9d trans Richard M W Ho in Y W Ma and Joseph S M Lau Traditional Chinese Stories  Themes and Variations Boston Zheng  Zui Co 1986 358 \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cTu ShihNiang Sinks the Jew Box in Anger\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'So her husband\xe2\x80\x99s failure to follow through on his end of the bargain completely forgetting the love he once had for her makes readers more sympathetic to Madame White Snake\xe2\x80\x99s plight'
b'However no matter how much sympathy Madame White Snake may gather from readers the story still ends with her trapped under the pagoda'
b'These stories draw from the long tradition of supernatural and ghost stories which usually end with the demon destroyed or at least subdued'

b'In the initial versions of this story Madame White Snake harmed her human lover so her entrapment under a pagoda by a Taoist monk or later a Buddhist monk Lai 53 would have been a satisfying ending'

b'Readers of early versions of the story might have been cheering for the defeat of this demon disguised as a beauty and would have enjoyed reading the stories for the lurid horror details and later her crushing defeat'

b'Conversely the authors of the two stories examined here do not give readers motivation to wish for the death of Madame White Snake so the pleasure of the narrative  to borrow appropriate phrasing from film theory  comes not from the death of the insubordinate disruptive force from watching the transgressions themselves'

b'In an essay on the femme fatale heroines of film noir Janey Place argues that the strong behavior of the female characters supersedes the moral lessons supposedly imparted by their morals at the end'

b'She writes \xe2\x80\x9cthe final \xe2\x80\x98lesson\xe2\x80\x99 of the myth often fades into the background and we retain the image of the erotic strong unrepressed if destructive woman\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cthe final \xe2\x80\x98lesson\xe2\x80\x99 of the myth often fades into the background and we retain the image of the erotic strong unrepressed if destructive woman\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x98lesson\xe2\x80\x99'
b'Janey Place \xe2\x80\x9cWomen in Film Noir\xe2\x80\x9d in Women in Film Noir ed E Ann Kaplan London British Film Institute 2003 48'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cWomen in Film Noir\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'In these two stories the femme fatale Madame White Snake is going to live on in the minds of readers not as the shrunken snake trapped under a pagoda but the sexy aggressive woman who took a weaker human man as her lover'
b'This resistant reading of the text may be too colored by modern viewpoints since it is impossible to know for certain what readers in the past enjoyed about these stories'
b'However consciously or unconsciously these authors created a female character who fits the characteristics of a feisty heroine'
b'In fact Communists in the PRC in the 1970s reclaimed her as a feminist symbol for women who rebel against the patriarchy'
b'Lai 52'

b'Just as the dangerous femme fatale of noir films has reemerged as a heroine in her own right rather than the sexy death trap for the male protagonist so too Lady White Snake should be reclaimed for her sexual assertiveness and life slightly outside the bounds of conventional social expectations'
b'The Decline of the Northeastern Ohio Steel Market Why Did Attempts by Union Leaders and Concerned Citizens to Revive the Steel Industry Ultimately Fail'
b'An Extended Essay in History'
b'September 19 1977 is a date that few people in Youngstown Ohio will ever forget'
b'On that date Jennings Lambeth president of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced that most of the steel company\xe2\x80\x99s Campbell Works would close'
b'Although for other cities this would simply be a minor economic setback for the people of Youngstown and the surrounding area it meant disaster'

b'Mahoning County was a oneindustry area and the people of Youngstown Struthers Campbell Boardman Township and the numerous other small towns and villages in the area only had one main employer the steel mills'

b'The events that would follow this date known as Black Monday are seen by the people who witnessed them either as stories of great courage and determination or as monuments to human failure and false hope'
b'Rather than sit back and wait for their jobs to be snatched away the workers and local union members in the mills fought long and hard to be able to keep the factories open'

b'Petitions protests rallies collectivization and even the takeover of a steel company\xe2\x80\x99s headquarters were all attempted in a desperate movement by those in the industry to preserve the only source of employment that this town had'
b'These wellintentioned efforts ultimately failed leaving thousands with shattered dreams and a distinct lack of trust in fellow humankind'
b'But why did the brave attempts by union leaders and concerned citizens to revive the steel industry ultimately fail'

b'When examining the area\xe2\x80\x99s history culture and economic situation we can identify four main reasons the refusal of the international leadership of United Steelworkers of America to support their union\xe2\x80\x99s Youngstown branch the lagging international steel market the lack of a clear organized vision for individual initiatives such as the Save Our Valley Campaign and crippling regionalism which caused animosity between different small towns in the region all contributed in some way to the failure of the workers and union leaders to save the industry'
b'Most importantly the problem in Youngstown was a nationwide problem'
b'Although it affected Youngstown and the surrounding area more than it affected other regions the local people simply could not solve a national crisis on a local level'
b'A Brief History of Steel in Northeastern Ohio'
b'In 1802 James and Daniel Heaton discovered ore and coal lining Yellow Creek in an area outside of Youngstown known as Poland Township'
b'Their blast furnace \xe2\x80\x9cHopewell\xe2\x80\x9d was the very first blast furnace in the area'
b'During the Civil War Youngstown played a vital role in supplying the Union army with iron products'
b'Youngstown also was a major railway crossroads due to its strategic position between Cleveland Pittsburgh New York and Chicago'
b'In fact \xe2\x80\x9cMore rail cars passed under the Center Street Bridge a major bridge in Youngstown per day than any other location in the country\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'During the 19th century the center of iron manufacturing had gradually shifted from the far East Coast Massachusetts and Eastern Pennsylvania to the Ohio Valley Pittsburgh regions of the Northeast including the Mahoning Valley and the Hanging Rock region of Ohio and Kentucky'
b'By 1880 Youngstown\xe2\x80\x99s population had grown to nearly 16000 which meant it had doubled in size over a twentyyear period'
b'The town continued to prosper driven by the flux of immigrants pouring in with the hopes of employment at the mills'
b'This prosperity continued until the late 1920s when the Great Depression hit the area hard'
b'Despite the Congress of Industrial Organization\xe2\x80\x99s successful efforts to establish a national steel workers\xe2\x80\x99 union the industry barely survived the Depression years'
b'Finally the outbreak of the Second World War made iron and steel important again and Youngstown was bolstered out of its economic standstill into a fastpaced period of booming growth'
b'Strikes racked the town during the forties fifties and sixties and they were often long and bloody'
b'In 1973 the Experimental Negotiating Agreement was signed'
b'This prohibited strikes and lockout angering workers and driving productivity and laborer morale down'

b'At the same time stricter governmental standards for environmental protection and the growth of imported steel were making it harder to produce and market American steel parts and the overeager shareholders in the companies\xe2\x80\x99 stock were pushing for more and more of their share of the pie'
b'Most importantly Youngstown\xe2\x80\x99s steel mills were slowly becoming less efficient and more expensive'
b'Old technology was not replaced obsolete methods were not updated and almost none of the industry\xe2\x80\x99s profits were being utilized to help modernize'
b'It was a recipe for disaster that would soon explode in the faces of hundreds of thousands of workers and their families'
b'Black Monday and the Crash of the Steel Industry'
b'The announcement of the closing of the mills in 1977 was the beginning of a downward spiral which would send the entire valley into chaos and ruin'
b'Between 1977 and 1981 a total of five mills were closed and approximately 25000 jobs were lost countywide'
b'Meetings of union officials and mill bosses were hurriedly set up in an attempt to persuade the powers that be to reconsider their statement'
b'However it was clear that in the words of USWA president Lloyd McBride \xe2\x80\x9cIf you can\xe2\x80\x99t make a buck you get out of the business\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf you can\xe2\x80\x99t make a buck you get out of the business\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The closings meant the end of Youngstown\xe2\x80\x99s only real industry the end of its population growth and then end of economic progress'
b'Without the mills people sought other places of employment in adjoining states or even other areas of the country'
b'Those that could afford to move did so those that couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford to move mostly ended up on the streets'
b'Without an industrial or a residential base commerce shrank considerably'
b'It was becoming increasingly clear that without the industrial base provided by the mills the city of Youngstown would soon become a ghost town inhabited by those too poor or hopeful to escape'
b'The workers decided they needed to do something to save their city and so they mobilized in a variety of ways'
b'Attempts to Save the Mills'
b'The very first thing that the workers could do was \xe2\x80\x9cto get up a petition to stop the shutdown\xe2\x80\x9d says Ed Mann a local union leader and organizer'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cto get up a petition to stop the shutdown\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The petition was circulated eventually including thousands of signatures it was then given to USWA representatives to present to President Carter in Washington'
b'However the representatives were shunted to the side and ignored in Washington since Youngstown\xe2\x80\x99s political influence had died with its industry'
b'The International chapter of the USWA had much more lobbying power but they refused to support the local union members'
b'The petition was lost among paperwork and bureaucratic procedure'
b'Next workers decided to form the Ecumenical Coalition an organization of local religious groups which spearheaded the attempt to reopen the Youngstown works'
b'The Coalition drafter letters to the Lykes Company asking if a group of workers might purchase the mill and run it collectively'
b'Lykes ignored the letters so the Coalition turned once again to the federal government'
b'Here too they were ignored'
b'The Coalition had no proper funds to buy the mills so they could do nothing but sit back and watch as the mills closed'
b'Finally following the shutdown of US Steel\xe2\x80\x99s plant in 1980 local union leaders congregated outside the US Steel Headquarters in Youngstown'
b'They invited local people and politicians to witness the scene then charged the Headquarters and took it over'
b'The workers stayed there until the next day when US Steel declared that they were ready to talk about selling the mill'

b'Immediately after the workers left the building US steel representatives told the local union leaders that they had changed their minds and were no longer interested in allowing the workers to purchase the mill'
b'All these efforts eventually came to nothing and Youngstown\xe2\x80\x99s steel mills remained closed'
b'These attempts to save the mills were hindered by several major factors including the decline of the world steel market which made American steel impossible to sell or export'
b'The Decline of the World Market'
b'The efforts to save the mills failed partly because the international market for steel had largely dried up'
b'In fact American steel imports were beginning to outweigh exports'
b'Foreign steel was easier and more efficient to make and was often of higher quality than domestic steel'
b'Foreign steel companies invested in their factories updating their technology and replacing their equipment often'
b'This meant that foreign facilities were more modern and efficient than any plants in America and therefore were able to export a more competitive product'
b'Foreign steel was also much cheaper'
b'Wage hikes although they helped to improve living conditions of steel workers in the US made American steel far more expensive'
b'Also international competitors drew on a large supply of very cheap labor'
b'Jobs were scarce in other steelexporting countries and labor laws were either nonexistent or allowed employers to pay much less for work'

b'Labor costs in America continued to go up draining US companies of their resources while companies overseas were able to cut labor costs and put that money back into updating and renovating their facilities'
b'On a worldwide scale newer materials such as aluminum plastic and composites were beginning to substitute steel both at home and abroad'
b'Steel demand worldwide was beginning to decline and it affected both domestic and foreign companies'
b'However to American companies already suffering financial setbacks outdated machinery and fierce competition this lack of demand was an inconvenience they could not afford'
b'America\xe2\x80\x99s steel remained unsold flooding the world market with inferior products that no one wanted to buy'
b'Since this problem was a national one rather than a local one the problems that were occurring in Youngstown were not unique'
b'Youngstown was perhaps hit harder than any other town by the collapse of the steel industry but it was not alone'
b'The problem was a national one involving many more mills and issues than Youngstown\xe2\x80\x99s alone'

b'J Philip Richley a union member and organizer of many attempts to save 5the mills has summed it up thus \xe2\x80\x9cYou just can\xe2\x80\x99t solve a nationwide problem in a single city\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou just can\xe2\x80\x99t solve a nationwide problem in a single city\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The decline of the world steel market affected not just Youngstown but the entire steel community in America'
b'Trying to prop up one city\xe2\x80\x99s mills was impossible when faced with the depression that spread throughout the entire industry'
b'The Save Our Valley Campaign Lack of Funds and Plans'
b'Eventually some religious leaders involved in the Ecumenical Coalition joined forces within community members and former steel mill employees to create the Save Our Valley Campaign'

b'As the name suggests local leaders wanted to instill the people of Youngstown with a fierce sense of urgency driving them forward to confront steel companies and owners and help secure the future of the region'
b'Marches speeches and letter writing were all employed to help stimulate the Campaign and rally the people'
b'But the Campaign was bogged down heavily by the lack of proper funding'
b'The people of Youngstown being now unemployed had very little money to spend on anything but staying alive'
b'College tuition clothes food and heating all had to come before donations to nonprofit organizations'
b'People outside of the area had no personal investment in the mills and so it was difficult to convince anyone from out of the county to contribute funds'
b'The lack of money proved to be crippling because it prevented the organizations involved from purchasing the mills to run collectively'
b'Without funds the Save Our Valley Campaign could do nothing major to help salvage the city\xe2\x80\x99s dying economy'
b'The Save Our Valley Campaign also lacked one essential component an actual concrete plan'
b'No one seemed to know just how to go about fixing the problems'
b'Letters and petitions were all very well but they did little to improve the situation'

b'People clung to vague ideas of worker collectivization but no one could really fathom exactly how that would work the people of Youngstown were after all not particularly familiar with socialism or collectivization in general'

b'Beyond that no one knew how they should proceed everyone knew that saving the mills was important but nobody stepped forward with a fullfledged plan to do it without losing huge amounts of money and dragging even more people down'
b'Without a real plan nothing could truly be achieved'
b'Without funds to drive the efforts or even a real plan of action the Save Our Valley Campaign did more harm than good'
b'In effect it raised the hopes of workers without having any real chance at saving anything'
b'People became excited and waited for the mills to reappear but they never did'
b'The Campaign failed to save any jobs and Youngstown was plunged into economic chaos'
b'The Apathy of USWA'
b'United Steel Workers of America was the union representing the Youngstown steel workers when the closings hit'
b'Initially many assumed that their union would take a lead role in fighting for the recovery of their jobs'
b'However it soon became clear that although the local union leaders were prepared to fight the international branch was not'

b'The higher levels of the union became increasingly disassociated with Youngstown and its plight attempting to shut out the appeals from workers and local union representatives and to ignore what was really happening'
b'Actually one main reason for the behavior of the USWA was that union leaders really had no idea what to do'
b'No one had ever seen a shutdown of this magnitude and rapidity before and none of the leaders of USWA not even president Lynn Williams knew what could be done'
b'It was clear to everyone that the economic fallout from this series of closings would be one of the worst in US history and so without any real precedents the union leaders were flustered'

b'Rather than try and come up with some sort of scenario the USWA simply ignored what was going on in Youngstown hoping that perhaps the problem would resolve itself or at least not spread any further than it already had'
b'Besides incompetence the USWA had one other major reason for rejecting their local counterpart fear of socialism'

b'Obviously the union itself was not afraid of socialist action but they worried that the federal government might see the efforts of Youngstown workers to collectivize as a movement towards socialism and perhaps even communism'

b'If the USWA supported the efforts to revive the mills and encouraged worker control and ownership of the factories then the government and potentially other important people and institutions as well might begin to think that the UWSA leaders were encouraging socialism'
b'This would mean that UWSA would lose credibility with the American government and its people something they could not afford to do'
b'Therefore they decided to withdraw support and let the local branch fight it out alone'
b'Regionalism'
b'From its very first days the Mahoning Valley has been an area packed with small villages and hamlets'
b'Youngstown is the name of the major city area but surrounding it on all sides are small communities which to the casual viewer are indistinguishable from the main city itself'
b'Boardman Poland Township Struthers Lowellville Warren Lordstown Canfield Niles and many other towns and districts are crowded around Youngstown see Figure 3'
b'People from each town work shop eat and socialize in towns separate from their own making each town strongly dependent on every other town'
b'However although traffic is heavy between each separate district each area has its own distinct cultural ethnicity educational system heritage history and even food'
b'For example Struthers is a poor town with a large Slovak population where education is generally better than in surrounding towns but unemployment is much higher and pollution is widespread'
b'Most people in Struthers are either Orthodox or Baptist'
b'Two blocks over one finds Boardman a welloff township with a reputation for rich but unsuccessful schools'
b'Its residents are mainly Italian and Roman Catholic with a small concentration of Methodists on the east side'
b'Unemployment is low in comparison with surrounding towns and the streets are clean and well kept'
b'With many more cultures religions and economic levels living in close proximity to one another a curious phenomenon has overtaken the area regionalism'
b'Each town with their own identity instills a strong regionalistic feeling within their respective populations which dictates many habits exchanges and interactions between populations'
b'Oftentimes this regionalism takes the form of bizarre forms of hatred with certain towns becoming sworn enemies of others'
b'With so much regional tension it became very hard for workers to unite under a common cause even one that would save their jobs and their futures'

b'Workers from Poland Township would refuse to attend rallies with workers from Campbell and citizens of Struthers would become suspicious of people from Boardman even if they were supposed to be working towards the same thing'
b'A lack of cooperation became a crippling problem for the movement because no one was willing to put aside regional differences to work together'

b'In some instances small companies would express interest in helping the movement or in relocating their business in the area but because of regional pride no one could ever agree where the new businesses should relocate'

b'In this way the people of the Mahoning Valley missed many opportunities for new industrial or commercial lifeblood because of arbitrary arguments where the goal was simply to protect regional pride'
b'Conclusion The Aftershock and the Significance of Black Monday'
b'Black Monday was a devastating blow to an entire generation of people'

b'The efforts to avoid catastrophe after the fact were unsuccessful for four main reasons the failure of the international steel market the lack of funds and plans in initiatives such as the Save Our Valley Campaign the refusal of the USWA to support their local chapter out of ineptitude and fear and the absurd but very real regionalism which corrupted solidarity efforts and drove away any hope for brining in new companies'
b'What happened in Youngstown may not seem significant on an international or even on a national level and perhaps it is not'
b'But to the thousands of people living there the loss of the mills was a devastating event that sent shock waves through their economic political and social futures'
b'Because of the mills and their conspicuous absence hundreds of people were uprooted forced to leave their homes and tightly knit communities'
b'Hundreds more joined the unemployment lines or even began living on the streets'
b'For the people of Youngstown Black Monday was not just a historical event it was the most important event in their lives'

b'I remember Papas stopbox a teal blue Tiempo Capturado that Mama brought home for his birthday'
b'It was huge and inefficient and she should never have spent so many pesos on a toy but Papa would not let her return it'
b'He used it to preserve baby tomatoes cucumbers and strawberries in translucent cubes that he stored in the pantry for springtime meals in the middle of winter'
b'Mama kept her mink jacket a family handmedown safe from time in a stopbox and lent the capturador to my uncle for his stamp collection'
b'Sometimes they would let us little ones to seal a treasured toy or a last piece of birthday cake until we begged them for its release usually a few hours after enclosing it'
b'When my father died a year after my mother my sisters and I cleaned out their apartment'
b'We found our baby shoes protected in stopboxes'
b'I took mine home where they sat above my computer while I worked on my first play'
b'One night when I did not believe love had ever existed for anyone I used my own capturador a sleek titanium Sanyo Tardar Ahora to undo the stopbox'
b'Bringing my face close to the shoes I breathed deeply of air that my parents had trapped while closing up that symbol of their love for me'
b'The instant would have been improved had my baby shoes been cleaned before they were encased'
b'But as soon as I coughed I laughed and I did not try to kill myself that night'
b'Let me begin again'
b'Last year I rented a small house on Vega IV a sea world all islands and reefs and archipelagos turquoise waters and aquamarine skies sunrises like symphonies and sunsets like stars gone supernova'
b'Theres only one city called Nuevo Acapulco in La Enciclopedia del Empirio de la Humanidad its Napulco to the locals'
b'The Napulcans are mostly emigrants from Polaris II the only difference between them and their Carribbean ancestors is that the ancestors fleeced NorAm tourists'
b'Now the Napulcans profit from their Hispanic siblings'
b'I dont mean to sound cynical'
b'I suppose I wish to show that Im still capable of a certain authorial distance a semblance of dispassionate observation'

b'In fine tourist tradition most homes on Vega IV are named'

b'Your Sleeping Flamingo should be put to sleep'

b'The recycled air tasted sweet in my mouth and all thoughts that crossed my mind were cheap metaphors about lifegiving substances and how breathing was like sex only better'
b'I reserved the right to revise this opinion later'
b'When I was done mentally exclaiming over my impossible rescue I looked around'

b'The ship it was odd and old either so outdated or so heavily modified that I couldnt tell what make it was and somehow the crew standing around me fit the same description a singularly atypical amalgamation of folk'
b'And me I guess I was one more piece in their puzzle'
b'I was one more scrap to weld onto the rest one more stranded survivor who was found'
b'I was now one of them'
b'This story its our story'
b'The survivors of the unfortunate accidents the catastrophic malfunctions the fateful crashes this is us'
b'Floating alone each of us facing the silence of the vacuum we were found'
b'Once found we can never be lost'
b'This is our Hotel California'
b'We can never leave'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo Im on a ship now You do this a lot\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo Im on a ship now'
b'You do this a lot\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'A woman introduced as Tiffany and neither tall nor beautiful shrugged'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNow and then\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about my crewmates'
b'Why didnt you save them\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'As much as Jesse had irritated me I didnt like the picture my brain drew of him floating in his grave body swollen and bloated'
b'Who would tell his girl how he had died'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cCouldnt\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cCouldnt\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'An opportunist and a businessman that was Jefferson'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cWere selective about our passengers\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Tiffany she looked at the captain grinned and flipped her greasy brown locks over her shoulder'
b'She turned to me'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome on\xe2\x80\x9d she said before I could say anything else \xe2\x80\x9clets get you settled in\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome on\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9clets get you settled in\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'No time for questions'
b'No time for answers'

b'The ship had all the usual accoutrements artificial gravity tastefully painted walls sound dampeners to keep the noise of the engines from driving the crew batshit insane recycled air systems and a few lessusual lush carpeting lighting that was decorative as well as functional spacious corridors'
b'The occasional painting hung on the wall generic landscapes and portraits of old people no one has ever met primarily'
b'Glimpses of elegant rooms down the branching hallways music voices the aroma of real food'
b'This was heaven'
b'No seventytwo virgins but it would do'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are we going\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'I asked'
b'Tiffany looked back'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo your quarters Its not far youre not going to get blisters\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo your quarters'
b'Its not far youre not going to get blisters\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo I meant wheres the ship going Whats our destination\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo I meant wheres the ship going'
b'Whats our destination\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Tiffany she stopped walking'
b'She gave me a look pitying and a little pleased that she got to be the one to share the news'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cHoney\xe2\x80\x9d she said \xe2\x80\x9cYoure going to be delighted'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cHoney\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cYoure going to be delighted Destination everywhere Destination nowhere\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Destination everywhere'
b'Destination nowhere\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'This was hell'
b'I died in those last moments suffocating on my own exhaled breath and this this was my reward'

b'Fact The speed of sound in dry air at twenty degrees Celsius or sixtyeight degrees Fahrenheit is three hundred and fortythree meters per second or one thousand one hundred twentyfive feet per second'
b'It took me a couple days to realize I was in fact still alive'
b'I mean sure Id had my moment of elation when I had first realized Id been rescued but it didnt sink in'

b'After watching my ship tear apart after spending a good twentythree hours floating in silence in the wreck wondering whether I was currently facing stars belonging to the constellation Libra or the constellation Orion when those stars were viewed from Earth wondering what it felt like to suffocate and after the feeling that yes I was in fact going to die alone in space had sunk in it took time for that feeling to dissipate'
b'Fact I wasnt dead'
b'After I realized this I left my quarters'
b'The lightscreen provided had informed me when and where official meals were taking place but I hadnt bothered to acknowledge the invitations'
b'It hadnt seemed relevant somehow given that I was still reeling over the explosion the deaths of my crewmates and the rescue'
b'Ive heard there are a number of stages of grief and shock I guess I was working my way through them'
b'Initially I couldnt figure out why\xe2\x80\x94I hadnt requested any be sent'
b'Then I realized someone must have noticed I hadnt left and was nice enough to send food my way'
b'The accompanying bottle of wine was a nice touch'
b'I must have consumed it too because later on the plates and the bottle were both empty'
b'I spent a lot of time lying on my back on the bed staring up at the little etched swirls in the ceiling or slumped in the oldfashioned armchair staring out the windows at the stars'
b'I did a lot of staring and not moving'
b'Man was it good to be done with that stage'
b'It was time to find out what hell looked like'
b'Fact Hell is other people'
b'Sure the ship was spacious'
b'We didnt pick up many passengers\xe2\x80\x94just the select special few scattered here and there between the stars'
b'But we were all on this ship and we were on it together'
b'Cliques form in any decentsized group of people'
b'Me I was singled out by Sarah an unassuming fortysomething lady with a glass of champagne in one hand and the arm of a scrawny but tall blond man in the other'
b'She sidled up to me as I was scooping little round crackers and what appeared to be a baked cilantro cream dip onto a plate'

b'The plate by the way was already loaded with folded pieces of smoked pink fish paprikadusted deviled eggs toothpicks stabbed through green vegetables and slices of cheese and balls of meat smothered in a tomatobased sauce'
b'Luxurious even compared to the fare one would find in the highclass space stations and pleasure cruisers'
b'Compared to what a mere engineer would get on your typical cargo ship it was mouthwateringly lipsmackingly gorgeous'
b'I wondered if the food delivered to my quarters the past few days had been similarly amazing'
b'I decided it couldnt have been'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiking the taste of the sweet life eh Im Sarah and this is Alexis\xe2\x80\x94you must be the new pickup\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLiking the taste of the sweet life eh'
b'Im Sarah and this is Alexis\xe2\x80\x94you must be the new pickup\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'She looked me over approvingly'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cCome on lets get you a glass of champagne\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'I looked longingly at the slices of cheddar olive bread as she whisked me over to the bar but didnt protest'
b'The bar was manned by an expensive humanoid robot'
b'It turned toward Sarahs wave and acknowledged her with a nod moments later setting a fluted glass of sparkling liquid in front of her'
b'I marveled at the robots smoothness and coordination'
b'Clearly it was a highend model'
b'Sarah transferred the glass to my free hand and pulled me away from the bar for more introductions with Alexis trailing after us'
b'I spent the evening listening mostly'
b'Listening and stuffing my face with all the bits of fine food provided'
b'No one minded Sarahs inner circle was content to fill our circle of couches with plenty of chatter'
b'Ray a plump man who was grey where he wasnt bald'
b'Zheng short and dark and lean with a very intense gaze'
b'He made me a little uncomfortable'
b'Kishori petite her hair strung out in a series of braids that reached nearly to her waist'
b'I categorized them based on their appearances hoping Id be able to pick them out of the crowd again later'

b'Most of their chatter was meaningless to me\xe2\x80\x94stories of daytoday activities how soandso had been seen in soandsos table at lunch and my wasnt that a surprise and why hadnt the chef concocted this delectable a selection of appetizers for the dance the other night but of course those rolled meat pastries reminded one of the pastries back on Earth didnt they and this was somehow an interesting fact'
b'After the first halfhour I stopped expending effort to keep names and stories and gossip straight'
b'I could have started asking questions but I wanted to get my bearings first'
b'Tonight was for observation'
b'I didnt bother trying to seek out a different group of potentially more interesting people though'
b'They all looked the same clusters of social butterflies surrounded by the less apt the hangerson the circle with whom the gossip was shared'
b'I wondered at the ship instead'
b'All the fine food and the ornamental lighting it had to be exorbitantly pricey to maintain'
b'If the barkeep was any indication I suspected similarly highclass robots fulfilled other positions on the ship'
b'How they were all powered was a mystery\xe2\x80\x94as good as the technology got a quality robot like that was still an energy sink'
b'It was the brain mostly the amount of information the machine had to process to be able to function at the level it did ate up a lot of resources'
b'Sarahs crowd took turns taking my champagne flute to the bar to be refilled all seemingly pleased to have a new set of ears to talk at'

b'I slowly returned my attention to the conversation and was pleasantly surprised to find that it had turned to a heated analysis of a recent abstract film\xe2\x80\x94done in the style of old flatscreen movies\xe2\x80\x94that I had seen during offtime at Geminia Station'
b'By the end of the evening when I finally followed the slow trickle of people out of the room a satisfying haze had settled on my mind'
b'It was nice I decided'
b'This ship'
b'This life'
b'Did it truly matter what the ships origin was and why Jefferson had saved me if now I was content'
b'Fact Its easy to fall into patterns'
b'I would wake late checking the clock on my rooms lightscreen to make sure I hadnt slept through brunch'
b'I would join the rest of the ship for meals and I would take my turn in the weight room'
b'I would watch old films on the entertainment screens taking mental notes for later dinnertime discussions'
b'I would immerse myself in new virtual reality flicks'

b'I would attend afternoon dance classes so that when the evening dances came around modeled after the historical social gatherings of several hundred years prior I would be less of an embarrassment to myself'
b'I did not ask questions'
b'I told myself I should'
b'I told myself that tonight the observation period would end and Id start puzzling out the ships mystery'
b'But I fell under the ships sway'

b'Bereft of my previous familiar life I latched onto Kishori and Ray and Zheng and Sarah with Alexis dragged along on her arm now and then he was mostly her favorite dancing partner she confided to us one night that his conversational skills left something to be desired'
b'I smothered thoughts of friends back on Earth\xe2\x80\x94this was my longawaited vacation my clean break and my temporary retreat Id try contacting those friends tomorrow'

b'I continued to care little for shipwide gossip but our discussions of films and flicks old and new brought out my artistic storyloving argumentative side a side of me Id tucked into a back storage compartment during my years as an engineer'
b'It was a good life if surreal'
b'But I wasnt sure I wanted the dream stage to end'
b'Fact Some places are timeless'
b'Days passed weeks passed but I couldnt tell if it had been months or years since I was rescued'
b'All there was all I remembered was a blur'
b'Gathering for drinks in the parlors playing dress up with all the fine clothes I found in the closets some of it modern some of it period dress for special themed events idling in the lounges'
b'Now and then a new face mingled in the crowd'
b'Other faces washed out fading into the backdrop of carpets and fake glass chandeliers and the muted hum of the engines'
b'One of these evenings we were gathered in the South Ballroom for postdinner drinks lounging on couches and watching other members of our populace move in circles on the dance floor'
b'The South was in the title to suggest that there were more ballrooms'
b'South'
b'There werent'

b'Sarahs circle had picked up another newcomer Adrienne a short blond girl who we all agreed was barely old enough to attend a traditional university back on Earth let alone work on the ship in whose wreck Jefferson had found her'
b'Maybe it was her curiosity asking a question I should have asked long before that turned the conversation serious maybe there was just something special about that evening'
b'Maybe we had all tired of the frivolity of our life hitting some threshold or some breaking point'
b'Regardless when Adrienne asked what the ships purpose was we all gave it a measure of thought'
b'We dredged up halffledged theories and inchoate explanations tossing these out the same way we pitched ideas about the art films'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou cant hold on forever even if you dont ever ever want to forget How long until the memories slip away How long until all you remember is this the ship the thick red carpeting the chandeliers the empty conversations you hold with the other shells who used to be people When your life the reason you lived the people and faces and places the emotions you felt who and what you loved when all that is gone faded what will you have left\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'I sat sideways in the armchair feet dangling over one arm neck resting against the other absently tracing invisible lines between the stars outside my window as I ruminated on the situation'

b'I inspected the arrays of entertainment options\xe2\x80\x94abstract oldstyle flatscreens engrossing VR flicks and action games a selection of quondam bestsellers and a few recently released novels hoping to gain popularity'

b'A simple contact system for communicating with other people on the ship'

b'I shifted my feet in the plush green carpeting of the Emerald Lounge looking out the windows at the stars'

b'Times like that running on less sleep than I should alone because everyone else had had the sense to retire for the night I had a tendency to get all meditative about the universe and my place in it'
b'The stillness of the room contributed as did the view'
b'Black and more black speckled by tiny points of light that flared up to break the emptiness if only for a brief time'
b'All of it was temporary save for the black'
b'That was tonights melodramatic theme the ephemeral nature of life'
b'Everything temporary'
b'Everything to fade away lost as dust and scattered atoms between the stars and every one of us to be left as alone as the moment we were born'
b'Some things in this world we have to make them permanent ourselves'
b'And Jefferson he had done that'
b'He had made us a constant'
b'He made this ship\xe2\x80\x94this life\xe2\x80\x94a constant'
b'The one thing that was known'
b'The one thing that wouldnt change'
b'Maybe everything we did all the stories we told maybe it was all lies'
b'But ultimately this ship its purpose our purpose\xe2\x80\x94did it matter'
b'We each had our own theory'
b'Maybe that was enough'
b'And all of us we were permanent characters in each others stories'
b'Maybe that made us more real'
b'Maybe it made us feel less alone'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cI cant see the meaning in any of it All these things I do theyre just to pass the time until I die\xe2\x80\x9d'
