b'Tara stood stockstill waiting for the first tiny gleam from the scout craft to appear in the darkness of the wormhole'
b'The gentle constant breeze of recycled air from the vent above blew an annoying hair against her nose but she ignored it'
b'A gasp from the psychic broke her silent vigil and she turned'
b'Results Harmon'
b'she suppressed the surge of annoyance that ran through her as she contemplated the psis gift of getting all the hot news first'
b'Harmons face slowly animated  joy sweeping in to replace stern concentration'
b'Tarrin says the planets a freaking gemstone'
b'Thriving with life large and small forms no buildings of any kind hydrocarbons metals and a stable atmosphere'
b'Hes not even bringing them back through for a face to face briefing'
b'He says we should come through now immediately before the probe is reported late'
b'Harmon tell that good for nothing son of a beta to get his hindquarters through the gate and back here NOW or Ill open fire on him when we come back through'
b'Tara fumed'
b'Of all the impertinence'
b'Tarrin no doubt with orders from Mason was questioning her command decisions'
b'Thats what I get for not using mercenaries'
b'She returned to her watch regarding her own reflection in the long window'
b'Mahoganyblack curly hair cut short in the typical military style framed a careworn darkskinned face'
b'It was not an attractive face right now her ebony eyes shadowed by hours on the watch full lips pursed with frustration'
b'She had the look of every leader she had ever known'
b'At six foot two she stood a full head taller than even her Arrallin first officer'
b'Her glowering expression completed the imposing effect'
b'She picked imaginary flecks off her stark gray jumpsuit and snorted'
b'You look like hell Tar'
b'Dont blow this'
b'Dont let fatigue get to you'
b'She used the discretion of the mirrored window to secretively survey her crew'
b'Harmon was an excellent addition to the bridge team but was she open minded enough to defy United Earth Command and sever all ties from Earth'
b'She watched the psi bob her head unaware of the rest of the bridge shaking blonde curls as she chattered away with the approaching psi relay on Masons ship'
b'She seemed so depthless  self conscious and shallow on the outside but having that incredible gift'
b'There had to be more to her'
b'Well if she didnt pan out shed be terminated'
b'Any crew member that would jeopardize the project was meat'
b'It would be a shame to lose that talent though'
b'Rakal her first officer was staring pensively at his panel'
b'He was what this was all about'
b'She watched his graceful fingers ending in thick black claws tap out calculations on the panel'
b'Only those of the Arrallin Insurrection inner team knew he was no common beta furry'
b'His silken fur which would be tawny golden and striped with jet black bands was dyed perfectly to a pure black and his mane trimmed and thinned as to be indistinguishable from the rest of his coat'
b'His eyes had been treated and darkened to a rich purple to disguise the brilliant golden yellow color that would mark him as an Alpha Arrallin and leader of his hive'
b'The scout ship reemerged from the hole  a brilliant speck emerging from a sphere of velvety blackness'
b'Launch the second probe'
b'Wont Central be crushed to learn that another gateway has yielded little more than a class F planet and a white dwarf system'
b'Level 1 and 2 staffers should prepare to be briefed and move out'
b'This sounds like its the one'
b'The distinctive whuffle of pleasure rippled through the betas on the bridge and Rakal let loose a small growl as if to caution his charges against false hope'
b'Theyd scouted twentyseven gates so far and none had turned up anything worth the Insurrections time'
b'Tara would not let giddy hopes drag them onto a rock that would spell the end for the project and the Arrallin species'
b'Nathan\xe2\x80\x99s Bylichka'
b'Strange things have always happened to my family'

b'It came in through my mothers blood my Russian grandmother would always tell me stories bylichkas of ancestors with the second sight stupid mill owners who discovered bags of gold after letting a special fish off their hooks and dark strangers who used to appear to help or interfere at crucial times'

b'When I asked her if shed ever seen them \xe2\x80\x93 before I was old enough to stop believing I mean \xe2\x80\x93 she would always look sad and tell me No not since the family came to America has anything happened to us'
b'No not since the family came to America has anything happened to us'
b'But if you ever should see a faerie tell him that you are of the blood of Ivan Bogatyrivitch and he will not pass you by so quickly'
b'As I got older I shook the tales off with a nod and a Yes Nana'
b'Yes Nana'
b'I got older and went to school then to college and I replaced the dreams my Nana gave me with the music DJs mixed for crowds in clubs webs of pulse that shook us until we could believe anything'
b'My girlfriend Rachel and I would go to the clubs near our school'
b'Sometimes wed get word that people were gathering under one of the bridges and wed rush down to hit it before the cops broke it up'
b'Boston is a strange place at night'
b'You wouldnt believe half of the shit Ive seen even when I was straight'
b'It was a Friday night'
b'Rachel and I went out to dinner and when we finished she saw that there was a message on her cell phone'
b'She checked it there in the restaurant'
b'Her head tilted into the phone as she listened her pleather purse on her lap shining jet against the worn black of her snug Dead Can Dance Tshirt'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s from Mitch\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe says we should meet him tonight there\xe2\x80\x99s a good one going on in that church that closed down last month\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'I danced with Rachel for a while but then something by the bar seemed to be pulling her eyes'

b'When she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t come back halfway through the next song I glanced over at the bar'

b'Saturday morning I woke up and saw that she still hadn\xe2\x80\x99t come home'

b'I called out to Amy to shut the door in case the vampire had any friends who might be trying to follow us'
b'Inside was a dark room that looked like a storage space for DJ equipment'
b'Nepthys urged me on from the back of the room then made a turn out of sight'
b'When I came to the door at the end of the room it looked like it had been torn off its hinges'
b'I didn\xe2\x80\x99t imagine that Nepthys had done it and it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t without alarm that I ran after him'
b'A black hallway opened into a space like a cathedral'
b'The vault rose into obscurity above me and a massive rose window stood ahead of me'
b'The panes looked dyed black and only a few cold beams slipped through the filter'
b'Footsteps echoed through the stone chamber and the sound reflected back to me from everywhere'
b'I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell how many people were running much less where they were'
b'On the steps in front of the altar I saw pale forms and realized that they were Rachel and two other women'
b'Then I heard Nepthys shout \xe2\x80\x9cNathan'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNathan'
b'Behind you\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'I whirled and dropped in time to see the vampire shoot over my head leaping like a panther'
b'He smashed into the pews behind me and I heard him leap across the rest of the row'
b'There was Nepthys on the other side of the pews holding the wooden box in his hand'
b'He tossed it to me and I just barely had it open before I saw the vampire again turning to face me'
b'I pulled out the hammer and one of the stakes'
b'He leapt over the pews soaring like a grasshopper and drew a gleaming knife in midair'
b'I dodged but he tossed it and I held the box in front of my face'
b'The blade lodged in the wood its silver point penetrating the velvet and nearly reaching my skin'
b'My arms shook from the force of his throw'
b'Then he landed heavy beside me and I scrambled to stand'
b'His first move pulled out the dagger almost wrenching my arms from their sockets as I held on to the box and the second shattered the box with a crushing punch that sent me reeling backwards'
b'I dropped the splinters and the broken second stake and raised my hammer ready to drive the ash spike into his heart'
b'Behind him I saw Nepthys running between the pews'
b'I braced my legs against the stone floor and he was on me'
b'I raised the stake he drew back the dagger for a slash that could doubtless open my neck from throat to spine'
b'The stake went down there was a blur and then my hands were empty and I felt pain under my jaw'
b'Two points of fire opened in my throat for an instant then all went numb'
b'Taste hearing and touch became a single blur and I do not know if my eyes were open'
b'My mind began to dissipate but then I felt the pain withdraw and a lifeless voice said \xe2\x80\x9cThis one\xe2\x80\x99s blood isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth drinking\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis one\xe2\x80\x99s blood isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth drinking\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Hands closed on my neck and I felt my spine crack'
b'I must have fallen to the floor then'
b'I could perceive Nepthys\xe2\x80\x99 sword flashing over me and I heard steel crack then bone'
b'I thought I heard Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s voice blearily calling for me'
b'Then one set of footsteps began walking toward the altar'
b'I was content to let myself drift away and I had almost forgotten the body lying with broken neck on the cathedral\xe2\x80\x99s hard tiles when I felt a warm touch on its cheek'
b'A girl\xe2\x80\x99s voice soft and almost recognizable spoke \xe2\x80\x9cNathan\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNathan\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'I felt my head turn and something in my neck reconnected'
b'Then my eyes opened and Amy handed me the hammer and stake'
b'I stood and turned toward the altar'
b'The vampire was walking just steps ahead of me'
b'I stepped up behind him and raised my hands which almost seemed to be glowing'
b'Then the stake came down into his back and one two three strikes with the hammer drove it in'
b'The vampire fell forward and blood began to flow from his mouth'

b'Behind me Amy was kneeling beside Nepthys whose arm and rib cage were knitting back together like a wooden toy that falls apart when its string is released but draws itself together at a slight tug'
b'I pulled the vial of liquid that he\xe2\x80\x99d been giving me from his pocket and ran to the altar'
b'Rachel her clothes torn and her face drawn looked like she might cry when she saw me'
b'I pulled her into my arms and she tried to put hers around me'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy fuckin\xe2\x80\x99 hero\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy fuckin\xe2\x80\x99 hero\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The Black Willow'
b'Allan sat down at his desk and pulled the chair in close'
b'Opening a side drawer he took out a piece of paper and his inkpot'
b'After filling his pen Allan looked at his paper in the orange glow from the lantern set back in the desks righthand corner'
b'His pen cast a forbidding line of shadow slanting across the page echoing the inky darkness crouching in the edges of the lanterns struggling glow'
b'The only other illumination came from a lurid moonlight filtered through thin branches and clouds casting its bonepale glow onto the pine floorboards'
b'Allan unfolded another page this one crowded with ranks of letters in tight formation from left to right'
b'The lines of letters stepped into their divisions in the shape of a storys outline the loose dry skeleton of a tale lay exposed beneath their feet awaiting tendons muscle and blushing skin'

b'Allan reviewed the troops all prepared to disembark their task to form the tale of a young man returning home from Life Abroad to find his childhood friend a bride tobe thus upsetting the apple cart of his lifes plan clarified \xe2\x80\x93 of course \xe2\x80\x93 by his very time away from her he loved best'
b'Although the concept was a simple one Allan thought it had potential'
b'Besides the public liked a good simple romance'
b'Perhaps this will be more saleable he thought and began to write'
b'They gazed at each other lost in the rapture of love based so deeply within their hearts that they had never seen it before'
b'What about Roger'
b'she asked knowing that the answer no longer mattered'
b'This is good he thought pausing to raise the low light of the lantern'
b'Im almost done and the happy ending is just falling into place'
b'I hardly dare to think it but \xe2\x80\x93 I may finish this story'
b'As he thought this a sinuous wind encircled the house slipping through the walls to chill him'
b'The papers and the lanterns flame trembled as the thin fingers of a great black willow rapped gently on Allans window and wall like a stranger knocking on his chamber door'
b'This was no stranger however the twisted ancient thing was older than Allan its branches rapping on his window since his childhood'
b'Its thin drawn fingers framed the bloated moon whose eerie radiation now bathed the room directly'
b'The great jaundiced eye stared down unblinkingly at the author who gazed up through his windows tiny frame with trepidation'
b'Allan recalled himself and focused once more on the incomplete page before him'
b'His pen flickered forth words dancing out from its nib'
b'In the authors eye gleamed the lanterns reflection \xe2\x80\x93 or was it a reflection'
b'For while the lanterns spark shivered in the chill breeze this burn was steady and true as the motion of its owners pen scratching out the rhythm of the willows fingers'
b'The frenzied writing ceased at last the author leaned back with a slight sigh as if both exhausted and satisfied by his effort'
b'He held a hand to his forehead eyes closed and face flushed'
b'After all that \xe2\x80\x93 so near the end to lose control again'
b'His breath returning to its normal rhythms he dared to look at the page before him'
b'His face soft as if caught between a smile and tears he draped his loose cape over her shoulders'
b'Come darling'
b'Where I am to take you one need never think of those left behind'
b'They took their seats within the car and his driver set the horses trotting'
b'For a few yards they kicked up dust along the roadway then they raised their hooves and took to the air'
b'She gaped afraid but knowing that no harm would come to her by his hand'
b'The New England woods disappeared even the greatest pines shrinking to insignificance as they mounted the sky'
b'Above them the Milky Way drew near as if the stars themselves could be reached'
b'A magnificent glow infused the carriage as they merged with the skys glory'
b'Allan crushed the page in his hand and hurled it at the window'
b'Damn you he cried will you never leave me be'
b'Damn you'
b'will you never leave me be'
b'Shall I never finish a story in peace'
b'He pounded his desk in vain cursing the foul muse that drove him'
b'The next day Allan sat on a florally patterned chair in a wellfurnished parlor'

b'Taking a measured sip of white wine from his crystal glass he glanced at his host \xe2\x80\x93 a cultured man dressed in a light suit of the current fashion and wearing his pale hair with a heavy set of sideburns \xe2\x80\x93 who passed him a silver tray'
b'Cucumber sandwich'
b'Allan took a sandwich between his fingers'
b'Thank you Arthur'
b'Arthur replaced the tray onto the lacquered cherry table that stood in the center of his ordered chamber'
b'In a manner delicately balanced between somber and genial he refilled their glasses'
b'How is the writing these days my dear Mr Clemm'
b'Perfectly dreadful my dear Mr Mason Allan sighed'
b'Perfectly dreadful my dear Mr Mason'
b'I had a perfect story in my pages my hero returned home and reclaimed his love I nearly had it tied together before\xe2\x80\xa6'
b'Before'
b'Before that blasted impulse came over me and I started writing like Edgar Poe \xe2\x80\x93 though the most recent was not so morbid as my many others thank Heaven'
b'Arthurs face assumed a longsuffering aspect of authoritative exasperation'
b'Im not familiar with Mr Poes works but I assume youre referring to your unhealthy penchant for the fantastic'
b'Its far from a penchant Arthur'
b'This is more like a compulsion a beast that lies waiting in the dark for the perfect moment then leaps and takes ahold of me screaming out through my quill'
b'How perfectly awful'
b'Arthur grimaced at the vivid description'
b'Im sure you know that you must curb this behavior if you wish to produce any writing fit for public consumption'
b'I know Allan replied but how am I to do that'
b'but how am I to do that'
b'You know I do not wish to make my stories thus but it is my nemesis confronting me anew at every turn'
b'Arthur raised a critical brow'
b'Perhaps you could make some headway if you denied your darker side the outlet of the colorful metaphors you so enjoy'
b'Every action you take to deny it nourishment will bring you closer to your goal and believe me Allan you must take every opportunity to quash this uncivilized obsession if you intend to publish'
b'There simply is no audience for fairy tales \xe2\x80\x93 no literate audience at least'
b'It is true Allan admitted fidgeting with his cufflinks that I would not dream of submitting one of these corruptions of literature to any publisher'
b'It is true'
b'that I would not dream of submitting one of these corruptions of literature to any publisher'
b'Ive even tried rewriting the corrupted sections but once my characters have gone down that road nothing can recall their former life'
b'My prodigal inkblooded children simply lose their vitality when forced along the proper road'
b'If only you would restrain this morbid impulse of yours you might write something really worth reading'
b'Its hard enough listening to your wild speech without seeing it appear in the refined world of print like a surly foreigner among a genteel crowd'
b'Allan hung his head holding his wine with both hands between his arched knees'
b'His hair was slightly unkempt after his sleepless night and his clothing had a rumpled look as if by mere proximity it had taken on the aspect of his weariness'
b'He scratched the back of his darkhaloed head and blinked bleary eyes'
b'I would drive it out he said softly but I fear for what would remain'
b'I would drive it out'
b'but I fear for what would remain'
b'Perhaps you require a rest from writing suggested Arthur'
b'Perhaps you require a rest from writing'
b'You might find that some time in an honest occupation would ground you somewhat improve your disposition'
b'Perhaps it would Allan replied rising and vainly straightening his suit'
b'Perhaps it would'
b'I shall consider it in the meantime however I must be off'
b'You have been a gracious host as always'
b'Arthur rose and shook his hand'
b'So dear a friend is always welcome to my counsel and my home he said'
b'So dear a friend is always welcome to my counsel and my home'
b'I hope soon to see you in better sorts'
b'They parted and Allan made his way pensively from Arthurs gate'
b'He walked the wheelruts hands in his pockets and unshined shoes collecting dust'
b'Some quartermile from Arthurs gate he halted confronted by a halloo'
b'Nathan'
b'he called out to the empty road'
b'The reply came from above him and Allan turned to see his friend reclining in the fork of a great tree'
b'I had a hunch youd be at Arthurs today said Nathan so I thought Id wait here for you'
b'I had a hunch youd be at Arthurs today'
b'so I thought Id wait here for you'
b'Nathans lanky frame dressed in a loose tan jacket fit into the branch like an elegant skeleton'
b'His hair fell loosely across a face that seemed always to have a knowing smirk hidden just beneath its surface infusing his body with a rakish energy'
b'So Allan said Nathan unfolding and lowering his legs to the roadside how goes life for the quintessential American author'
b'So Allan'
b'how goes life for the quintessential American author'
b'I wouldnt know replied Allan dryly before continuing in another tone entirely'
b'I wouldnt know'
b'I destroyed another story last night Nathan'
b'Leaning against his tree Nathan shook his head'
b'You mean finished another story'
b'Yes it is finished'
b'Ended'
b'Never again shall it see the rosyfingered dawn'
b'Nathan youve read these abominations of mine'
b'You know just as well as I that they have no future no potential'
b'At best they are faery tales at worst expeditions into macabre realms no healthy mind need ever see'
b'So instead you would write \xe2\x80\x93 what'
b'Something saleable something worth reading worth writing'
b'I want to write as others do a tale set in our real world of characters who might live therein not citizens of some airy demesne beyond the stars'
b'Why is that more desirable than what you write today'
b'People will read such stories they are worth publishing'
b'If you never finish such stories how can they be worth publishing'
b'That is precisely why I must excise this malignant instinct'
b'Why do you write'
b'\xe2\x80\xa6Why \xe2\x80\x93 to earn a living I suppose'
b'Why do you ask'
b'You choose to write rather than become a fisherman or a carpenter though you face such difficulty'
b'I would not be happy thus separated from it'
b'So at its heart then your writing \xe2\x80\x93 as opposed to working otherwise \xe2\x80\x93 is for yourself'
b'Yes I suppose one could see it thus'
b'But really Nathan your queer habits of conversation have reached a new level'
b'Ignoring the statement Nathan continued'
b'Your writing is for you Allan not for the publishers or some imagined audience'
b'Since you seem unable to write normally why not embrace your tales as they are leave behind the one unhappiness in the art you admit is a source of pleasure'
b'Your stories strike a chord with the deepest most ancient stories of mankind the tales basic to humanity'
b'Tell them and they will create an audience'
b'You need not pander to what you imagine their wants are speak and they shall listen'
b'Allan crouched over his desk once more pen in hand and mind blank'
b'He contemplated a story an outline he had laboriously constructed some time ago'

b'He had filled his pen and raised it the nib descending towards the paper before the sound came the gentle persistent tapping of the gnarled primeval willow touching the window with long insistent fingers'
b'His eyes awoke with a passionate determined flame though the only light came from the glutted moon'
b'Allan filled page after page the words escaping from his mind onto the paper'
b'Where before they had marched in regiments practiced in ranks and followed their leaders commands the words now escaped in their true forms unhindered by any stricture'
b'He continued long into the night until the eldritch orb had sunk into the waiting hands of the willow raised perpetually skyward'
b'Arthur looked up from the results of a night\xe2\x80\x99s frenzied labors and looked Allan in the eye'
b'What is this'
b'he queried indicating the pages he held in his left hand'

b'I decided that\xe2\x80\xa6 since I wasnt having much success with more \xe2\x80\x93 traditional \xe2\x80\x93 stories I might see what sort of work I produced if I let my imagination go freely Allan replied somewhat less selfassured than he had been the previous night'
b'I decided that\xe2\x80\xa6 since I wasnt having much success with more \xe2\x80\x93 traditional \xe2\x80\x93 stories I might see what sort of work I produced if I let my imagination go freely'
b'What in Gds name could have possessed you to do such a thing cried Arthur nearly raising his voice'
b'What in Gds name could have possessed you to do such a thing'
b'After all I said the day before why have you abandoned centuries of literary progress for some selfindulgent fantasy'
b'He shook the papers at Allan raising them like a belt above the head of a disobedient son'
b'This is nothing but a glorified Grimms tale a miscarried child of Stoker a creation less fit to be published than to be told around an open fire at the hovel of some peasant'
b'He spoke the last word with such heavy intonation that Allan shrank back before the physical wave of sound emanating from Arthurs throat'
b'Do you hate the modern system of literature'
b'Do you personally despise the works the Enlightenment or the progress made since Shakespeare'
b'Do you personally despise the works the Enlightenment or the progress made since Shakespeare'
b'For a moment Allan could hardly do more than shake his head'
b'No of course not\xe2\x80\xa6 I\xe2\x80\x93 '
b'Then why Arthur barreled on do you disregard them all and return to this superstitious babble this morbid paganistic drivel'
b'Then why'
b'do you disregard them all and return to this superstitious babble this morbid paganistic drivel'
b'Why do you disregard my warnings my careful advice given in the best of friendship and designed only to save you from sinking into this very type of corruption this literary debauchery'
b'He glared at Allan eyes impaling him and demanding a response'
b'Could you write decent tales with that willow at your window'
b'Allan cried out at last stepping forward and casting his arms open confronting Arthur with this demanding pleading interrogation'
b'Its twigs rap constantly against the wall the wind always demanding my attention'
b'How could any writer accommodate the edicts of popular literature with the very forces of nature knocking upon his door'
b'Arthur looked down his nose at the distraught author viewing his complaint with pure disdain scantily concealed by the veneer of politeness that animated the construct that was Arthur Mason'
b'A tree'
b'A tree forced you to write this my dear Mr Clemm'
b'I must admit this seems farfetched even by your standards \xe2\x80\x93 even your Nathan might have difficulty believing you'
b'You dont know what this is like said Allan shaking his head'
b'You dont know what this is like'
b'Nathan would understand completely'
b'Even as he said it Allan prayed that his statement was true'
b'Very well said Arthur then take your story to that hedonist and let him defend you when no civilized publisher will approach you'
b'Very well'
b'then take your story to that hedonist and let him defend you when no civilized publisher will approach you'
b'If you insist on abandoning me I shall not hold you'
b'With that he tossed the papers at Allan and left the room'
b'Stunned Allan slowly gathered up the pages and placed them in order'

b'He then turned and left through the door opposite that Arthur had taken making his way past his hosts doorman without assistance and setting off on foot towards Nathans residence several miles away'
b'Nathan read the package of words in silence his only motions the steady progress of his eyes and occasional replacement of pages'
b'Allan sat nervously across from him in a chair Nathan had probably upholstered himself a patchwork design of fabric containing easily more stuffing than any other furniture item of the period'
b'At long last Nathan reached the end and set down his reading on the table between them'
b'Allan leaned forward unconsciously'
b'Its the best story youve ever written'
b'Allan exhaled and leaned back into the chair his face relaxing in imitation of his thoughts'
b'So he asked you dont think its a waste of ink and paper a futile expedition into morbidity or literary debauchery'
b'So'
b'you dont think its a waste of ink and paper a futile expedition into morbidity or literary debauchery'
b'Heavens no said Nathan aghast'
b'Heavens no'
b'This is one of the strongest works Ive read in ages'
b'It speaks to the deepest storytellers instinct within us all yet is entirely original'
b'My dear friend you have done it'
b'Oh they may rail against you at first they may decry you as a heathen or a literary savage but while those in power say such things others will read your tales and see their true worth'
b'Believe me when I say that you will be read a century from now'
b'Allan though dubious as to that possibility felt some temptation from the compliment mainly it granted him the encouragement he still needed'
b'Nathan promised to show the story to a printer he knew and Allan left it with him then walked home under the spreading maples with a smile lingering on his face'
b'He felt now that perhaps Nathan was right although the man was somewhat peculiar he had both an unimpeachable honesty and a certain propensity for insight'
b'Certainly it was undeniable that the stories had an originality to them'
b'His minds strangest fruit had ripened at last and he found the taste less bitter than expected'
b'These thoughts and others like them filled his head as he walked the long road home'
b'It was evening and the sky burned orange in the west when he neared home at last'
b'Passionate fiery colors filled the western sky before him though the sun itself had reached the trees and a few dark clouds circled overhead'

b'As Allan drew closer he distinguished a new cloud a pillar rising directly ahead a road of smoke ascended in the west its source hidden by the very hillock that concealed his house from the traveler until one had nearly reached its door'
b'Allans thoughts fled as one scattering on the breeze that scattered the warning plume'

b'He ran the last distance crested the hill puffing to reveal Arthur below walking to the carriage parked before Allans house as two laborers wrapped a great saw in oilcloths and loaded it onto the vehicles roof'
b'Arthur paused in the door looking up at Allan for a moment then he turned and shut the door behind him'
b'The driver snapped the reins and set the horses on'
b'As they trotted forth Allans eyes remained trapped by the carriage following it up the hillock and past himself'
b'The heavy curtains had been drawn across its windows'
b'He watched as the carriage drew still more distant the horses hooves still kicking up dust along the roadway'
b'When they had gone he remained stunned until the scent of woodsmoke recalled him to himself'
b'He turned to regard the pillar still rising behind his house and ran to see what had been done'
b'Rounding the corner he saw a great bonfire'
b'A mass of flaming wood stood before him heat singeing him and sparks flying too close to his house'
b'It was a moment before he realized what else had changed near the wall beneath his window was a stump with black and ancient bark'
b'In a thoughtless panic Allan flew to the stream that ran by his house and began frantically throwing handfuls of water onto the pyre'

b'His thoughts were not of the acts futility nor even of the nights spent tormented by the twisted thing instead all that filled his mind was the trees constant presence in his life growing with him and beside him its persistent reminders that he had higher truer things to write the simple beauty of the great black tree for its own sake'

b'His handfuls could do nothing to quench the hewn burning logs but when the night sky grew dark above him and the fire dwindled to black ashes tears threatened to spill forth and extinguish the final embers'
b'But he did not weep'
b'Instead he bethought himself of the loss of the tree considered also Arthurs motivation and whether some good might not come of this after all'
b'Leaving the circle of ashes he stood and turned towards the woods in which it was his habit to walk when in a pensive mood'

b'He stepped slowly beneath the branches a gust of wind stirring up the ashes behind him in a great swirling eddy a burning brand that rose up and dispersed on the winds as though it were the willows last breath'
b'Allan wandered beneath the trees for a time thoughts drifting through his mind like great banks of fog strangely beautiful but impossible to penetrate'

b'He considered Arthurs intervention considered that it might be better to accept the fog and continue as his lifelong friend had suggested to write stories that others would read for after all what purpose writing if not to be read'
b'And without that torturous willow he might be free to write whatever he saw fit'
b'Indeed if he still could not he could at any time follow Arthurs advice and seek a profession more grounded in reality'
b'Perhaps that would be more healthy for his mind'
b'He found himself along the bank of a low wide stream and allowed himself to follow its current'

b'As it turned to the deeper woods elder giants rose above him a beech smooth bark a graygreen pennant hoisted on a slope and standing out between the dark cracked trunks of the nearer trees great pines a few magnificent specimens still bearing the threestroke symbol of the British King a towering black birch leaves impossibly high above him'

b'As the stream wound its way through the largest pines grown so great as to eclipse that feature of the landscape they had once crowded about for sweet water as saplings Allan continued slowing his pace to climb across the toes of the slumbering giants'
b'There was hardly enough room for his slim frame between the trunks that overshadowed any fleeting mortal trespass'
b'Emerging from between the antediluvian trunks Allan set his feet softly down onto the carpet of needles and stopped'
b'Before him roots imbibing the sweet water of the stream grew a stand of black willows'

b'Fallen trunks lay rotting across the rivulet the living elders oversaw the grove while younger trees still small and not yet as knotted and gnarled as their forefathers sprang up where branches reached the ground'
b'Though the elders trunks fell and died their children first roots grown from the very branches that now lay dead continued unabated a continuous line from the most ancient of their ancestors'
b'Allan stumbled forward jaw slightly slack until his outstretched hands encountered the rough bark of a twisted threetrunked willow whose waists were each larger than Allan himself'

b'Collapsing at its base Allan wrapped his arms around the stoic tree and let forth a moan a cry of purest agony that escaped him as the first tears seeped from the corners of his eyes and slid down his cheeks falling to the ground and seeping though the fallen leaves and needles to join the water of the stream flowing through the ground beneath them'

b'He has no time to waste'

b'With the help of friends like you Goodwill has continued to adapt our services to meet the human needs of our changing society'
b'We dont waste time as we are helping the community'
b'And we dont waste money'
b'The gift that I am asking you to make will be used to continue our mission of helping people prepare for find and keep jobs'
b'In their December 1995 review of the nations best charities US News  World Report called Goodwill one of the five Standout Good Guys'
b'The magazine stated that Goodwill as well as the other standouts is uniquely effective innovative or valuable'
b'While I appreciate US News  World Reports endorsement the true value of your support is measured by the way Goodwill takes on problems that affect all of us'
b'Every time we help someone find a solution to their employment barrier the positive effects radiate throughout our community'
b'The business community welcomes not only another worker but a consumer with increased purchasing power'
b'Parents act as role models of selfsufficiency instead of dependency'
b'Tax dollars that would have been spent on public assistance are saved'
b'You and I know that solutions to difficult problems dont just happen'
b'At Goodwill it is the hard work of staff and those who benefit from our services that produces the kind of inspiring results I see every day'
b'A Goodwill staff member addresses a group of welfare recipients'
b'You can earn the money to support yourself and your family she says'
b'You can get off welfare'

b'I did'

b'once his tears have subsided he confirms what his classmates have already figured out he just received a job offer  his first in five years'
b'Addressing a meeting at a neighborhood center a Goodwill staff member tells the audience how Goodwill can help them find and keep jobs'
b'At the next corner he tells five more'

b'Eventually he turns your support into a payoff for all of us'

b'Just like the respect weve earned from US News  World Report'

b'Real results'
b'A real difference in peoples lives  in all of our lives'

b'Think of your greatest accomplishments'
b'Think of the joy and success they bring to you and your loved ones'
b'Michael Sims felt that way at age 39  the day he earned a job'
b'Michael was born with cerebral palsy'
b'Upon entering the work force he discovered few job opportunities that seemed to match his abilities'
b'For several years he performed packaging and clerical work'
b'His most recent job lasted only a year before cutbacks eliminated his position'
b'For 18 long months Michael could not find a job'
b'He resorted to public assistance dollars to survive'
b'Finally Michael called Goodwill'
b'At Goodwill Michaels counselors felt that his personable demeanor could be a major attribute and identified for him a possible jobmatch where his people skills could shine'
b'After three interviews Michael proved that he was the right person for the job'
b'As the Clubhouse Monitor at Bent Tree Apartments he now provides customer service for 50 to 60 tenants each night'
b'At last he has found success in a job that he loves'
b'Now his goals are set on moving up in the company'
b'Every year thousands of people come to Goodwill'
b'Like Michael they share two common characteristics'
b'They face some barrier to employment and they want to work'
b'With support from people like you they can overcome their barriers and earn success and the selfsufficiency that comes with it'
b'And then the payoff begins for the entire community'
b'Individual successes at Goodwill mean fewer persons receiving public support and more paying taxes'
b'Last year participants in Goodwill programs earned and paid taxes on  wages of nearly 35 million'
b'Their successes at work also saved taxpayers more than threequarters of a million dollars in public assistance'
b'The savings are counted in more ways than dollars and cents however'

b'The families of the new wage earners may feel the accomplishment in terms of a house to live in money to purchase food  without food stamps  and the beginning of a family focused on success not hopelessness'
b'Wont you help make all of these successes possible'
b'Please send the largest contribution you can comfortably make'
b'Your gift will help give new meaning to the word success  for people who have seldom had reason to use the word'
b'Sincerely'
b'James M McClelland President'

b'Your gift will make a difference'
b'For every dollar of public support Goodwill received last year we returned 159 to the community in the form of earned wages and reduced public assistance payments'
b'Some of the strongest critics of our welfare system are the people who have become dependent on it'

b'Thats where you and Goodwill come in'
b'We help people train for and find jobs that make it possible for them to get off of welfare'

b'We need your support to continue getting people off of public assistance'
b'Welfare is not the answer'

b'When Jerry was released from prison he knew it would take hard work and determination to straighten out his life'
b'He knew he had made a bad mistake but despite his commitment to rebuilding his life he just didnt count on the obstacles that would be thrown up in his path'
b'Reality hit when he was unable to reconcile with his wife and ended up on the street'
b'He went to the Center Township Trustee for food stamps until he could find a job and a place to live'
b'The Trustee referred him to the Blue Triangle where he consulted Goodwills Career Academy staff for job search assistance'
b'Jerrys Goodwill caseworker found him a job immediately'
b'But Jerrys troubles didnt end there'
b'The seasonal construction job he obtained soon ended and he returned to Career Academy for help once more'
b'Unemployed homeless and with a prison record Jerry now faced going back to prison for failure to pay child support'
b'It took some time and hard work but with the help of Goodwill Jerry was able to work out a payment plan with the prosecutors office find housing and conduct a more thorough job search'
b'With unemployment at its lowest point in years in central Indiana many people still have a hard time finding meaningful employment'
b'Of the more than 42000 people Goodwill served in 1999 over 5000 of them have multiple barriers to finding and keeping a job'
b'Some like Jerry are exoffenders'
b'Some are blind deaf or have other physical disabilities'
b'More than 100 were homeless'
b'But Goodwill offers hope even to people with numerous obstacles to overcome like Jerry'

b'With a promising new job at a plastic injection molding manufacturer his legal troubles in check and a safe place to live Jerry can get on with the business of building a life for himself and contributing to his community'

b'Your generosity will help people help themselves'

b'Do you remember the combination of elation and apprehension you felt when you first left home'
b'The young adults who leave Pleasant Run have those same feelings'
b'Very few have family support to get them started'
b'Many need furniture linens and other basic necessities to begin lives on their own'

b'To help them establish themselves in the community the Pleasant Run Emancipation fund was begun in 1993 by private donors who wanted to provide a measure of financial support for those leaving our programs'
b'Individuals who are being emancipated are eligible to receive up to 500 from the Fund if they formally apply and meet four requirements'
b'1 Release by the courts'
b'2 Successful completion of all life skills tests'
b'3 Positive termination of his or her Pleasant Run program'
b'4 Possession of a high school diploma or GED'

b'Proof of meeting these two staff reference letters and an essay stating why they should receive a grant and how it will be used are all reviewed by a Pleasant Run panel which determines if the applicant merits the funds'
b'Such fund are often used for college tuition vocational training or a deposit on an apartment'
b'Because Pleasant Run is the only family for so many our Emancipation Fund is one way we can help a young person take the first steps into his or her new life as an independent and productive adult'
b'Without private donor support this Fund doesnt exist'
b'Please take a few minutes to send a donation to help one or more of our children successfully cross that threshold into the future'
b'Sincerely'
b'Mary Roth Executive Director'

b'What kind of people benefit by your contribution to Pleasant Run Childrens Homes'

b'Young adults like Mary T a jobless mother of three trying desperately to keep her kids out of trouble in a crimeridden neighborhood'

b'Kids like Tommie J made a ward of the court because of repeated beatings by an alcoholic father'
b'Alice sent to a group home to get help because of severe behavior disorders'
b'and John H a recovering alcoholic rebuilding a relationships with his family so they can live together again'
b'Pleasant Run Childrens Homes began serving children nearly 130 years ago'
b'Then the task was to help children who lost parents in the Civil War'
b'Today we serve children and families with a multitude of problems emotional physical psychological and sexual abuse'
b'Some come from families where through therapy there is hope for reunification'
b'For others families are the counselors are housemates at the group homes where they live'
b'The biggest tragedy is that the problems dont go away they only grow'
b'In 1995 we will serve over 850 children and 340 families'
b'In 1996 these figures will triple'
b'The children and families who come to Pleasant Run are given the opportunity to become happy loving and productive members of our society'
b'They welcome the chance to belong to become self sufficient to regain their selfesteem and confidence'
b'Often it is a long hard struggle but the results are well worth it'

b'Sincerely'
b'Mary Roth'

b'The goal of MCCOY Inc has been to make a difference'
b'In 1998 MCCOY Inc led two efforts that we believe will help our community continue to take the steps necessary to help all young people grow up and develop well'

b'Participants in the Youth Outcomes Educational Initiative identified three goals for all our youth to obtain economic selfsufficiency healthy family social relationships and involvement in the community'

b'A short time later the Community Youth Mapping Project sent 55 young people out into the community to identify the resources they need to grow up well caring adults safe places to go and positive things to do'

b'One group of adults and one group of youth through two very different processes have arrived at the same conclusion our community still has much to do if we are to help ALL of your youth successfully develop into the responsible productive adults who will our community in the future'
b'As a provider of youth services MCCOY Inc is here to support your valuable efforts to develop young people'

b'Recently through a lot of hard work and alliances with organizations like yours some steps have been taken in our community that will help young people continue to be involved in positive activities'
b'One IndyGo in April adopted a muchneeded policy that all young people under the age of 19 may ride on their buses at half the normal fare all year long'
b'Two funding was made available this summer for youth organizations and churches to conduct positive youth programming on Saturday evenings'
b'Through the youth mapping process it was confirmed that the positive opportunities for youth on weekend evenings were lacking'
b'That need is being met'
b'As it has been an exciting year for all of us MCCOY Inc cannot do its part without the support of organizations like yours'
b'Annually we ask several of our youth serving organizations to join us in our effort to help young people grow up well in Indianapolis'
b'Enclosed is a donation card that will enable you to make Indianapolis a great place for ALL of us to live'
b'If you have any questions or concerns at any time please do not hesitate to call me at 9211288'

b'As you begin that process this year I would like to ask you to consider helping young people in Marion County toward more positive youth development by becoming a supporter of the Marion County Commission on Youth Inc'
b'MCCOY Inc originally founded as a government agency but reorganized in 1993 as an independent notforprofit is a countywide youth services coordinating planning and convening agency'

b'Dear Name'
b'In the summer of 1993 the Marion County Commission on Youth began what can best be described as a new era in its history'
b'MCCOY was reorganized as an independent notforprofit agency separate from local government'
b'It retained however the same mission with which it had been charged from its inception to serve as a catalyst for effective coordinated and collaborative service delivery to youth in our community'

b'For the past three years MCCOY has been actively engaged in accomplishing this declared mission in cooperation with many others youth service providers youth funding bodies and interested citizens to name a few'
b'We have met with a number of successes along the way most notably the Summer Fun Line the Metro Summer Bus Pass and the development of ten neighborhood youth councils'
b'A Providers Council and a Youth Coalition are building relationships that will hopefully bear great fruit in the years to come'

b'The formation of The Community Academy a pilot project directed at expelled students from local school systems has come about as a result of MCCOYs efforts to mobilize community agencies in response to a pressing issue'

b'McCoy is actively represented and working with numerous community collaborations where we regularly raise our voice to speak out for the inclusion of young people in both decisionmaking and program planning processes'
b'One concrete example is a joint project undertaken in the United Northwest Area in partnership with The Junior League of Indianapolis and Community Partnerships with Youth from Fort Wayne Indiana'

b'As a team these three organizations are working with neighborhood youth and adults to build a Caring Neighborhood with Youth  mobilizing the assets of young people and adults as partners to build a better neighborhood for all'

b'Since its reorganization MCCOY has established its unique niche within the community by refraining from direct service programming and focusing on what it does best helping to identify youth needs convening groups of individuals and organizations which can address those needs and moving toward collaborative solutions'
b'McCoy has only one interest the well being of Marion Countys young people'
b'McCoy invites the support of The  Company Foundation in the amount of 1000000 to support such activities as'
b' the coordination of youth leadership training and youth empowerment efforts at the neighborhood level by means of neighborhoodbased youth councils'
b' the promotion of youth employment opportunities'
b' the facilitation of ongoing discussions regarding effective and efficient youth service delivery'
b' the provision of technical assistance and guidance to neighborhoods which seek positive youthadult relationships'
b' the development of communitywide supports for the positive growth of all Marion County young people'
b'In the last several years the business and corporate community has recognized that the positive development of youth is directly related to the development of a competent workforce'
b'Youth who are supported and encouraged by both a family and a society that values Them have a much greater likelihood of becoming productive and contributing members of adult society'
b'While we have made significant inroads there remains much to be done and it is clear that we cannot do it alone'
b'We seek the financial support of the Foundation to help us be successful in creating the atmosphere in our community where young people can grow and develop well'
b'In our fund raising efforts to date we have received the support of local government foundations and corporations as well as the personal financial commitments of individual MCCOY Board members'
b'We believe there is no more appropriate time to have a coordinated and collaborative effort to financially support the services MCCOY offers to the community as a whole'
b'Thanking you in advance for your support we remain'
b'Sincerely'
b'John T Neighbours Philip B Roby President Treasurer'
b'John F Brandon Executive Director'

b'Its tough growing up today'
b'We know that children do better when they have a network of caring adults to nurture and motivate them'
b'When young people dont have that support they need other resources for encouragement to guide them along the way'
b'Big Sisters helps bridge that gap by providing children with the resources they need  Big Sisters volunteers'
b'Big Sisters are mentors and friends who empower girls to more fully reach their potential experience lifes opportunities and perhaps begin to dream'
b'The relationships that are formed provide strong foundations from which healthy values and strong selfconfidence can grow helping youth become strong independent adults of tomorrow'
b'This year we will serve over 1000 girls through our mentoring programs'
b'This is an impressive number but for each girl served more are left unserved'
b'Over 150 girls are currently waiting for a Big Sister'
b'You can make an impact by supporting Big Sisters Annual Campaign and our 200000 goal'
b'If you are a regular contributor to the Annual Campaign I encourage you to consider increasing your gift by 10'
b'If you have not supported Big Sisters in the past please join me in doing so by completing and returning the enclosed pledge form'
b'Early adolescence is the most vulnerable age for youth'
b'But caring adults like you can reach out and help'
b'Its the perfect time to make a world of difference'
b'Sincerely'
b'August 6 1998'
b'Dear Friend'
b'Adolescence'
b'It is a pivotal time in the life of a young girlwhen small changes in her behavior or the choices she makes can affect her future'
b'Its hard enough for her to make good decisions when shes surrounded by support'
b'Its even harder when she isnt'
b'Big Sisters helps fill that void by matching caring responsible adult volunteers with atrisk girls ages 814'
b'A Big Sister is a mentor a friend and a role model helping a young girl to develop the selfconfidence and life skills necessary to become a responsible productive and successful adult'
b'Your 1000 contribution can put a mentor in a childs lifeand hope in a childs future'

b'The results of an 18month study completed by PublicPrivate Ventures showed that children participating in onetoone Big Sister and Big Brother matches for just one year reduced first time drug use by 46 lowered school absenteeism by 52 cut aggressive behavior by 33 enhanced school performance and improved relations with family and friends'
b'This is positive proof that Big Sisters onetoone mentoring program helps change lives'
b'Today we are offering you the opportunity to help change a life'
b'By contributing 1000 you can support one match for one year'
b'This money maintains the infrastructure that fosters and supports the development of effective relationships'
b'This includes a volunteer screening process orientation training and ongoing supervision and support by a professional staff'
b'As a Matchmaker you will receive a description of your match and be identified as a Matchmaker on a plaque in the Big Sisters office in the agency newsletter and annual report'
b'Today Big Sisters serves over 1000 girls in central Indiana'
b'But for each girl served more are left unserved'
b'Over 235 girls are currently waiting for a Big Sister'
b'Imagine the difference the community could make if each congregation pledged its support of one Big Sisters match'
b'Sincerely'
b'Dr Linda McCoy Pastor THE GARDEN A Blossom of St Lukes United Methodist Church'

b'Understand the world and change it where it needs to be changed'
b'Make our society better'
b'Make a world worthy of the children that your generation will bear'
b' Carl Sagan'
b'You can help make positive changes in the lives of atrisk youth in central Indiana'
b'We often hear about economic poverty but what some of these young people are growing up with is emotional povertythey have often given up on hope and the possibility of a successful future'
b'With your help we can change that'
b'Many Little Sisters are preparing to go back to school this fall full of hope and with a positive outlook'
b'Thanks to our Big Sisters volunteers these young people are selfconfident believe in themselves and are beginning to realize their full potential'
b'A recent study by PublicPrivate Ventures PPV showed that girls who had a Big Sister for just one year'
b'reduced firsttime drug use by 46'
b'lowered school absenteeism by 52'
b'cut violent behavior by 33'
b'enhanced school performance showed improved peer and family relationships'

b'I was matched with my Big Sister in June of 1992'

b'I am very thankful to the Big Sisters program for allowing me this very special opportunity'

b'Dear Outdoor Enthusiast'

b'The Appalachian Mountain Club is looking for men women and children who share our love of the outdoors\xe2\x80\x94and our commitment to preserving our region\xe2\x80\x99s natural beauty for future generations'
b'Please use your Temporary Membership Card to \xe2\x80\x9cJoin the Club\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'And join the fun while making a real difference for the environment'
b'You name it\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99ve got it'
b'Our roots are in hiking'
b'And our roots go deep'
b'Only 50 million people lived in a country where Colorado had just become its 39th state'

b'From beginners to experts they are into hiking camping and backpacking crosscountry skiing and snowshoeing rock climbing and mountaineering canoeing kayaking and bicycling nature photography and birdwatching  and relaxing alongside nature'
b'Our mission is great'
b'With our volunteers we maintain 1400 miles of trails'
b'We provide overnight shelters including the famous AMC Mountain Huts to more than 80000 hikers annually'
b'We built our first hut more than 100 years ago in New Hampshire\xe2\x80\x99s northern Presidential Range and we helped protect the White Mountains so that they are still open to you now'
b'Today our unique network of 10 huts and lodges\xe2\x80\x94each a day\xe2\x80\x99s hike apart\xe2\x80\x94stretches 56 miles through the White Mountain National Forest'
b'And we offer the same hospitality atop beautiful Mt Greylock in the Berkshires'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re partnering with agencies and other organizations to introduce innercity youth to the fun of the outdoors in Boston Philadelphia and New York City'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re helping to develop'
b' the Northern Forest Canoe Trail from Old Forge New York to Fort Kent Maine '
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re helping to protect the Sterling Forest in New York'
b'And we\xe2\x80\x99re working with the National Park Service in upgrading the trail system in the Delaware Water Gap and Acadia National Park in Maine'

b'We\xe2\x80\x99re determined to conserve the Northern Forest of Maine New Hampshire Vermont and New York as well as the White and Berkshire ranges and the countryside surrounding the Appalachian Trail'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re working to keep our air clean and healthy our waterfalls clear our rivers running free and recreational activities open'
b'Here in the Northeast we hold stewardship of a precious portion of planet Earth'
b'Contained within it are more than 100 species of trees more than 2000 species of plants and flowers'
b'Plus all the birds and animals of the forests and the fish of our rivers and lakes'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re committed to preserving a healthy environment that sustains us all'
b'The Call of the Wild'
b'Despite centuries of neglect\xe2\x80\x94wildlife still abounds in the 12 states where we are active'

b'His belly was empty'
b'So empty it hurt'
b'At least Astro could drink water from a puddle near the stake he was chained to'
b'But then the puddle dried up'
b'Astro had only a few days to live'
b'Dear Friend'
b'As you read my letter somewhere  perhaps not far from you someone is inflicting pain on an innocent animal  an animal like Astro'
b'You may not be able to rescue that particular animal'
b'But you CAN join the crusade to stop animal abuse and neglect by making a generous contribution to the ASPCA today'
b'I have sent you the enclosed complimentary nameandaddress labels to call your attention to the work of the ASPCA'
b'Please USE them on your correspondence to help get our name in front of as many people as possible'
b'Because the ASPCA  and the thousands of animals we help every year need all the friends we can get'
b'As a person who cares about animals you\xe2\x80\x99re probably anxious to know what happened to Astro'
b'A neighbor reported Astro\xe2\x80\x99s plight to the ASPCA and our Humane Law Enforcement officers went to investigate'
b'When our officers arrived Astro was too weak to even stand up'
b'The officers knelt down slowly speaking gently to the emaciated dog'
b'Then they saw it'
b'Astro was wagging his tail'
b'He was barely moving'
b'but yes  the poor sick dog was saying'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cWelcome friends\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The officers brought Astro to the ASPCA\xe2\x80\x99s Bergh Memorial Animal Hospital'
b'The dog weighted only 45 pounds  less than half of what a dog his size should weigh  and he had several infections'
b'But with firstrate medical attention and tender care from ASPCA staff he slowly got well again'
b'Stories like Astro\xe2\x80\x99s are all too common'
b'Every day the ASPCA gets reports of animal cruelty abuse and neglect'
b'Every day our officers rescue animals like Sammy a 10monthold kitten who was deliberately thrown from a highrise window by teenagers'
b'In a world where cruelty is common animals like Sammy and Astro desperately need friends like you'
b'That is why I have written to you  to ask you to support the ASPCA today'

b'Our vital anticruelty efforts are just part of the ASPCA mission We also find loving adoptive homes for rescued animals  provide firstrate veterinary care through our Bergh Memorial Animal Hospital  offer lowcost spay and neuter programs for cats and dogs  reach out to children teachers and parents through our Education Programs'
b'And we don\xe2\x80\x99t stop there'
b'The ASPCA pushes for the passage and strengthening of anticruelty laws so that crimes against animals will be treated with the seriousness they deserve'
b'Since the ASPCA was founded in 1866 as America\xe2\x80\x99 s first humane society ending cruelty has been our primary goal'
b'Today over 130 years later the scope of the problem is greater than ever'
b'The ASPCA urgently needs your help to push back the tide of violence against animals'
b'The task is too large for the ASPCA to handle without emergency assistance from dedicated friends'
b'That is why I\xe2\x80\x99m asking you to join the ASPCA today with your gift of 20 or more if at all possible'
b'Your contribution will help us rescue more animals like Astro  make sure the perpetrators of cruelty are brought to justice  nurse abused animals back to health and find them loving adoptive homes'
b'Please help the ASPCA with your most generous gift today  the animals are counting on you'
b'Sincerely Hawk DVM and CEO'
b'PSWe found Astro a wonderful adoptive home'
b'He is the pride and joy of this loving family'
b'Please accept the enclosed name stickers as our gift to you and use them to spread the word about the ASPCA and the animals we help  thank you'

b'20 POST CONSUMER WASTE'
b'I\xe2\x80\x99m outraged '
b'and I think you will be too'

b'Just imagine finding your favorite hiking trail or birding area littered with dead birds  among the hundreds of thousands of unsuspecting and innocent creatures who were unlucky enough to consume lethal doses of a slowacting poison spread in fields miles away'
b'And who plans to commit such a mass bird killing'
b'The US Department of Agriculture'
b'In fact the USDA has plans to spread poisoned rice in sunflower fields throughout the northern Great Plains targeting two million migrating blackbirds and threatening nearly 70 other bird species'
b'it\xe2\x80\x99s almost unthinkable that a program this reckless could be implemented  in view of the tragic impact that poisonous chemicals and pesticides like DDT have had on wildlife and people'

b'Thanks to the help of caring and concerned people like you Audubon won a temporary halt to this planned killing last spring  but the USDA\xe2\x80\x99s plans could be up and running for the next blackbird migration unless we act now'

b'Let me tell you exactly what\xe2\x80\x99s at stake  and how this could set a dangerous precedent First of all you might wonder why blackbirds are not benefiting from the Migratory Bird Treaty Act\xe2\x80\x99s prohibition against actions that cause intentional harm'
b'You see the USDA found a loophole allowing these protections to be lifted for \xe2\x80\x9cexperimental\xe2\x80\x9d activities'

b'So they applied for the right to spread poison as Dart of a \xe2\x80\x9cscientific experiment\xe2\x80\x9d  to learn whether lowering the population of blackbirds by poisoning them will reduce sunflower crop loss'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cscientific experiment\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Can you believe it'
b'The USDA wants to conduct an \xe2\x80\x9cexperiment\xe2\x80\x9d that will spread enough poison in our environment to kill two million blackbirds'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cexperiment\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'And if the death of two million birds doesn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cprove\xe2\x80\x9d their theory  and show a reduction in crop loss  they\xe2\x80\x99ll likely seek the right to kill even more birds the next year'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cprove\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s time to tell the USDA in no uncertain terms'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cYOU WILL NOT CONDUCT MASSIVE BIRD KILLS TO BENEFIT A HANDFUL OF SPECIAL INTERESTS\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Because the USDA\xe2\x80\x99s slowacting pesticide takes three days to kill its victims will likely fly many miles from the poisoned fields before falling to the ground'
b'Meanwhileblackbirds aren\xe2\x80\x99t the only birds threatened directly by the poison'

b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve noted the presence of 68 other species of grassland songbirds in the proposed poisonbaited areas  including the Bobolink Grasshopper Sparrow Harris\xe2\x80\x99 Sparrow and Le Conte\xe2\x80\x99s Sparrow'
b'In all nine birds on the Federal threatened or endangered lists and 11 birds on Audubon\xe2\x80\x99s WatchList of imperiled species could be found in these killing fields'
b'We simply cannot afford to let the government repeat the mistakes of the past  and operate this deadly and uncontrolled experiment on wildlife'
b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s what I need you to do to make sure we prevail First I need you to sign and return your Petition to the US Secretary of Agriculture'

b'I\xe2\x80\x99ll forward your Petition along with those from thousands of other Audubon members and supporters urging the USDA to withdraw its cruel plan to poison blackbirds  in favor of alternative benign methods of protecting sunflower crops'
b'I can assure you that thousands of Audubon Petitions can make a difference  just as they did in a successful battle against an adverse wetlands proposal a few years ago'

b'But today\xe2\x80\x99s battle is one we must win  to block a dangerous experiment that would begin to erase 50 years of steady progress eliminating pesticides and other harmful chemicals from our environment'

b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll also agree to help even more by making a taxdeductible gift to support this crucial initiative and all of Audubon\xe2\x80\x99s vital conservation work to protect birds other wildlife and habitat'
b'And with a donation of 15 or more you\xe2\x80\x99ll receive a FREE Birdfeeder in appreciation for your concern'
b'I\xe2\x80\x99ll make sure your gift is put right to work in our efforts to'
b'\xc2\xb7Win a ban on the USDA bird poisoning'
b'\xc2\xb7Gain strict enforcement of wildlife laws'
b'\xc2\xb7Ensure wildlife programs are based on sound science'
b'\xc2\xb7Monitor the health of Audubon\xe2\x80\x99s WatchList species'
b'\xc2\xb7Conserve America\xe2\x80\x99s remaining grassland habitat'
b'And Audubon will draw upon its centurylong track record of highly effective conservation work to make a real difference in other key areas'
b'Audubon protects birds'

b'Your help will be instrumental to our bird conservation work designating Important Bird Areas to protect vital habitat  maintaining the WatchList of bird species near endangered status wwwaudubonorg birdwatch  and engaging citizen participation in the vast BirdSource database of North American bird trends'
b'Audubon rescues endangered wildlife'
b'Nearly 25 years ago the National Audubon Society helped win passage of the Endangered Species Act'
b'With your help Audubon will remain committed to wildlife laws and regulations that are well funded properly implemented and strongly enforced'
b'Audubon establishes and protects wildlife refuges and sanctuaries'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cAudubon is truly making a difference for wildlife refuges everywhere\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'And your support will help sustain our innovative Audubon Refuge Keepers program and maintain our own network of more than 100 wildlife centers and sanctuaries'
b'Audubon restores wetlands'
b'Wetlands are not only crucial to wildlife  they also help purify our drinking water and prevent billions of dollars worth of flood damage'
b'Your gift today will help us reach our goal to restore one million acres of irreplaceable wetlands'
b'Audubon educates the public'
b'Teaching Americans particularly young people  how to become better stewards of our environment is one of the best investments that you and I can make for wildlife'
b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why we\xe2\x80\x99re expanding our network of Audubon Centers to reach children and adults in every corner of the nation'

b'And of course your support will enable Audubon to stand ready to act whenever a wildlife crisis emerges like the USDA\xe2\x80\x99s bird poisoning proposal that I\xe2\x80\x99m asking you to help us defeat today'
b'So let me urge you to do your part by supporting a group that the San Francisco Chronicle calls \xe2\x80\x9cone of America\xe2\x80\x99s most respected and influential conservation organizations'
b'Firstsign and return your Petition to the Secretary of Agriculture immediately to declare a firm and resounding \xe2\x80\x9cNO\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNO\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'to the USDA\xe2\x80\x99s bird poisoning plan'
b'And I also hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll take a second important step today by supporting Audubon\xe2\x80\x99s vital conservation work with a generous taxdeductible gift'
b'Thank you'
b'Very truly yours'

b'This morning I closed my office door to interruptions sat alone at my desk and did something I think will please you and everyone in your home'

b'I thought about our new enhanced local efforts our expanding scientific research and educational programs our fresh new writing in AUDUBON magazine'

b'I\xe2\x80\x99m inviting you back to full membership for just 17  51 off the regular rate'
b'By accepting my personal invitation you\xe2\x80\x99ll provide yourself and every member of your family with a fulfilling sense of proprietorship and a steady flow of priceless enjoyment'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll once again be enthralled by the striking photography and insightful environmental journalism that makes our exclusive magazine AUDUBON a treasure worth saving'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s already won the prestigious National Magazine Award not once but four times '

b'This awardwinning style is evident in every issue with behindtheheadlines reporting passionate coverage of the environment exotic journeys to remote places you may never otherwise experience and of course in AUDUBON\xe2\x80\x99s famous photography of nature\xe2\x80\x99s most aweinspiring creations'
b'Bring beauty mystery adventure and the natural world back in your life'

b'You may have missed learning the mysteries of the spectacled eider a duck with an uncertain future  missed traveling with us to Asia where we found and followed the last wild tigers missed marveling at the magic of mangroves missed discovering in Peru the newest bird known to science the barbet but you won\xe2\x80\x99t miss a thing anymore'
b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve had a look at the magazine\xe2\x80\x99s upcoming subjects and I can tell you the best is yet to come'
b'From what I see the magazine\xe2\x80\x99s editorial staff and fresh new look and content may soon be granted a fifth National Magazine Award'
b'There\xe2\x80\x99s much more to membership than AUDUBON magazine'

b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll be protecting preserving and promoting America\xe2\x80\x99s wetlands endangered species ancient forests our National Wildlife Refuges the Everglades and the Platte River our Living Oceans Program and much more'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll be supporting sanctuaries field research environmental education and legislation and many other vital efforts critical to the protection of wildlife and their habitats'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll also be educating youngsters in 15000 schools across America \xe2\x80\x94 most likely some in your own school district'
b'By accepting my special invitation to join again you\xe2\x80\x99ll receive special invitations to our sanctuaries and Ecology Camps \xe2\x80\x94 and FREE ADMISSION to our Nature Centers'
b'There you\xe2\x80\x99ll have the rewarding opportunity to study with Audubon experts and take part in workshops of special interest to you'

b'What\xe2\x80\x99s more you\xe2\x80\x99ll receive FREE MEMBERSHIP in your local chapter there are more than 500 Audubon chapters nationwide \xe2\x80\x94 with access to field trips and activities everyone in your family will enjoy'
b'There\xe2\x80\x99s still more'
b'Special travel opportunities and special FREE'
b'membership in the Audubon Activist Network will also be yours'
b'Incredibly all this is possible for just 517'
b'Think of all the ways everyone in your household will benefit from your membership in Audubon'
b'And then please take advantage of this opportunity to regain full membership for 51 less than the regular rate'
b'We simply can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to lose you'
b'May we become partners once again'
b'I\xe2\x80\x99ll be waiting for your reply'
b'Sincerely John Flicker'

b'ALASKA EMERGENCY'
b'Dear Defender'
b'Look closely at this photo and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see a wolf  running'
b'Soon this wolf won\xe2\x80\x99t be merely running in the snow'
b'This wolf will be running for its life'
b'The airplane above will be tracking her  in order to land and immediately gun her down '
b'You see the Alaska legislature passed a law that once again allows any private citizen with just a 15 trapping or 25 hunting license to track wolves by aircraft and then land and gun them down'
b'This cruel unethical wolfhunting practice is called \xe2\x80\x9csameday airborne landandshoot\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9csameday airborne landandshoot\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'It was a total shock and surprise'
b'In May the Alaska legislature voted to reinstate sameday airborne wolf killing'
b'But they did overriding Governor Tony Knowles\xe2\x80\x99 veto \xe2\x80\x94 and ignoring the will of the majority of Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s citizens'
b'Unfortunately this practice will begin after the first snow  this September  when wolves will be \xe2\x80\x9ccan\xe2\x80\x99tmiss\xe2\x80\x9d targets against Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s snowy terrain'
b'\xe2\x80\x9ccan\xe2\x80\x99tmiss\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Wolves can run fast \xe2\x80\x94 but they certainly can\xe2\x80\x99t outrun airplanes'
b'Given the urgency of the situation in Alaska Defenders needs your immediate assistance to help save Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s wolves from sameday airborne landandshoot slaughter'
b'Support the Emergency Effort to Save Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s Wolves'
b'Defenders hopes to raise at least 100000 to help Alaskans For Wildlife a coalition of Alaska citizens win a citizens\xe2\x80\x99 ballot initiative this November'
b'And we face very wealthy opponents'

b'So today I urge you to do these two things FIRST Sign the enclosed Citizens\xe2\x80\x99 Advisory Ballot to show our Alaska allies your strong personal support to reinstate the ban on \xe2\x80\x9csameday airborne landandshoot\xe2\x80\x9d wolf killing in Alaska SECOND Rush an urgent donation to help put this measure on the ballot and win passage in November'
b'\xe2\x80\x9csameday airborne landandshoot\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The Alaska Legislature is completely out of step with the will of Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s citizens and the American public at large'
b'Like you the majority of Alaskans oppose sameday landandshoot wolf killing'
b'But the antiwolf politicians in the Alaska legislature don\xe2\x80\x99t care what the majority of Alaska citizens want'
b'And they didn\xe2\x80\x99t listen to the recommendations of the Alaska Department of Fish and Game which opposed this legislation'
b'They are utterly out of step with their Alaska constituents  the state agency that manages Alaska wildlife  and the rest of the American public'

b'In the name of \xe2\x80\x9cwolf control\xe2\x80\x9d wolf killers will predictably once again use aircraft to hunt wolves to the point of exhaustion so that the wolves have literally no chance of survival'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cwolf control\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'And if history is any guide over the years thousands of Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s wolves will be brutally killed'
b'Before the 1996 ban on sameday landandshoot as many as 400 wolves were killed in Alaska each year because of this barbaric and unethical practice'
b'Antiwolf interests are prepared to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to make sure that the new landandshoot law stands \xe2\x80\x94 even though most Alaskans do not support it'
b'So if we don\xe2\x80\x99t act right now Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s snowy tundras will once again become bloody killing fields for wolves in America\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLast Frontier\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cLast Frontier\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Say \xe2\x80\x9cNO\xe2\x80\x9d to the barbaric practice of sameday airborne wolf killing'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cNO\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The only way Alaskans can repeal the new law and reinstate the ban on sameday airborne landandshoot wolf killing is with a Citizens\xe2\x80\x99 Referendum'
b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why your special financial support is so important \xe2\x80\x94 and urgently needed'
b'Alaska wolf advocates need your immediate support to save wolves'
b'As I mentioned this new sameday airborne landandshoot practice will start in September after the opening of hunting season and the first snow \xe2\x80\x94 and when wolves will be an easy target'
b'To repeal this unconscionable law Defenders must help provide our friends in Alaska  Alaskans For Wildlife \xe2\x80\x94 with the resources necessary to win at the polls in November'
b'Our wellfunded opponents will spend whatever it takes to mislead and confuse voters about this ballot measure'

b'We need help to supplement the funds raised by Alaskans For Wildlife for careful polling the development of voter education spots for television radio and newspapers the placement of those ads and \xe2\x80\x9cgetoutthevote\xe2\x80\x9d efforts on election day'
b'If Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s new law is not replaced thousands of Alaskas wolves will die in the years to come'
b'And it will be a major setback for wolves nationwide \xe2\x80\x94 at a time when the American public overwhelmingly favors wolf reintroduction and protection'
b'A loss will encourage those antiwolf fanatics who want to stop wolf restoration and put bounties on those wolves already in the wild'
b'So please don\xe2\x80\x99t wait another minute'
b'Please sign your Citizens\xe2\x80\x99 Advisory Ballot to demonstrate to our Alaska allies that you\xe2\x80\x99re behind them and send an urgent donation today to help them win this effort'
b'So how will your money be spent'

b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s the projected budget breakdown 35000 \xe2\x80\x94 indepth statewide survey conducted by a top pollster to determine voters\xe2\x80\x99 positions on the ballot measure and arguments that will help persuade undecided voters'
b'45000 \xe2\x80\x94 salaries office expenses for staff to oversee the effort between now and election day'
b'30000 \xe2\x80\x94 production of television and radio spots alerting the public to the findings of the above survey'
b'100000 \xe2\x80\x94 placement of voter education spots in the key media including print radio and television'
b'Money must be in hand by midAugust to reserve time for September and October'
b'15000 \xe2\x80\x94 election day \xe2\x80\x9cgetoutthevote\xe2\x80\x9d drive including phone calls to get voters to the polls'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cgetoutthevote\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'You stood by Defenders when we defeated the wealthy American Farm Bureau in court and saved the lives of the wolves in Yellowstone National Park and central Idaho'
b'Now I\xe2\x80\x99m hoping I can count on your moral and financial support again today'
b'to help save Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s wolves from sameday airborne landandshoot killing'
b'Your special donation today is absolutely critical because many of Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s politicians clearly have antiwolf agendas'
b'They have the financial backing of powerful special interests and the determination to ignore the will of the people of Alaska and the American public'
b'Please let Alaskans know that you\xe2\x80\x99re behind them'
b'Let them know you share their concern about protecting Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s wolves'
