b'Dear Friend of Animals'
b'I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll use the enclosed name labels and colorful pet stickers designed especially for friends of animals'
b'Your name  and the name of The Humane Society of the United States HSUS  are very important to the wellbeing of all animals because together we can prevent suffering and save lives'
b'I wish I could tell you that everyone is concerned about protecting earth\xe2\x80\x99s animals  dogs cats farm animals and wildlife'
b'The sad truth is animal cruelty abuse and neglect continues at an alarming rate across the nation and even in your own community'

b'Every day of the year The Humane Society of the United States receives reports about all kinds of animal cruelties such as the horrors of the leghold trap the use of dog and cat fur needless or repetitive experiments on animals and the abusive treatment of dogs and cats'

b'Still others are less obvious but just as horrible dogs fighting to the death for the benefit of blood thirsty gamblers baby calves confined and malnourished to provide \xe2\x80\x9cmilkfed\xe2\x80\x9d veal for the gourmet and the \xe2\x80\x9caccidental\xe2\x80\x9d drowning of porpoises in the nets of tuna fishermen'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cmilkfed\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'\xe2\x80\x9caccidental\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'And almost 6000000 companion pets are put to death in shelters throughout America'
b'What is even more shocking is that more than 30 million animals die these cruel painful deaths each year '
b'needless deaths that could have been stopped'

b'And with so much animal cruelty and suffering going on I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you can understand why the work of The Humane Society of the United States is so vitally important and why we need the support of many other people like you to help us bring an end to animal suffering abuse and neglect'

b'Since 1954 our programs and activities have been aimed at stopping and eliminating all animal abuse and we continue to spend a great deal of time investigating animal cruelty cases and working with the courts to prosecute the guilty parties'
b'We also work hard and lobby for better animal welfare laws at the local state and federal government levels and we insist they enforce existing laws to prevent animal cruelty'

b'Our primary goal though has always been to stop the cruel and inhumane treatment of animals before it happens so we teach the public about the need to protect all animals from suffering abuse and exploitation'

b'But while our programs and activities have been successful in reducing animal cruelty we are constantly faced with new problems of animal suffering which need immediate attention and drain our resources'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a difficult problem because we have to fight the wellfinanced and powerful agribusiness and research industries but we do our best to protect the animals'
b'Right now the problems are mounting and we need all the help we can get to stop animal cruelty'
b'And that\xe2\x80\x99s where you can help'

b'You can be a lifesaving \xe2\x80\x9cfriend\xe2\x80\x9d to all animals by telling friends and family about the important work of The HSUS and asking them to become vigilant in safeguarding the lives of ALL animals'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cfriend\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Today we are placing special emphasis on pet adoption'
b'I hope you will visit your local animal shelter and consider adopting a dog or cat into your home'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a wonderful way to enjoy their companionship and save the life of a loving animal too'
b'I also hope you will give a big boost to our work to protect all animals by sending a generous taxdeductible donation today'
b'Your gift of at least 5 or 10 or even 15 will help The HSUS save millions of animals'
b'I know you care deeply for the wellbeing of all animals'
b'Please help us carry this message to others so that animal cruelty and abuse can be eliminated'
b'Sincerely President'
b'PS We are totally committed to putting an end to all forms of animal cruelty and neglect'
b'But your help of 5 or 10 or even 15 is absolutely needed today'
b'Please take this moment to be as generous as possible to send your best gift today and don\xe2\x80\x99t forget to use your free colorful pet stickers and name labels enclosed'
b'Thanks in advance'

b' Help keep the promise alive'
b'Dear Friend of Wildlife'
b'A significant promise comes with your enclosed personalized address labels which are ready for your immediate use'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a big promise'
b'And that\xe2\x80\x99s our vow to work hard to protect our country\xe2\x80\x99s wildlife and the wild places on which they \xe2\x80\x94 and all of us depend'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a promise we\xe2\x80\x99ve kept for nearly 65 years'
b'And one we will keep for as long as there are people like you who care about our country\xe2\x80\x99s wildlife and wild places'
b'Will you join us in this exciting mission  and help keep the promise alive'
b'This is why we decided to send you your special sheet of labels'
b'We hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll use them on all of your letters packages and cards'

b'By doing this you tell the world that you too care about what we leave our children \xe2\x80\x94 clean water thriving grassland and wetlands teeming with life and an amazing array of animals birds and other creatures that share this planet with us'
b'Using your address labels is an easy way to show you care about wildlife'
b'But I also hope you will help us keep alive the promise behind these labels and become the newest member of National Wildlife Federation today'
b'You see we need a strong membership base to continue delivering on our promise'
b'And with more than 3000 species facing rapidly disappearing habitat we have never needed members like you more'
b'We need your support today to help us face off against a noisy chorus of antiwildlife forces who oppose all efforts at commonsense environmental protection'
b'These enemies of conservation are mounting an intensive effort to weaken the Endangered Species Act  and our ability to protect threatened and endangered species'
b'The enclosed copy of Wildlife Watch highlights what is involved in the major campaigns we\xe2\x80\x99re currently conducting for wildlife  and the challenges that lie ahead'
b'The feeling that you are a real partner in helping us achieve victories for wildlife is probably the biggest benefit of membership there is'
b'But membership carries many tangible benefits as well  benefits that will keep you uptodate on the latest wildlife news and benefits designed to enhance your own personal enjoyment of nature'
b'For a membership gift of just 15 you will receive a full year of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most beautiful nature magazine NATIONAL WILDLIFE'
b'With its spectacular fullcolor photographs compelling features and updates on the important work your membership helps us to accomplish this awardwinning publication alone is worth the modest gift'
b'As a member you will look forward to and enjoy a new issue of NATIONAL WILDLIFP every other month'
b'And when you join we\xe2\x80\x99ll acknowledge your membership right away with a lovable gray wolf plush toy'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s our FREE gift to you for joining now and a charming reminder that your support helps NWF protect valuable wildlife species like this one'
b'Like your address labels your gray wolf toy says good things about you and your love of wildlife'
b'PLUS there are additional membership benefits for you to enjoy'

b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll receive a membership card and attractive decal wildlife and legislative alerts indepth monthly information packets on wildlife topics invitations to outdoor programs exciting travel opportunities and regular receipt of our trademark wildlife stamps \xe2\x80\x94 a national tradition since 1936 \xe2\x80\x94 greeting cards a calendar and address labels'
b'But best of all your membership provides you with an opportunity to make a real personal difference in the world we all share'
b'So please send us your membership gift today  by using the convenient form attached to your personal address labels'
b'We look forward to your reply'
b'Appreciatively Mark Van Putten President'
b'PS As soon as we hear from you by return mail and receive your 15 membership gift we will send your NWF gray wolf plush toy'

b'Then be on the lookout for NATIONAL WILDLIFE\xc2\xae where you\xe2\x80\x99ll see spectacular pictures of wildlife species like this one  and learn just how NWF goes about safeguarding them with your help'
b'December 7 2000 FirstName LastName StreetNumber StreetName CityName StateName ZipCode'
b' Dear Friend'
b'As a member of World Wildlife Fund you know that our efforts are essential to preserving the astonishing yet desperately threatened diversity of life here on Earth'
b'I\xe2\x80\x99m also hoping you know that you play a vital role in achieving our conservation goals around the globe'
b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why I want to extend my appreciation for your last membership contribution of 500'
b'And why I\xe2\x80\x99m writing you today to ask you to renew your support for the pivotal year ahead'

b'In fact I want to urge you to strengthen your dedication to saving life on Earth \xe2\x80\x94 by sending a generous leadership gift of 750 and becoming a member of World Wildlife Funds prestigious Living Planet Society'
b'With your increased commitment we can move forward to thwart the most serious threats to endangered ecosystems'

b'After all conservation begins with saving those atrisk places \xe2\x80\x94 our forests and deserts wetlands and oceans mangroves and coral reefs \xe2\x80\x94 that provide a lifeline for precious animals and plants'
b'To this end we\xe2\x80\x99ve designated some 200 ecoregions those with the most outstanding and diverse habitats as our Global 200'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99re now creating model projects in 25 of these highpriority areas  in order to balance conservation with people\xe2\x80\x99s need to use natural resources to sustain their livelihoods'
b'With your increased commitment we can intensify our campaigns to protect species that are in grave peril by both the loss of habitat and the illegal trading in animal parts'
b'Quite simply WWF must do even more to safeguard the tigers rhinos pandas whales and other creatures that still remain in the wild'
b'While we still have the chance'

b'So in addition to our efforts to conserve wildlife preserves we\xe2\x80\x99ll escalate our trailblazing program to find alternatives for traditional tigerbased medicines  rescue more rhinos in Kenya and Nepal through our ambitious translocation projects  complete the first survey of China\xe2\x80\x99s pandas in over a decade  and fight to halt all commercial whaling as well as the whale meat trade'
b'We\xe2\x80\x99ll also award more small grants through our Species Action Fund to help a wide range of animals including whooping cranes giant river otters and Tibetan antelopes'
b'And with your increased commitment we can battle against destructive global forces that transcend regional and national boundaries'
b'For instance our innovative \xe2\x80\x9cForests for Life Campaign\xe2\x80\x9d establishes an international network of parks and reserves'
b'\xe2\x80\x9cForests for Life Campaign\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'This will protect at least 10 of each different type of forest found in every country'
b'Another WWF goal'
b'To end government subsidies that promote overfishing and to encourage new markets for sustainably managed fisheries'
b'The challenges we face are daunting to be sure'
b'However I\xe2\x80\x99m confident that by joining together again we can make exciting progress in the year ahead'
b'I want to ask you therefore to renew your valued World Wildlife Fund membership and hopefully at the Living Planet Society level of 750'
b'When you do you\xe2\x80\x99ll extend your commitment as an esteemed partner with WWF  the largest and most effective international conservation group in existence'

b'Now with your increased commitment we can save more of our planet\xe2\x80\x99s cherished wild species and their irreplaceable habitats  as we strive to ensure a healthy and thriving future for our extraordinary natural world'
b'Once again please accept my warmest gratitude for your past support And please take a moment today to renew your critically important WWF annual membership'
b'Thank you'
b'Sincerely Kathryn S Fuller President'
b'PS As a Living Planet Society member you\xe2\x80\x99ll receive the wonderful array of benefits described in the enclosed brochure'
b'Plus to acknowledge your increased gift of 750 we\xe2\x80\x99ll send you a free copy of our stunning coffeetable photography book Living Planet Preserving Edens of the Earth'
b'Please let it be a constant reminder of all you\xe2\x80\x99re doing to preserve our endangered wildlife'
b'Iraq clears visit by Ohio official'
b'By Scott Montgomery Washington'
b'The Iraqi government has agreed to let US Rep Tony Hall visit the country next week to assess a humanitarian crisis that has festered since the Gulf War of 1990 Halls office said Monday'

b'The Dayton Democrat who has traveled to other crisis points including Sierra Leone and North Korea will spend three days visiting hospitals and other facilities to seek understanding why aid has been ineffective in stemming malnourishment and other medical problems'
b'Iraq has been under economic sanctions since the war ended which some say have thwarted the countrys ability to recover from the devastation of the bombing campaign'
b'The Persian Gulf War destroyed much of the countrys medical infrastructure according to a report by the World Health Organization'
b'In 1996 the WHO found that much of the population existed in a state of semi starvation'
b'Hall will be only the second member of Congress to travel in Iraq since the war according to Halls office'
b'The last visitor was thenUS Rep Bill Richardson of New Mexico who went to help a pair of US oilmen in diplomatic trouble'
b'Hall flies to Amman Jordan on Friday where hell spend the night before driving to Iraq'
b'Hall is to return to Washington on April 22'
b'Story Filed By Cox Newspapers'
b'Ohio Congressman Arrives in Jordan'
b'AMMAN Jordan AP'
b'US Representative Tony Hall arrived in Jordan on Saturday en route to Iraq where he is expected to look into the plight of Iraqis after nearly 10 years of UN trade sanctions'
b'Hall an Ohio Democrat and one of very few US congressmen to visit Iraq since the 1991 Gulf War over Kuwait is scheduled to embark Sunday the 12hour overland trip to the Iraqi capital Baghdad'
b'He did not speak to reporters in Jordan but he told The Associated Press before leaving the United States that he hopes to separate the humanitarian work from the political issues'
b'During his four days in Iraq Hall said he wanted to investigate reports from relief agencies that a quarter of Iraqi children may be suffering from chronic malnutrition'
b'He said he would pay particular attention to what happens to food and medicine entering the country under the UN oilforfood program'

b'If supplies are not reaching the people who need them Hall said he wanted to find out whether the United Nations or relief agencies needed to handle things differently or whether Iraq needs to get out of the way and let us do the job'
b'The Iraqi government blames the embargo for the malnutrition infant mortality and other hardships'
b'The sanctions cannot be lifted until UN inspectors certify that Iraq has eliminated its weapons of mass destruction and the means to produce them'
b'Iraq says it has done so and has barred inspectors since late 1998'
b'At least one other congressman has visited Iraq'
b'Energy Secretary Bill Richardson went to Baghdad in 1995 while a representative for New Mexico'
b'Lawmaker Appeals for Innocent Iraqis'
b'By HASSAN ABDULWAHAB Associated Press Writer'
b'BASRA Iraq AP'

b'A US lawmaker assessing the impact of UN sanctions on Iraq said Wednesday it is important not only to force Baghdad to give up its weapons of mass destruction but also to do more to ease the hardships on ordinary Iraqis'
b'Rep Tony Hall DOhio did not call for a lifting of sanctions imposed on Iraq for its 1990 invasion of Kuwait but said the United Nations should make sure that sanctions do not hurt innocent Iraqis'
b'It was very very important to compel Iraq to rid itself of weapons of mass destruction so that it cannot use or export them to other countries he told Associated Press Television News'
b'But he insisted the international community can do a much better job in helping Iraq deal with its economic and health problems'
b'One way would be to speed up the flow of health supplies and other urgent commodities to the country under a UN humanitarian program he said'
b'Iraq says the United States and Britain hold up delivery of needed supplies using their clout in the United Nations'
b'The US government says it wants to ensure that Iraq is not buying items that appear to be humanitarian in nature but that could be used for making weapons'

b'The Senate Ethics Committee on Tuesday night severely admonished Sen Robert G Torricelli DNJ saying he had violated Senate rules by accepting and failing to disclose expensive gifts from a former contributor to whom he repeatedly gave help'
b'severely admonished'

b'On the basis of thousands of pages of information developed in an earlier federal inquiry into Torricellis activities the committee chastised him for using poor judgment and disregarding Senate rules in his dealings with the former donor David Chang'

b'Your actions and failure to act led to violations of Senate rules and related statutes and created at least the appearance of impropriety the three Democrats and three Republicans on the committee said in a threepage letter to Torricelli'
b'Your actions and failure to act led to violations of Senate rules and related statutes and created at least the appearance of impropriety'
b'The committees action comes six months after federal prosecutors ended a lengthy criminal investigation into Torricellis activities without filing criminal charges'

b'The ethics panel to which evidence from the criminal case was forwarded concluded its review just as Torricelli is gearing up his campaign for reelection against the Republican candidate Douglas R Forrester'
b'After months in which polls showed Torricelli well ahead of his relatively unknown Republican rival the contest has narrowed in recent weeks'

b'It was the first time that the Senate Ethics Committee had voted to take action against a senator since 1995 when it recommended that Bob Packwood an Oregon Republican be expelled on the ground of sexual and official misconduct'
b'Packwood later resigned'
b'The document speaks for itself said Inouye who said that he considered the matter closed with the letter'
b'The document speaks for itself'

b'Within minutes after the committee released its letter publicly Torricelli took the Senate floor Tuesday night to apologize to the people of New Jersey for allowing his seat in the chamber to be placed in this position'
b'to be placed in this position'

b'During nearly seven hours of sworn testimony last week before the members and staff of the ethics panel Torricelli said that he had not taken any gifts from Chang and that what items he had accepted from the businessman he had later paid Chang for one person familiar with his account said'

b'Torricelli also insisted that he had not done any unusual favors for Chang who first turned to the senator in 1995 for help in winning the repayment of some 71 million he said he was then owed in a failed business deal with the North Korean government'
b'The Ethics Committee was unconvinced'

b'In its letter which was signed by all six members the panel wrote that it was troubled by incongruities inconsistencies and conflicts particularly concerning actions taken by you which were or could have been of potential benefit to Chang'
b'troubled by incongruities inconsistencies and conflicts particularly concerning actions taken by you which were or could have been of potential benefit to Chang'

b'The committee criticized Torricelli for maintaining a personal and official relationship with Chang under circumstances where you knew that he was attempting to ingratiate himself in part through a pattern of attempts to provide you and those around you with gifts over a period of several years'

b'personal and official relationship with Chang under circumstances where you knew that he was attempting to ingratiate himself in part through a pattern of attempts to provide you and those around you with gifts over a period of several years'

b'During that time the panel said Torricelli and members of his Senate staff took a series of actions to help Chang contacting US government officials writing letters to foreign government officials and bringing Chang or his business representatives into meetings with foreign officials'
b'The committee did not confirm some of the most serious allegations including Changs claim that he gave Torricelli tens of thousands of dollars in cash'

b'The committee said it had weighed the fact that Torricellis principal accuser in the case had been Chang a witness whose credibility has been called into question by the Department of Justice a United States District judge and his own conduct'
b'a witness whose credibility has been called into question by the Department of Justice a United States District judge and his own conduct'
b'In May that judge sentenced sentenced Chang to 18 months imprisonment for obstructing justice and making 53700 in illegal campaign contributions to Torricellis 1996 Senate campaign'

b'But at the time of Changs sentencing the judge Alfred M Wolin also said the businessman had cooperated closely with federal investigators providing them with information that was material and credible'
b'material and credible'
b'The ethics committee has the power to punish lawmakers with sanctions ranging from public or private letters of admonition to censure or expulsion'
b'In Torricellis case it acted without conducting a full investigation saying the case had been exhaustively scrutinized by federal authorities'

b'A lawyer for Chang Bradley D Simon said Tuesday night that he was disappointed that the ethics panel had confirmed only a handful of the gifts he said his client had given Torricelli and that the panel did not deal with what he said were actions by Torricelli to thwart the federal investigation'
b'This matter was far more serious than what the committee found Simon said'
b'This matter was far more serious than what the committee found'
b'According to two government officials involved in the inquiry the Ethics Committee received a vast amount of information from federal investigators some of it under a court order issued in March'

b'That information included witness statements store receipts and other documents indicating that Chang had paid for expensive items given to Torricelli his sister one of his longtime aides Roberta Stern and one of Torricellis former girlfriends Judy D Balaban'
b'The committees letter did not mention Changs reported gifts to Torricelli of an 8100 Rolex watch about a dozen Italianmade suits and a 3816 antique grandfather clock'
b'Nor did it cite a 1590 Oriental carpet that Chang gave to Torricellis former wife Susan Holloway Torricelli'
b'A government official involved in the inquiry said that evidence of those gifts was either incomplete or the subject of conflicting accounts by different witnesses'
b'The committee confirmed Torricellis claims he had made partial repayments to Chang for two gifts a largescreen television and a stereo compactdisc player'
b'But it said the senator had showed poor judgment by failing to reimburse him for the full market value of the gifts'
b'poor judgment'
b'A person familiar with Torricellis testimony to the committee said he had told its members that he repaid the wholesale cost of the appliances because Chang told him that was what he had paid'
b'wholesale'
b'The ethics panel also criticized Torricelli for taking two bronze statues on loan from Chang'
b'The statues the existence of which had not been publicly known before were displayed in Torricellis Senate office'
b'Finally the committee appeared to have discounted Torricellis contention that he was not responsible for expensive earrings that Chang had given as Christmas gifts to his sister Stern and Balaban'
b'The senators belief that such items were of little value or were not gifts to you under the circumstances displayed poor judgment and violated Senate gift rules the panel found'
b'that such items were of little value or were not gifts to you under the circumstances'

b'According to a government official involved in the inquiry the information reviewed by the Ethics Committee also included an analysis by federal investigators showing that during the period in which Chang claimed to have made numerous cash payments to Torricelli the senator spent thousands of dollars more in cash than investigators could account for from his bank withdrawals and other known sources of income'

b'The analysis which was assembled from banking and credit records incometax returns and congressional financialdisclosure forms showed by March of 1998 Torricellis cash expenditures were more than 22000 in excess of the cash he had generated from checks and automaticteller machines an official who has reviewed the document said'
b'A spokeswoman for Torricelli Debra DeShong said he had fully accounted for all the money he had spent'
b'Senator Torricelli provided the committee with a full explanation of sources of income and any funds used for cash purposes she said'

b'Even after the ethics committee admonished Torricelli on Tuesday night one of his most important political supporters Senate majority leader Tom Daschle DSD continued to defend him stating that the panel had found Chang a witness wholly without credibility'
b'a witness wholly without credibility'

b'Moving quickly to make a campaign issue of the Senate letter Bill Pascoe Forresters campaign manager said the findings were evidence that Torricelli had undertaken an extensive campaign of misinformation and deceit and called on him to release the sworn testimony he gave to the panel'
b'extensive campaign of misinformation and deceit'
b'Pascoe said Only then will New Jersey voters be able to decide Torricellis fitness for office'
b'Only then will New Jersey voters be able to decide Torricellis fitness for office'

b'US Secretary of State Colin Powell arrived here on Tuesday night for meetings with fellow foreign ministers aimed at solidifying a second front in Southeast Asia in the campaign against global terrorism'
b'But he has had to balance that goal with longstanding concerns about human rights abuses in the region'

b'In meetings on Tuesday in Malaysia and Singapore before touching down in this oilproducing sultanate for two days of talks with members of the Association of South East Asian Nations Powell said he repeatedly raised the issue'
b'We still believe strongly in human rights and that everything we do has to be consistent with universal standards of human rights he said'
b'We still believe strongly in human rights and that everything we do has to be consistent with universal standards of human rights'

b'But at a news conference in Singapore Powell hinted that the Bush administration was ready to discuss resuming military cooperation with Indonesia the worlds most populous Muslim nation and a sometimes reluctant partner in the efforts to crack down on militant Islamic groups'
b'The United States cut virtually all military links with Indonesia in 1999 after its forces were implicated in the violence that swept East Timor after that territory voted for independence'

b'On Thursday Powell and representatives of the nations of the Asian group including Indonesia are expected to sign a declaration promising cooperation to prevent terrorism by sharing information blocking funds tightening borders and making it hard to use forged travel papers'

b'We recognized that terrorism is a global threat and that the disturbing acts of terrorism and transnational crimes which continue to threaten world peace and stability must be tackled by the international community the ministers said in a communique on Tuesday'

b'We recognized that terrorism is a global threat and that the disturbing acts of terrorism and transnational crimes which continue to threaten world peace and stability must be tackled by the international community'
b'Powell is among the representatives from 13 nations outside Southeast Asia including China Japan and Russia that are taking part in the annual meeting of the groups regional forum'
b'Terrorism dominates the agenda though the possibility of a meeting here between Powell and his North Korean counterpart Paek Nam Sun has generated the most news'
b'It would be the highestlevel contact between the United States and North Korea since President Bush took office'
b'Powell heads to Indonesias capital Jakarta late on Thursday before finishing a weeklong trip through the region in the Philippines on Saturday'
b'He said that when he arrives in Jakarta he will have some ideas and some initiatives to present to President Megawati Sukarnoputri'
b'some ideas and some initiatives'

b'Indonesia is already receiving 400000 in the current fiscal year for civilian training programs and is to receive a like amount next year and the United States expects to provide an additional 16 million this year to train police officers in counterterrorism'
b'At the same time the Pentagon is reviewing how to allocate another 17 million in counterterrorism fellowships some of which could go to Indonesia'
b'counterterrorism fellowships'
b'But a senior State Department official also acknowledged that some in the administration and Congress are pushing for more direct military cooperation which would require congressional approval'

b'I think they recognize the danger that we all face and I think they have been cooperating more fully with us as time goes by and Im quite sure that Mrs Megawati is committed to this cause Powell said in Singapore'
b'I think they recognize the danger that we all face and I think they have been cooperating more fully with us as time goes by and Im quite sure that Mrs Megawati is committed to this cause'
b'He met there with Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong who endorsed the idea of renewed military ties between the United States and Indonesia as an important step in stabilizing that country'
b'Powell contended that it was not inconsistent to want to foster cooperation even with an organization like the Indonesian military which has a history of human rights abuses'
b'If you get young officers expose them to a military organization that is within a democratic political institution such as the United States then that rubs off on them he said'
b'If you get young officers expose them to a military organization that is within a democratic political institution such as the United States then that rubs off on them'
b'In Malaysia Powell met with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad who has led the country since 1981'

b'The Malaysian foreign minister Syed Hamid Albar later told local reporters that Powell had proposed that American and Malaysian officials review the idea of forming a regional training center in Malaysia to coordinate antiterrorism activities'
b'His brief stop in Malaysia also highlighted the moral ambiguities of the effort to prevent terrorism and its emphasis on cooperation with governments that the United States has often criticized'

b'The United States once distanced itself from Mahathir for strongarm tactics with political rivals and human rights groups criticize him for arresting and jailing scores of suspected militants including some who may be linked to alQaida without trial'

b'Powell said his discussions with Mahathir touched on the case of his former deputy Anwar Ibrahim who is serving a 15year sentence on charges of sodomy and abuse of power after trials that Powell said the United States had always felt were flawed'
b'always felt'

b'The assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs James Kelly met on Tuesday morning with Anwars wife Wan Azizah Wan Ismail for what she later told Malaysian reporters was a discussion about both the detention of her husband and six supporters and the campaign against terrorism'
b'Microsoft plans to announce on Wednesday a partnership with ATT Wireless Services to offer software for wireless devices and services a person close to the talks said Tuesday night'

b'The deal would be part of Microsofts drive to sign up wireless carriers to use its socalled smart phone software  a pareddown version of the Windows operating system  and services that Microsoft is developing as part of its Net Internet strategy'
b'Neither Microsoft nor ATT Wireless would comment'
b'The main market for the MicrosoftATT partnership is expected to be business customers'
b'Microsofts efforts to persuade wireless carriers to use its cell phone operating system have struggled'
b'It has run into particular opposition from companies aligned with Nokia which has developed a competing software'
b'But Microsofts potential advantage analysts say is its ability to link its cell phone software to its desktop PC software a Microsoft stronghold'
b'Customers who want access to Microsoft desktop email documents and calendar information may prefer Microsofts wireless technology'
b'In recent months Microsoft has announced partnerships with wireless carriers like Verizon and Sprint PCS'

b'Less than three weeks after outfielder Cliff Floyd was imported to Montreal to play a pivotal part in the Expos playoff plans he was traded to Boston Tuesday night to try his hand in what the Red Sox hope will be their postseason plans'

b'Floyd did not produce the kind of offense the Expos expected from him so Omar Minaya the Expos aggressive rookie general manager turned around and sent him to the Red Sox in exchange two South Korean pitchers and a player yet to be named'
b'The teams made the deal less than 24 hours before Tuesdays 4 pm'
b'deadline for making trades without first getting waivers on players'
b'Minaya obtained Floyd from the Florida Marlins on July 11 only two weeks after he stunned baseball by acquiring Bartolo Colon from Cleveland'
b'Colon has won four of five decisions for the Expos but Floyd batted only 208 for them while hitting three home runs including one Tuesday night and driving in four runs'
b'With the Marlins Floyd bated 287 hit 18 home runs and drove in 57 runs'

b'The Expos who had a 4641 record when they made their first Floyd deal had only a 712 record with him on the team dropping from 9 12 games behind Atlanta in the National League East to as many as 16 games back'

b'Floyd can be a free agent after this season and Minaya decided it would be more prudent to trade him and get value in return than have to settle for a draft choice or two as compensation when he signed with another team as a free agent'
b'The Expos acquired Sun Wookim and Seung Junsong'
b'Kim 24 is a righthanded pitcher from Seoul'
b'The Red Sox signed him in 1997'
b'Song is a 22yearold righthander from Pusan'
b'The Red Sox signed him in 1999'
b'The Red Sox wanted to bolster their offense'
b'They led the Yankees for most of the first three months of the season but then slipped behind them in the American League East'
b'Earlier in the day Tuesday one member of the Red Sox organization was not sure they would be able to get Floyd'
b'I dont know that hes that serious about moving him the person said of Minaya'
b'I dont know that hes that serious about moving him'
b'But as the day wore on the Red Sox tried harder and by Tuesday night were able to get the player they wanted for their lineup'
b'With the barrage of crack cocaineconnected killings in the 1980s came the realization that young people were too often fullfledged players in the violence'

b'That was more evident here than in any other city said George Starke who after his career as an offensive tackle with the Washington Redskins from 1973 to 1984 stuck around and decided to make this place more than his home'
b'There was death in DC throughout the 80s and into the 90s and there was death everywhere said Starke who was reared in New Rochelle NY and played at Columbia'
b'There was death in DC throughout the 80s and into the 90s and there was death everywhere'

b'It wasnt like New Yorks or Bostons organized crime It was kids shooting kids It was a 14yearold from R Street who got his crew of six together and ran their drug block killing another 14yearold and his crew from a block away And from the beginning I could see that it was all about jobs I could see that you needed the private sector involved'
b'It wasnt like New Yorks or Bostons organized crime'
b'It was kids shooting kids'
b'And from the beginning I could see that it was all about jobs'
b'I could see that you needed the private sector involved'
b'Starke could see that in many instances these were cases of lost dignity'
b'I had a young man come up to me three years ago and say Mr Starke Im tired of going to bed at night with a Tech9 gun under my pillow'
b'I had a young man come up to me three years ago and say Mr Starke Im tired of going to bed at night with a Tech9 gun under my pillow'
b'And Starke was tired of seeing Washington and its young people suffer a black eye'

b'So after six years of planning he opened the Excel Institute Automotive Program a twoyear school that gives people a chance at a new life as an auto technician or in another job related to the field'
b'The school now in its third year has been so successful that it recently received a 2 million grant from Congress'
b'The program is being copied by other cities and has attracted students from all walks of life ages 16 to 68'
b'The program is coordinated with the University of the District of Columbia'
b'Students learn automotive intricacies and can earn a a high school equivalency diploma'
b'Starke 54 played in two Super Bowls and won one'
b'He played for George Allen Jack Pardee and Joe Gibbs'
b'In 1973 he was young enough to be a part of the Redskins Over the Hill Gang and in 1981 he was old enough to be one of the teams original Hogs'
b'He was recently named one of the 70 greatest Redskins'

b'He earned a physics degree from Columbia became a Redskin studied drama worked in sports broadcasting opened a Washington restaurant and built his own home here when he thought he might become a developer just so I could know how the business worked from the ground up he said'
b'just so I could know how the business worked from the ground up'
b'In 1988 he bought a Ford dealership'
b'In 1992 he sold it to begin work on the Excel Institute putting up 300000 to get things started'

b'I saw a lot of kids and young men out there with no dads and no structure who couldnt read and some of them were beginning to realize that there is no growing old as a crack dealer  you either die or go to jail he said'

b'I saw a lot of kids and young men out there with no dads and no structure who couldnt read and some of them were beginning to realize that there is no growing old as a crack dealer  you either die or go to jail'
b'My experience in the automotive industry was there was a dire shortage of auto technicians not only in America but internationally'
b'So Starke matched a problem with a problem and found a solution'
b'The institute has a fulltime staff of 18'
b'Twelve of those are teachers'
b'Seventy students are participating in summer classes'
b'Forty new students are expected for fall classes and there is a waiting list of at least that many Starke said'
b'Angela Nafis 47 of Ecuador has been in the school for a year'
b'She learned to speak English got a drivers license and earned her GED'
b'Charles Easterling 24 said he had been enrolled for a month but lived wherever'
b'wherever'
b'Im homeless now trying to find a place to lay my head'
b'Starke said the school was helping Easterling find housing'
b'Easterling said he would do whatever it took to become stable'
b'John Orellana 22 just got a technicians job at a Jiffy Lube last week'
b'Not bad for a guy who was kicked out of high school in 1997 for threatening a teacher'
b'I did a lot of walking got an interview and got a job and an opportunity of a lifetime Orellana said'
b'I did a lot of walking got an interview and got a job and an opportunity of a lifetime'
b'It shows if you have the will and the dedication here you can learn a lot and be something It taught me maturity This school is like a big family'
b'It shows if you have the will and the dedication here you can learn a lot and be something'
b'It taught me maturity'
b'This school is like a big family'
b'Edward Jewell 56 retired from his job as a copyright assistant at the Library of Congress in 1993'
b'Ive been flapping my wings since until I found this school he said'
b'Ive been flapping my wings since until I found this school'
b'I needed a new skill'
b'This has been invaluable enriching'
b'I get up and come down here at 6 am'
b'every day full of joy and energized'
b'Im grateful to George Starke to have had the vision to set something like this up not just for me but for all the students'
b'George is doing what hes supposed to be doing because God is blessing him and hes sure blessing me'
b'And when I become a technician I will help the poor and needy by giving them affordable rates'
b'Starke said the school would move to a building near the citys bus depot in the fall'
b'The city has talked with Starke about using his students for some vehicle repairs'
b'He is proud of the red Cobra 427 that sits in the schools workshop'
b'It was rebuilt from shell to finish by his first class and was included in the districts millennium celebrations'
b'His current class is rebuilding a black one'
b'This one will be auctioned for the school'
b'I just wanted to be a part said Starke who is certain he is the lone Redskin past or present who lives in the city'
b'I just wanted to be a part'
b'He has lived here for 20 years'

b'A lot of kids are afraid of the process and I wanted to take the process out For this school once they are in all they have to do is come every day come on time every day and work hard A little more than 50 percent of our kids make it through I want it to be more but my job is not to see that everybody makes it my job is to see that everybody has the opportunity to make it'
b'A lot of kids are afraid of the process and I wanted to take the process out'
b'the process'
b'the process'
