b'A little more than 50 percent of our kids make it through'
b'I want it to be more but my job is not to see that everybody makes it my job is to see that everybody has the opportunity to make it'

b'The 1933 double eagle a 20 gold piece with a mysterious history that involves a president a king and a Secret Service sting operation was auctioned Tuesday last night for a record price for a coin 759 million nearly double the previous record'
b'The anonymous buyer believed to be an individual collector who lives in the United States made the winning bid in a fiercely contested nineminute auction at Sothebys in Manhattan'
b'Eight bidders were joined by 500 coin collectors and dealers in an auction house audience seemingly devoid of celebrity bidders while an additional 534 observers followed the bidding on eBay'

b'As auction houses prepare for their fall seasons in an uncertain economy the sale price suggests that the marketplace for important items is enormously strong said David Redden a vice chairman at Sothebys who was the auctioneer'
b'suggests that the marketplace for important items is enormously strong'
b'This is an astonishing new record for a coin he said'
b'This is an astonishing new record for a coin'

b'In an unprecedented move the auction proceeds were split by the US Mint and a London coin dealer Stephen Fenton who had won that right in court after having been arrested by Secret Service agents for trying to sell the coin in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel in Manhattan in 1996'
b'Henrietta Holsman Fore the director of the US Mint who witnessed the sale said The monies we receive will go toward helping to pay down the debt and to fight the war on terrorism'
b'The monies we receive will go toward helping to pay down the debt and to fight the war on terrorism'
b'Fenton commented that the double eagle had been on a long historic journey with a very satisfying ending'
b'a long historic journey with a very satisfying ending'
b'I am thrilled with the price'
b'The previous numismatic record holder was an 1804 US silver dollar which sold for 414 million in 1999'
b'Sothebys partner in the onelot auction was Stacks Rare Coins with which it shared the customary 15 percent commission'
b'I have never seen as much interest in the sale of any coin in my 30 years in the business said Lawrence R Stack the companys managing director'
b'I have never seen as much interest in the sale of any coin in my 30 years in the business'
b'This is the Mona Lisa of coins said Beth Deisher editor of Coin World the largest weekly coin publication in the United States with a circulation of 85000'
b'This is the Mona Lisa of coins'
b'It is unique Forbidden fruit'
b'It is unique'
b'Forbidden fruit'
b'Collectors Web sites have surged with speculation about the sale price and enthusiasts even organized betting pools'
b'On Tuesday night Redden took the podium for nine minutes before the gavel came down recognizing bidders in the audience and on the telephone'
b'The tension in the crowd was broken with a burst of applause after the 5 million mark and a louder explosion at 6 million'
b'The rumor in the crowd had been that anything under 6 million would be a bargain said Ute Wartenberg executive director of the American Numismatic Society in Manhattan'
b'anything under 6 million would be a bargain'
b'Most bidders dropped out after that price'
b'The gavel sounded at 66 million after a Sothebys senior vice president Selby Kiffer made the final bid for the anonymous buyer on the telephone'
b'The sale price of 66 million when added to the commission totaled 759 million'

b'The auction attendance was swelled by coin collectors who had gathered on the eve of the American Numismatic Association Convention the largest coin show of the year expected to draw more than 10000 people to the Marriott Marquis Hotel Wednesday'
b'So the auction was almost like the ribboncutting ceremony for the convention Stack said'
b'So the auction was almost like the ribboncutting ceremony for the convention'
b'Fore of the mint said the high price for the coin was reached because it is one of a kind it is beautiful and it has a great story'
b'because it is one of a kind it is beautiful and it has a great story'

b'The coin was the only 1933 double eagle that has ever been legally offered for sale and its Maltese Falconesque history only recently came to light thanks to documents unearthed during the fiveyear legal battle over its ownership'
b'In 1792 it was deemed that all gold and silver US coins would bear the depiction of an eagle but gold pieces were issued only after a gold rush boom in 1850'
b'They were called double eagles because their face value was twice that of the original 10 gold piece'
b'Following the suggestion of President Theodore Roosevelt the sculptor Augustus SaintGaudens redesigned the coin in 1907 in high relief forever after giving the coins the designation saints'
b'saints'

b'But in 1933 President Franklin D Roosevelt took the United States off the gold standard and ordered all the 1933 saints already manufactured destroyed save for two reserved for the Smithsonian Institution'
b'They were never declared legal currency'
b'Presumably after being stolen by a mint employee nine double eagles surfaced during the mid1940s and 1950s'
b'They were seized by the Secret Service and melted down'

b'But before these coins came to light the royal legation of Egypt turned up with one at the Department of the Treasury and somehow got an official to issue an export license for the coin to enhance the collection of King Farouk'
b'By the time that blunder was discovered the coin had left the United States'
b'In 1954 after the king was deposed his coins were sold at auction and the double eagle vanished'
b'It went underground until it came to Fenton in 1995'

b'His arrest in Manhattan after attempting to sell the coin for 15 million led to a court battle over whether  thanks to the Treasurys mistaken export permission in 1944  the coin could be legally owned'
b'The double eagle came close to being melted down many times'
b'The coin once again escaped destruction when it was moved from the Treasury Department vault in 7 World Trade Center eight months before the building collapsed after the Sept 11 terrorist attack'
b'The record price was seen as a gift by coin collectors'
b'Many people believe that our great coin rarities are vastly undervalued in comparison to old master paintings Deisher said'
b'Many people believe that our great coin rarities are vastly undervalued in comparison to old master paintings'
b'In a ceremony after the sale Fore of the mint declared the coin the only 1933 double eagle ever to be legally issued by the US government'
b'This monetized the coin making it legal tender'
b'monetized'
b'The buyer will receive a certificate of transfer stating just that but only after paying the auction price and a fee of 20 for the face value of the coin'
b'Following are excerpts from the findings of the Senate Ethics Committees report on Sen Robert G Torricellis dealings with David Chang'

b'Your acceptance of a television and stereo CD player upon payment from David Chang of an amount you understood to be the cost to Mr Chang rather than fair market retail value evidenced poor judgment displayed a lack of due regard for Senate rules and resulted in a violation of the Senate Gifts Rules 35 and consequently a violation of your public disclosure obligations under Senate rules'

b'Your acceptance on loan from Mr Chang of bronze statues eagle and bronco buster for display in your Senate office under your offices policy of accepting the loan of home state artwork was not consistent with Senate rules governing such loans evidenced poor judgment displayed a lack of due regard for the Senate rules and resulted in a violation of the Senate Gifts Rule 35 and consequently a violation of your public disclosure obligations under Senate rules'

b'Your failure to act to prevent the acceptance of or to pay for gifts of earrings from Mr Chang to individuals your sister an employee and a friend in your home at Christmas on the mistaken belief that such items were of little value or were not gifts to you under the circumstances evidenced poor judgment displayed a lack of due regard for Senate rules and resulted in a violation of the Senate Gifts Rule 35 and consequently a violation of your public disclosure obligations under Senate Rule 34'

b'Continuation of a personal and official relationship with Mr Chang under circumstances where you knew that he was attempting to ingratiate himself in part through a pattern of attempts to provide you and those around you with gifts over a period of several years when you and your Senate Office were taking official actions of benefit to Mr Chang contacting United States Government officials writing letters to foreign government officials and involving Mr Chang of his representatives in situations where you were meeting with officials of foreign governments evidenced poor judgment'

b'The committee has also considered that the principal source of the allegations against you is David Chang a witness whose credibility has been called into question by the Department of Justice a United States district judge and his own conduct'
b'In court documents the government noted that Chang could not be trusted'

b'On May 23 2002 Mr Chang was convicted of attempting to corruptly persuade a witness to give false testimony a conspiracy to violate the federal election law and four violations of the federal election law'

b'After evaluating the extensive body of evidence before it and your testimony the committee is troubled by incongruities inconsistencies and conflicts particularly concerning actions taken by you which were or could have been of potential benefit to Mr Chang'

b'Therefore the committee    expresses its determination that your actions and failure to act led to violations of Senate rules and related statutes and created at least the appearance of impropriety and you are hereby severely admonished'

b'Further the committee notes section 1c1 of the Senate Gift Rule 35 concerning anything which is paid for at market value or returned    as well as your commitment to pay for any item which the committee might conclude were in violation of the rules and has further concluded that you must pay Chang an amount sufficient to bring the total to fair market retail value of the TV and CD player as well as the fair market retail value of the earrings given to the three individuals at your home with appropriate interest'
b'The committee understands that you have previously delivered the bronze statues to the Department of Justice from whence they should be returned to Chang'

b'This 30second commercial is the first in H Carl McCalls campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor and will be broadcast upstate in major broadcast markets and on cable in New York City starting today'
b'The words His resume is an American dream a quotation from Time magazine appear on the screen'
b'His resume is an American dream'
b'A series of snapshots and images are then a visual resume for McCall'

b'They show him as an Army lieutenant at his swearingin as a state senator as ambassador to the United Nations surrounded by children as New York City school board president and at other jobs leading up to his current position state comptroller'

b'A photograph of the candidate standing in his Army uniform next to his mother is shown then the advertisement shifts to McCall talking about education while images of the candidate looking at a computer screen with a small child and of him surrounded by children appear'
b'The action then shifts to him in an office speaking to the camera as the words Experience'
b'Experience Excellence Carl McCall'
b'Excellence'
b'Carl McCall appear on the screen'
b'A male voice says Time Magazine called his life an American dream'

b'Time Magazine called his life an American dream Carl McCall Army lieutenant state senator ambassador to the United Nations school board president Citibank vice president and one of the most effective comptrollers in New York history'
b'Carl McCall Army lieutenant state senator ambassador to the United Nations school board president Citibank vice president and one of the most effective comptrollers in New York history'
b'The candidate says I grew up poor with a single mother'

b'I grew up poor with a single mother She said educations a sledgehammer It can open doors to opportunity Thats what education did for me As governor Ill make sure that every kid in New York has the same opportunity I had to get a good education'
b'She said educations a sledgehammer'
b'It can open doors to opportunity'
b'Thats what education did for me'
b'As governor Ill make sure that every kid in New York has the same opportunity I had to get a good education'
b'This advertisement is long on introductions and short on claims of merit'
b'Thus most of the facts presented are a matter of record'
b'He had the title of ambassador when he was at the United Nations but he was not the chief of the American mission'
b'And Time magazine actually called his resume not his life an American dream but it also followed that up with a reference to his life saying he was one of six children and raised on welfare'

b'As for the claim about his success as comptroller where he controls the state pension funds there is no disputing the funds growth during his terms but some critics say it had more to do with the buoyancy of the stock market in the 1990s than skilled management'
b'The advertisement attempts to make several points and reach several different constituencies'

b'For one it counters the high name recognition of Andrew M Cuomo McCalls opponent by offering voters a straightforward introduction to the candidate emphasizing his long list of highlevel jobs in both the public and private sector'
b'It also emphasizes leadership an important campaign issue after Sept 11'
b'At the same time it gives McCall a chance to intertwine his bootstraps story with the broader issue of children and education a priority of many Democratic voters'
b'The New Jersey Supreme Court on Tuesday overturned the death sentence of Leslie Ann Nelson a transsexual gogo dancer who killed a police officer and an investigator with an AK47 rifle'

b'The court vacating Nelsons death sentence for the second time ruled on two grounds that the jury could have been confused by instructions on the verdict sheet and that the prosecutor made improper accusations in his closing argument'
b'Nelson 44 had been the only woman of 14 people on New Jerseys death row'
b'The ruling which does not affect Nelsons guilty plea sends the case back to the trial court for resentencing'
b'The state attorney generals office has not decided whether to seek the death penalty again a spokesman Peter Aseltine said Tuesday'
b'The court upheld the sentence of another death row inmate Robert O Marshall convicted of arranging the murder of his wife at a picnic area on the Garden State Parkway'

b'In its 5to0 decision in the Nelson case the court showed continuing uneasiness with the death penalty as it has done even since adopting a voluminous set of review procedures in 1999 to govern capital cases'
b'New Jersey has not had an execution since 1963'

b'Justice James R Zazzali and Justice Virginia Long said in a separate opinion that in addition to the reasons given in the majority opinion also written by Zazzali they believed the death penalty would constitute cruel and unusual punishment because of Nelsons history of emotional disturbance'
b'Zazzali and Long had expressed similar reservations in June 2001 when the court overturned the death sentence of Thomas J Koskovich who was 18 when he killed two pizza deliverymen in an ambush'
b'The majority opinion Tuesday said the court would impose higher standards in capital cases when reviewing prosecutors conduct and possibly ambiguous jury instructions'

b'While all five members of the majority found the instructions to the jury on weighing aggravating and mitigating factors to be confusing two of those justices wrote in a partial dissent that the prosecutors statements in his summation about the defenses expert witnesses were within the bounds of acceptable argument'
b'Two of the courts members Chief Justice Deborah T Poritz and Justice Peter G Verniero did not participate in the Nelson case because both are former attorneys general'
b'Nelson born Glenn Nelson had severe psychological problems and a history of reclusive behavior into adulthood and was convicted on a weapons charge in 1988'
b'After undergoing sex change surgery in 1992 she pursued a career as an exotic dancer'
b'In April 1995 while she was living with her parents in Haddon Heights outside Philadelphia law enforcement officers arrived at the house with a warrant for Nelsons arrest on another weapons charge'
b'During a 14hour standoff she killed a patrolman and an investigator from the Camden County prosecutors office'
b'She pleaded guilty to murder and was sentenced to death by a jury in 1997'
b'The Supreme Court overturned that sentence in July 1998 ruling that the prosecution had failed to disclose important information to the jury'
b'A second jury sentenced Nelson to death in March 2001'
b'In Marshalls case the 51 decision upheld a lower courts dismissal of his petition for further review of his 1986 murder conviction'
b'Marshall an insurance agent from Toms River was convicted of hiring a man to kill his wife while the couple were going home after an evening of dining and gambling in Atlantic City'
b'The case was the subject of Joe McGinniss bestselling book Blind Faith'
b'Blind Faith'
b'The New York Times said in an editorial for Wednesday July 31'
b'President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt describes himself as Americas leading Arab ally'
b'Yet his antidemocratic behavior is an embarrassment to Washington and an affront to his own people'

b'The latest example is Mondays resentencing of Saad Eddin Ibrahim a sociologist and human rights activist to seven years in prison for his efforts to register voters monitor elections and report attacks on Egypts Coptic Christians'
b'Ibrahim who holds dual United States and Egyptian citizenship is 63 years old and ailing'
b'The verdict should be annulled not just on humanitarian grounds but because his prosecution is an abrogation of the most basic standards of justice'
b'Ibrahims harsh punishment sends a chilling message to Egyptians yearning for a more accountable and tolerant society'
b'Egyptian courts are neither fair nor independent'
b'Like every other government institution they hew closely to Mubaraks wishes'
b'That is especially true of the State Security Court that ruled in this case'
b'Ibrahim might never have been tried had he not written an article taking note of Mubaraks efforts to create a presidential dynasty'

b'Nor is it likely his sentence would have been reaffirmed if Mubarak believed that convicting an American citizen for promoting democracy and human rights might jeopardize his own standing with the Bush administration and the 2 billion annual American subsidy that keeps his government afloat'
b'That aid bonanza was granted to reward Mubaraks predecessor Anwar Sadat for signing a peace treaty with Israel'
b'Washington has never demanded good governance and democracy from Cairo in return'
b'In recent months President Bush has spoken of the need to promote democracy in the Arab world'
b'But so far he has pushed the point only with the Palestinians'
b'It is time to extend this policy to Egypt'
b'While hardly the worst example of dictatorship in the Middle East Egypt is one of the saddest'
b'It is a country with a long and glorious history a substantial middle class a peace treaty with Israel and large quantities of American aid'
b'Under Mubarak it has squandered economic and diplomatic opportunities and relentlessly stifled political debate'
b'Its official media are awash in antiAmerican and antiSemitic propaganda'
b'The State Department and American officials in Cairo have issued diplomatically phrased protests of Ibrahims trial and sentence'
b'This is entirely insufficient'
b'What is needed is a message delivered personally by Bush and other top officials not only about the inexcusable treatment of Ibrahim but of the contemptuous approach to democratic values'
b'The New York Times said in an editorial for Wednesday July 31'
b'Responding to a wave of public dismay over the first designs for rebuilding Lower Manhattan Gov George Pataki has sent word that its time to go back to the drawing board'
b'It is the right message sent while it is still early enough to do something constructive about the disappointing quality of the work so far'
b'The governor like Mayor Michael Bloomberg now seems committed to creating a better mix of uses for ground zero and a 24hour community in Manhattans downtown'
b'While rethinking the plans will delay the original rebuilding schedule slightly it does not need to stall progress if the governor keeps the pressure on the Lower Manhattan Development Corp'
b'and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey'
b'New York cannot afford to have a gaping hole that mocks the city and its process for rebuilding what was destroyed'
b'Pataki openly questioned the Port Authoritys requirement that any plan for the site replace all the office hotel and retail square footage lost in the attack on Sept 11'
b'More than anything else that specification limited the designs to the undistinguished options presented two weeks ago'
b'Renegotiating that issue with the World Trade Center leaseholders should begin immediately'
b'Opening the process to other designers both here and internationally will help separate this urban plan from the ordinary'
b'The city also needs to begin openly discussing what happens underground in particular with the transportation network'

b'At this point planners have focused on shortterm repair of PATH and subway lines with mediumrange proposals being shopped in Washington that could untangle the disorganized web of subway lines downtown'
b'Within the next few weeks the Lower Manhattan Development Corp'
b'and the Port Authority should offer some bigger ideas about how to connect the downtown area better to the rest of the region'
b'Lowering West Street alongside the World Trade Center site and building a park or esplanade on top is another option that has been popular with those reviewing the first six public proposals'
b'But it would be expensive and the governor the mayor and their friends in Washington will have to look at longrange ways to pay the bill'
b'Patakis recent remarks are a sign that he understands how central the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan will be to his own political legacy'
b'Now he needs to follow through with action to keep demonstrating that his core concern is coming up with the best possible plan not simply keeping the issue on hold until after this falls election'
b'The New York Times said in an editorial for Wednesday July 31'
b'President Bush has now unveiled his longawaited Clear Skies proposal which he promises will simplify and strengthen the Clean Air Act without crippling American industry'
b'A debate on how to make the 32yearold Clean Air Act a stronger and more efficient instrument is surely long overdue'
b'But the Bush plan falls well short of the only other credible proposal on the table a bill sponsored by Sen James Jeffords Independent of Vermont'
b'Like Jeffords the president calls for substantial reductions in three major pollutants  the nitrogen oxides that produce smog sulfur dioxide which causes acid rain and mercury'
b'But he ignores emissions of carbon dioxide the main global warming gas'
b'That is a huge omission'
b'Even for the pollutants he addresses Bushs timetable is too leisurely'
b'He aims to reduce all three by 70 percent by 2018'
b'The Jeffords proposal would make the same sizable reductions by 2008'
b'Finally the Bush proposal would roll back key provisions of the existing Clean Air Act that Jeffords would keep'

b'Bush argues that the regulatory mechanisms he has in mind for reaching Clear Skies goals chiefly a marketbased emissions trading scheme will be so effective that the need for many existing rules will disappear'
b'This page has long embraced emissions trading as an essential tool for reducing pollution at manageable cost'
b'We also agree that the law needs streamlining'
b'But some regulations aimed at specific regional problems that nationwide trading alone is unable to address cannot lightly be abandoned'
b'Among these are rules governing emissions that limit visibility in the national parks and rules governing pollution that drifts eastward from Midwestern power plants'

b'Indeed Bush has already made clear his intention to roll back one of the most important of these regulations a provision known as new source review that compels utilities to install modern pollution controls whenever they significantly upgrade older plants'
b'The 1970 Clean Air Act is a landmark statute deserving of thoughtful improvement'
b'The Bush bill as written is not the way to get there'
b'ANGELS MAKE TRADE TO GET OUTFIELD DEPTH'
b'ANAHEIM Calif  The Anaheim Angels got help where they felt they needed it most agreeing to trade for Milwaukee Brewers outfielder Alex Ochoa only hours before Wednesdays nonwaiver trading deadline'
b'In addition to Ochoa the Angels got minorleague catcher Sal Fasano'
b'In return the Brewers got backup catcher Jorge Fabregas and two players to be named later'
b'By rule the players to be named later cannot be players on the active majorleague roster'
b'In the past week the Angels deemed outfield depth their biggest need above adding a reliever to the bullpen'
b'Orlando Palmeiro was the only backup outfielder on the majorleague roster and the outfielders in the minorleague system are too inexperienced to be counted on in a pennant race'
b'In Ochoa 30 the Angels get an experienced majorleague outfielder who is hitting 256 with six homers and 21 RBI this season'
b'Ochoa has played in the majors for five different teams starting in 1995'
b'His best season came in 2000 with the Reds when he hit 316 with 13 homers and 56 RBI'
b'Going into this season he was a career 281 hitter'
b'He gives you a lot in all areas Angels general manager Bill Stoneman said'
b'He gives you a lot in all areas'
b'Hes a good defender he has a good arm he plays the tough rightfield position and plays it well'
b'Hes a righthanded bat which complements Palmeiro off the bench'
b'From a realistic standpoint were we going to find an outfielder that pushed one of our outfielders to the bench'
b'The answer is no'
b'He accepts his role with a club and hes a team guy'
b'Hes got that reputation and thats important to us especially a club like ours that is an egoless club'
b'Ochoa will join the club today in Anaheim before tonights game against the Yankees'
b'He said hes fine with his role as a reserve outfielder and pinch hitter'
b'Ive done that a lot in my career Ochoa said during a conference call'
b'Ive done that a lot in my career'
b'Coming in theyve got three great outfielders I knew that from the getgo'
b'Ochoas new teammates were generally pleased with the move even if it wasnt a blockbuster'
b'Its not the big earthshattering stuff right fielder Tim Salmon said'
b'Its not the big earthshattering stuff'
b'But we didnt need something earthshattering right now'
b'It didnt seem like we had a lot of holes to fill'
b'Its good it gives us something we didnt have and we didnt lose much'
b'Its because of Molina The Angels felt they could part with Fabregas because of the play of catcher Jose Molina'
b'Molina spent all season at TripleA Salt Lake before joining the majorleague club July 17 to replace his injured brother Bengie'
b'Bengie is expected to be activated from the disabled list today giving the Angels both Molina brothers on the active majorleague roster for the first time'
b'I feel bad for Jorge hes a good friend of mine Bengie said'
b'But they liked the way Jose has played and theyre giving him a chance'
b'Im very excited well be on the same team for a while'
b'Jose went into Wednesdays game hitting 304 and had thrown out 33 percent two of six of baserunners trying to steal'
b'Angels pitchers had a 333 ERA with Jose catching better even than Bengies 369'
b'I just hope they keep me here Jose said'
b'I just hope they keep me here'
b'Ochoa took Fabregas spot in the roster but the Angels will have to clear another spot today to make room for Bengie'
b'Infielder Jose Nieves is likely to be sent down but since he is out of options he would have to clear waivers before he could join TripleA Salt Lake'

b'Not expected Fabregas who hit 193 with no homers and eight RBI in 35 games with the Angels this season said he was surprised and shocked to get traded from a pennant contender to a team 22 games out in the NL Central'
b'I understand baseball moves Ive been through this before said Fabregas who is headed for his eighth majorleague team'
b'I understand baseball moves Ive been through this before'
b'Obviously Im disappointed to go from a team playing for first place to a team that isnt contending'
b'I felt like I was a big part of the team I went through the struggles last year and I wanted to be a part of it in the good times'
b'OLYMPIC JUDGING SCANDAL DEEPENS WITH ARREST OF RUSSIAN CRIME FIGURE'

b'A Russian accused of being in organized crime was arrested in Italy on Wednesday on an American complaint that he conspired to fix the pairs figure skating and ice dancing competitions at the recent Salt Lake Winter Olympics which were dominated by the sports judging scandals'

b'The Russian Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov who was arrested by the Italian authorities at his resort home in Forte dei Marmi appeared to have a singular motivation for rigging the competitions getting a visa to return to France where he once lived'

b'The federal prosecutor in Manhattan alleged in a criminal complaint that Tokhtakhounov had conceived and directed a scheme with a second man alleged to be in the Russian mob and a member of the Russian Skating Federation to secure a gold medal for the top Russian pairs skaters and for the top French ice dancers one of whom is a Russian'

b'The Russian team of Yelena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze narrowly won the gold medal over the Canadians Jamie Sale and David Pelletier who were later awarded a duplicate gold medal because of the ensuing judging controversy'
b'Sale and Pelletier declined to comment on Wednesday'
b'The French ice dancers Marina Anissina and Gwendal Peizerat later won the gold over a Russian team'
b'The complaint casts the Salt Lake City figure skating scandal in a more serious light than the cronyism and voteswapping that have tainted the increasingly troubled sport'

b'Over the past four years four judges have been suspended including a Ukrainian who was taped by a Canadian judge detailing the order of finish for the ice dancers before the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano Japan'

b'If convicted of the charges against him  conspiracy to commit wire fraud and conspiracy to commit bribery both felonies  Tokhtakhounov faces maximum prison time of 10 years and a fine of 500000 or more'
b'The United States is seeking his extradition from Italy'
b'The Italian authorities provided the FBI with information from wiretaps of Tokhtakhounovs home telephone part of an investigation into his criminal activities'

b'The FBI said explicit conversations about the scheme had been recorded between Tokhtakhounov and his conspirators and between him and Anissina who was born in Russia and skated for France and her mother'
b'The FBI cited a vivid conversation with Anissinas mother in which Tokhtakhounov assured her that even if her daughter falls we will make sure she is No 1'
b'falls we will make sure she is No 1'

b'After the Winter Olympics a French judge MarieReine Le Gougne was suspended by the International Skating Union for not reporting pressure she said was put on her by Didier Gailhaguet president of the French Skating Federation to vote for the Russian pairs team'
b'She later recanted and said that Canadian officials had pressured her'
b'The ISU later suspended Le Gougne and Gailhaguet for three years'
b'The federal complaint did not describe the possibility of a wider conspiracy or any contact between Tokhtakhounov or his unnamed coconspirators with Le Gougne'

b'We have alleged no connection between this man with any officials other than with Russian federation officials James B Comey the US attorney for the Southern District of New York said at a news conference'
b'We have alleged no connection between this man with any officials other than with Russian federation officials'
b'He said that Tokhtakhounov reached out to a coconspirator somebody connected to the Russian Skating Federation who did the legwork for him'
b'reached out to a coconspirator somebody connected to the Russian Skating Federation who did the legwork for him'

b'Maxwell Miller Le Gougnes lawyer in Salt Lake City said no evidence of organized crime influence came up in her suspension hearings before the ISU I think this situation vindicates the argument that weve made all along he said'
b'I think this situation vindicates the argument that weve made all along'
b'Shes a scapegoat and a target of a corrupt system and was unfairly singled out'
b'Tokhtakhounov whose age was given by Comey as 53 or 62 is a major figure in international Eurasian organized crime Comey said'
b'major figure in international Eurasian organized crime'
b'Born in Tashkent Uzbekistan and now a Russian citizen he is known as Taivanchik or Little Taiwanese for his Central Asian ethnic background'

b'Since the collapse of the Soviet Union he has been implicated in arms trading and Russian art smuggling and in the Russian news media he was accused of complicity in a plot to extort 10 million from the head of a Russian sports foundation'
b'He appears to have moved to France in 1989 according to news media reports and is reported to have Israeli citizenship also'
b'Comey said Tokhtakhounov had three residences in Italy Forte dei Marmi Rome and Milan'

b'The complaint against Tokhtakhounovs traces his contact with figure skating to 2000 when he proposed to Gailhaguet the creation of a professional hockey team in Paris that would provide revenue for the French Skating Federation'
b' Gailhaguet and Anissina are not referred to by name in an accompanying FBI agents affidavit but by their descriptions their identities are obvious'
b'In return Gailhaguet told the FBI on Feb 23 as the Olympics were taking place Tokhtakhounov asked for Gailhaguets help in renewing his French visa which was about to expire'
b'But when Gailhaguet sought guidance from a French government official he was told that Tokhtakhounovs money is bad the affidavit said'
b'Tokhtakhounovs money is bad'
b'The federal complaint offers many details of the alleged conspiracy including excerpts from a transcript of the Italian wiretaps'
b'On Feb 5 the Italian wiretaps recorded Tokhtakhounovs request to someone identified as another Russian mobster to get the number of a Russian Skating Federation official'
b'The second mobster told Tokhtakhounov that the federation official is close to us  he is a good guy he will do it'
b'is close to us  he is a good guy he will do it'
b'Tokhtakhounovs action apparently came soon after he said he received a phone call from the mother of the female ice dancer presumably Anissina'
b'A week later after Berezhnaya and Sikharulidzes pairs victory the mobsters spoke again'
b'The second mobster expressed satisfaction with the outcome of the competition and suggested that Tokhtakhounov could call the ice dancers mother or the father and tell them everything will be OK'
b'mother or the father and tell them everything will be OK'
b'He appears to be referring to Anissina'
b'The second mobster added Our Sikharulidze fell the Canadians were 10 times better and in spite of that the French with their vote gave us first place'
b'Our Sikharulidze fell the Canadians were 10 times better and in spite of that the French with their vote gave us first place'
b'He added Everything is going the way you need it'
b'Everything is going the way you need it'
b'They also discussed the coming judging in ice dancing in which the French and the Italian teams were the favorites'
b'The second mobster said the French pair had only three judges and of the two judges they needed to win the gold medal one is ours and the other our friends will give them'
b'only three judges'
b'one is ours and the other our friends will give them'
b'Their concern for lining up more votes than they thought the Italian ice dancers had may stem from the Italian teams defeat of Anissina and Peizerat in the 2001 world championships'
b'But they seemed pleased that the Russian pairs victory was achieved with the French judges vote'
b'The French have nothing but the ice dancing the second mobster said'
b'The French have nothing but the ice dancing'
b'Again Tokhtakhounov voiced his need to have his French visa extended and he said Anissina had tried to help him but Gailhaguet had thwarted her'

b'Also on Feb 12 a week before the ice dancing finals Tokhtakhounov told Anissinas mother in a telephone call that the Russian federation official had called me from America to assure that we are going to make Anissina an Olympic champion'
b'had called me from America'
b'we are going to make'
b'an Olympic champion'
b'He told her that the Russian skating federation official will help  he has two or three judges'
b'will help  he has two or three judges'
b'On or about March 7 in a conversation between Tokhtakhounov and Anissina she said she would have won the event without his assistance because the Russian judge did not vote for her and her partner'
b'She also apologized for not calling to thank him earlier but that Gailhaguet had forbidden her'
b'She told Tokhtakhounov that she knew the FBI had interviewed Gailhaguet because of information that Tokhtakhounov was involved with the results of the ice dancing'
b'was involved with the results'
b'He assured her that it was nonsense but that Gailhaguet knows my name very well  he tried to help me and later he made stuff up to scare you so you would not connect me to him even more'
b'knows my name very well  he tried to help me and later he made stuff up to scare you so you would not connect me to him even more'
b'The conversations seem to indicate a familiarity between Tokhtakhounov and Anissina'
b'Tass the official Russian news agency reported that Anissina attended a ceremony in 1999 at a Paris hotel honoring Tokhtakhounov for his philanthropy'
b'That Russian organized crime may have infiltrated international sport at the Olympics stunned Phyllis Howard president of the US Figure Skating Association'
b'This is a criminal act and it certainly puts things in a different league Howard said'
b'This is a criminal act and it certainly puts things in a different league'
b'Lloyd Ward chief executive officer of the US Olympic Committee said in a statement Competitors from all nations must be assured that they compete on a level playing field'
b'Competitors from all nations must be assured that they compete on a level playing field'
b'IBM OPENS 25 BILLION CHIP PLANT IN UPSTATE NEW YORK'

b'EAST FISHKILL NY  IBM opened a sprawling and sophisticated semiconductor factory here on Wednesday that cost more than 25 billion to build and equip the largest single capital investment the company has ever made'
b'The factory which opens as the computer chip business is in a slump is a costly and risky move for IBM'

b'But it is also an expression of confidence by the company that it can remain a technology leader in the highly competitive global semiconductor industry and a commitment that the best place to execute that strategy is in upstate New York'
b'IBM is an exception among computer makers in that it still invests heavily in research to advance the design manufacture and materials used in semiconductor chips'
b'It is spending more than 500 million a year on semiconductor research and development'
b'The factory will produce a wide range of specialized semiconductors used in everything from the largest mainframe computers to cell phones and videogame consoles'
b'The new plant is part of IBMs push to gain a strong lead in chipmaking beyond the personal computer business where Intel and East Asian chip producers hold the advantage'
b'The core of our strategy is to lead in technology and attack the highperformance segments of the market said John Kelly senior vice president in charge of IBMs technology group'
b'The core of our strategy is to lead in technology and attack the highperformance segments of the market'

b'An advantage to having the semiconductor fabricating factory here Kelly explained was that it was very close to its research laboratories in nearby Westchester County NY To stay ahead in advanced chip technology he said moving innovations out of the labs and into the factory as fast as possible is crucial'
b'What we call the labtofab time should be as close to zero as possible Kelly said'
b'What we call the labtofab time should be as close to zero as possible'
b'If our strategy were anything but to be on the leading edge wed have put the plant in Asia'
b'The new factory which will begin normal production early next year will employ about 1000 people'

b'In remarks during a ribboncutting ceremony here on Wednesday Gov George E Pataki said he expected the facility to generate thousands more jobs in the Hudson Valley area for contractors and suppliers catering to the factory'
b'He praised IBM for being a critical partner in our economic development efforts in New York state'
b'a critical partner in our economic development efforts'
b'In a brief speech Samuel J Palmisano IBMs chief executive emphasized that it was important to make longterm investments despite the current slump in the technology business'
b'To play to win in technology you innovate and you lead'
b'But manufacturing technology products is a costly and cyclical business'
b'In June IBM announced that it was taking a charge of more than 2 billion against earnings'
b'But Kelly said the demand for advanced chips like those produced at IBMs facility in Burlington Vt is strong'
b'I need more capacity in that end of the market he said and this is factory is critical to meeting that growing demand'
b'I need more capacity in that end of the market'
b'If IBM has miscalculated the demand it will suffer badly as both the high operating costs and depreciation on the huge capital investment for the East Fishkill factory drag down earnings'
b'But industry analysts said the plant should be insulated from a falloff in one or a few segments of the semiconductor market'
b'The factory is highly automated and designed to shift flexibly to produce many different kinds of chips to suit demand'
b'The diversity is the big difference with this plant said Richard Doherty president of Envisioneering a research firm'
b'The diversity is the big difference with this plant'
b'It gives IBM the capability to make so many different kinds of custom chips and the world is going to custom chips'
b'The 140000squarefoot plant is a testament to advanced manufacturing technology'
b'The 300millimeter silicon wafers  about the size of a standard pizza  are shuttled around the facility in enclosed plastic pods which ride on overhead tracks'
b'They drop down from wires automatically into machines sheathed in stainless steel and glass for each stage of processing and fabrication'
b'Throughout the 500 processing steps which typically last 20 days the wafers are not touched by human hands'
b'The circuits etched into the chips are less than one thousandth the width of a human hair'
b'Human operators are there to monitor the systems catch errors and finetune the production process for maximum efficiency'

b'Because each of the hundreds of processing machines is selfenclosed and essentially airtight the uniforms operators wear are less constricting than in the previous generation of chip plants which looked like space suits'
b'The operators at the East Fishkill factory wear light nylon uniforms light blue shoe coverings and translucent hair nets made of paper'
b'They look more like workers in a bakery'
b'Yes said Richard Brilla director of the new facility but the donuts are a lot more costly here'
b'but the donuts are a lot more costly here'
b'Each wafer holding hundreds of chips is worth 6000 to 10000 apiece depending on what insulation circuitry and materials are used'

b'Hurricane force A change in the rules and a fluke in the calendar this season allows colleges to play 12 regularseason games'
b'Of all the 12th games added to the schedule Floridas might be the most daunting Miami on Sept 7 after the Gators open up with AlabamaBirmingham'

b'CHRON EDITORS NOTE Each week The Chronicle offers readers a look at the more unusual fruits vegetables and herbs of each season and how to use them'
b'THE PRODUCE BIN Bitter melon'
b'SAN FRANCISCO  A staple of Chinese and Indian cooking these gourds botanically Momordica charantia with skin like toads grow on climbing vines that can reach 12 feet'
b'The Chinese and Indian varieties differ little in taste'
b'Though they resemble squashes they are natives to Asia rather than the Americas but are now cultivated in many regions of the world that boast moderate to warm climates'
b'Hmong farmers grow them in Californias Central Valley and Mexico has a substantial crop'
b'SEASON Bitter melons can be found in Asian and specialty produce markets primarily from spring through late fall'
b'Right now some particularly nice ones are in Bay Area farmers markets'
b'HOW TO SELECT As the gourd ripens its color changes from near whitepale green to vivid green often flecked with yellow and eventually bright orange'
b'When young the flavor is relatively mild with a fresh sour note'
b'As it ripens it gets progressively more bitter due to the quinine it contains'
b'USES Bitter melons are used in many Asian cuisines most prominently Indian Chinese and Vietnamese'
b'Generally they are halved lengthwise the seeds and fibrous pulp removed and the flesh sliced into crescents'
b'They are frequently blanched or salted and left to macerate for up to an hour then rinsed and patted dry to tame the bitterness'
b'Chinese hotandsour soup made with egg white and crabmeat often includes bitter melon'
b'It also appears in stirfrys especially those based on pork'
b'Black bean sauce is a favorite seasoning'
b'When pickled bitter melon makes a savory condiment'
b'In Vietnam bitter melon halves are stuffed with meat mixtures such as ground pork with black mushrooms and cellophane noodles then braised'

b'Colin Spencers Vegetable Book details an intriguing Indian chapati in which bitter melon seeds left intact is sliced parboiled then mixed with lightly fried garlic and Indian spices flour and yogurt'
b'The mixture is fried like a thick pancake and served sliced with rice naan and other curries'
b'Grande dame of cooking still going strong at 90 Julia Child celebrates in San Francisco'
b'How does it feel to turn 90 and have attained the status of an icon a living legend'
b'It feels just like it felt before Julia Child says with the throaty laugh familiar to millions who cut their culinary teeth on her French Chef television series'
b'The show along with her seminal book Mastering the Art of French Cooking 1961 revolutionized the way America cooks and eats'
b'While making light of the difference a day  or another decade  makes Child intends to enjoy her birthday thoroughly'

b'First there will be all the public observances including a soldout dinner Thursday at San Franciscos tony Fifth Floor restaurant which  like dinners that night at 19 other venues across the country  will benefit the scholarship fund of the International Association of Culinary Professionals which Child cofounded'
b'Friday to Sunday the action moves to Napa with both membersonly and public events at COPIA The American Center for Wine Food and the Arts of which she is an honorary board member'

b'Aug 15 her actual birthday will see her in Maine at an annual gathering of nieces nephews their offspring and friends who for many years have rolled a joined birthday celebration for several members of the group into a jolly reunion'

b'The schedule Child and her assistant of 14 years former pastry chef Stephanie Hersh have laid out is not exactly a seniorcitizen routine even though Child has always been candid about her age and realistic in assessing her own capabilities'

b'When the Pasadena native moved back to California from her longtime home in the Boston area last year she also made the move from a condominium she and her late husband Paul had purchased many years ago to a progressive retirement home'
b'She is in the most active of the four levels available but should the need arise she can move on to assisted living facilities within the same complex'
b'Julia explains Hersh made these retirement plans many years ago'
b'She thinks its selfish for people not to make arrangements for their old age in good time'
b'But so far age has been kind to the ebullient Child'

b'In a phone interview a couple of weeks ago she reported with glee that surgery early this month to remove a small cyst on her spinal cord had miraculously cleared up recent problems in walking Turned out there is nothing wrong with my legs at all'
b'So she can once again go shopping buying whatever seems best on any given day'
b'Though she had a nice kitchen installed in her new home Child said its like a ships galley  a far cry from the huge threepantry kitchen Paul Child designed for their house in Cambridge'
b'That may well be the bestknown kitchen in America since it became the site of the French Chef television programs which started airing in 1962'
b'Back there we always ate in the kitchen Child reminisced I cannot do that here'
b'That means her entertaining has been curtailed even though she still has an active social life with the many friends the Childs made during 22 winters spent in Santa Barbara'
b'She will have reunions of sorts with her famous kitchen in the next few weeks'
b'One of its PegBoard walls was dismantled and reinstalled at COPIA the rest went to Washington DC and the Behring Center of the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of American History'
b'all CQ Hersh recalls the museum staffs approach to preserving the famous kitchen as awesome They cataloged and photographed everything from stove to windows blinds to drawer contents'
b'As reinstalled in Washington the kitchen should be as we all remember it from countless TV shows right down to the toothpicks'
b'Child will go to the capital for the debut of the exhibit right after the Maine birthday bash'
b'To see her kitchen  and by extension herself  enshrined in the Smithsonian she said will be an odd feeling and no doubt bring back memories'
b'But Child is not one to get maudlin about the past though she does want to keep it alive'
b'Shes already got her next project picked out A memoir of her and Pauls life in the diplomatic service with his professional photographs and some of her collected recipes'

b'It will undoubtedly retell how the seeds of her culinary career were sown Fresh off the boat on their way to Paris and Paul Childs new posting they had met in Sri Lanka during World War II they stopped for lunch in Rouen'

b'That lunch lit a spark that made Julia decide to take classes at the Cordon Bleu which in turn led to her friendship and collaboration with Simone Beck and Louisette Bertholle coauthors of Mastering the Art of French Cooking and ultimately to Americas culinary revolution'
b'For information on COPIA events open to the public sign on to wwwcopiaorg or call 707 2591600'
b'How to feed a legend'
b'So what do you prepare when asked to cook a birthday dinner for Americas most famous culinary personality'
b'Some of the countrys top chefs will answer that question Thursday at the 20 dinners nationwide that will celebrate Julia Childs approaching 90th birthday'
b'The question may be most acute for three San Francisco chefs preparing the long soldout dinner at Fifth Floor restaurant because the honoree herself plans to be there'
b'They are the host restaurants executive chef Laurent Gras his counterpart at Masas Ron Siegel and Masa pastry chef Keith Jeanminette'

b'The three put their heads together thumbed through Mastering the Art of French Cooking and In Julias Kitchen and selected what seemed like the honorees favorites though with a few twists of their own'
b'It seems she loves soups said Siegel so I am picking up on her vichyssoise'
b'But since its the middle of summer I am adding fresh corn to it  plus a dollop of caviar for good measure'
b'In the same vein Gras is tweaking her salade nicoise and Jeanminette is adapting her mousse au chocolat to become a spectacular sixlayer pecan marjolaine'
b'He could hardly go wrong'
b'When Child was asked some years back what she would order for her last meal she ended the list with something chocolate for dessert'
b'Here is the San Francisco chefs menu'
b'Corn vichyssoise with caviar'
b'Julias composed nearnicoise salad'
b'Atlantic halibut with flavored butters'
b'Sonoma duck breast a la Julia Child with crispy pancetta and sweet summer onions and naturally enriched duck sauce'
b'Sixlayer pecan marjolaine with Julias coffee chocolate mousse cocoa meringue pecan crust and citrus sorbet'
b'list'
b'Words of wisdom'
b'Julia Child doesnt have much use for fads and trends  never has'

b'She never subscribed to cuisine minceur cholesterolfree cooking meatfree meal plans organic food or any of the other politically correct trends of different times  and that includes restricted diets in spades'
b'However an active woman all her life she is aware of the need to keep ones weight and fitness in mind'
b'Here are her personal rules for achieving these goals'
b'Take small helpings'
b'No seconds'
b'No snacking'
b'Eat a little bit of everything'
b'Drink modest amounts of good wine'
b'Why we love Julia'
b'Its easy to imagine what Bay Area chefs like Alice Waters or Michael Mina might have to say about Julia Child on her 90th birthday'
b'But what about Bay Area notables who like to cook but are not connected to a professional kitchen'

b'Susie Tompkins Buell socialite and political activist who cofounded the Esprit de Corps fashion company When I think of Julia Child I think of the television episode where shes showing you how to make a turkey dinner and the turkey fell on the floor'
b'Its live and she leans over and picks it up and says What the guests dont see wont hurt them'
b'You have to be playful and confident about cooking'
b'She cooks that way and I cook that way'
b'Denise Hale social icon and Liza Minnellis stepmother Julia Child gave to all women one beautiful present Watching her series you found out you dont have to be perfect'
b'Francis Ford Coppola film director I think shes a fascinating woman and I enjoy very much watching her shows with Jacques Pepin'
b'Harry Denton San Francisco nightclub owner My favorite thing about her is her straightforward honesty and that her favorite food is butter'
b'I love butter too'

b'Michael Chabon author of Pulitzer Prize winner The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier  Clay All I think of when I think of her now is Dan Akroyd pretending to be her on Saturday Night Live and chopping his fingers off and bleeding all over'
b'RESPONSIBLE SEAFOOD SALES ARE THE CATCH OF THE DAY'
b'ATTENTION EDITORS This article from the NEWHOUSE NEWS SERVICE report of TUESDAY JULY 30 2002 is available as a separate buy'
b'UNDATED Chefs and seafood retailers are wading into one of the hottest natural resource issues of the day fisheries management'
b'Its no longer unusual for chefs to refuse to serve a species they think to be at risk of extinction or for a retailer to promote seafoods that are abundant and part of a healthy marine ecosystem'
b'Most say theyre driven by the desire to do right by the environment'
b'Some also say they must listen to their customers concerns or risk a consumer backlash'
b'The nationwide boycott of Chilean seabass is a potent example of the new activism'
b'I have made it a policy of mine never to serve Chilean seabass said Billy Hahn executive chef at Jakes Famous Crawfish a Portland Ore landmark since 1892'
b'I have made it a policy of mine never to serve Chilean seabass'
b'I refuse to sell it'
b'Chilean seabass also known as Patagonian toothfish came into vogue in the 1990s in US restaurants and fish markets'
b'With rising demand for the firm oilrich fish came pirate fishing fleets eager to cash in on its popularity  even if it meant skirting catch limits and environmental regulations'
b'Contrary to what some restaurants and retailers tell their customers the US government does not consider the Chilean seabass to be endangered'
b'But in some areas the seabass are being overfished'

b'That is potentially a problem because Chilean seabass are a longlived species  living as long as 50 years  and reproduce slowly said Susan Buchanan a spokeswoman for the federal governments National Marine Fisheries Service'
b'The NMFS estimates that in 2000 more than 16000 tons of Chilean seabass were legally caught from an internationally regulated harvest area in the Antarctic Ocean'
b'But more than 32000 tons may have been taken illegally from those same waters the fisheries service said'
b'Impatient with regulators the National Environmental Trust began a boycott campaign in February called Take a Pass on Chilean Seabass'
b'The Washingtonbased conservation group says more than 530 restaurants have signed on'
b'A number of restaurants not officially part of the National Environmental Trust boycott also have stopped serving Chilean seabass'
b'And its not just the white tablecloth crowd'

b'Red Lobster with 660 restaurants in the United States and Canada dropped Chilean seabass from the menu in the past year because of sustainability concerns said Wendy Spirduso communications director for the Orlando Flabased chain'
b'sustainability'
b'Some retailers also have pulled Chilean seabass'
b'Weve discontinued selling swordfish Chilean seabass orange roughy and marlin said Mark Cockcroft national seafood buyer for Wild Oats Markets a chain of 103 stores'
b'Weve discontinued selling swordfish Chilean seabass orange roughy and marlin'
b'We are also taking a real hard look currently at almost all species of shark though we havent made a formal statement about that'
b'Whole Foods Markets with 133 stores nationwide also does not sell Chilean seabass'

b'All of this comes at a time when Americans are consuming more seafood 15 to 16 pounds per person each year compared with 103 pounds per person in 1960 and 125 pounds in 1980 according to the National Fisheries Institute an industry association'
b'At the same time about half the worlds fisheries are being fished to capacity'

b'The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reports that 47 percent to 50 percent of stocks are fully exploited meaning that catches have either reached or are close to maximum limits'
b'Another 15 percent to 18 percent are overexploited and 9 percent to 10 percent have been depleted or are recovering from depletion'
b'The seafood industry is less than thrilled about this surge of interest in ocean ecosystems from people who are not scientists'
b'Fisheries management is best left to the experts said Thor Lassen president of Ocean Trust a research and conservation foundation partly financed by the fishing industry'
b'It involves very complicated choices that have to do with the biology of species their life cycles how they respond to various changes in the oceans etc'
b'When theres a boycott Lassen said its not environmentalists or chefs making the sacrifice its coastal communities'
b'its not environmentalists or chefs making the sacrifice its coastal communities'
b'Rod Moore executive director of the West Coast Seafood Processors Association suggests that activists with an agenda are manipulating chefs and retailers'

b'The conservation groups providing information to chefs and retailers and lists of environmentally appropriate seafoods to consumers are the same groups working to affect fisheries management on the political and regulatory level Moore said'
b'Thats simply good strategy said James Leape deputy director of the conservation program for the David and Lucile Packard Foundation in Los Altos Calif'
b'In 2000 and 2001 the Packard Foundation awarded 26 million in marine fisheries conservation grants'
b'They included support for marine reserves and money for fisheries management reform'
b'More than 7 million was given to projects aimed at educating the general public'
b'One of the principal concerns of the Packard Foundation is the preservation of natural resources particularly in the oceans and one of the greatest threats is overfishing Leape said'
b'One of the principal concerns of the Packard Foundation is the preservation of natural resources particularly in the oceans and one of the greatest threats is overfishing'
b'We have seen that raising consumer awareness and concern among restaurants and retailers about a particular fishery can really make a difference'
b'The Monterey Bay Aquariums Web site rates different species of fish for overfishing habitat damage and other factors'
b'The California aquarium also created Seafood Watch wallet cards designed to take to restaurants'
b'More than 600000 of the cards and seafood guides have been distributed since 2000 said Jennifer Dianto Seafood Watch program manager at the aquarium'
b'Chefs and retailers around the country know they must be prepared to deal with customers who arrive with the aquariums seafood card in hand'
b'But in a business in which 12hour shifts are the norm some chefs worry about their lack of time to stay informed about complicated rapidly changing fisheries management issues'
b'Some working chefs say they routinely review conservation group Web sites government reports and industry sources'
b'For me its very difficult to be certain that the information which is given to me is real'
b'For me its very difficult to be certain that the information which is given to me is real said Eric Ripert chef at Le Bernardin a fourstar seafood restaurant in Manhattan'
b'I dont know'
b'I dont have enough information to know for example if Chilean seabass is really disappearing or if its political pressure'
b'Despite being uncertain of its status Ripert pulled Chilean seabass'
b'Le Bernardins menu also informs diners that the restaurant will not serve swordfish to support efforts to recover the species'
b'to recover the species'
b'I dont wish to be a spokesman for any campaign Ripert said'
b'I dont wish to be a spokesman for any campaign'
b'I do it as somebody who has a conscience and is caring'
b'Michelle Cole is a staff writer for The Oregonian of Portland Ore'
b'She can be contacted at michellecoleatnewsoregoniancom'
b'PRESCRIPTION PRIVILEGES MAKE SOME PSYCHOLOGISTS ANXIOUS'
b'ATTENTION EDITORS This article is for use by clients of The New York Times Syndicates SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN NEWS SERVICE'
b'For information about becoming a client of this service contact the New York Times Syndicate sales representatives listed at the end of the text'
b'Intending to ease consumer access to mental health care New Mexico legislators in March passed a law allowing psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medications such as antidepressants'

b'The states action the first in the nation has the blessing of the American Psychological Association APA which considers prescriptive authority a logical extension of psychologists role as healthcare providers'

b'But powerful groups including the American Medical Association oppose the idea and have a surprising source of support psychologists themselves some of whom call it a radical experiment and fear that the most likely victim will be the science of psychology'

b'I am concerned that nonmedically trained people as legitimate prescribers of drugs will not be accepted by the American public says psychologist Gerald C Davison of the University of Southern California'
b'I am concerned that nonmedically trained people as legitimate prescribers of drugs will not be accepted by the American public'
b'The APA has spent more than 1 million to help state psychological associations develop and lobby for such prescription privileges  or RxP  legislation'
b'A total of 31 state psychology associations have task forces dedicated to developing and lobbying for prescriptionprivileges legislation'

b'The version endorsed by the APA would license doctorallevel psychologists to independently prescribe psychotropic drugs after completing 300 hours of classroom instruction in neuroscience physiology and pharmacology followed by four months supervised treatment of 100 patients'
b'Critics say that is not nearly enough compared with other prescribers such as MD psychiatrists or nurse practitioners who have at least six years medical education and clinical experience'
b'Neither Davison nor most other RxP opponents doubt the efficacy of medications'
b'Their greatest objection is to the notion of turning psychology into a prescribing profession'

b'In a field that has struggled long and hard to prove that mind mood and behavior can be studied empirically the past decade Davison says has seen exciting developments that demonstrate the validity of various psychotherapeutic interventions and the psychosocialbehavioral models on which they are based'
b'exciting developments'

b'The timing is peculiar to abandon psychological science or to convert it to a medical science explains Elaine M Heiby of the University of Hawaii who chairs a committee of the 1000member American Association of Applied and Preventive Psychology that is concerned about the medicalization of psychology'
b'The timing is peculiar to abandon psychological science or to convert it to a medical science'

b'Making sure that practicing psychologists are giving patients interventions based on the best available psychological science should be the APAs priority argues Emory Universitys Scott Lilienfeld president of the Society for a Science of Clinical Psychology SSCP'
b'Making sure that practicing psychologists are giving patients interventions based on the best available psychological science should be the APAs priority'
b'More than any philosophical betrayal of psychology RxP opponents fear that the movement will undermine the science they love'

b'They believe that if prescriptive authority becomes the norm biomedical requirements will inevitably seep into the psychology curriculum at the expense of traditional psychological science and methodology'
b'Lilienfeld feels that many clinical psychologists already receive inadequate training in fundamentals such as research design and evaluation'
b'RxP opponents charge the APA with pushing its prescriptionprivileges agenda without adequately assessing support for it in the field'
b'The 300member SSCP is the only group within the APA to have taken a formal stance against prescription privileges'
b'The APA has scheduled 30 minutes at its meeting in August for an RxP debate but its leadership believes it already has an accurate sense of support for its RxP policy'
b'Except for this small vocal minority we have just not gotten a lot of groundswell against this from members says APA president Philip G Zimbardo of Stanford University'
b'Except for this small vocal minority we have just not gotten a lot of groundswell against this from members'
b'With prescription privileges now a reality in one state some RxP opponents concede that it may be too late'
b'This year four states besides New Mexico  Georgia Hawaii Illinois and Tennessee  have pending legislation for psychologist prescription privileges'
b'Over the past decade 14 state legislatures have considered such laws'
b'Between 1991 and 1997 a US Department of Defense psychopharmacology demonstration project involving two to four years training produced 10 military psychologists who can write prescriptions'
b'For more information on the topics covered in the Scientific American News Service visit wwwsciamcom'
