b'A mission to end a war'
b'AUSTIN Texas  Tom Karnes was dialing for destiny but not everyone wanted to cooperate'
b'Karnes sat in his woodpaneled office in a Quonset hut in the middle of the Great Salt Lake Desert a black telephone to his ear'
b'He was tracking down men to join a group so secret he couldnt admit it existed'
b'On his metal desk were names of military men being ordered into the organization'
b'He was calling bases all over the United States to line up their transfer to the desert outside Salt Lake City'
b'Where is the authority asked one officer who didnt want to lose a valuable man under his command'
b'Where is the authority'
b'Who says this another commanding officer asked Karnes'
b'Who says this'
b'Each time Karnes said what he had to Call Air Force headquarters if you dont believe me'
b'Call Air Force headquarters if you dont believe me'
b'This is a Silverplate request he said'
b'This is a Silverplate request'
b'Silverplate code word for the historic mission that would end World War II'
b'Almost 1800 men were assembled n late 1944 to join the topsecret unit called the 509th Composite Group'
b'Col Paul Tibbets the pilot who would drop the worlds first atomic bomb over Hiroshima Japan was commander of the unit and chose the men'
b'And the first person he chose to join him was Karnes though he couldnt reveal the mission to Karnes'
b'Karnes 87 is a retired history professor who lives in suburban Austin with his wife Virginia who also worked for the 509th as a civilian bookkeeper for six months'
b'Karnes was Tibbets adjutant the man in charge of writing the orders and cajoling the transfer to the unit of servicemen proficient in bombing mechanics ordnance engineering and communications'
b'Tibbets hated paperwork'
b'Karnes thought it was a breeze'
b'They were a wartime match that changed the world'
b'Japan surrendered within days of the detonation of the atomic bombs that killed 140000 people in Hiroshima on Aug 6 1945 and 70000 in Nagasaki three days later'

b'The story of the 509th is a tale of an elite outfit that lived in a bubble of secrecy and endured the taunts of other warweary US units that resented sharing a small Pacific island with the 509th which appeared exempt from combat'
b'Tinian Island was the staging area where the 509th moved after its creation in the desert'
b'Karnes has never spoken publicly about his role as Tibbets righthand administrative aide'
b'He never even told his story to students in his 40 years of teaching college'
b'War is hell he says and when it was over he wanted to come home and rejoin his young family and not dwell on it'
b'He earned a doctorate in history from Stanford University and taught Latin American history at Tulane University and Arizona State University'
b'Next week marks the 57th anniversary of the atomic bombings'
b'Each year on Aug 6 I always think of Paul Tibbets and how he handled unbelievable responsibility Karnes said'
b'Karnes met Tibbets when the 29yearold bomber pilot walked into Karnes office at Wendover Army Air Field on the UtahNevada border'
b'Karnes was the personnel and classification officer'
b'He was only a captain but he had been left in charge at Wendover the day Tibbets surprised them by landing a B29 a new plane no one at Wendover had seen'
b'Tibbets had just been ordered to organize a combat force to drop a bomb being developed by a secret enterprise known as the Manhattan Project'
b'He was searching for a remote installation to train bomber crews and support units in total secrecy'
b'Tibbets instantly liked the isolation and vast size of Wendover and the surrounding Bonneville Salt Flats'
b'And he immediately liked Karnes who showed him around the base'
b'In Karnes Tibbets found a kindred spirit  and a handball partner'
b'Both were smart disciplined quiet men who thrived on efficiency perfection and selfreliance'
b'Each had skills the other admired'
b'Tibbets was a decorated topgun pilot but Karnes could wrangle the military rule book as well as Tibbets could fly'
b'I dont recall ever having to tell Tom to do anything Tibbets said in an email this week'
b'I dont recall ever having to tell Tom to do anything'
b'He was so knowledgeable he just got things done allowing me to concentrate on other matters'
b'I was very lucky to have Tom'
b'Tibbets quickly returned to Wendover after that first visit to set up his headquarters'
b'His first order appointed Karnes adjutant for the 509th'
b'Almost overnight Wendover became a highsecurity base filled with offlimit areas covered in barbed wire'
b'No one was allowed to talk about what they saw or heard even though most of the 509th had no idea why they were there except that 15 B29s were being modified to carry a heavy load'
b'Karnes and his staff read outgoing mail to make sure no secrets slipped out'
b'Karnes hated to pry and skimmed over personal portions of the letters'
b'Phone calls were monitored'
b'An undercover force of Manhattan Project security agents infiltrated the base and bars in the little town of Wendover population 103 to spy on airmen'
b'Karnes knew the 509th was preparing for a special bombing mission but he had no idea what kind of bombs were involved'
b'I had a friend the finance officer'
b'He said that they had split the atom and that we were going to drop an atomic bomb Karnes said'
b'He said that they had split the atom and that we were going to drop an atomic bomb'
b'I said No'
b'A noncommittal mmmmm was the most Karnes could ever get out of Tibbets on matters of the bomb'
b'mmmmm'
b'By spring the 509th prepared to move to Tinian Island near Guam and Saipan'
b'That would put the B29s about 1500 miles from Japan  a 13hour roundtrip flight'
b'Karnes was deluged with orders for inoculations equipment transfers and promotions'
b'Karnes arrived on Tinian on May 18 1945 as part of an advance team that flew in the five C54 transport planes of the 509th'
b'On May 29 1200 men arrived on the troopship Cape Victory after a fiveweek trip from Seattle'
b'Tinian Island had been captured from Japan and the Seabees the construction arm of the Navy had built two large airfields'
b'The 509th took North Field and stayed in relative isolation from other B29 units on the island'
b'Karnes handed out bunk assignments choosing the mess officer Chuck Perry to share his tent'
b'Karnes had his own Jeep and went to the beach and to evening movies shown by other units as often as he could'
b'Not until the day before Tibbets and his crew flew to Hiroshima was the 509th told what was happening'
b'The word spread This is it'
b'This is it'
b'This is the big mission'
b'Karnes and hundreds of other men from the 509th stood along the flight line as Tibbets and the Enola Gay took off at 245 am on Aug 6 a warm tropical night'
b'Three B29s had gone ahead to check the weather at Hiroshima and two other possible bomb sites'
b'Two other B29s left in twominute intervals after Tibbets so their crews could take photos and drop devices to measure radiation and other effects of the bomb'
b'Tibbets got the word only an hour from Hiroshima that the citys weather was clear'
b'As they approached Tibbets braced for Japanese antiaircraft fire'
b'None came'
b'Early in the flight the crew had inserted a plug of uranium into the 9000pound bomb nicknamed Little Boy'
b'Ninety seconds from the bomb drop Tibbets put the plane on autopilot'
b'The crew slipped on dark glasses to prepare for the blinding flash of the bomb'
b'At 815 am Hiroshima time the pneumatic bombbay doors opened and Little Boy equivalent to 20000 tons of TNT fell out'
b'The Enola Gay climbed and Tibbets fought to turn the plane in the airbending 155degree the crews had been practicing off Tinian for months'
b'He pushed off the dark glasses because he couldnt see to fly'
b'When the bomb exploded as planned 1890 feet over Hiroshima Tibbets mouth tingled and he tasted the lead fillings in his teeth'
b'A minute later the shock wave hit'
b'The crew was horrified by the purple mushroom cloud that climbed to 10 miles and looked as if it would engulf the Enola Gay'
b'More shocking was the city of Hiroshima which was on fire and bubbling like tar'
b'We were all appalled the pilot said in his book The Tibbets Story'
b'We were all appalled'
b'Back on Tinian Karnes had gone to bed'
b'But he didnt sleep long'
b'Someone woke him to say Gen Hap Arnold chief of the Army Air Forcesin Washington was on the phone and asking for him'
b'Arnold told Karnes Tibbets is going to be landing in three to four hours and I want to give him the Distinguished Service Cross and it is your job to write up the explanation'
b'Tibbets is going to be landing in three to four hours and I want to give him the Distinguished Service Cross and it is your job to write up the explanation'
b'I had no idea how you wrote up an award'
b'Id never written up any award Karnes said'
b'Id never written up any award'
b'So I got all of my sergeants out and theyre all digging through their books'

b'When an unsuspecting Tibbets descended from the Enola Gay on Tinian he barely managed to palm his pipe as Gen Carl Spaatz commander of the Strategic Air Forces stepped forward to pin the medal on his bomb flight coveralls'
b'Karnes like the hundreds of others gathered along the flight line was jubilant'
b'He knew the war would soon be over and he would be heading home'
b'A yearof secrecy and hard work wasover'
b'Three days later another B29 from the 509th bombed Nagasaki'
b'Five days later Japan surrendered and World War II was over'
b'Today Karnes is frustrated that some of his fellow historians the ones he calls revisionists question the wisdom and morality of the bombings'
b'What matters he believes is that his generation thought the bomb should be dropped'
b'We were not bloodthirsty guys he said'
b'We were not bloodthirsty guys'
b'We were convinced then and I still am that we ended the war a year or two earlier'
b'And what the casualties would have been who knows  but heavy'
b'On Tinian and probably elsewhere the Seabees were building enormous hospitals while we were there he said'
b'On Tinian and probably elsewhere the Seabees were building enormous hospitals while we were there'
b'Those hospitals were not for us'
b'They were for an expected invasion of Japan'
b'And then the casualties were going to be terrible'
b'Karnes carries the image of hundreds of hospital beds in his mind'
b'In his heart he holds the unshakable conviction that the mission he helped organize saved America from disaster'
b'Denise Gamino writes for the Austin Texas AmericanStatesman'
b'Inauguration of free zone in Dubai for ecommerce'
b'Dubai 1028 FP '
b'Dubais Crown Prince Sheikh Mohamed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum inaugurated a free zone for ecommerce today called Dubai Internet City'
b'The preliminary stages of the project the only one of its kind according to its designers are estimated at 200 million'
b'Sheikh Mohamed who is also the Defense Minister of the United Arab Emirates announced at the inauguration ceremony that we want to make Dubai a new trading center'
b'The minister who has his own website also said I want Dubai to be the best place in the world for stateoftheart technology companies'
b'He said companies engaged in ecommerce would be able to set up offices employ staff and own equipment in the open zone including fullyowned foreign companies'
b'The ecommerce free zone is situated in north Dubai near the industrial free zone in Jebel Ali the top regional and tenth international leading area in container transit'
b'The inauguration of Dubai Internet City coincides with the opening of an annual IT show in Dubai the Gulf Information Technology Exhibition Gitex the biggest in the Middle East'
b'Launching the Electronics Free Trade Zone in Dubai'
b'Dubai 0182 AFP '
b'Crown Prince of Dubai Al Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoom crown prince of Dubai launched today ie on Saturday an electronics free etrade zone which has been named Dubai Internet City'
b'The cost in the first stage of this unique project is estimated at 200 million dollars'
b'Sheikh Mohammed who is also the UAE Defence Minister said during the launching ceremony we wish to make Dubai a center of modern economy'
b'The minister who has a personal website on the internet further said that he wanted Dubai to become the best place in the world for the advanced hitech technological companies'

b'He said that it would he possible for the companies working in the electronic trade sector to make Dubai their headquarters and to establish offices here and provide employment and own machinery in the zone opened to companies fully owned by the foreigners'

b'The electronic trade free trade zone is situated in the north of Dubai close to the free industrial zone in Jabal Ali Mountain an area which is considered to be the first in the country and tenth in the world for transit movement'
b'Launching Dubai Internet city  coincided with the opening of the annual information fair in Dubai which is considered to be the biggest in the Middle East  Gulf Information Technology Getix'

b'Upjohn Co said it will offer an early retirement package to as many as 1100 employees in a costcutting move expected to result in a fourthquarter charge'

b'The Finnish government and major creditors of bankrupt shipyard Waertsilae Marine Industries Oy agreed in principle to form a new company to complete most of the troubled shipyards backlog of 15 ships'

b'Subcontractors will be offered a settlement and a swift transition to new management is expected to avert an exodus of skilled workers from Waertsilae Marines two big shipyards government officials said'

b'Ralston Purina Co reported a 47 decline in fourthquarter earnings reflecting restructuring costs as well as a more difficult pet food market'
b'The St Louis company earned 452 million or 65 cents a share compared with 849 million or 124 a share a year earlier'
b'Sales in the latest period were 176 billion a 13 increase from last years 155 billion'
b'For the year ended Sept 30 Ralston earned 4225 million or 644 a share up 89 from 3878 million or 563 a share'
b'This years results included a gain of 702 million on the disposal of seafood operations'
b'Sales for the full year were 66 billion up 13 from 58 billion'

b'Ralston said its restructuring costs include the phaseout of a battery facility in Greenville NC the recent closing of a Hostess cake bakery in Cincinnati and a reduction in staff throughout the company'
b'The battery plant which makes rechargeable nickel cadmium and carbon zinc products will be closed over the next year or so a spokesman said'
b'Ralston attributed its fourthquarter slump partly to higher costs of ingredients in the pet food business as well as competitive pressures which required higher advertising spending'
b'For the year pet food volume was flat the company said'
b'Its cereal division realized higher operating profit on volume increases but also spent more on promotion'
b'The Continental Baking business benefited from higher margins on bread and on increased cake sales it added'
b'Ralston said its Eveready battery unit was hurt by continuing economic problems in South America'
b'Ralston shares closed yesterday at 8050 off 1 in New York Stock Exchange composite trading'
b'Electronic theft by foreign and industrial spies and disgruntled employees is costing US companies billions and eroding their international competitive advantage'
b'That was the message delivered by government and private security experts at an allday conference on corporate electronic espionage'

b'Hostile and even friendly nations routinely steal information from US companies and share it with their own companies said Noel D Matchett a former staffer at the federal National Security Agency and now president of Information Security Inc Silver Spring Md'

b'It may well be that theft of business data is as serious a strategic threat to national security as it is a threat to the survival of victimized US firms said Michelle Van Cleave the White Houses assistant director for National Security Affairs'

b'The conference was jointly sponsored by the New York Institute of Technology School of Management and the Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association a joint industrygovernment trade group'
b'Any secret can be pirated the experts said if it is transmitted over the air'
b'Even rank amateurs can do it if they spend a few thousand dollars for a commercially available microwave receiver with amplifier and a VCR recorder'
b'They need only position themselves near a companys satellite dish and wait'
b'You can have a dozen competitors stealing your secrets at the same time Mr Matchett said adding  Its a pretty good bet they wont get caught'
b'The only way to catch an electronic thief he said is to set him up with erroneous information'
b'Even though electronic espionage may cost US firms billions of dollars a year most arent yet taking precautions the experts said'
b'By contrast European firms will spend 150 million this year on electronic security and are expected to spend 1 billion by 1992'
b'Already many foreign firms especially banks have their own cryptographers conference speakers reported'
b'Still encrypting corporate communications is only a partial remedy'

b'One expert whose job is so politically sensitive that he spoke on condition that he wouldnt be named or quoted said the expected influx of East European refugees over the next few years will greatly increase the chances of computermaintenance workers for example doubling as foreign spies'
b'Moreover he said technology now exists for stealing corporate secrets after theyve been erased from a computers memory'
b'He said that Oliver North of IranContra notoriety thought he had erased his computer but that the information was later retrieved for congressional committees to read'
b'No personal computer not even the one on a chief executives desk is safe this speaker noted'

b'W Mark Goode president of Micronyx Inc a Richardson Texas firm that makes computersecurity products provided a new definition for Mikhail Gorbachevs campaign for greater openness known commonly as glasnost'
b'Under Mr Gorbachev Mr Goode said the Soviets are openly stealing Western corporate communications'
b'He cited the case of a Swiss oil trader who recently put out bids via telex for an oil tanker to pick up a cargo of crude in the Middle East'
b'Among the responses the Swiss trader got was one from the Soviet national shipping company which hadnt been invited to submit a bid'
b'The Soviets eavesdropping paid off however because they got the contract'
b'We dont know who is winning the drug war in Latin America but we know whos losing it  the press'
b'Over the past six months six journalists have been killed and 10 kidnapped by drug traffickers or leftist guerrillas  who often are one and the same  in Colombia'
b'Over the past 12 years at least 40 journalists have died there'
b'The attacks have intensified since the Colombian government began cracking down on the traffickers in August trying to prevent their takeover of the country'

b'The slaughter in Colombia was very much on the minds of 450 editors and publishers from Latin America the United States the Caribbean and Canada attending the 45th general assembly of the InterAmerican Press Association in Monterrey Mexico this week'
b'On Tuesday the conference got word of another atrocity the assassination in Medellin of two employees of El Espectador Colombias secondlargest newspaper'
b'The papers local administrator Maria Luz Lopez was shot dead and her mother wounded while her car was stopped for a red light'
b'An hour later the papers circulation manager Miguel Soler was shot and killed near his home'
b'The drug lords who claimed responsibility said they would blow up the Bogota newspapers offices if it continued to distribute in Medellin'
b'They bombed the Bogota offices last month destroying its computer and causing 25 million in damage'
b'El Espectador has been a special target because of the extraordinary courage of its publisher and his staff'
b'At Monterrey publisher Luis Gabriel Cano although shaken by the murders issued a statement saying We will not cease our fight against drug trafficking'
b'They want to terrify the press and in particular El Espectador because it has always been a torchbearer in this war'
b'This comes from a man whose brother Guillermo was murdered in 1986'
b'The publishers in Monterrey command no battalions but they agreed to express their outrage with editorials in todays editions'
b'Many will use a common editorial'

b'A final statement yesterday said While some advances are being made in nations throughout the hemisphere the state of press freedom in the Americas still must be regarded as grim as long as journalists and their families are subject to the crudest form of censorship death by assassination'
b'The report charged that Panamas Manuel Noriega is not only in league with the drug traffickers but also is bullying the press as never before'
b'Noriega has closed every independent newspaper radio and television station and arrested tortured or forced into exile a long list of reporters the statement declared'
b'It added In Cuba public enemy No 1 of press freedoms in the hemisphere repression of journalists both Cuban and foreign is worse than ever'
b'And in Nicaragua promises of press freedom by the Sandinistas have not materialized'
b'As it happens the four countries cited Colombia Cuba Panama and Nicaragua are not only where the press is under greatest attack but also are linked by the drug trade and leftwing politics'
b'Noriega is close to Castro and may once have been his agent'
b'Sandinistas Thomas Borge and the Ortega brothers are Castro proteges he backed their takeover of Nicaragua'
b'In Colombia the drugfinanced guerrillas trying to seize the country and destroy democracy include M19 which Castro has clearly backed'

b'Robert Merkel a former US attorney handling drug indictments in Florida doesnt think for a minute that Castros much publicized trials of high officials engaged in the drug trade mean he has broken off with the Medellin drug cartel'

b'If the cartel succeeds in blackmailing the Colombian authorities into negotiations the cartel will be in control and Fidel can exploit his past relationships with them he told the Journals David Asman recently'
b'The struggle against the drug lords in Colombia will be a near thing'
b'This week the government arrested Jose Abello Silva said to be the fourthranking cartel leader'
b'He will probably be extradited to the US for trial under an extradition treaty President Virgilia Barco has revived'
b'Later another highranking trafficker Leonidas Vargas was arrested and 1000 pounds of dynamite seized'
b'Mr Barco has refused US troops or advisers but has accepted US military aid'
b'President Bush has agreed to meet within 90 days with Mr Barco President Alan Garcia of Peru and President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia to discuss the drug problem'
b'After the Panama fiasco they will need some reassurance'
b'Certainly the Colombian press is much in need of that'
b'A Brief History'
b'Early Habitation'
b'The inhabited history of the Las Vegas Valley stretches to 23000 bc  when much of the area was covered by a prehistoric lake'
b'During this period the indigenous people lived in caves hunting the mammals that gathered at the shoreline'
b'The landscape of the valley changed dramatically over the next 200 centuries'
b'The glaciers feeding the lake melted away and the lake evaporated'
b'Fossils tell an obscure story of man\xe2\x80\x99s slow and sporadic development'
b'Around 3000 bc  native Archaic Indians began to develop a lasting hunting and gathering culture'

b'By this time the valley was in much the same geographic state as it exists in today with one exception\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the presence of artesian springs that bubbled to the surface in several areas'
b'These springs fed a network of streams draining through the Las Vegas Wash to the Colorado River'
b'The areas surrounding the springs were desert oases sprawling collections of grasses trees and wildlife'
b'Many springs lay in areas that would eventually become the center of the modern Las Vegas metropolis'
b'For about 4000 years the Archaics thrived in a culture that included many signs of early civilization'
b'Signs of even more advancement appeared halfway through the first millennium ad  when the Anasazi Indians inhabited the valley'
b'Far more progressive than the Archaics the Anasazi utilized such formal agricultural techniques as irrigation to assist their harvest'
b'This permitted the Anasazi to achieve a benchmark of advanced society\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the ability to live in permanent shelters yearround without need to follow wildlife'
b'Mysteriously the Anasazi vanished from the valley around ad 1150 leaving it to be repopulated by the Southern Paiutes another huntergatherer tribe'

b'Unable to replicate the agricultural techniques of the Anasazi the Paiutes were destined to a seminomadic lifestyle until European settlers arrived changing the nature of existence in the valley forever'
b'From Mailmen to Mormons'
b'In the early nineteenth century America\xe2\x80\x99s western territories were still largely unexplored'

b'It was not until 1829 that Rafael Rivera a Mexican scout found a springfed valley and dubbed it Las Vegas\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82a Spanish name that leaves many modern visitors wondering exactly where \xe2\x80\x9cthe meadows\xe2\x80\x9d really lay'
b'For fifteen years Las Vegas was used as a Spanish Trail waystation'
b'In 1844 American explorer John C Fremont parked his horses at Big Springs and his report to the government resulted in a mail route leading past the spot on its way to California'
b'This put Las Vegas on the map and was one of the crucial turning points of its history'

b'In 1855 Mormon leader Brigham Young responded to promising reports of Las Vegas by sending 30 missionary settlers to the valley they eventually built a fort not far from today\xe2\x80\x99s Downtown'
b'Surrounded by acres of farmland hewn from the hard desert the adobe fort became a focal point for the development of Las Vegas for the next fifty years'
b'The missionaries struggled valiantly against the dictates of the desert trying simultaneously to survive the harshness of their circumstances and spread the Mormon faith'
b'Additional pressures from arriving miners pushed the missionaries\xe2\x80\x99 plight beyond recovery'
b'Their supplies scarce their harvest meager and their spirit broken they abandoned the fort in 1858'
b'Despite the fact that the local land was rich in silver by 1865 most of the mining traffic through Las Vegas was of prospectors headed to California or Northern Nevada in search of gold'
b'One opportunist who stayed was Octavius Decatur Gass'

b'Bestowed with plenty of the invaluable pioneer spirit that characterizes Las Vegas to this day Gass redirected his life by picking up where the Mormons left off\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82at least when it came to ranching and farming'
b'Gass took over the abandoned Mormon fort and 640 acres 260 hectares surrounding it dubbing it the Las Vegas Ranch'
b'He expanded the ranch and irrigated the land so that it would support crops and cattle'
b'His determination had other results as well Gass was named a justice of the peace and a territorial legislator'
b'Despite his ambition Gass\xe2\x80\x99 success was shortlived'
b'In the late 1870s he defaulted on a loan from rancher Archibald Stewart so Stewart took the Las Vegas Ranch for his own'
b'True to wildWest stereotypes Stewart was slain by a neighboring farmer leaving his strongwilled wife Helen to assume the duties of the ranch'
b'Through 1905 Helen Stewart expanded the ranch to 2000 acres 810 hectares making quite a bit of money in the process'
b'What happened next would mark the end of the successful Las Vegas Ranch and the beginning of the era of the subdivision seen across almost all of Western America to this day'
b'The railroad was coming and when it arrived Las Vegas would never be the same again'
b'Of Tracks and Tracts'
b'At the turn of the 19th century Los Angeles and Salt Lake City were among the burgeoning metropolises of the new American West'
b'Though the two cities remained unlinked by rail this was about to change quickly'
b'When it did the Las Vegas Valley which at the time had a nonnative population of less than 30 would change as well'
b'In 1903 officials of the San Pedro Los Angeles and Salt Lake Railroad arrived in Las Vegas eager to secure a rightofway for their Los Angeles\xe2\x80\x93Salt Lake connection'
b'Las Vegas would serve as a major stopover for crew rest and train repair'
b'For all this the railroad needed land'
b'As mapped the track traveled directly through Helen Stewart\xe2\x80\x99s Las Vegas Ranch'
b'Stewart sold 995 percent of her ranch to the railroad'
b'The remainder she returned to the native Paiutes'
b'In early 1905 the route between Los Angeles and Salt Lake City was completed and train tracks bore right down the center of the Las Vegas Valley'
b'On 15 May 1905 the railroad held a land sale\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82a momentous step in Las Vegas history'
b'Standing at the depot at Main and Fremont streets railroad officials auctioned 1200 lots they had subdivided from forty square blocks of desert scrub'
b'Land speculators and locals alike were anxious to own a part of the newest railroad boomtown and within an afternoon more than 80 percent of the lots were sold'
b'Las Vegas was no longer a small pioneer settlement'
b'With rail service in place and forty blocks of private property it was ready to become a real town'
b'Businesses sprang up overnight and wooden houses were erected to replace the tent city in which many of the early settlers had lived'
b'One year after the auction the population of Las Vegas had ballooned to 1500 residents a portent of things to come for the next ninety years'
b'Dam Good Luck'
b'From the beginning Las Vegas was built to serve travelers'
b'The railroad needed a way station and Las Vegas was the place'

b'Growth continued for ten years and by 1915 the town had telephones roundtheclock electricity and a growing population\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82many of whom worked in the railroad repair shop'
b'But such heady progress would soon come to a halt'
b'The growing competition in rail transport resulted in Union Pacific buying the Los Angeles\xe2\x80\x93Salt Lake line'
b'Union Pacific then consolidated its operations eliminating the Las Vegas repair facility'
b'Additionally Las Vegas had been made a part of Nevada\xe2\x80\x99s new Clark County in 1909 a year when the legislature also outlawed gambling'
b'These unfortunate circumstances threatened to relegate Las Vegas to the status of a small desert community that could no longer support its 3000 residents'
b'But the southwest\xe2\x80\x99s growing need for water combined with Las Vegas\xe2\x80\x99s fortuitous proximity to the Colorado River would give Las Vegas a second chance to achieve prosperity'
b'Construction on Hoover Dam originally Boulder Dam subsequently renamed for the president who authorized the project began in 1931 in a canyon 45 miles 72 km southeast of Las Vegas'
b'Providing an influx of 165 million to the southwestern economy Hoover Dam played a major role in preventing Las Vegas from drying up both financially and literally'
b'Not only did it create jobs but it also created Lake Mead the massive reservoir that today provides water to all of southern Nevada'
b'More Government Help'
b'The construction of Hoover Dam did not singlehandedly save Las Vegas however'
b'The state legislature helped as well by legalizing gambling in 1931 and thus solidifying the future of the town though legislators and residents could never have known this at the time'
b'They went to work on what has become one of the lengthiest citywide tourism campaigns ever attempted'
b'It didn\xe2\x80\x99t take long for the city to establish itself as a wildWest town with an \xe2\x80\x9canything goes\xe2\x80\x9d attitude'
b'Vices outlawed or heavily controlled elsewhere were legal here available any hour of any day or night'
b'Thus originated Las Vegas\xe2\x80\x99s reputation as an adult theme park'
b'Additional catalysts for the valley\xe2\x80\x99s growth came from World War II'

b'Both the Las Vegas Aerial Gunnery School which became Nellis Air Force Base and the Nevada Test Site in the north and Basic Magnesium in the nearby town of Henderson arrived in the early 1940s as a result of America\xe2\x80\x99s war effort'
b'By 1945 the population had grown to almost 20000 with workers and airmen moving in at a rapid pace'
b'But this was not yet the Las Vegas of folklore'
b'Mobsters and Rat Packers'
b'While many gambling halls opened Downtown in the 1930s and early 1940s only two were built on the stretch of old Los Angeles Highway that ultimately became the Strip'
b'The El Rancho Vegas 1941 was the first followed by the Last Frontier 1943'
b'During this period East Coast Syndicate member Benjamin \xe2\x80\x9cBugsy\xe2\x80\x9d Siegel earned a foothold as a local casino operator'
b'When the Flamingo opened in December 1946 it did so with Hollywood flair and the new Vegas flash'
b'But the Mafia bosses who financed the operation were displeased with its performance Siegel was murdered in the summer of 1947'
b'Despite its initial failings Siegel\xe2\x80\x99s Flamingo survived him as did mob infiltration of casinos'
b'In fact the Flamingo would launch over two decades of strong mob presence in Las Vegas'

b'Freely flowing \xe2\x80\x9ccomps\xe2\x80\x9d complimentary food drink and entertainment were the order of the day with mob bosses content to provide an environment of pleasurable excess as long as the cash kept rolling in'
b'While the mob was running the casinos promoters were busily selling Las Vegas as a glamorous Hollywood in the desert'
b'From the mid1940s to the mid1960s Las Vegas nurtured a growing sense that it was the \xe2\x80\x9cEntertainment Capital of the World \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Emerging stars no longer content with playing small nightclubs came to Las Vegas with dreams of making it big'
b'Many of them did'
b'Frank Sinatra Wayne Newton and Louis Prima each arrived with mediocre status and suddenly found themselves with names as big as the marquees on which they were written'

b'The Rat Pack\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82originally Frank Sinatra Dean Martin Sammy Davis Jr  Peter Lawford and Joey Bishop all in town to film Ocean\xe2\x80\x99s 11\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82landed at the Sands in January 1960 for a legendary stay'
b'Other Hollywood stars came as well simply because Las Vegas was the place to be'
b'As a result more casinos emerged along the Strip'

b'The Thunderbird Desert Inn Sahara Sands and Riviera hotels were erected during this period luring a curious clientele drawn by tales of allnight partying exclusive entertainment and cheap accommodations'
b'There was no longer any question when you wanted some unbridled adult fun Las Vegas was the place to be'
b'New Legitimacy'
b'Organized crime was soon to have a formidable adversary in its bid to control Las Vegas\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82corporate cash'
b'Though Las Vegas had developed a powerful local economy few major outside investments were made in the city due primarily to mob infiltration and its inherent ties to illegal activities'
b'That would change dramatically with the 1966 arrival of billionaire Howard Hughes'
b'A legitimate businessman Hughes was nonetheless eccentric and dramatic a style suited to the Las Vegas ethos'
b'True to the myth the reclusive Hughes immediately cloistered himself in the Desert Inn\xe2\x80\x99s penthouse'

b'Several weeks later he was asked\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82then ordered\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82to vacate the room to make room for high rollers whereupon he promptly bought the property and fired the management'
b'Thus began Hughes\xe2\x80\x99 legendary threeyear 300million Las Vegas buying spree'
b'When it was over Hughes owned six casinos an airport and an airline along with numerous plots of land stretching from the Strip to the mountains'
b'Hughes\xe2\x80\x99 actions would have beneficial repercussions both immediate and lasting'

b'Because of the new legitimacy Las Vegas acquired from Hughes\xe2\x80\x99 investments established companies such as Hilton Hotels bought into the gaming business and their influence helped draw a line in the desert sand between legitimate operations and mob casinos where illegal skimming of profits was rampant'
b'That combined with the formation of the Nevada Gaming Control Board would signal the beginning of the end for heavy mob influence in the city'
b'Las Vegas with a Vision'
b'As corporations moved in and the mob was slowly pushed out a new Las Vegas emerged'
b'The legitimization of gambling led to its increased legalization across the US'
b'What was once a sure thing became much more competitive'
b'Casino operators had to reassess the nature of their business'
b'The first to really do so was Steve Wynn a Las Vegas resident and owner of the Golden Nugget'
b'In the mid1980s Wynn began plans to reinvigorate Las Vegas with a new resort'

b'He bought several Strip properties\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the Silver Slipper and Castaways among them\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82and demolished them to make way for a new kind of resort\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82Mirage\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82 which became an instant success'

b'Wynn\xe2\x80\x99s demolition of the existing properties started a trend that more than any other describes Las Vegas at the end of the 20th century removal of old properties in exchange for the potential of new ones'
b'This trend has led to many more demolitions including the Dunes replaced by Bellagio Aladdin the new Aladdin and Sands Venetian hotels'
b'Wynn\xe2\x80\x99s casinos have also set new standards'
b'They can no longer be just a box filled with gaming tables restaurants and a showroom'
b'Excalibur the MGM Grand the Luxor and New YorkNew York all followed Mirage\xe2\x80\x99s lead during the 1990s offering themed environments and attractions for families'

b'As evidence of the \xe2\x80\x9ceverfaster\xe2\x80\x9d nature of the city by the middle of the 1990s the new approach showed signs of backlash with many visitors criticizing the mediocrity of the Las Vegas experience'
b'The latest approach is perhaps the best of the postmob era the comprehensive resort'
b'New resorts offer attractions and amenities modeled after those available in top resort cities worldwide including luxurious spas signature restaurants and exclusive boutiques'

b'Additionally a handful of resorts\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82such as the SouthSeas themed Mandalay Bay the Mirage and the new Four Seasons\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82are now catering exclusively to the luxury travel market'
b'The cr\xc3\xa8me de la cr\xc3\xa8me of Las Vegas deluxe is Steve Wynn\xe2\x80\x99s Bellagio'
b'Perhaps more important such highend accommodations raise the standards of expectations back to the mythology of the Rat Pack era'
b'As it changed from mob gam bling town to corporate gaming venue the population of Las Vegas skyrocketed'
b'Over 20000 additional hotel rooms have been added in a few short years including resorts in Summerlin and Lake Las Vegas'
b'The growth that has characterized Las Vegas for nearly a century may be facing a roadblock'
b'Still the future of Las Vegas is sure to be determined as much by the pioneering spirit that built the city as by anything else'
b'With its new look and new aim the prospects are good despite the warnings'
b'Inevitably some people will get burned in the process but others will rise triumphantly from the fray to even greater successes'
b'And that more than anything is the one constant that characterizes the past present and future of Las Vegas'
b'Dublin and the Dubliners'
b'As capital of Europe\xe2\x80\x99s most explosive economy Dublin seems to be changing before your very eyes'
b'New construction is everywhere the streets buzz traffic is increasingly congested and in the frenetic pace of rush hour everyone in Dublin seems intent on changing places with everyone else'
b'At night the streets are crowded with people bent on having a good time'
b'Prosperity is in the air the roar of the \xe2\x80\x9cCeltic Tiger\xe2\x80\x9d can clearly be heard'
b'But this is not the whole picture'
b'The proverbial hospitality and warm welcome are still here'

b'This busy modern European city sits on a thousand years of history\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82history is present everywhere from elegant Merrion Square to the bullet holes on the General Post Office'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s also a city of the imagination reinvented and reappraised in the literature of its exiles'
b'And the old Dublin is with us too\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the irreverent city of wit and charm and that peculiar magic possessed by Ireland and the Irish'
b'Prosperity has brought with it a new emphasis on historic preservation'
b'Dublin excels in packaging its past for the visitor'
b'You can view artifacts from the Bronze Age trace the history of the Easter Rising or revisit Leopold Bloom\xe2\x80\x99s odyssey in Ulysses'
b'Old buildings are being recycled for example the 17thcentury Royal Hospital now holds the Museum of Modern Art'
b'And Dublin a city large in expectations is still small enough for the visitor to see most of its sights on foot'
b'City on the Liffey'
b'The River Liffey flows from west to east through the center of the city to Dublin Bay'
b'The river forms a natural line between the north and south sections of the city'
b'This geography is important in understanding Dublin'
b'Historically and culturally this northsouth distinction has always been significant and it still is today with a dose of goodhumored rivalry between the two areas'
b'\xe2\x80\x9c I never go north of the Liffey\xe2\x80\x9d one man remarked'
b'\xe2\x80\x9c I never go north of the Liffey\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Farther out both north and south are the sweeping curves of the Royal and Grand Canals'
b'The occasional cry of gulls and unexpected distant vistas will remind you that Dublin is by the sea and the Wicklow mountains which hold Dublin closely to the coast are visible from everywhere'
b'Dublin is an intimate city physically small but tightly packed a perfect place for walking'
b'College Green the home of Trinity College provides a natural focus just south of the O\xe2\x80\x99Connell Street bridge'
b'O\xe2\x80\x99Connell Street the city\xe2\x80\x99s grand boulevard leads north to Parnell Square'
b'To the south and east is St Stephen\xe2\x80\x99s Green and Georgian Dublin where the national museums are located'
b'Along the Liffey to the west is Temple Bar center of nightlife and home to many of Dublin\xe2\x80\x99s cuttingedge artists and artistic endeavors'
b'Up the hill from Temple Bar are Dublin Castle and Christ Church Cathedral'
b'It won\xe2\x80\x99t rain on you in Dublin all the time'
b'The climate here can best be described as \xe2\x80\x9cchangeable\xe2\x80\x9d and yet the sudden shifts from light to dark sunshine to shower are part of the city\xe2\x80\x99s magic'
b'Buildings seem to transform themselves depending on the light Dublin under a lowering sky is a different place from Dublin in sunshine'
b'Enjoying Dublin'
b'Literature has always flourished in Dublin the only city to have produced three Nobel Prize winners for literature\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82Yeats Shaw and Beckett'
b'Joyce the high priest of literary Modernism imagined and interpreted Dublin for the world in Ulysses you\xe2\x80\x99ll see references to it all over'
b'However sometimes it seems that the city produced artists of this stature by accident even against its will'
b'Beckett and Joyce among others had to leave their homeland to understand it\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x82and to be understood'
b'Dublin theater is legendary and no visitor should miss seeing a performance at the Abbey Theatre or Gate Theatre'

b'The city\xe2\x80\x99s impact on the rock and pop music scene with the likes of U2 and Bob Geldof is well known\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82there\xe2\x80\x99s even a selfguided tour of their haunts'
b'Traditional Irish music is also alive and well especially in the pubs and there has been a revival of storytelling poetry reading and traditional dancing'

b'And in this city where literature and theater have historically dominated the scene visual arts are finally coming into their own with the new Museum of Modern Art and the many galleries that display the work of modern Irish artists'

b'The constantly crowded and busy Grafton street is the most visible center for shopping but there are shops all over that carry an international array of goods as well as the Irish crafts and souvenirs you expect'
b'And while multinational chains have made inroads they seem less blatant here than elsewhere'
b'Many shops and also hotels and guest houses have been owned and managed by the same families for years and theirs is the welcome of traditional Dublin hospitality'
b'Dublin\xe2\x80\x99s food has undergone a metamorphosis'
b'There was a time when you might have apologized for it but no longer'
b'Dublin has international restaurants galore and the New Irish Cuisine is built upon fresh products of Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s seas rivers and farms'
b'Coffee has replaced the ubiquitous tea\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82Dublin is now almost as much a coffee city as Vienna or Seattle'
b'City and Countryside'
b'In a city of such human proportions it is not surprising that parks and gardens abound for recreation and relaxation'
b'Phoenix Park in the northwest is the largest open space but squares like St Stephen\xe2\x80\x99s Green are the garden oases of the city'
b'On the coast Sandymount Dollymount and Killiney strands are the places to go'

b'The beautiful Wicklow Mountains and the Wicklow Mountains National Park provide a more rugged countryside and the area has breathtaking houses and gardens such as Castletown Mount Usher and Powerscourt'
b'To the north and west are the ancient sites of Ireland Malahide Castle the evocative hill of Tara and the long barrows of Knowth and Newgrange'
b'The DART Dublin Area Rapid Transit runs north and south along the coast'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s an ideal way for the visitor to reach outlying sights and villages'
b'There are many guided bus tours to sights outside the city and some are accessible by city bus'
b'Young at Heart'
b'Dublin is a young city'
b'Almost half of Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s population is under twentyfive and with its universities and professional schools Dublin also has a large student population'
b'The universities attract students from all over the world and this influx helps to make Dublin a busy buzzing international city'
b'However young and old stranger and Dubliner rub shoulders quite happily'
b'Religion and respect for parents has not yet gone out of fashion'
b'And young graduates are not leaving now\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82multinational corporations and European Union investment mean there are plenty of opportunities for them at home'
b'Unemployment is at an alltime low'
b'The Irish are actually beginning to come home'
b'Hong Kong and Its People'
b'Exciting mysterious glamorous\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82these words have described Hong Kong for at least a century'
b'With its vibrant atmosphere and nightandday activity it is an intoxicating place'
b'Hong Kong is crowded\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82it has one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s greatest population densities'

b'But it is also efficient with one of the best transportation systems anywhere and for such a crowded place quiet\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82you don\xe2\x80\x99t hear voices raised in anger motorists sitting on their horns or loud boomboxes'
b'Shopping never ends\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82there\xe2\x80\x99s always another inviting spot just down the street'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll find Hong Kong easy to get around the people helpful English spoken everywhere and food that lives up to its reputation'
b'On 1 July 1997 the British Crown Colony of Hong Kong reverted to Chinese sovereignty as a Special Administrative Region of the People\xe2\x80\x99s Republic of China'
b'Today Hong Kong remains a capitalist enclave with its laws and rights intact and China has promised that Hong Kong will continue in this fashion for at least 50 years'
b'Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s announced policy of maintaining Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s prosperity and stability makes sense'
b'Hong Kong has long been China\xe2\x80\x99s handiest window on the West and the city is unrivaled in its commercial knowhow and managerial expertise'
b'Around the time of the transition there was much speculation about how things would change'
b'But in fact once news of the handover vanished from the front pages the people of Hong Kong returned to their usual topics of conversation the economy and the price of housing'
b'The impression of the visitor today will be that very little has changed'

b'Establishments are no longer called \xe2\x80\x9cRoyal\xe2\x80\x9d Queen Elizabeth has vanished from the coinage and the Union Jack has been replaced by the flag of China and the new Hong Kong flag with its bauhinia flower'
b'But in fact there have been changes many of them due to economic progress new construction and other factors that influence cities all over the world'
b'Others are more subtle'
b'British social customs are still evident in the kind of polite service you get in hotels and in the long lines of people waiting for buses at rush hour'
b'The British population has decreased today there are as many American and Australian expats as there are British'
b'With a population of nearly eight million and a total area of just over 1095 square km 423 square miles housing is one of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s perennial nightmares'

b'To alleviate the problem the government has become the city\xe2\x80\x99s major landlord with the construction of massive apartment blocks that though they have every modern facility average only 9 square m 100 square ft in size'
b'Whole cities have been created in the New Territories although the unimaginative architecture of these towns has been criticized'
b'Of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s population 98 percent are Chinese'
b'The Chinese people have been described as hardworking and pragmatic attitudes that have contributed to Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s success'
b'There are many stories of refugees who arrived with nothing in their pockets set up a small sidewalk stall worked diligently until they had their own store and then expanded it into a modest chain'
b'Old customs are still followed Fate and luck are taken very seriously and astrologers and fortunetellers do a steady business'
b'Before a skyscraper can be built a feng shui see page 68 investigation must take place to ensure that the site and the building will promote health harmony and prosperity'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll also notice that gambling is a passion whether it be cards mahjong the lottery or the horses'
b'Hong Kong has two major racetracks as well as an intensive offtrack betting system and on weekends the ferries to Macau are crowded with people on their way to the casinos'
b'Sightseeing in Hong Kong starts at sea level with the enthralling water traffic\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82a mix of freighters ferries tugs junks and yachts'
b'Views of the city and the harbor are panoramic'
b'From Victoria Peak Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s highest point or from skyscrapers and hotels they are especially exciting at night when the lights are on'
b'The business and financial center and the signature soaring architecture are on Hong Kong Island'
b'Across Victoria Harbor connected by ferry and the MTR rail line is the Kowloon peninsula with its hotels nightlife and almost nonstop shopping'
b'Beyond in the New Territories are a mixture of highrise suburban towns ancient sites and walled villages country parks and farms with ducks and fish ponds'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s other less developed islands Lantau Lamma and Cheung Chau provide getaways'
b'You can also take a ferry to Macau to find an entirely different kind of city a unique blend of Chinese and Iberian culture'

b'It\xe2\x80\x99s anyone\xe2\x80\x99s guess what may happen in the future but for now Hong Kong bristles with energy and ambition and for the visitor this beautiful city with its contrasts and variety is an exhilarating experience'
b'Inflation has taken its toll in Hong Kong'
b'While it\xe2\x80\x99s no longer the bargain shopping destination it once was there are still some good buys to be had'
b'Since Hong Kong is a dutyfree port and charges no sales tax goods are cheaper here than in the country where they were made'
b'On photographic equipment electronic goods and watches you avoid the luxury tax payable in your home country'
b'Specialty goods and souvenirs often handmade come from Hong Kong and elsewhere in China'
b'Custommade garments by skillful Hong Kong tailors are still much in demand and cost less than elsewhere for comparable garments'
b'Note that alcohol and tobacco are both exceptions to Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s dutyfree regime and are subject to tax'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll find that prices are about the same in Hong Kong Central and Kowloon and somewhat cheaper in Causeway Bay which caters to local shopping'
b'Large shops on the fashionable thoroughfares tend to be more expensive than smaller \xe2\x80\x9cfamily\xe2\x80\x9d shops tucked away in the side streets'
b'Stores do not open until 10am or later but shopping goes on into the evening up to 930pm'
b'Most shops are open seven days a week'
b'Shops in Central are an exception they generally close at 6pm and are not open on Sunday'
b'The only holiday on which all commerce comes to a halt is the Chinese New Year in January or February'
b'Buyer Beware'
b'Be aware that name brands including electronics are sometimes fakes glass may be sold as jade and that antique you bought may have been made last night'
b'Always ask for a receipt that records information about the item and if you buy an antique be sure to get a certificate of authentication'
b'Needless to say avoid peddlers who approach you on the street and offer to take you to wondrous bargains'
b'The large department stores have fixed prices but elsewhere you should ask whether there is a discount especially if you buy several items in one shop'
b'Compare prices before you buy any significant item'
b'Always ask to see the manufacturer\xe2\x80\x99s guarantee when purchasing watches cameras and audiovisual and electronic equipment'
b'Note that when haggling the merchant assumes you are prepared to pay cash'
b'If after concluding a deal you try to pay with a credit card he may then boost the price in order to cover the card charges'
b'It is advisable to shop at outlets that are members of the Hong Kong Tourist Association HKTA identified by a red junk logo'

b'Membership imposes an obligation to maintain standards of both quality and service and provides dissatisfied customers with an officially recognized channel for redressing complaints the number to call is Tel 2508 1234'
b'Pick up a copy of HKTA\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Official Dining Entertainment  Shopping Directory\xe2\x80\x9d in which all member stores are listed'
b'Shipping'
b'Many stores will pack and ship purchases'
b'Ask if automatic free insurance is provided'
b'If the goods are very valuable or fragile it is a good idea to buy an allrisk insurance for the shipment'
b'Packages sent to the US or to Europe generally take six to eight weeks by surface mail and one week by airmail'
b'Shopping Areas'

b'Major shopping areas are Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon especially along Nathan Road Central on Hong Kong Island particularly for upscale designer goods Causeway Bay for slightly better prices and the Hollywood Road area'
b'Department Stores'

b'Look for Lane Crawford Ltd an upscale store with branches at Pacific Place 70 Queen\xe2\x80\x99s Road and Harbour City Wing On one of the oldest in Hong Kong Marks and Spencer and the Japanese department stores Mitsukoshi Sobo and Seibu'
b'Malls'
b'Hong Kong is full of giant malls'

b'Harbour City just west of the Star Ferry Terminal in Tsim Sha Tsui is one of the largest Pacific Place 88 Queensway is Central\xe2\x80\x99s biggest mall with retail outlets and department stores Times Square is a collection of retail outlets in Causeway Bay'
b'In addition most topline hotels have upscale malls full of designer boutiques'
b'Factory Outlets'
b'These stores sell excess stock or factory overruns'
b'Hong Kong is no longer a factory outlet center since much of its clothing manufacturing has moved elsewhere'
b'There are factory showrooms in the Pedder Building 12 Pedder Street in Central'
b'Markets'
b'Markets are the places to use your bargaining skills'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s most famous and colorful market is the Temple Street Night Market near the Jordan MTR stop'
b'Every conceivable kind of goods is sold here clothing all kinds of electronics CDs souvenirs crafts and jewelry'
b'Stanley Market is located on Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s southern coast and is wellknown for all kinds of clothing including silk and cashmere'
b'Bargain and carefully examine any merchandise you buy here'
b'The Jade Market on Kansu Street in Yau Ma Tei is known for both jade and freshwater pearls'
b'This is not the place to make expensive purchases but it\xe2\x80\x99s great for inexpensive pendants earrings and gifts'
b'What to Buy'
b'Antiques'
b'Hollywood Road in the MidLevels above Central is the most famous antiques street in Hong Kong'
b'Look for fine Chinese bronzes embroidery lacquerware and porcelain tomb figures and wood carvings among other possibilities'
b'The experts point out that it is not age alone that determines a Chinese antique\xe2\x80\x99s value\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the dynasties of the past had their creative ups and downs'
b'For serious antiques try Honeychurch Antiques at no 29 for furniture and silver Tai Sing Company at 122 for porcelain'
b'For fun you can visit the Low Price Shop at no 47 or the Cat Street crafts stores and flea market'
b'Brocades and Silks'
b'Fabrics from China are a bargain and well worth taking home'
b'Chineseproduct department stores stock silk fabrics silk scarves finely embroidered blouses and traditional padded jackets'
b'Chinese Arts and Crafts is at Pacific Place in Central and in Star House in Tsim Sha Tsui CRC Department Store is on Hennessy Road in Causeway Bay'
b'For fabrics also try Western Market Morrison Street in Central'
b'Cameras'
b'Photo buffs know that Hong Kong is the place to buy some of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most advanced photographic equipment and there are some real bargains around'
b'However be sure you compare prices and models before buying'
b'Two reliable places to start looking in Lan Kwai Fong are Photo Scientific in the Eurasia Building and Hing Lee Camera Company 25 Lyndhurst Terrace'
b'Carpets and Rugs'
b'Hong Kong is a mecca for Chinese handknotted wool carpets and silk rugs'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s stores are usually able to arrange shipment'
b'Caravan at 65 Hollywood Road and the shops in The Silk Road at Ocean Center in Tsim Sha Tsui are good places to start looking'
b'China Porcelain'
b'In Hong Kong you can have a plate or even a whole dinner service handpainted to your own design'
b'Factories in Kowloon and the New Territories producing traditional and modern china are geared to entertain and instruct visiting tourists prices are appealing'

b'Two of the largest places to go are the Wah Tung China Company in the Grand Marine Industrial Building in Aberdeen and the Overjoy Porcelain Factory in Block B of the Kwai Hing Industrial Building Kwai Chung in the New Territories'
b'In antiques shops look for highly valued porcelains from China'
b'Note that because of the dutyfree situation good bargains may be found in European china including Spode and Wedgwood'
b'Electronics'
b'The latest gadgets are sometimes available in Hong Kong before anywhere else'
b'Before you begin shopping pick up HKTA\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cShopping Guide to Consumer Electronics \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Prices on electronics have risen in the past two years check prices at home before you buy here'
b'Nathan Road has many electronics shops'
b'Also check out Star Computer City in the Star House near the Star Ferry terminal'
b'Furniture'
b'The choice ranges from traditional handcarved Chinese rosewood furniture to wellmade reproductions of modern Western styles'
b'Rattan furniture is highly popular'
b'Hollywood Road has several furniture shops'
b'Queen\xe2\x80\x99s Road East in Wan Chai is a furniture manufacturing and retail area'
b'Jade'
b'\xe2\x80\x9c Good for the health\xe2\x80\x9d is just one of the many magical qualities that are attributed to these beautiful emeraldgreen or turquoise stones'
b'Real jade is extremely expensive and you may be offered counterfeit jade which looks exactly like the genuine article'
b'Some people say you can test the authenticity by touch\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82real jade feels smooth and cool'
b'Alternatively you can shine a lamp on the stone\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82real jade shows no reflected light'
b'Better still go shopping with an expert'
b'Jewelry'
b'Thanks to the dutyfree situation prices in Hong Kong are lower than they are in some other places'
b'You can buy gemstones loose or set or have them made up to your own design'
b'Popular purchases include diamonds and freshwater pearls'
b'If you do plan to buy jewelry be sure to consult the \xe2\x80\x9cShopping Guide to Jewellery\xe2\x80\x9d published by the Hong Kong Tourist Authority to find a reputable dealer'
b'Kitchen Equipment'
b'Woks and any other gadgets essential for Chinese cookery make good purchases'
b'Department stores sell all sorts of intriguing kitchen equipment'
b'Leather Goods'
b'Leather is not a great bargain in Hong Kong'
b'Locally made items do not live up to their European models'
b'However the leather garment industry is growing and there is a wide range of locally produced leather accessories all at extremely attractive prices'
b'For European imports you will pay top dollar'
b'Musical Audio and Video Equipment'
b'Hong Kong has a vast range of the most hightech audiovisual sound and screen equipment'
b'Before purchasing visitors should make sure of compatibility with systems in their own countries'
b'Be sure to look around and compare before buying'
b'Whatever you buy you may be able to work out a discount'
b'Readytowear Clothes'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s shops carry almost every recognizable European and many American labels from topend designers to the moderately priced or trendy'
b'Nathan Road Central and the hotel malls are places to look'
b'There are still a great many factory outlet stores with reasonable prices'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll also find bargain clothes for sale at the markets and on pushcarts'
b'Tailoring'
b'Tailormade clothes are not as popular in Hong Kong as they were in the past but hundreds of shops still remain'
b'Local tailors are experts when it comes to producing customtailored garments for both men and women and are also adept at copying patterns'
b'In choosing a tailor look for HKTA membership'
b'Many tailors have Web sites or are listed on Web sites'
b'Tea'
b'Shops all over town will sell you gift tins of exotic blends'
b'If you want to learn something about tea go to the Tea Shop at 149 Hollywood Road or the Moon Garden Tea House at 5 Hoi Ping Road Causeway Bay'
b'The owners will brew up a pot so you can taste before making a choice'
b'Watches'
b'The saying \xe2\x80\x9cTime is money\xe2\x80\x9d is quite literally true in Hong Kong more is spent on watches and clocks here than on cameras and optical goods'
b'An enormous variety of makes and models are on sale'
b'Be sure to get the manufacturer\xe2\x80\x99s guarantee stamped or signed if you buy a watch'
b'Entertainment'
b'Day and night the action goes on in this vibrant city'

b'To help you choose a nightlife scene pick up a copy of Hong Kong Tourist Authority\xe2\x80\x99s dining and entertainment guide for listings or just simply wander through the maze of neon signs and take your pick'
b'Hong Kong Diary published weekly by HKTA tells what\xe2\x80\x99s happening in the arts'
b'Hong Kong Life is published by the Hong Kong Standard on Sunday and the South China Morning Post has an entertainment section on Friday'
b'Culture buffs are well catered to and there is always a varied program of events ranging from worldclass concerts to local amateur dramatic productions'

b'A highlight of the arts calendar is the annual Hong Kong Arts Festival a threeweek dose of international culture in February with concerts recitals plays jazz Chinese opera and innovative productions put on by leading talent from both East and West'
b'Tickets for the shows must be reserved well in advance'
b'The Festival of Asian Arts takes place every other October bringing to Hong Kong for two weeks orchestras dance groups opera and drama companies from all over Asia'
b'There are more than 30 cinemas in Hong Kong and the latest Western releases are shown in some of the larger ones'
b'Englishlanguage films have Chinese subtitles'
b'The Hong Kong International Film Festival takes place in April'
b'More than 200 films from all over the world are shown at this twoweek event'
b'Ask at City Hall center about advance reservations'
b'The Performing Arts'
b'Performance Venues'
b'The theaters in the Hong Kong Cultural Center in Tsim Sha Tsui are the main venues for concerts and opera'

b'Other performance centers are the City Hall cultural complex with exhibition halls and theaters that present concerts plays and films the Hong Kong Academy for the Performing Arts with two major theaters for dance drama and concert performances and the Hong Kong Arts Centre in Wan Chai where both local and visiting groups perform'
b'Other centers for concerts plays and entertainment are Sha Tin Town Hall and Tsuen Wan Town Hall in the New Territories'
b'Larger arenas including the Queen Elizabeth Stadium the Hong Kong Coliseum and the Ko Shan Theater in Kowloon play host to various concerts pop concerts sporting events and variety shows'
b'Classical Music'
b'The Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra performs new and traditional works a wide assortment of traditional and Chinese instruments are featured'
b'The Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra was founded in 1975'
b'Under its conductor David Atherton it offers Western classical works and new works by Chinese composers in a SeptembertoJune season'
b'Chinese Opera'
b'Cantonese opera is alive and well in Hong Kong and the two other forms Beijing and Kun are sometimes presented'
b'To most foreigners this unique art form is likely to be inscrutable at first exposure but everyone can appreciate the spectacle and the elaborate glittering costumes'
b'Although the music may seem strange to the unaccustomed ear it certainly won\xe2\x80\x99t put you to sleep cymbals and drums guarantee your alertness'
b'Dance'

b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s three professional dance companies\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the Hong Kong Ballet Company the Hong Kong Dance Company and the newer City Contemporary Dance Company\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82perform regularly often at the Hong Kong Academy for the Performing Arts'
b'Theater'

b'The two leading local troupes the Chung Ying Theatre Company and the Hong Kong Repertory Theatre perform in Cantonese there are Englishlanguage performances at the Fringe Club theaters 2 Lower Albert Road in Central'
b'Puppet Shows'
b'The classic Chinese puppet is the shadow puppet manipulated behind a screen by three rods but hand puppet and marionette shows are also on offer often for free at public parks and playgrounds'
b'Nightlife'
b'Hong Kong by night can suit any taste\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82riotous sedate raw or cultured'
b'Note that sometimes there is a cover charge of HK50 to HK200 at clubs which may or may not include a couple of drinks'
b'There are nightclubs in the principal hotels with bands dancing and floor shows'
b'Jazz fans will find live jazz presented by international artists at the Jazz Club and Bar 2F 3436 D\xe2\x80\x99Agular Central and at the Blue Note in the Kowloon ShangriLa Hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui'
b'The Frin ge Club 21 Lower Albert Road Central is Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s bestknown alternate entertainment venue with jazz rock and other live music in addition to a gallery for visual arts'
b'Bars with views and live music include Sky Lounge in the Sheraton Hotel and Towers Tsim Sha Tsui and Cyrano in the Island ShangriLa in Pacific Place'
b'Pubs are numerous'
b'In Tsim Sha Tsui Ned Kelly\xe2\x80\x99s Last Stand on Ashley Road is an Aussie institution Delaney\xe2\x80\x99s 7177 Peking Road is one of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s enduring Irish pubs'
b'The clubs and bars of Wan Chai long the center of seedy nightlife have become almost respectable'
b'Joe Bananas 23 Luard Road is a Wan Chai mainstay for allnight partying'
b'Rick\xe2\x80\x99s Cafe 7882 Jaffe Road is a longtime disco that\xe2\x80\x99s still popular'

b'A lot of the raunchy action has moved across the harbor to Tsim Sha Tsui East this is also where you\xe2\x80\x99ll find pricey hostess clubs popular with Japanese tourists but definitely not for those on a budget'
b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s trendy spot is Soho SOuth of HOllywood around Hollywood Road Elgin and Stauton streets'
b'Soho along with the Lan Kwai Fong area is popular with chuppies Hong Kong yuppies and has a lively bar scene'
b'Causeway Bay also has a variety of bars and clubs'
b'TOTT\xe2\x80\x99s in the Excelsior Hotel is a restaurant with live music and dancing and a harbor view'
b'Japanese karaoke bars have now become extremely popular with the locals'
b'There are a number of these on Chatham Road South and around Cameron Street in Tsim Sha Tsui'
b'The most typical of these are harbor cruises usually including dinner and dancing on board an airconditioned floating nightclub'
b'There are evening bus tours that include visits to a restaurant and night spots some tours combine a Chinese banquet with a visit to an openair market and the panorama from Victoria Peak'
b'Beaches'
b'In subtropical Hong Kong you can swim from April to early November'
b'There are more than 40 beaches in Hong Kong that are free to the public'
b'Most have lifeguards on duty from April to October changing rooms toilets and snack stands'
b'On Hong Kong Island Repulse Bay is the most popular others are Shek O on the east coast and Stanley and Deep Water Bay on the south coast'
b'They are very crowded especially on summer weekends'
b'On the outlying islands Cheung Chau and Cheung Sha are on Lantau and Hung Shing Ye and Lo So Shing on Lamma inquire about water pollution levels'
b'The Hong Kong Golf Club Tel 2812 7070 welcomes visitors to its three 18hole courses at Fanling in the New Territories or the 9hole course at Deep Water Bay'
b'The Discovery Bay Golf Club on Lantau island Tel 2987 7273 has an 18hole Robert Trent Jones Jr course open to visitors Monday Tuesday and Friday'
b'Many Hong Kong residents and visitors take the express train to Guangzhou to play at the Guangzhou Luhu Golf and Country Club Tel 2317 1933 in Hong Kong or 0208350 7777'
b'The 72par course was designed by Dave Thomas'
b'Hiking'
b'In the New Territories the famous MacLehose Trail stretches 97 km 60 miles from Sai Kung Peninsula to Tuen Mun'
b'The Lantau Trail is a 69km 43mile circular trail on Lantau Island that begins and ends at Silvermine Bay'
b'Both trails are divided into smaller segments of varying difficulty'
b'Maps of hiking trails are available at the Government Publications Center Low Block Government Offices 66 Queensway in Central'
b'HKTA also has trail maps and sponsors the Guided Nature Walks led by rangers that include hikes in all the different regions of Hong Kong'
b'Jogging'
b'Victoria Park has a jogging track in Causeway Bay'
b'Sailing'
b'Because of the heavy harbor traffic only sailors licensed by the Hong Kong authorities can run pleasure boats in local waters'
b'Contact the Hong Kong Yacht Club at Tel 2832 2817 for information'
b'Taijiquan Tai Chi'
b'HKTA offers lessons in these exercises that improve concentration and balance at Garden Plaza Hong Kong Park Admiralty Tel 2058 1234'
b'Tennis'
b'There are 13 public courts at Victoria Park Tennis Centre Tel'
b'Horseracing'
b'All levels of society share a feverish interest in the Sport of Kings'

b'The racing schedule is September to June and Hong Kong maintains two tracks\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the older Happy Valley course on Hong Kong Island and the striking Sha Tin track in the New Territories'

b'The Hong Kong Tourist Association runs a \xe2\x80\x9cCome Horseracing Tour\xe2\x80\x9d which includes entry to the Hong Kong Jockey Club visitors\xe2\x80\x99 box and members\xe2\x80\x99 enclosure and a buffetstyle meal'
b'Cricket'
b'Rugby'
b'The Rugby Sevens sees teams come together from all over the world for 15 matches in March or early April'
b'Hong Kong has many attractions that appeal to children of all ages'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s many beaches are especially fun for children'
b'Children love riding on Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s antique trams'

b'A ride on the Peak Tram is sure to provide a thrill and in the Peak Tower they\xe2\x80\x99ll enjoy the Peak Explorer ride and Ripley\xe2\x80\x99s Believe it or Not Ocean Park see page 32 is popular with children of all ages'
b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a special Kid\xe2\x80\x99s World that those under 12 can enter free when accompanied by a paying adult'
b'The more daring can try out the terrifying rollercoaster rides'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s stateoftheart interactive museums will interest children of all ages'

b'The Science Museum in Tsim Sha Tsui East allows children to get their hands on over half of its 500 exhibits while the nearby Space Museum has regular screenings on an enormous Omnimax screen in its Space Theater making the night sky come vibrantly alive'
b'For children who love boats riding the Star Ferry or ferry trips to outlying islands will be exciting and the Dolphin Watch trip see page 113 is certain to appeal'
b'If you plan to visit during May the carnival atmosphere of the Cheung Chau Bun Festival with its high bambooandpaper towers covered in sticky buns will fascinate the young ones'

b'T he crowded Kowloon peninsula and the booming New Territories on the mainland call for some serious sightseeing but we begin across Victoria Harbor on Hong Kong Island where the city was first founded and which remains the center of government business and commerce'
b'No matter how many tunnels and transit systems speed crossharbor traffic nothing matches the ride on the Star Ferry from Kowloon to the Central District across Victoria Harbor'

b'As the doubledecker boats get ready to leave the pier bells ring the gangplank is raised deckhands in blue sailor suits man the hawsers and a couple of hundred commuters begin a sevenminute sightseeing tour'
b'The big greenandwhite boat weaves its way through an everchanging obstacle course of both large and small craft and the soaring skyline of Hong Kong Island draws nearer'
b'As you get off the 52story Jardine House with portholeshaped windows catches the eye'
b'There are restaurants and a Starbuck\xe2\x80\x99s in the basement and you can access the raised pedestrian crosswalk from the escalators on the ground floor'
b'Next to the Jardine building is Exchange Square a complex with a large shopping mall just behind it is the General Post Office with a philatelic center on the ground floor'
b'Farther west is the ferry terminal for the outlying islands'
b'On Connaught Road Central you\xe2\x80\x99ll find one of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s curiosities the 244m 800ft long MidLevels outdoor escalator'
b'It ferries commuters from the MidLevels apartment complexes downhill from 6 to 10am and uphill from 10am to midnight'
b'Nearby is Central Market the wholesale food market of Hong Kong and the Hang Seng building private offices'
b'Just east of the Star Ferry terminal you\xe2\x80\x99ll come to City Hall'
b'No longer a center of government it now functions as a cultural center'
b'Go through the underground walkway to Statue Square on the east side of the square is the Legislative Council Building one of the few colonial buildings left in Hong Kong'
b'So great is the pressure on the available land that most of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s colonial architectural heritage has been demolished and replaced by new skyscrapers'
b'Despite protests by preservationists there was little alternative'
b'Nearby is Chater Garden and a number of notable architectural landmarks'

b'Most famous is the striking 74story IM Pei Bank of China Tower not beloved by the people of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82its triangular prisms and sharp angles violate the principles of feng shui see box page 68 and its radio masts stick up like an insect\xe2\x80\x99s antennae'
b'The rival Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank is by architect Norman Foster built on a \xe2\x80\x9ccoathanger frame\xe2\x80\x9d its floors hang rather than ascend'
b'From inside the vast atrium you can view the whole structure as well as the mechanical workings of the building'
b'Two bronze lions carrying out feng shui principles guard its doors'
b'You can catch one of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s historic trams along Des Voeux Road and ride from Central to Causeway Bay see box page 66'
b'In 1904 the narrow doubledecker trams ran along the waterfront but land reclamation has placed them far inland'
b'From the Bank of China Tower make a short detour up Garden Road and turn into Battery Path to reach the landmark St John\xe2\x80\x99s Cathe\xc2\xaddral'
b'Built 1847\xe2\x80\x931849 this usually deserted Anglican foundation is Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s oldest church'
b'During World War II the church was turned into a club for Japanese officers it was restored after the war'
b'Note the stained glass windows in the Quiet Chapel designed by Joseph Edward Nuttgens in the late 1950s'
b'Behind the church is the 1917 French Mission Building now used as the Court of Final Appeal'
b'Across from the IM Pei tower a winding path leads up to Hong Kong Park'
b'The park\xe2\x80\x99s 105 hectares 25 acres of landscaped gardens and lakes contains a large greenhouse that holds many species of plants and an aviary of exotic birds'
b'In the park is the Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware see page 54'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s in Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s oldest colonial building with exhibits describing the history of tea from the Warring States period 475\xe2\x80\x93221 bc  to the present'
b'If you leave the park and walk up Cotton Tree Drive you will find the Peak Tram terminal'
b'For more than a century the most exhilarating way up Victoria Peak has been by funicular'

b'The Peak Tram starts its scenic climb just across the street and around the corner from the American Consulate in Garden Road and makes its way sometimes at a startlingly steep incline to the summit at 398 m 1305 ft'
b'The rightofway travels past fancy apartment blocks bamboo stands and jungle flowers'
b'The Peak is still the most fashionable place to live in Hong Kong but real estate prices here are astronomical rents run around HK50000 a month'
b'The Peak Tram originally steampowered was built to speed the wealthy taipans to their mountainside retreats'
b'Before the tram was built sedan chairs and rickshaws were the only way to get here'
