b'Since the tram\xe2\x80\x99s inauguration in 1888 it has stopped only for typhoons and World War II'
b'The modern 120passenger cars make the journey in around eight minutes'
b'However on sunny Saturdays and Sundays you may have to brave a crowd lining up at the lower terminal'
b'During the spring and autumn festivals when people traditionally seek out the hilltops the throngs are so large you would be better advised to try another time'
b'At the upper terminus there is a fourlevel shopping center the Peak Galleria and the Peak Tower which resembles an airport control tower and has shops entertainment and restaurants'
b'You can walk around the peak for impressive views of Hong Kong the coastline and the islands in 45 minutes on Lugard and Harlech roads'
b'The view is especially effective at night'

b'There are also souvenir stands benches for a rest and perhaps Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s last surviving rickshaws\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82however these are not for rides but are a tourist photo opportunity'
b'If you\xe2\x80\x99re up to a climb take the Mount Austin road to the Victoria Peak Gardens'
b'These gardens used to belong to the governor\xe2\x80\x99s mountain lodge but the building was demolished by the Japanese during the occupation of Hong Kong'
b'From the lower terminal of the Peak Tram it\xe2\x80\x99s only a short walk to the former governor\xe2\x80\x99s residence Government House now a museum'
b'Across from the mansion the Zoological and Botanical Gardens gardens open daily 6am\xe2\x80\x9310pm zoo 6am\xe2\x80\x937pm admission free provide a welcome oasis amid the bigcity pressures'
b'In the very early morning the park is taken over by people doing taichi exercises'
b'Both young and old go through balletlike movements in slow motion to discipline the mind and body'
b'The park\xe2\x80\x99s zoo has a collection of weird and wonderful chattering jungle birds'
b'The Western District is one of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s oldest neighborhoods and its narrow streets hold a collection of fascinating traditional shops and enterprises'
b'Opposite the Macau Ferry Terminal you\xe2\x80\x99ll find the Western Market open 10am\xe2\x80\x937pm'
b'It is more interesting for its architecture than for its shopping it\xe2\x80\x99s situated in a fourstory Edwardian building built in 1906'
b'For an interesting glimpse of small and familyowned shops walk along Bonham Strand East and West Man Wa Lane and Cleverly Street'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll find herb and medicine shops incense shops chop makers\xe2\x80\x99 shops makers of Chinese seals and more'
b'Hong Kong University\xe2\x80\x99s campus is spread along Bonham Road'
b'When it opened in 1912 the university had a total of 72 students'
b'At the top of a sloping driveway the stately Edwardian structure that was the original university building presides over the institution\xe2\x80\x99s newer buildings'

b'The University\xe2\x80\x99s Fung Ping Shan Museum 94 Bonham Road open Monday\xe2\x80\x93Saturday 930am\xe2\x80\x936pm admission free holds a significant collection of antiquities bronzes dating from 3000 bc  and ceramics including Han Dynasty tomb pottery'
b'It also has the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest collection of Nestorian crosses from the Yuan Dynasty period'
b'Take the MidLevels Escalator to Hollywood road known for its antiques and curio shopping'
b'Here the windows and open doors of the shops reveal an alluring selection of Asian furniture carpets carvings tomb figures porcelain and bronze'
b'Walk west along Hollywood Road until you come to Man Mo Temple the island\xe2\x80\x99s oldest house of worship though the date of its founding is subject to dispute'
b'Visitors entering the temple are confronted by a dense pall of smoke from all the burning joss sticks and the incense coils hanging from the ceiling these will burn for as long as a month'
b'The goldplated sedan chairs on the lefthand side of the temple were once used for transporting the statues of the temple\xe2\x80\x99s gods in religious processions'
b'The statues in the main shrine represent Man the god of literature and Mo the god of war a curious juxtaposition'
b'The temple is always crowded with worshipers'
b'Just past the temple is the aptly named Ladder Street'
b'Go down one flight of steps to Lascar Row popularly known as Cat Street for more antiques and curio shops'
b'Walk up the steps to reach Caine Lane where you\xe2\x80\x99ll find the Museum of Medical Sciences open Tuesday\xe2\x80\x93Saturday 10am\xe2\x80\x935pm admission by donation'
b'The interesting Edwardian building was formerly the Pathological Institute founded to combat the 19th century\xe2\x80\x99s 30yearlong outbreak of bubonic plague'
b'The old laboratory is still intact and there are exhibits on Chinese pharmacology and the history of medicine in Hong Kong'
b'Just to the east of the financial district Wan Chai was once an area of sleazy clubs and topless bars this was the setting for The World of Suzy Wong'
b'Servicemen relaxing from the rigors of the Vietnam War poured millions of dollars into the Wan Chai boom of the 1960s'
b'There are still bars and clubs here but the area has become almost mainstream and office towers are replacing many of the sinful old premises'
b'The Wan Chai waterfront is dominated by the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre the largest in Asia which includes hotels theaters and exhibition halls'
b'The convention center an extension on reclaimed land affords stunning views of the Wan Chai waterfront'
b'Adjacent just west of the convention center is another modern highlight the Academy for the Performing Arts on Gloucester Road'
b'On Wan Chai\xe2\x80\x99s Bowen Road Maiden\xe2\x80\x99s Rock also called Lover\xe2\x80\x99s Rock is the gathering place for the annual Maiden\xe2\x80\x99s festival'
b'Although it is not a tourist attraction the rock is steeped in tradition'
b'Every August young women convene to light joss sticks and some even climb the ninemeter 30ft rock to pray for good husbands'
b'About 2 km a mile east of Wan Chai Causeway Bay is second only to Tsim Sha Tsui as Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s place to shop'
b'A prosperous tourist district it is full of shopping centers and department stores along with a number of good restaurants'
b'The busy nightandday crowds make this area vibrant and lively'
b'On the nautical side is the Causeway Bay typhoon shelter where expensive yachts are anchored almost gunwale to gunwale and the Hong Kong Yacht Club has its headquarters'
b'Across Gloucester Road opposite the World Trade Centre is the Noonday Gun which under British rule was sounded on the stroke of midday'
b'Silent for a time the tradition has been revived and is a tourist attraction'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not clear how the custom started'

b'One story has it that traders Jardine Matheson  Co fired a private salute for a visiting tycoon an act that incensed the colonial authorities who felt that they had the sole right to issue such a 21gun welcome'
b'As a result the merchants were forced to limit their salvoes to one a day\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82and from then on they signaled the noon hour daily for all to hear'
b'The gun was made famous by Noel Coward\xe2\x80\x99s satirical song \xe2\x80\x9cMad Dogs and Englishmen \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Farther east is Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s largest park Victoria Park with sports grounds and other facilities'
b'On the eastern side of Victoria Park on Causeway Road is Tin Hau Temple dedicated to Tin Hau the Taoist Queen of Heaven and patroness of seafarers'
b'Originally the temple was on the shore but reclamation projects have now left it high and dry'
b'On the 23rd day of the Third Moon the birthday of the goddess is celebrated here and in all Hong Kong fishing communities'
b'Inland from the bay is Happy Valley'
b'At one time it was a very miserable valley a swampland conducive only to breeding malarial mosquitoes'
b'It is home to Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s first racetrack'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s gamblers are so eager to play the horses that despite the opening of a bigger and better racetrack at Sha Tin the Happy Valley Racecourse is thriving'

b'Up Tai Hang Road behind Causeway Bay is Aw Boon Haw Tiger Balm Gardens open daily 930am\xe2\x80\x934pm founded in 1935 by the late Aw Boon Haw who became a millionaire by producing the medicinal Tiger Balm'
b'It does not in fact contain any ingredients from tigers but does promise to cure a wide range of problems such as colds headaches rheumatism gout toothache and scorpion bites '
b'With its garish pagodas artificial caves and brightly painted statues of wellknown Taoist and Buddhist legends the garden is an obvious photo opportunity'

b'Aberdeen the island\xe2\x80\x99s oldest settlement once a pirate lair is home to the \xe2\x80\x9cfloating population\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94 the boat people who spend their entire lives on the junks in the harbor some proudly claiming never to have set foot on land except for funerals which don\xe2\x80\x99t count'

b'The junks are a picturesque sight children frolicking on the poop deck women preparing food or playing mahjong elderly folk watching the sunset dogs and cats underfoot songbirds in bamboo cages overhead\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82and all afloat'
b'The boats may appear deceptively primitive but many of them have their own electric generators and all the modern conveniences'
b'There are fewer boats now than in the past many boat people especially the younger generation have moved to housing projects'
b'You can take a tour of the port in one of the small sampans propelled by hand by women drivers'
b'A halfhour tour costs HK50 pay at the end or the driver may cut your trip short'
b'Aberdeen\xe2\x80\x99s theatrical floating restaurants have been a tourist attraction for many years'
b'The food may not live up to expectations but the fantasy environment makes up for it'
b'If you can get up early enough you can attend the predawn auction held at the vast local wholesale fish market otherwise have a look at the street market that goes on later in the day'

b'The peninsula opposite the east coast of Ap Lei Chau island contains Ocean Park open daily 10am\xe2\x80\x936pm admission HK150 adults HK75 children which has become one of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s biggest attractions'
b'It is divided into three areas a highland a lowland and the Middle Kingdom'
b'Linking the lowland and highland sections of the park a cablecar system offers spectacular views across to the islands of the South China Sea'
b'The Oceanarium is said to be the largest in the world and the Ocean Theatre features displays by dolphins killer whales seals and pelicans'
b'An enormous rollercoaster rising way above the sea space wheels and highdiving shows guarantee a day of excitement'

b'The Middle Kingdom is a recreated \xe2\x80\x9cliving\xe2\x80\x9d history of China\xe2\x80\x99s past presented through a number of fullsize replicas of shrines temples pagodas palaces and street scenes'
b'There are also demonstrations of traditional Chinese crafts including silkweaving pottery and p apermaking'
b'Water World formerly in the complex has closed for redevelopment'
b'The next inlet is Repulse Bay a roomy sandy crescent with green hills'
b'It\xe2\x80\x99s so attractive and so easy to reach that it\xe2\x80\x99s packed with sunbathers all summer long'
b'Stanley was once one of the main fishing villages on Hong Kong Island'
b'The wellknown Stanley Mar\xc2\xadket see page 55 is a major source for bargain clothing and other merchandise'
b'Stanley is also a favorite place of residence for expats'
b'The waterfronts at Repulse Bay and Stanley are lined with good caf\xc3\xa9s and restaurants'
b'Though much smaller than Hong Kong Island Kowloon has almost twice the population'
b'In many areas the density reaches the equivalent of 150000 inhabitants per square km a quarter square mile'
b'Most of Kowloon\xe2\x80\x99s attractions for visitors are centered near the tip of the peninsula in the district known as Tsim Sha Tsui'
b'Adjacent to the Star Ferry terminal is Ocean Terminal where international cruise ships dock and the gigantic Harbour City a complex of malls hotels and restaurants'

b'If you walk east on the Star Ferry terminal concourse you will find yourself on the wonderful Promenade which begins at the clock tower all that remains of the once grand KowloonCanton Railway Terminus'
b'The waterfront here offers unparalled views of the harbor and Hong Kong Island'
b'If you continue to the end of the promenade you will be in Tsim Sha Tsui East a busy commercial district built on more than 60 hectares 150 acres of reclaimed land'
b'Flanked by the clock tower is the imposing Hong Kong Cultural Centre'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s major venue for the performing arts the building has been criticized for its fortresslike architecture and windowless fa\xc3\xa7ade'
b'The interior is a comfortable amalgam of Chinese and Western design with an impressive main lobby'
b'The center contains a concert hall with acclaimed acoustics theaters a library an exhibition gallery shops restaurants and bars'

b'Next door is the Hong Kong Space Museum and Theatre open Monday Wed\xc2\xadnesday\xe2\x80\x93Friday 1\xe2\x80\x939pm Sat\xc2\xadur\xc2\xadday Sunday 10am\xe2\x80\x939pm closed Tuesday admission HK10 adults HK5 children separate admission to theater'
b'Its futuristic dome design is striking inside are interactive exhibits including one in which you can experience weightlessness'
b'The theater presents \xe2\x80\x9csky shows\xe2\x80\x9d and IMAX films'
b'The Hong Kong Museum of Art see page 54 stands behind the Space Museum next to the cultural center'
b'It contains the Xubaizhi collection of painting and calligraphy galleries devoted to antiquities and ceramics and a gallery of modern Chinese art'
b'Particularly interesting is the collection of paintings and photographs of old Hong Kong'
b'The museum mounts special exhibitions and has an excellent gift shop'
b'A few blocks up Chatham Road South are two more major museums'
b'The Scien\xc2\xadce Mus\xc2\xadeum see page 55 is a stateoftheart interactive museum that will teach you how everything and anything works from ancient sailing ships to the latest technology'
b'The fascinating collection of artifacts pertaining showcases 6000 years of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s history and Chinese culture'
b'Just across Salisbury Road from the cultural center is the historic Peninsula Hotel now expanded and modernized by a 32story tower'
b'Its restored lobby is Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s most elegant gathering place afternoon tea here is a visitors\xe2\x80\x99 ritual'
b'Alongside the hotel runs busy Nathan Road Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s fabled shopping street lined with shops hotels and restaurants'
b'Kowloon\xe2\x80\x99s main street was created by Sir Matthew Nathan when he was governor of Hong Kong at the turn of the 19th century'
b'At the time it was built many thought it absurd to have a treelined boulevard running through what was practically a wilderness'
b'Now the former \xe2\x80\x9cNathan\xe2\x80\x99s Folly\xe2\x80\x9d is known as the \xe2\x80\x9cGolden Mile \xe2\x80\x9d'

b'A few blocks up Nathan Road is Kowloon Park open daily 6am\xe2\x80\x93midnight elegantly laid out with fountains promenades and ornamental gardens be sure to go up the steps to see the Sculpture Walk'
b'Farther up Nathan Street you will reach Yau Ma Tei one of the older parts of Kowloon'
b'Turn off Nathan and walk down Kansu Street to find the Jade Market open 10am\xe2\x80\x933pm see page 80 with more than 100 stalls spread out in a large tent just before you reach the overpass'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s liveliest market scene is the Temple Street Night Market see page 55 near Jordan Road'
b'Everything is sold here from clothing to souvenirs to electronic goods and the market is known for its streetside food stalls where you can dine inexpensively on seafood'
b'The market runs all the way up to Tin Hau Temple where you will find fortune tellers\xe2\x80\x99 tables some speak English and possibly street performers singing Chinese opera or pop songs'
b'The temple is one of the many dedicated to Tin Hau goddess of seafarers this one also houses an altar to Shing Wong the city\xe2\x80\x99s god'
b'In the daytime the temple open 8am\xe2\x80\x936pm attracts worshipers and its park attracts strollers and mahjong players'
b'Nathan Road goes all the way up to Boundary Street which marks the boundary between Kowloon and the New Territories'
b'Near Boundary Street off Prince Edward Street West is the Yuen Po Street Bird Garden open 8am\xe2\x80\x937pm'
b'Birds are favorite pets in Hong Kong valued for their singing rather than their plumage and here you\xe2\x80\x99ll find all kinds of birds for sale as well as elaborate teak and bamboo cages'

b'Off the beaten path in Sham Shui Po west of the junction of Nathan Road and Boundary Street is the Lei Cheng Uk Han Tomb and Museum on Tonkin Road open Monday\xe2\x80\x93Wednesday and Friday\xe2\x80\x93Saturday 10am\xe2\x80\x936pm Sunday 1\xe2\x80\x936pm closed Thursday'
b'This ancient burial vault is believed to date back to the Han Dynasty ad 25\xe2\x80\x93220'
b'The barrelvaulted chambers were discovered while excavating for a nearby housing project'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s New Territories begin at Boundary Street'

b'Surprises spring up on all sides new industrial complexes alongside sleepy farming villages skyscraper towns blooming in the middle of nowhere Hakka women in their traditional flat straw hats with hanging black curtains water buffalo and flashes of azalea everywhere'
b'The New Territories can be explored by taking the Kowloon\xe2\x80\x93Canton Railway KCR which makes 10 stops between the station in Kowloon and Sheung Shui the last stop before entering China'
b'Ask the tourist authority about its interesting Heritage Tour from Kowloon and other countryside tours see page 113'
b'The main highway makes a circuit of the New Territories beginning with the new town of Tsuen Wan situated in an area of heavy industry just west of Kowloon'
b'North of the town a commanding view over all the New Territories to the north can be seen from Tai Mo Shan Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s highest peak at 957 m 3140 ft'
b'The highway continues parallel to the coast'
b'Onethird of all Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s beaches are to be found in a single 14km 9mile stretch of this region\xe2\x80\x99s shoreline'
b'Place names are often based on the distance to the nearest milepost as measured from the tip of the Kowloon peninsula'
b'Thus you will find \xe2\x80\x9c1912mile Beach\xe2\x80\x9d at Castle Peak Bay'
b'The main road continues clockwise around the New Territories'
b'As you approach the border you can glimpse the skyscrapers of Shenzhen'

b'The lookout point at Lok Ma Chau was once known as Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cwindow on China\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82in the years of China\xe2\x80\x99s isolation from the West tourists would come to the lookout point here and rent binoculars in order to get a glimpse of the great mystery beyond'
b'Set amid Tseun Wan\xe2\x80\x99s residential towers is the 18thcentury walled village of Sam Tung Uk now preserved as a museum and a short walk from the MTR station'
b'Not far away at milepost 21 near the large new town of Tuen Mun is a Taoist retreat known as Ching Chung Koon'
b'This \xe2\x80\x9cTemple of Green Pines\xe2\x80\x9d is a spacious complex containing temples and pavilions statues and gardens'
b'It is known for its collection of bonsai and houses a jade seal more than 1000 years old'
b'Among the ponds is one inhabited by turtles Visitors toss in coins in the hope of bouncing one off a turtle\xe2\x80\x99s head a sure way of achieving good fortune'
b'An even more interesting image out of Chinese history is the walled village of Kat Hing Wai in the village of Kam Tin just outside the market town of Yuen Long'
b'This is the most easily accessible of the New Territories\xe2\x80\x99 walled villages'
b'It is built in a square and the only way in is through the gate in the brick defensive wall'
b'Kat Hing Wai was built four or five centuries ago by the Hakka Tang clan one of the Five Great Clans that migrated here from North China see page 11'
b'Many of the old houses in the village have been replaced by modern structures'
b'The Tang clan\xe2\x80\x99s earliest walled village was Lo Wai which also has its defensive wall intact and is entered by a narrow gate'
b'Adjacent to the village is the restored Tang Chung Ling Ancestral Hall'
b'Few traditional ancestral halls remain in China since the antihistorical destruction during the Cultural Revolution so these New Territories ancestral halls are rare survivors'
b'Another such hall belonging to the Liu Clan is Liu Man Shek Tong in the village of Sheung Shui'
b'One of the most interesting sites in the New Territories is Tai Fu Tai another rare survivor this one a mansion that belonged to a Confucian high official'
b'The house was built in 1865 by a member of the Man clan who achieved the rank of tai fu mandarin by doing well in the Imperial Exam\xc2\xadinations'
b'The preservation of this wonderful home is ongoing a projected restoration of the original garden is still in progress'

b'The traditional Qing Dyna\xc2\xadsty style of the mansion is enlivened by a few West\xc2\xadern touches a Baroquestyle ceiling and stained glass above the doorways showing the builder\xe2\x80\x99s uptodate attitude at the time of construction'
b'The highway and the railway stay close together from Fanling site of the best golf courses in the area'
b'Tai Po just south of Fanling is known for its market Tai Po Market which buzzes with activity daily from 7am to 6pm'
b'Just up a lane from the market is the Man Mo Temple with longburning incense coils hanging from its ceiling a popular spot dedicated to the Taoist gods of war and literature'
b'The railway line then curves gracefully around Tolo Harbor an idyllic body of water wellprotected from the open sea'
b'You can take a ferryboat through the harbor past the ingenious Plover Cove reservoir a water catchment area appropriated by damming and draining a broad inlet from the sea'
b'The boats go on to the friendly fishermen\xe2\x80\x99s island of Tap Mun in Mirs Bay with stops in remote hamlets of the Sai Kung Peninsula'
b'The Sai Kung area is the location of two official parks and nature preserves while on the south side of the peninsula are some of the territory\xe2\x80\x99s best beaches'
b'From the next railway station the modern campus of the Chinese University of Hong Kong is visible'
b'Teaching here is conducted in both Chinese and English'
b'The Art Gallery in the Institute of Chinese Studies Building is worth a visit for its painting and calligraphy collections'
b'Sha Tin is the site of the Monastery of 10000 Buddhas which looks down on a burgeoning town'
b'There are hundreds of stone steps in the hillside to walk up before you reach Man Fat Temple with its regiments of small gilt statues of Buddha lining the walls'
b'Some indefatigable climbers will want to go up to the top of the ninestory pink pagoda for a panoramic view'
b'There is a total of 12800 Buddha statues here plus the remains of the monastery\xe2\x80\x99s founder embalmed in gold leaf'
b'Also here is the Hongkong Heritage Museum call Tel 2180 8188 for open hours'
b'The museum has an art collection and displays of toys and other artifacts'

b'Down to earth the Sha Tin Racecourse can accommodate over 80000 spectators and is equipped with every imaginable luxury including a giant video screen facing the stands and for the horses airconditioned stables'
b'Opposite the Sha Tin railway station New Town Plaza features shops cinemas and even a computercontrolled musical fountain'
b'Two natural rock formations are always pointed out on excursions'

b'Legend has it that a local woman climbed the hill every day to watch for her husband returning from across the sea one day the wife and her child were turned to stone as a permanent symbol of her enduring faith'
b'Closer to town is Lion Rock shaped like a lion lying in wait'
b'It really looks the part the tourists know its name even before the guide can translate it'
b'Excursion companies sell a variety of orientation cruises of Hong Kong harbor that include a look at some of its 235 outlying islands'
b'These pleasant but expensive outings can lay the foundation for your own explorations aboard the cheap but usually comfortable ferries used by the islanders themselves'

b'From the ferry terminals on Hong Kong Island you can escape to islands without cars or cares where the local people smile \xe2\x80\x9chello\xe2\x80\x9d and if you\xe2\x80\x99re lucky point you to a secret beach for the ultimate in quality leisure time'
b'The mountainous island of Lantau is the biggest in the colony and covers nearly twice the area of Hong Kong Island'
b'Chek Lap Kok airport sits on reclaimed land just off Lantau plans to build a bridge may change Lantau but at present it is sparsely populated and makes a perfect getaway'
b'At 934 m 3064 ft Lantau Peak is high enough to attract the occasional rain cloud\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82refreshingly cool breezes blow on most hot summer days'
b'More than half the island is parkland and there is a 70km 45mile circular hiking trail see page 92'
b'Ferries depart from Central every two hours between 610am and 1030pm to Silvermine Bay Mui Wo where a bus terminal has buses to all parts of the island'
b'There are also ferries to Discovery Bay'
b'A short bus ride away is Cheung Sha Beach 3 km 2 miles long and popular for its white sand and excellent facilities'
b'The most famous site on the island is the world\xe2\x80\x99s tallest seated bronze statue of Buddha at 22 m 726 ft the Tiantan Buddha see page 55'
b'The statue and a small museum are on a peak up 268 steps above Po Lin Monastery'
b'The monastery is strictly vegetarian and visitors are warned not to bring any meat with them'
b'You can have a delicious vegetarian lunch here'

b'From the monastery hikers enjoy the twohour crosscountry trek down to Silvermine Bay but the authorities have warned walkers to be on the lookout for snakes which can be plentiful in the Lantau hinterland especially in summer'
b'The hillsides that surround the monastery are the site of Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s only tea plantation'
b'Visitors are welcome to visit the 24hectare 60acre establishment and may sample the end product Lantau tea'
b'The island\xe2\x80\x99s largest community is Tai O The people of this picturesque village make their living by fishing duckbreeding and foodprocessing'

b'Many of the inhabitants live\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82by choice not necessarily through economic hardship\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82on the water aboard houseboats or in houses on stilts in the main creek'
b'A Trappist monastery situated on a hillside overlooking the east coast of Lantau is also open to visitors'
b'To get here follow the path from the southwest end of Discovery Bay the walk takes about 30 minutes'
b'Some 10 km 6 miles west of Hong Kong lies this small crowded island only one square mile in size'
b'More than 25000 people live here mostly by fishing but there are also expats attracted by its laidback Mediterranean ambience'
b'The island has a checkered past of smuggling and pira cy'
b'That era is gone now but other elements of the island\xe2\x80\x99s old life are preserved'
b'The people still carve jade and build seaworthy junks all by hand'
b'Fish heads discreetly wrapped in paper are still hung out to dry in the sun'
b'Cheung Chau becomes the center of Hong Kong life once a year usually in May during the Bun Festival a folklore extravaganza see page 89'

b'The rest of the year life goes on at its accustomed pace rickety machines chugging in twoman factories children in school uniforms being ferried home to houseboats and the old fishermen stirring shrimp paste'
b'By way of formal tourist attractions Pak Tai Temple built in 1783 has some fine carvings and a great iron sword said to be 600 years old'
b'But the most interesting thing to do here is to explore the two villages on the island Cheung Chau and San Wai'
b'They are an easy walk apart by the harbor road or a longer 45minute hike on the scenic Peak Road'
b'The Praya the promenade in front of the ferry pier is a good place to observe the many junks and fishing boats in the harbor'
b'There are also several openair restaurants where you can enjoy fresh seafood'
b'Only 35 minutes by ferry from Central Lamma Island is perfect for swimming hiking picnicking birdwatching or just sitting back to watch the bananas grow'
b'Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s third largest island has a population of only about 12000 it is still largely undeveloped and life on Lamma if not totally primitive is close to the essentials'
b'Archaeologists indicate that Lamma has probably been inhabited for some 4000 years and the island is known as \xe2\x80\x9cHong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s Stone Age Island \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The principal settlements are Yung Shue Wan on Lamma\xe2\x80\x99s northwest and Sok Kwu Wan on the east coast'
b'Both villages offer good waterfront restaurants with homestyle Chinese food principally seafood fresh from the tank'
b'The ports are within hiking distance of several beautiful beaches and within a onehour hike of each other on a marked trail'
b'You can build an appetite for dinner by making your way from the beach to the restaurant'
b'Yung Shue Wan is still a very British residential enclave with many nice pubs'
b'Macau the final bastion of Portugal\xe2\x80\x99s great 16thcentury empire is much more than just a quirk of history'
b'Here where East and West first met life combines the spirit of Asia with something of the sunny atmosphere of the Mediterranean'
b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s historic center with its colonial architecture has a distinctly Medit\xc2\xader\xc2\xadranean flavor'

b'Col\xc2\xad\xc2\xado\xc2\xadn\xc2\xadna\xc2\xad\xc2\xadded public buildings iron balconies winding streets flagstoned squares and the many churches all speak of the Portuguese inheritance as well as the Chinese a fusion of East and West that has produced the unique Macanese culture'
b'The story of the Western discovery of Macau begins in 1513 when Portuguese explorer Jorge Alvares reached the south coast of China'
b'Traders followed in his wake setting up bases in several parts of the Pearl River estuary'
b'Finally in 1557 they were all consolidated in Macau'
b'It was the only European gateway to China and through Macau flowed Western technology and religion'
b'In 1576 Pope Gregory XIII created the Macau diocese covering all of China and Japan'
b'No less impressive were the secular challenges'
b'China and Japan were not on speaking terms so trade between them had to be channeled through a neutral middleman'
b'Lucky Macau fit the specifications exactly'
b'Portugal\xe2\x80\x99s resulting nearmonopoly of East\xe2\x80\x93West trade understandably awakened the competitive instincts of other European powers'
b'The Dutch sent an invasion flotilla to Macau in 1622 but the defenders triumphed'
b'However the end of the golden age was drawing near'
b'China began to relax trade restrictions and with the rise of Hong Kong Macau became an isolated Portuguese outpost'
b'A haven for persecuted Japanese Christians in the 17th century Portugal\xe2\x80\x99s neutrality during World War II assured the territory a flood of refugees'
b'They were joined by a swarm of spies of all conceivable nationalities and Macau won a name for international intrigue'
b'Portugal\xe2\x80\x99s very precarious foothold on the Asian coast ended in 1999 with a formal handover to China'
b'Macau now the Chinese Special Economic Zone of Zhuhai is becoming something like a boomtown as an exporter of toys furniture and electronics'
b'New construction in the past 10 years has changed the city\xe2\x80\x99s skyline with new glittering hotels and highrise apartment blocks the city is beginning to look a little more like Hong Kong'
b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s population is estimated at around 450000 an appallingly high figure for such a small area recent land reclamation has eased the situation to some extent'

b'If a trace of tropical lethargy still adds to the charm in this city of sidewalk caf\xc3\xa9s palm trees and pedicabs any torpor definitely ends once inside the doors of Macau\xe2\x80\x99s casinos scene of some of the liveliest gambling west of Las Vegas'
b'Gambling provides almost 40 percent of the government\xe2\x80\x99s tax revenues and is a major source of employment'
b'Its spinoff industries prostitution and pawn shops also thrive'
b'The easiest way to get to Macau is by jetfoil operated by TurboJet Tel 28593333'
b'The 40mile trip takes about an hour'
b'Departures are from the Macau Ferry Terminal just west of Central in the Shun Tak Centre 200 Connaught Road Central in Hong Kong'
b'Jetfoils leave every 15 to 30 minutes 24 hours a day'
b'Entry procedures are similar to those in Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82most nationalities need only a passport to enter Macau'
b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s own currency the pataca is pegged to the Hong Kong dollar and you can use your Hong Kong currency freely in Macau'
b'Upon arrival in Macau be sure to stop by the Macau Government Tourist Office for a map brochures and directions'
b'Outside the terminal you will find taxis as well as buses to all points take 3 3A 10 or 10A to the historic center exact change is required'
b'You\xe2\x80\x99ll also be approached by pedicab drivers these are tricycles carrying two passengers'
b'Pedicabs were once the most common form of transportation in Macau but today they are mainly a tourist attraction'

b'Directly across the street from the wharf where passengers arrive from Hong Kong is the first surprise to greet visitors to Macau\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the vast Jaialai Palace said to be the world\xe2\x80\x99s most luxurious front\xc3\xb3n'
b'In an effort to provide yet one more thing to bet on players are imported from Spain to take part in this lightningfast Basque ball game'
b'The grandstand situated on the seaside road the Avenida da Amizade Friendship Avenue marks the finishing line for the Macau Grand Prix the international carracing event held here every November'
b'Also in front of the ferry terminal is a new Cyber fountain with 86 water spouts that shoot up to 70 m 230 ft and are illuminated at night by 288 spotlights producing 80 colors'

b'Continuing around the peninsula in a clockwise direction brings you to the Rua da Praia Grande Big Beach Street\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82a pleasant promenade with shaded benches under the banyan trees'
b'Along this elegant avenue is Government House a modest pink palace'
b'The central square of the historic city center is Largo do Senado'
b'For an authentic feel of old Portugal slip into the cool entrance hall of theimpressive Leal Senado \xe2\x80\x9cLoyal Senate\xe2\x80\x9d building a fine example of colonial architecture'
b'On the inside walls are flowered blue tiles azulejos and coats of arms'

b'The inscription over the archway reads \xe2\x80\x9cCidade do nome de Deus n\xc3\xa3o ha outra mais leal\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cCity of the Name of God None is More Loyal\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82a bit of praise attributed to Portugal\xe2\x80\x99s King John IV in the 17th century'
b'For all its historic grandeur the loyal Senate now is the equivalent of a city council its statesmanship dedicated to water supplies sewage lines and the establishment of playgrounds'
b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s most memorable monument is the Baroque fa\xc3\xa7ade of the ruins of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo the only remains of a beautiful 17thcentury Jesuit church'
b'On top of a hill in the center of the city it\xe2\x80\x99s approached by a grand staircase'
b'The rest of the building and an adjoining college were destroyed in a typhoonfanned fire in 1835'
b'The rich sculptural effects on the fa\xc3\xa7ade mix Eastern and Western symbols familiar saints Chinese dragons and a Portuguese caravel'
b'Beneath the church the Museum of Sacred Art houses a collection of sacramental objects'
b'The ambitious Museum of Macau open Tuesday\xe2\x80\x93Sunday 10am\xe2\x80\x936pm admission HK15 opened in 1998 in the lower levels of the Monte Fortress'
b'Entrance is by escalator near St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s'
b'It gives an overview of Macau\xe2\x80\x99s history and its daily life and traditions'
b'A recreated street of colonial Macau is lined with traditional Chinese shops'
b'The fort built by the Jesuits in the 17th century as a defense against the Dutch was largely destroyed by the same fire that burned St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s'
b'Lu\xc3\xads Vaz de Cam\xc3\xb5es 1524\xe2\x80\x931580 the Portuguese national poet whose work immortalized that country\xe2\x80\x99s golden age of discoveries may have stayed in Macau'
b'Local legend claims that he wrote part of his great saga Os Lus\xc3\xadadas in what is now called the Cam\xc3\xb5es Grotto situated in the spacious tropical Cam\xc3\xb5es Garden'
b'Next to the museum behind a gate opened to anyone who knocks is the Old Protestant Cemetery'
b'Those whose fate was to die on some far foreign field could not have wanted a more peaceful lovely graveyard'
b'The small whitewashed chapelwas the first Protestant church built in China'
b'For a different vision of Old China spend a few quiet moments in the classic Lou Lim Ieoc Garden'
b'Here arched bridges pagodas fish ponds and stands of bamboo create the mood of a timeless Chinese painting'
b'Nearby is the Memorial House of Dr Sun Yatsen founder of the Chinese Republic'
b'Photos and documents tell the life story of the physicianrevolutionarystatesman who lived for a time in Macau but never in this building'
b'Kun Iam Tong off Avenida do Coronel Mesquita open daily 8am\xe2\x80\x936pm is a 17thcentury Buddhist temple of considerable splendor and charm'
b'An unexpected piece of historical memorabilia turns up in the monastery garden where guides point out a small stone table used for a treatysigning ceremony in 1844'

b'The signatories who were the Chinese viceroy from Canton and the minister plenipotentiary of the United States of America put their names to a historic document\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the firstever treaty between the two countries'
b'Another important ceremony took place in 1999 when Macau became part of China'
b'The Handover Pavilion was meant to be a temporary structure but public outcry ensured its preservation located on Xian Xing Hai open weekdays 10am\xe2\x80\x936pm until 10pm weekends'
b'Nearby is the Macau Cultural Center and the Museum of Art open Tuesday\xe2\x80\x93Sunday 10am\xe2\x80\x937pm closed Monday small admission'

b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s oldest museum the Maritime Museum Wednesday\xe2\x80\x93Monday 10am\xe2\x80\x93530pm admission HK10 HK5 children over 10 traces the history of Macau\xe2\x80\x99s connection to the sea'
b'Exhibits cover fishing seaborne trade sea transport and there is an aquarium'
b'The museum also offers boat tours aboard a fishing junk'
b'The museum is almost on the spot where the Portuguese first landed'
b'When they came ashore they found the AMa Temple properly called Ma Kok Temple open daily dawn to dusk dedicated to the favorite goddess of fishermen who is also known as Tin Hau'
b'The area was called AMa Gau \xe2\x80\x9cBay of AMa\xe2\x80\x9d and in this way Macau got its name'
b'The ornate picturesque temple dates from the Ming Dynasty 1368\xe2\x80\x931644 and is the oldest building in Macau'
b'The remains of the 17thcentury Barra Fortress which once defended the southern tip of the peninsula contains the chapel of Santiago St James'
b'The saint is much revered in the surrounding area'

b'Among other legends surrounding the statue is a very modern one During the Chinese Cultural Revolution when Red Guards were running rampant on Wanchai island just a swim away the image of St James is said to have stepped down from the altar and halted an invasion'
b'Part of the fortress has been converted and is now used as a luxury inn'
b'The northernmost point in Macau is the frontier between two contrasting worlds'
b'The Barrier Gate Portas do Cerco which was built more than a century ago marks the boundary between the enclave of Macau and the People\xe2\x80\x99s Republic of China'
b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s casinos are a source of nonstop excitement'

b'There are 12 of them you can\xe2\x80\x99t miss the eyepopping Lisboa which has several floors of gambling but there\xe2\x80\x99s also the Hyatt Regency the Mandarian Oriental and Taipa\xe2\x80\x99s Jockey Club'

b'The fancifully decorated Macau Palace a floating casino moored on the western waterfront is fitted out with gambling tables slot machines known locally as \xe2\x80\x9chungry tigers\xe2\x80\x9d and for hungry humans a restaurant'
b'Gambling is wildly popular with the Chinese of Hong Kong and they make up nearly 80 percent of all visitors to the casinos'
b'The casinos offer familiar international games\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82baccarat blackjack boule craps roulette\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82along with more exotic Chinese pastimes'

b'Watch the fantan dealer for a few minutes and you\xe2\x80\x99ll almost be an expert It\xe2\x80\x99s simply a matter of how many odd buttons are left after he has divided a pile of them into groups of four'
b'DaiSiu Big and Small is a dice game in which the croupier throws three dice inside a glass container'
b'Players bet on the numbers that will come up and on whether the result will be \xe2\x80\x9cbig\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9csmall \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Keno is a variation of bingo in which the player chooses numbers to bet on before the draw is made'
b'The casinos have no admission charge and formal dress is optional though long pants for men are required'
b'They keep busy 24 hours a day but if you want a change of scene there are always more gambling opportunities available'
b'You can try your luck at pari mutuel betting on jaialai at pari mutuel greyhoundracing at the Cani\xc2\xaddrome one of the largest in the world and harnessracing on Taipa'
b'Like Hong Kong Macau is a dutyfree port'
b'It is famous for its gold jewelry'
b'Market prices per tael 34 grams1'
b'2 ounces of gold are set daily'
b'You should always ask for a certificate of guarantee when you buy gold or jewelry'
b'Look for jewelry shops along Avenida do Infante D Henrique and Avenida de Almei\xc2\xadda Ribeiro'
b'Browsing is a real pleasure in Macau\xe2\x80\x99s main streets and byways where shops aimed at the tourist market are interspersed with the more workaday ironmongers herbalists and noodle stalls'
b'Knowle\xc2\xaddgeable visitors look for antiques\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82either Chinese heirlooms or leftovers from the gracious Portuguese colonial days'
b'However you are not likely to find bargains and you should be aware that unless you are an expert you can end up with a fake'
b'Also worth investigating are contemporary handicrafts both Portuguese and Chinese from across the border'
b'Gourmets award Macau high marks for dependable Chinese cooking with an exotic bonus Portuguese food and wines'
b'Macau\xe2\x80\x99s own cuisine is a combination of Chinese flavors with the flavors imported from Portugal Brazil and Africa'
b'Whether you choose to dine in one of the Macanese Chinese traditional Portuguese or internationalstyle restaurants you will be treated to a hearty meal at a good price'
b'The ingredients especially the fresh fish and seafood are firstrate'
b'A delicate delicious fish is Macau sole linguado'
b'Imported dried cod bacalhao is the Portuguese national dish several varieties are available usually baked'
b'Macau has an ample supply of Portuguese wines'
b'Try a vinho verde a mildly sparkling young wine from northern Portugal or a hearty red D\xc3\xa3o or Colares'
b'After dinner a glass of Madeira or port is recommended to round off the meal'
b'The more abstemious can stick to Portuguese mineral water'
b'Bridges link Macau with its two islands'

b'Since the construction of the New MacauTaipa Bridge has allowed easy access to the airport the population has grown to more than 30000 with industrial development new apartment blocks and luxury resort hotels'
b'The quaint Taipa Village with its narrow lanes and colonial buildings painted yellow blue and green has almost been completely swallowed up by the development of nearby housing projects'
b'The island is also the designated home of the University of East Asia'
b'Pay a visit to the Casa Museu da Taipa and you\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to get a glimpse of how Macanese families lived in former days'
b'A grand colonial house fully restored and outfitted with period furnishings provides the centerpiece for this expanding \xe2\x80\x9ccultural village \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Not as developed as Taipa it offers the joys of sand and sea and is known for its beaches'
b'Cheoc Van and Hac Sa \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Sands\xe2\x80\x9d are both popular resort areas with lifeguards on duty in summer and windsurfing boards for rent'
b'There are restaurants swimming pools and changing facilities'
b'The village of Coloane is picturesque with a central square lined with caf\xc3\xa9s'

b'The small Chapel of St Francis Xavier is dedicated to the 16thcentury patron saint of missionaries and has on display the elbow of the saint along with the bones of numerous Japanese and Vietnamese martyrs'
b'Seac Pai Van Park on the west coast of the island is an interesting natural preserve with aNatural History Museum'
b'Guangzhou was China\xe2\x80\x99s major seaport for 2000 years and the center for European traders in the 19th century'
b'The city still maintains its important gateway role'
b'Ever since 1957 the Canton Trade Fair officially the Chinese Export Commodities Fair has attracted throngs of international business people every spring and autumn'

b'Guangzhou with a population of more than 5 million straddles the Pearl River\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82China\xe2\x80\x99s fifth longest\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82which links the city to the South China Sea'

b'This waterway accounts for much of the local charm and excitement as the daily drama of the ferryboats junks sampans freighters\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82and even small tankers and big gunboats\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82unfolds right in the center of town'
b'The river also irrigates the carefully tended surrounding farmlands creating a beautifully lush subtropical scene'
b'Guangdong Province has some of China\xe2\x80\x99s most fertile land and grows two crops of rice a year along with vegetables of all kinds'
b'Guangzhou today is mostly about business and industry featuring new development skyscrapers a whole new business area and raised expressways'
b'Guangzhou is interestingly one of China\xe2\x80\x99s most prosperous cities determinedly on the move into the modern world'
b'It seems that the picturesque older sections with their old houses narrow streets and winding alleyways may not be around much longer'
b'There are many package tours to Guangzhou from Hong Kong see page 113 and this may be the easiest way to visit the city'
b'However it\xe2\x80\x99s also easy to get to Guangzhou by train or ferry'
b'Four comfortable express trains depart the KowloonCanton Railway KCR Station in Hung Hom Kowloon making the trip in less than two hours'
b'Turbo Cat ferries leave the China Hong Kong City CHKC terminal twice a day the journey takes two hours'
b'Citibus also travels to Guangzhou from CHKC there are five roundtrips a day taking 312 hours'
b'You will need a visa to enter China see page 109 for information'
b'Hong Kong currency is widely accepted in Guangzhou or you can change your currency into RMB yuan at any bank or hotel'
b'Note however that the exchange does not go the other way see page 116'
b'Guangzhou like Hong Kong is primarily Cantonesespeaking but many people also speak Mandarin'
b'English is spoken in hotels and tourist destinations'
b'If you travel by train you will arrive at the Guangzhou East Station a large modern complex which connects with the subway buses hotel transfer services and taxis'
b'The train station is in the newer business district nearby is Asia\xe2\x80\x99s thirdtallest building at 83 stories which will often be pointed out to you'
b'Sights in Guangzhou'
b'Yuexiu Park situated near the Trade Fair in the northern part of the city is Guangzhou\xe2\x80\x99s largest it covers a hilly 100 hectares 247 acres'
b'The park is landscaped with lakes and gardens'
b'In the park is the 1380 Zhenhai Tower one of the city\xe2\x80\x99s oldest buildings'
b'Actually a fivestory pavilion on a hilltop it contains a fine collection of historical exhibits'
b'Dr Sun Yatsen\xe2\x80\x99s Memorial Hall honors the founder of the Chinese Revolution flanked by his heroic statue in copper'
b'Dr Sun Yatsen 1866\xe2\x80\x931925 began his political career in Canton'
b'This enormous modern version of a traditional Chinese building with sweeping blue tile roofs contains an auditorium big enough to seat 4700 people'
b'It was built in 1931 with contributions from overseas Chinese'
b'The center of the park is the Five Rams Statue'
b'It celebrates the founding of Guangzhou when five spirits rode their goats down from the celestial realm to present the inhabitants of the city with their very first grains of rice'
b'Guangzhou\xe2\x80\x99s most important Buddhist monument is the 1400yearold Temple of the Six Banyan Trees open 8am\xe2\x80\x935pm'
b'Although the banyan trees that once flourished here are now no more the oftenrestored complex has remained a focus of local Buddhist activities'
b'Golden Buddha statues in several of Buddha\xe2\x80\x99s aspects adorn the temples and overlooking them is the 17story Flower Pagoda a slender relic of the Song dynasty ad 960\xe2\x80\x931279'
b'In the early Middle Ages Canton had a significant Muslim population as a result of its trade with the Middle East'
b'This explains the presence in Guangzhou of the Huaisheng Mosque reputed to be China\xe2\x80\x99s oldest and traditionally dated ad 627'
b'Rebuilt in modern times the mosque serves the small local community of Muslims'
b'The modern minaret is known as the \xe2\x80\x9cPlain or Naked Pagoda\xe2\x80\x9d in contrast to the Flower Pagoda of the Buddhist temple'
b'Chen Jia Ci the Chen Family Institute open daily 830am\xe2\x80\x935pm was built in the late 19th century to promote arts and crafts'
b'An architectural wonder it is itself a beautiful piece of craftsmanship with its sculpture and carved stone balustrades'
b'Porcelain friezes adorn the rooftops and ridgepoles telling the story of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms'
b'Inside is a collection of ceramics carvings and furniture'
b'There is also a market and a porcelain shop'
b'A former Confucian temple is presently the home of the historic National Peasant Movement Institute where the Chinese Communist Party trained its leaders in the 1920s'
b'Mao Zedong himself directed the institute in 1926 and gave lectures on geography rural education and \xe2\x80\x9cThe Problem of the Chinese Peasantry \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'Zhou Enlai also taught here'
b'The atmosphere of 19thcentury Canton is best evoked on Shamian Island a haunting nostalgic place in the Pearl River'
b'This small formerly residential island beautifully shaded by banyan trees was the home of the closed community of the foreign colony in the era of \xe2\x80\x9cconcessions \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'The bridges were barred by night with iron gates to keep the Chinese out'
b'Its stately Europeanstyle buildings have since been restored largely for use as government offices and foreign legations'
b'The island also has Guangzhou\xe2\x80\x99s first modern luxury resort hotel'
b'A popular optional excursion is an hour\xe2\x80\x99s detour to Guangzhou Zoo founded in 1958'
b'It houses more than 200 animal species most famous of which is the giant panda and has an imaginative monkey mountain behind a moat'
b'Not to be missed is a visit to Guangzhou\xe2\x80\x99s famous openair market Qing Ping'
b'Guangzhou is famous for its food'
b'The Cantonese love to eat and have the reputation of eating almost anything that walks on four legs'

b'The market bears this out Along with the usual ducks and chickens you will see for sale snakes dogs bats and sometimes monkeys\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82all are highly prized as delicacies'
b'More pleasantly you can browse among lanes of antiques flowers herbs fruit goldfish songbirds and more'
b'A very popular daytrip from Guangzhou goes to Foshan a city of nearly 300000 people renowned for its handicrafts for more than a thousand years'

b'The individual artisans\xe2\x80\x99 shops are no longer here but you can visit a silkweaving factory a ceramics plant and the Foshan Folk Art Studio where you can observe workers making Chinese lanterns carving sculptures painting scrolls and cutting intricate designs in paper'
b'The Foshan Art Porcelain Factory has traditional designs but also some attractive modern pieces'
b'Foshan\xe2\x80\x99s most outstanding artistic monument is Zu Miao the Taoist Ancestral Temple a Sung dynasty establishment rebuilt in the 14th century and well worth visiting'
b'Constructed in wood brick stone ceramic and bronze this is a work of extravagant beauty uniting many ancient art forms'
b'The complex contains the oldest wooden stage in China used by the Wan Fu Tai Chinese opera'
b'Shenzhen was China\xe2\x80\x99s first Special Economic Zone'
b'Literally created out of rural farmland it was set up in the 1970s as the answer to Hong Kong'
b'From a population of 20000 it has grown into a metropolis of 25 million with tightly clustered skyscrapers and some of China\xe2\x80\x99s highest grossing industries'

b'Because Shenzhen is much cheaper than Hong Kong it is a popular weekend destination for Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s Chinese who come to relax dine in its resorts and play golf\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82Shenzhen hosted the World Cup of Golf in 1995'
b'It is even becoming something of a commuter town\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82owning or renting an apartment here costs a fraction of what it would in Hong Kong'
b'Shenzhen is easy to reach\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82the KCR commuter train runs throughout the day the trip taking about 40 minutes'
b'Visitors need a visa to enter China and must disembark at the border now called \xe2\x80\x9cboundary\xe2\x80\x9d checkpoint Lo Wai'
b'City buses also go to Shenzhen'
b'A Turbo Cat ferry makes a onehour trip 7am\xe2\x80\x937pm from Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s Macau Ferry Terminal to Shekou on the Natau Peninsula which is part of the economic zone'
b'Shenzhen is a premier shopping center and much cheaper than Hong Kong'
b'It is known for its inexpensive but wellmade knockoff designer goods'
b'You can use your Hong Kong dollars here so there\xe2\x80\x99s no need to change currency'
b'Some places take credit cards but cash is better for bargaining'
b'Just across the border is the huge Lo Wu City shopping mall to which you can walk other shopping malls are nearby'
b'Shenzhen\xe2\x80\x99s main tourist attractions are its enormous theme parks'
b'One of them\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82Splendid China\xe2\x80\x82\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x82purports to show \xe2\x80\x9call of China in one day \xe2\x80\x9d'
b'It contains elaborate replicas of China\xe2\x80\x99s chief monuments in impressive detail including a scaleddown version of the Great Wall'
b'The 24 China Folk Culture Villages represent China\xe2\x80\x99s ethnic variety they feature craftspeople in traditional costumes along with folksong and dance performances'
b'In Shekou is a large Free Market and an exhibition of Xian\xe2\x80\x99s terracotta warriors'
